Whistler said that on May 27, a single fist-sized vertebra from the bison was spotted in an ancient streambed in the state park by Pam Owen, a paleontology graduate student at California State University, Long Beach. Scientists then unearthed about one-third of the bison's skeleton, which was broken in various pieces. The rest of the bison had been exposed by erosion over the ages and had weathered away. ``I'm afraid Mother Nature got about two-thirds of it and we got about one-third,'' Whistler said. ``We've got part of the chest, part of a hip, a shoulder blade, a hind leg, and about five isolated teeth.'' Red Rock park officials asked Whistler not to reveal the exact digging site, but he said it was close to State Route 14, the main highway through the park, which is located about 100 miles north of Los Angeles. The bison's worn teeth and arthritic bones show it was old when it died, Whistler said, adding that the species went extinct and was different than modern bison. Radiocarbon dating of fossil wood in the streambed near the bison allowed scientists to determine it died about 10,700 years ago. Museum spokeswoman Ellen Girardeau said the bison fossils will be used for research and won't be displayed. They will be moved to Los Angeles late this month.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Suspends Talks with PLO
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 11th graf, ``With PLO'' to remove extranous words and CORRECT with to without
DOC.TEXT: President Bush broke off America's dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization Wednesday, saying a guerrilla raid on Israel's coast ``is sticking in our throat'' and must be renounced by Yasser Arafat for the relationship to resume. ``We've given the PLO ample time to deal with this issue,'' Bush said at a news conference at the Marshall Space Flight Center in the midst of a day of campaigning for Republicans in Alabama and North Carolina. Bush said Israeli civilians were clearly the target of the May 30 raid, for which the Palestine Liberation Front has taken responsibility. The PLF is headed by Abul Abbas, an Arafat associate and a member of the PLO executive committee. The attack was thwarted when Israeli defenders intercepted five speedboats when they landed. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured. The boats, carrying 16 guerrillas armed with rockets and machine guns, reportedly were dropped off a Libyan ship 120 miles at sea. ``This terroristic act is sticking in our throat,'' Bush said, declaring he was acting even though his decision could incite new violence in the Mideast. Bush said he was willing to reopen the talks _ which enhanced Arafat's standing in the Arab world _ if the PLO condemns the raid, dissociates itself from the action and moves to discipline Abbas, who Bush said, was ``the perpetrator.'' Bush noted that the PLO did dissociate itself from the action, but said that and a general condemnation of violence against civilians was not enough. The PLO last week said: ``The PLO position remains unchanged. We are against any military action that targets civilians, whatever form it may take.'' Secertary of State James A. Baker III, who had recommended Bush's action, told reporters flying with him to Europe for talks on German unity that Israel still needs the acquiescence of the PLO to find a partner for peace talks. He admitted that Bush' action could hurt moderate Arabs. Without PLO consent, ``there won't be a dialogue for Israel. They (Israeli governments) have been seeking to develop one for 22 years and none has come forward,'' Baker said before a refueling stop at Shannon, Ireland. Bush's decision disrupts a relationship with the PLO started by then-President Reagan in December 1988 after Arafat met two U.S. conditions: he disavowed terrorism and recognized Israel's right to exist. The decision comes at a time when U.S. efforts to induce Israel to revive the Middle East peace process have run out of energy. Israel welcomed the administration's decision. A statement issued by the embassy in Washington said Bush's decision ``will encourage those Palestinians seeking peace with Israel to seize upon this opportunity to begin a direct dialogue with Israel.'' The League of Arab States called the suspension of the dialogue a ``blow to peace'' and said it ``signals a penalty to Arab moderation _ especially Palestinian moderation _ and rewards Israeli intransigence.'' And Faisal Husseini, one of the leading Palestinian nationalists in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, said the United States was ``punishing the wrong people.'' Israel, he said in an interview in Washington, was refusing to match the concessions made by the PLO. ``This will make the radicals and all those who oppose peace strong,'' he said. Yael Dayan, daughter of the late Israeli general Moshe Dayan, said cutting off the dialogue ``opens the doors to war.'' Ms. Dayan, who is touring the United States with Husseini on behalf of the Israeli Peace Now movement, said Bush's decision signals ``the burial of a slow process that had barely begun.'' On Capitol Hill, the speaker of the House, Rep. Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said he supported Bush's decision. ``I think the president sought to find a way to conscientiously continue this dialogue, but it has to be one in which conditions which we set forth ... are respected,'' Foley said. Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, the senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, also hailed Bush's action. ``America must let Arafat know that the PLO can't talk peace and wage war at the same time,'' he said, adding: ``President Bush was wise to suspend rather than terminate the talks. Arafat should know that the United States is still willing to cooperate in the search for peace, but not under the barrel of a gun.'' The Reagan administration's willingness to talk directly with the PLO had bolstered Arafat's claim to be the foremost spokesman for Palestinians and for their goal of achieving statehood. The Palestine Liberation Front, which Abbas heads, is a radical PLO faction. Even after the raid, contacts continued between the United States and the PLO while the United States awaited the PLO's response. Robert Pelletreau Jr., the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia, met with PLO officials outside Tunis several times. The PLO had played an offstage role in the Bush administration's attempt to reignite the peace process. Egypt, acting as an intermediary, checked with the PLO as Baker put together a formula for setting up talks in Cairo between Israel and Palestinian Arabs. That effort had been stalled since March, when the Israeli coalition government collapsed. Bush recently wrote Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who heads the newly formed Israeli government, in an attempt to revive the peace process. Through Cabinet Secretary Eliakim Rubinstein, the government in Jerusalem has promised to pursue peace with the Arabs. Last March, the State Department, in a report to Congress, said the PLO was adhering to Arafat's commitment to disavow terrorism. Although Palestinian groups have launched nearly 30 border and rocket attacks against Israel since the U.S.-PLO talks began, the report said, ``We have no evidence in those cases or any others that the actions were authorized or approved by the PLO executive committee or by Arafat personally.'' On other subjects in his meeting with reporters, Bush: _Said he has no plans for a ``bold new initiative'' to help Mikhail Gorbachev cope with the ailing Soviet economy. He said his administration is willing to talk with allies about helping the Soviet Union. Some Western nations are reported to favor a costly plan to assist Gorbachev. _Defended his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, for his comments on Tuesday critical of Democrats on the savings and loan bailout issue. He said Fitzwater was doing no more than ``responding to a couple of shots across my bow.'' _Said he would tell Nelson Mandela next week that American sanctions against South Africa will remain in place until conditions fixed under law are met. He also paid a tribute to South African President F.W. de Klerk ``for what he's done'' to start dismantling apartheid. ``He's come a long way,'' Bush said.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Must Denounce Terrorist Attack, Bush Says
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he's willing to resume the newly suspended talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization if Yasser Arafat denounces a recent foiled terrorist attack on an Israeli beach. The president, who announced the suspension Wednesday, said the PLO ``has not provided a credible account of this incident,'' in which a PLO affiliate group launched a guerrilla attack on the civilian-filled beach near Tel Aviv. ``We've given the PLO ample time to deal with this issue,'' but PLO leader Arafat has refused to denounce it or discipline the leader of the group, the radical Palestine Liberation Front, Bush said at a news conference during a one-day political trip to Alabama and North Carolina. The president said the administration is willing to resume the talks if Arafat fulfills those conditions. Bush said he believes the 18-month U.S.-PLO dialogue has encouraged moderation within the PLO. ``But I can't point to the fact that that has really solved the question of Middle East peace. I just feel that talking offers more potential than stiff-arming each other,'' he said. ``And yet we can't digest it as long as this terroristic act is sticking in our throat.'' Bush spoke during a trip to the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville on a day otherwise devoted to fund-raising for Republican Gov. Guy Hunt in Alabama and Sen. Jesse Helms in North Carolina. The president helped raise $450,000 for Hunt's bid for a second term, and about $1 million for Helms' fight against Democrat Harvey Gantt, aides said. He attacked a House Appropriations subcommittee that last week axed $300 million from his proposal to send manned flights back to the moon and on to Mars. Touching on other matters at the news conference, the president said: _Parents who work for employers who do not give parental leave time, as he urges them to do, should ``keep working for them until they do'' because he does not believe the government should require firms to offer such leave. _He has no plans to support a European move for an international economic aid package for the Soviet Union, although he is willing to discuss the matter with the allies. _His press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, acted appropriately in lambasting Democrats for partisanship in their criticisms on the government's massive savings and loan bailout. _Said he would tell Nelson Mandela next week that American sanctions against South Africa will remain in place until conditions fixed under law are met. He also paid a tribute to South African President F.W. de Klerk for steps toward dismantling apartheid. ``He's come a long way,'' Bush said. On the PLO question, the president said the evidence shows that civilians clearly were the target of the May 30 terrorist attempt, in which the perpetrators were intercepted by Israeli military forces before they could harm anyone. Four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who recommended the suspension, defended the decision even while admitting it would hurt moderate Arabs. ``We really could not let our pursuit of peace stand in the way of our commitment to fight terrorism,'' Baker said while en route to East Berlin for German reunification talks. The U.S. talks with the PLO began in 1988 after Arafat complied with U.S. conditions that he renounce terrorism and back the right of Israel to exist. The PLO last week insisted that it opposes ``any military action that targets civilians.'' But Bush said Wednesday that that generic statement is not enough, and he expects a specific condemnation of the May 30 action. Israel praised the president in a statement from its embassy in Washington, saying his decision will encourage Palestinians who want peace ``to seize upon this opportunity to begin a direct dialogue with Israel.'' The League of Arab States, however, said Bush's suspension of the talks ``signals a penalty to Arab moderation _ especially Palestinian moderation _ and rewards Israeli intransigence.'' Yael Dayan, daughter of the late Israeli general Moshe Dayan, said cutting off the dialogue ``opens the doors to war.'' Ms. Dayan, who is touring the United States for the Israeli Peace Now movement, lamented ``the burial of a slow process that had barely begun.'' On Capitol Hill, House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., backed Bush's move, saying ``the president sought to find a way to conscientiously continue this dialogue, but it has to be one in which conditions which we set forth ... are respected.''

DOC.HEAD: North Dakota's Last Abortion Doctor Retires
DOC.TEXT: No one wants to be the abortion doctor in North Dakota. The only doctor in the state who performed abortions retired earlier this year. None of the state's 1,200 doctors has come forward to take the place of Dr. Robert Lucy, a obstetrician and gynecologist. He predicts no one will. ``Peer pressure from colleagues is the main reason,'' said Lucy, who practiced in Jamestown, 100 miles west of here. ``They're also afraid of public pressure.'' Abortions still are performed at a women's clinic in Fargo, but it has to fly doctors in from neighboring Minnesota. Women in the western part of the state must drive up to 350 miles to Fargo, on the state's eastern side. Some have driven all night in bad weather. The distance adds to hurdles this conservative, mostly rural state has put up to restrict abortions. In North Dakota, a minor seeking an abortion must have the consent of both parents or a judge. The state allows no public financing for abortions and prohibits abortions at public hospitals. ``Our patients are pretty persistent,'' said Jane Bovard, director of the women's clinic, which operates out of a white clapboard house on a quiet city street. ``They've made up their mind and they get here no matter what.'' A 21-year-old patient who did not want to give her name said she was getting an abortion because she has a 4-year-old child, is getting divorced and is on welfare. ``I want to go to school,'' she said. ``Maybe it's selfish of me, I don't know. But if I go to school I can provide my child with a better life.'' The clinic, owned by the National Women's Health Organization, performs abortions twice a week. Last year, it performed 1,308, or about 25 a week. This year, it is averaging about 36 a week, Bovard said. The cost is $275 to $300. After years of picketing outside Lucy's clinic, abortion foes were thrilled when he announced his retirement. They hope the Fargo clinic will go next. ``I believe God is closing down the centers in North Dakota, and he'll close this one, too,'' said Aletha Schommer, one of a handful of protesters outside the clinic last week. Schommer, who drove four hours from her home in Munich to join the pickets, shouted, ``Mother, don't kill your baby!' at women entering the clinic. She seemed unperturbed by the angry gestures with which some women responded. ``By coming here, I've become a more loving person,'' she said. ``We don't want to personally harm them. We just want them to stop.'' Inside the clinic, a man who brought his 16-year-old daughter for an abortion was angry at the protesters. He refused to identify himself. ``You can believe whatever you want (about abortion) until it happens to your family,'' he said. ``Then you've got to make a decision, and it's not easy.'' ``And then to have people screaming at you _ what kind of people would do that?'' he added. Bovard said anti-abortion activists are fooling themselves if they think they can close the clinic, which opened in 1981. ``I know what we do is within the law,'' she said. ``The crazy things these people do out front here will hang them eventually.'' Lucy said the protesters had no bearing on his decision to retire after 42 years of practicing medicine. ``I felt I performed a service,'' he said. ``If they wanted to carry a pregnancy to term, I could take care of it. If they wanted to terminate it, I could still take care of it. So they had a choice. That's why I did it.''

DOC.HEAD: North American Trade Bloc Seeks Bigger Growth
DOC.TEXT: A free trade pact between the United States and Mexico would create a market of 400 million North American consumers and, supporters say, put more goods on shelves all over the continent. But some union leaders are asking who will get the additional money to buy those goods. President Bush and President Carlos Salinas de Gortari of Mexico agreed earlier this month to talk about a free trade agreement like the one between the United States and Canada. But the heads of the largest unions in Canada and the United States argue that an agreement with Mexico would push wages down in the two other countries. ``U.S. trade and investment with Mexico has already significantly harmed the domestic manufacturing sector,'' said Lane Kirkland, president of the AFL-CIO. Kirkland and Shirley Carr, head of the Canadian Labor Congress, voiced their opposition to the pact during a recent visit with Bush. ``Tens of thousands of American workers have lost their jobs or seen employment opportunities vanish as U.S. companies move to take advantage of the poverty of Mexican workers,'' Kirkland said. The average U.S. worker in manufacturing earns $14.50 an hour and the average Canadian not much less. The average Mexican gets only $1.90. Under a free trade accord, a U.S. auto manufacturer could make parts much more cheaply in Mexico than in the United States or Canada. The result: more jobs in Mexico and fewer jobs up north where the manufacturer sells a lot more vehicles. ``That could happen in the short run,'' acknowledged Claude Barfild, who worked for the U.S. trade representative under President Reagan. ``But in the longer run both stockholders and workers will get the money. Mexicans who make auto parts will be able to ask _ and get _ higher wages.'' Since the 1940s, he said, wages in countries that export to the United States have been rising toward American levels. Wages in some European countries are higher than here, said Barfild, a fellow at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group on public policy. The wage question was discussed last week at the first congressional hearing on the proposed pact with Mexico. Witnesses said a major purpose of the pact would be to encourage investors from the United States and elsewhere to put factories in Mexico rather than in low-wage countries on other continents. ``A North American trade alliance of the U.S., Canada and Mexico will allow us to better compete with other emerging trading blocs in Europe and Asia, and maintain our competitiveness around the globe,'' said Rep. Jim Kolbe, R-Ariz. ``A trading bloc from the Yukon to the Yucatan, with upwards of 400 million in population, would be the most powerful in the world.'' Rudiger Dornbusch, who teaches economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said manufacturers would in any case build factories where wages are low _ in Mexico, Asia, Africa or Europe. ``The right question to ask about free trade with Mexico is whether we should prefer that when jobs do go abroad that they go south rather than to Asia,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Agency Warns of Fireworks Accident Danger
DOC.TEXT: A 12-year-old Maryland boy who suffered third-degree burns in a firecracker accident warns other children not to play with pyrotechnics. ``I just want to say don't play with firecrackers,'' said Vincent Baxter of Upper Marlboro, Md., describing how two months ago a firecracker he lighted and tossed ricocheted back at him and set his clothing on fire. ``It caught another firecracker on fire,'' he said. ``Then it started sprinkling flames and sparks everywhere and caught my leg on fire.'' The boy's admonition came Wednesday during a Consumer Product Safety Commission demonstration on the dangers of fireworks. The agency warned consumers that Fourth of July celebrations can be marred by tragedy if precautions aren't taken to avoid the burns and injuries caused by improper or illegal use of the devices. Stephen E. Higgins, director of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, also warned in a statement that dangerous explosives are often peddled illegally to Independence Day celebrants. Using dolls set on fire, exploding furnishings and food and punctured plywood shelving, the CPSC showed how an estimated 6,300 injuries _ including burns, disfigurement, loss of eyes, fingers, hands and other limbs _ were associated with fireworks in 1989. ``We know that some 10,000 Americans, most of them adolescents and teenagers, will end up in hospital emergency rooms this year from injuries associated with fireworks,'' said CPSC Chairwoman Jacqueline Jones-Smith. ``I can guarantee you that those injuries could have been prevented,'' said Commissioner Anne Graham. She said parents should forego their own fireworks and take children to community fireworks displays by professionals. ``Fireworks by their very nature are dangerous,'' said the commission.

DOC.HEAD: House Tells Conferees to Accept Social Security Provision
DOC.TEXT: The House is overwhelmingly recommending an increase in Social Security benefits for some working elderly recipients, telling its negotiators to accept that Senate-approved provision in a child care bill. The House voted 384-36 Wednesday for a non-binding motion to instruct its conferees on the bill. It acted despite warnings by opponents that the benefit increases for working retirees would come at the expense of new programs. ``It means a difficult choice between generations,'' said Rep. Thomas Downey, D-N.Y., a leading sponsor of the child care bill. The vote came as the measure appeared to become more deeply mired in legislative disagreement. Bills establishing major new child care programs and expanding others, including the Head Start program, have followed a tortuous path leading to House and Senate approval of far different packages. The measures remain in two Senate-House conference committees created to resolve those differences, and one of the panels earlier this week produced a preliminary agreement on several provisions. That plan would keep the Senate's plan for a new categorical block grant child care program, instead of the House version's expansion of entitlement programs. That agreement appeared to run counter to House wishes. The chamber voted 411-0 on May 9 not to instruct conferees not to accept those Senate provisions on the main elements of a child care bill. The House on Wednesday pointed to that vote and delivered a direct rebuke to its own conferees. It voted 416-0 on a second non-binding motion reaffirming its opposition to the Senate version. Members said that accepting the Senate's provisions would prompt President Bush's veto as well as lose important House support. Neither vote binds the conferees, but they amount to recorded expressions of the chamber's sentiment. The motion on Social Security instructs the conferees to modify and accept the Senate's rider, allowing people 65 to 69 years old to earn more money through working while continuing to receive their retirement benefits. Rep. Hank Brown, R-Colo., said it would relieve ``a devastating penalty'' that Social Security recipients must pay for continuing to work, often part time. Opponents said the change in Social Security policy has no place in a child care bill and should await congressional budget talks with the White House and other panels deliberating Social Security changes. ``It would be truly unfortunate if we forgot that we are here to provide help to children who would otherwise be left alone,'' said Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee. The provision added by the Senate would raise the annual earnings limitation for Social Security recipients by $1,200, to $10,560. For those earning up to $5,000 beyond that, Social Security benefits would be reduced by $1 for every $4 earned. Brown recommended altering the Senate's provision by delaying the change in benefit reduction and recalculating lump-sum payments in the awarding of back benefits for some Social Security recipients. This in effect would reduce one benefit to pay for increasing another. The House Budget Committee chairman, Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Calif., estimated the bill's cost at $1.5 billion to $2.4 billion. But Brown said the lump-sum reduction would produce more than enough money to pay for the increase in the earnings limitation. ``It has no effect at all on child care,'' Brown said. ``It in no way limits or restricts the funds available for child care.''

DOC.HEAD: Possible Record Year for Farm Income on Tap
DOC.TEXT: It's shaping up as a possible record year for farm income, according to new forecasts by the Agriculture Department. Sales of farm commodities ``are showing some unexpected strength, so income prospects have brightened'' since the last 1990 forecast was issued three months ago, the department's Economic Research Service said Wednesday. ``Strong hog prices and firming coarse grain prices are behind the improvement,'' the report said. Coarse grains include corn, sorghum, oats and barley. Overall, the ``net cash income'' of farmers was forecast at $55 billion to $59 billion this year, up $1 billion from the range indicated since March. Last year's net cash income was about $54 billion, and the record was $57.2 billion in 1988. As used by the agency, net cash income ``measures the value of commodities sold in a calendar year plus government payments, less out-of-pocket costs.'' Some commodities sold actually may have been produced in earlier years and stored until marketed. Direct government payments to farmers in 1990 are expected to drop about 15 percent from last year to a range of $8 billion to $10 billion, the report said. In another method of accounting, the report said ``net farm income'' may be in the range of $47 billion to $51 billion, a $2 billion increase from the earlier 1990 forecast. Last year's was $49 billion, a record. Net farm income is used to measure the value of agricultural production, whether sold or stored, in a calendar year plus government payments, minus all costs, including depreciation and other allowances. The report said world wheat production is expected to exceed consumption in 1990-91, leading to the first increase in stockpiles in four years. However, supplies of corn and other coarse gains probably will drop for the fourth straight year, despite larger output this year. ``So wheat prices are slipping, while coarse grain prices are expected to remain firm'' the report said. ``Wheat will figure more prominently in livestock feeds as producers try to hold down costs.'' In the United States, unusually heavy rains have slowed the planting of corn, soybeans and rice this spring, meaning that some farmers will switch to soybeans and sorghum. Looking at the rural economy, the report said unemployment in the first quarter was unchanged from a year earlier at 6.6 percent, after declining in rural areas for four years. ``Rural areas are expected to see more moderate job growth and stable unemployment rates for the rest of the year,'' the report said. ``And rural jobless rates probably will remain above urban rates. Over half of all farmers now hold off-farm jobs.''

The Agriculture Department says egg producers will vote next month on whether to eliminate refunds permanently under a federal research and promotion program. Daniel D. Haley, administrator of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service, said Wednesday that ballots will be mailed by July 16 to all producers of record. All commercial egg producers owning more than 30,000 laying hens during the period Jan. 1 through March 31, 1990, except those who produce mostly hatching eggs, will be eligible to vote. In 1988, Congress amended the Egg Research and Consumer Information Act to suspend refunds for 18 months beginning Jan. 1, 1989, pending results of a national referendum. For the new provision to be adopted, approval would have to come from at least two-thirds of those voting this summer, or a majority of producers representing at least two-thirds of the volume of eggs produced by all voters. If adopted, producers will continue to pay mandatory, non-refundable assessments of five cents per 30-dozen case of commercial eggs to the American Egg Board for research, promotion and consumer education programs. Exemptions would continue for producers with flocks of 30,000 or fewer hens, and for all egg producers in Alaska and Hawaii. Currently, the assessments raise about $7.2 million annually, the agency said.

Recent surveys show that almost 20 percent of the farmers who bought federal crop insurance did so in order to obtain loans. The Agriculture Department said Wednesday that the surveys were for crop insurance bought in the 1988-89 season. ``Of those who said they had to buy the insurance before getting a loan, almost half dealt with commercial banks,'' the department's Economic Research Service said in its report. Roughly another one-third borrowed from the Farmers Home Administration, and one out of seven from the Farm Credit System. ``Farmers were more likely to say they had to buy the insurance if they borrowed primarily from one source,'' the report said.

DOC.HEAD: FAA to Closely Watch `Celebrity Airline'
DOC.TEXT: Federal aviation officials say they will closely watch operations of a charter air service that was allowed to resume flying last month after being shut down for safety violations. The operation _ nicknamed ``Celebrity Airline'' because it carried rock stars, politicians and other well-known passengers _ came under intense scrutiny during a two-day congressional hearing that ended Wednesday. Tony Broderick, head of regulation and certification for the Federal Aviation Administration, said Northeast Jet, operating as Personal Jet Services, met rigorous FAA qualifications to gain a new certificate. The FAA pulled the Allentown, Pa., airline's operating certificate in September 1988, accusing the service of overworking its pilots, skimping on training and keeping two sets of maintenance records: one for its own use and one for FAA inspectors. The owners denied the allegations but decided to seek a new certification a year later rather than appeal. The House Public Works investigations subcommittee has been looking into FAA oversight of Northeast Jet and the 3,000 other U.S. air charter and taxi services that carry more than 8 million passengers a year. The hearings focused on Northeast Jet because its owner had managed to get a new certification after being shut down for safety violations. Some lawmakers accused the FAA of having a ``revolving door policy'' of recertifying airlines whose licenses are pulled. Broderick testified that the case was unusual and that revocation of a flight certificate was ``usually a death sentence for an airline.'' He said FAA inspectors would pay especially close attention to Private Jet, which has only been operating for a few weeks and has only one plane, because of its previous violations. ``We often apply extra surveillance to carriers who have received a new certificate after having a certificate previously revoked,'' Broderick said. He said 100 small airlines have been shut down because of safety problems over the last five years. No special preference is given carriers that try to reapply for certification after being shut down for a year or more, Broderick said. The FAA does not have the power to permanently ban a company from flying but must re-evaluate it based on operations when it files a new application, he said. Northeast Jet gained the nickname ``Celebrity Airlines'' after flying clients such as first ladies Nancy Reagan and Barbara Bush, presidential hopefuls Michael Dukakis and Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., and pop singers Billy Idol, Bruce Springsteen and Barry Manilow. Company President Earl Holtz said he would carry anyone who pays, but his lawyer, Mark Kahan, said most passengers are business travelers.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Seeks Benefits for Displaced Personnel
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon is appealing to Congress to extend special benefits and severance pay to active-duty enlisted personnel who will be forced out as the armed services grow smaller. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney sent to Congress on Wednesday a proposal that would provide separation pay for enlisted men and women in uniform with at least five years' service. ``This benefit will be particularly important to those non-commissioned officers who don't serve long enough to retire, but who nevertheless have dedicated a big part of their working lives to the nation's service,'' Cheney said in a statement. Currently, separation pay is only given to active-duty officers and reserve enlisted personnel who have served for at least five years. The payment is based on a year's base pay. Under the defense secretary's plan, the separation pay would be 10 percent of the base pay times the number of years of service. The Pentagon envisions cutting the size of the 2.1-million-member active-duty force by at least 90,000 in the next two years, although further budget reductions could raise that number. While Cheney made his appeal, his senior enlisted advisers urged lawmakers to adopt legislation that would help ease the impact of significant cuts in the defense budget. Recent debate over reductions in President Bush's $303.3 billion budget has focused on Air Force fighter wings, Army divisions, Navy ships and base closings. But the Pentagon advisers, testifying before the Senate Armed Services subcommittee on manpower and personnel, put the reductions in personal terms. ``Spouses and even some of the children are becoming uneasy with the future outlook,'' Sgt. Maj. of the Army Julius W. Gates told the panel. Duane Bushey, master chief petty officer of the Navy, said the overriding concern among enlisted sailors let go after more than five years on the job is not an improvement in their education benefits but enough separation pay. ``At that point they're looking to survive. They want to put meat and potatoes on the table. Most with a family are looking to feed the family,'' Bushey said. Gates said Army personnel ``are not asking for free handouts or welfare.'' Last month, Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., and William Cohen, R-Maine, introduced legislation that would ease the pain for military personnel from the cuts in defense spending. The bill is a package of severance pay, health benefits and relocation and job counseling for those forced out of the service with more than seven years experience and before they are eligible for retirement. The current Pentagon system caps the severance pay at $30,000. The Senate legislation would increase the limit to $83,500. ``We have a personnel crisis of nearly unprecedented proportions,'' McCain said at the hearing. Later in the day, Senate and House Democrats introduced legislation that will assist the nation's communities that have been dependent on the defense buildup of the 1980s as they adjust to reduced military spending. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., touted the measure as a plan ``to move our economy from a Cold War footing to a new era of vitality.'' The bill would create a high-level federal office to assist defense adjustment, provide grants to communities to start adjustment planning and require advance notification to communities, workers and businesses of planned cuts.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Seeks Cooperation, But Endorses Attack on Democrats
DOC.TEXT: President Bush says he wants to cooperate with Democrats in Congress to clean up the savings and loan mess, but he's also endorsing remarks from his spokesman singling out Democrats for criticism. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater had gone on the offensive Tuesday, inviting reporters to examine the contributions to the crisis of specific Democrats. ``Marlin, properly, seeing a couple of shots across my bow from certain distinguished members of the United States Senate, decided not to acquiesce in those attacks without some response. What he did was appropriate,'' Bush said Wednesday. The spokesman had singled out for criticism Sens. Donald W. Riegle Jr., D-Mich., chairman of the Senate Banking Committee; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Bob Kerrey, D-Neb.; former House Speaker Jim Wright, D-Texas; and former Reps. Tony Coelho, D-Calif., and Fernand J. St Germain, D-R.I. However, Bush told reporters at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala., ``What I'm trying to do is not respond to individuals and to simply keep moving forward on this process.'' He conceded that ``a spark seemed to be ignited'' by Fitzwater's comments, but added, ``I think more important than continuing to pour fuel on the spark is to work cooperatively with the Congress in trying to get this mess solved.'' The president defended his administration's pursuit of S&L fraud, saying, ``There has been an active prosecution under way.'' He said ``impressive numbers'' of cases were being pursued and ``I expect we'll see plenty more.'' Meanwhile, the House voted 420-1 Wednesday to provide the Justice Department with $75 million to fight white-collar crime in financial institutions during the 1991 fiscal year, beginning Oct. 1. At the administration's request, Congress had provided $50 million for 1990, an amount Democrats said was inadequate. Democratic criticism of Bush's management of the S&L bailout has been growing since last month, when the administration said Congress would have to provide a second bailout of $30 billion to $50 billion later this year. Public Citizen's Congress Watch, an organization affiliated with consumer activist Ralph Nader, issued a report Wednesday criticizing the administration's ``anemic'' efforts to prosecute S&L fraud. The report estimated that the government's civil and criminal actions have recovered only $300 million in S&L losses. That is less than 2 percent of the $16.3 billion in losses attributed to fraud among the 440 S&Ls seized by the government since early last year, the group said. ``The Bush administration's efforts to pursue and punish S&L fraud have been anemic at best, irresponsible at worst,'' said Sherry Ettleson, an attorney who prepared the report. Congress Watch said the Justice Department is pursuing 891 cases actively, compared with a backlog of 6,993 cases. Yet, the department has added fewer than half the 425 additional agents requested by the FBI and only 118 of the 231 assistant U.S. attorneys requested by the department's field offices, it said. The group recommended that the administration spend more on pursuing fraud, turn its attention to accountants and lawyers who aided S&L executives in committing fraud and drop its support of legislation that would remove the threat of triple damages from civil racketeering suits. It said Congress should enact legislation that would permit whistle-blowers to bring suit against alleged S&L criminals on behalf of the government and share in the damages if fraud is found to have occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Says Government Gave Witness `Sweet Deal' on Drug Rap
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lewis resumes testimony at 10 a.m. EDT; will be led
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis got a ``sweet deal'' from the government in exchange for damaging testimony that Mayor Marion Barry staged a cover-up of his own cocaine use, Barry's lawyer contends. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy said Wednesday that Lewis' testimony is influenced by the fact that he still hopes to get a Justice Department recommendation of leniency when he is sentenced for a drug conviction in his native Virgin Islands. ``If you testify to exonerate the mayor ... you wouldn't get that letter'' of leniency, Mundy stated flatly during Lewis' second day of testimony in Barry's cocaine and perjury trial in U.S. District Court. ``My testimony isn't to convict the mayor,'' Lewis insisted. He said he is simply trying to testify ``completely and truthfully.'' Lewis acknowledged that he didn't start cooperating with the government until he was convicted in the Virgin Islands drug case in 1989. But he insisted that the agreement with the government ``wasn't like a present.'' Lewis recently was released from prison after serving seven months on two drug-related charges. Perjury charges have been dropped. ``You got a pretty sweet deal, didn't you?'' said Mundy. ``I don't have anything to measure it by,'' Lewis replied. ``Except self-preservation,'' the lawyer suggested. Lewis testified that he and Barry smoked crack cocaine on four occasions in December 1988 at Lewis' hotel room. Lewis said that an hour after Barry brought a crack pipe to the room and smoked crack there, Lewis found out from a Washington Post reporter that he was under suspicion by police for involvement with drugs. In a telephone call later in the day, Lewis and Barry agreed Lewis would tell police the same thing he had told the reporter: that there were no drugs in Lewis' room and that neither the mayor nor Lewis used any drugs. ``Did you and Mr. Barry talk about what you were going to tell the police?'' Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin asked. ``Yes,'' Lewis replied. ``What was your understanding?'' Retchin asked. ``I would tell the police the same thing I told the Post reporter,'' replied Lewis. ``The truth or a lie?'' Retchin asked. ``I told the Post reporter a lie and therefore I would be telling the police a lie,'' Lewis testified. In a later phone conversation with Barry, Lewis said he was concerned about a possible drug test the police might administer when he went in for an interview. He said he asked Barry if there was anything he could he do to get the drugs out of his system. ``He said `yes,''' Lewis recalled. ``Lemon juice and lots of water.'' Retchin asked Lewis what he did. ``I used a considerable amount of lemon juice and lots of water,'' he replied as the courtroom erupted in laughter. Lewis said he lied to the police and later to a federal grand jury. Barry also testified to the grand jury, saying he and Lewis hadn't ever exchanged cocaine and that he didn't know of any involvement by Lewis with drugs. Those statements form the basis of the three felony counts of perjury against Barry. The three-term mayor also is accused of one misdemeanor count of conspiracy and nine counts of cocaine possession. At one point Wednesday, Barry bantered with reporters about Lewis and other government witnesses who will testify against him. ``The canaries are singing,'' the mayor quipped. ``A whole flock of them,'' one reporter responded. ``Yeah, they're coming in droves,'' Barry agreed with a smile.

DOC.HEAD: Ethics Committee Members Split Over Punishment
DOC.TEXT: Members of the House ethics committee reportedly are deeply split over how severely to punish Rep. Barney Frank for his ties to a male prostitute and how soon to bring the matter to a vote. Those who favor a light sanction against the Massachusetts Democrat are pushing for a vote next week after months of deadlock face strong opposition from panel members seeking a tougher penalty, congressional sources said Wednesday. The sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the committee of six Democrats and six Republicans could find itself with a 6-6 split on the punishment question. The tie could be mostly, but not totally, along partisan lines. A mild punishment for Frank would be a letter from the committee criticizing his behavior. More serious would be a vote by the full House to either reprimand, censure or expel Frank, one of Congress' most outspoken liberals. Any mild sanction approved by the panel, formally the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct, is almost certain to be challenged on the floor in an attempt to upgrade the punishment. The committee will meet next Tuesday and Wednesday. Through months of stalemate, the panel has found it extremely difficult to deal with a member's personal behavior rather than his official actions. While there typically is vigorous debate in the committee's closed meetings in such investigations, the final decision is usually unanimous. But two sources said Democratic members favoring a milder punishment no longer want to wait for unanimity and believe the case should be settled before the July 4 recess. One of these sources, who favors action next week, said, ``We've investigated everything. There's not a lot more to do than decide it.'' One consideration is whether Frank violated the House's catch-all Rule 43, Clause 1, which says ``A member, officer or employee of the House of Representatives shall conduct himself at all times in a manner which shall reflect creditably on the House of Representatives.'' A floor debate is almost certain because Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif., has promised to push for an expulsion resolution and others reportedly will introduce resolutions for reprimand or censure. Reprimand and censure both require a resolution criticizing a member, but censure forces him to stand before his colleagues as the content is read. Frank has acknowledged hiring prostitute Stephen L. Gobie for sex in 1985. The lawmaker, an acknowledged homosexual, said he subsequently hired Gobie as an aide and driver and paid him with personal funds. Gobie has said he used Frank's former Capitol Hill apartment for a prostitution ring, with the lawmaker's knowledge. Frank strongly denied knowing of the illicit business. Some parts of the case center on Frank's official duties. Gobie said the two men had sex in the House gymnasium. And he contended that Frank invoked congressional privilege to waive parking tickets incurred by Gobie while using Franks's car to keep appointments for illicit sex. Frank said he fired Gobie in August 1987 after learning of the prostitution ring. The lawmaker denied the sex-in-the-gym allegation and said he asked for the waiver of parking tickets incurred only while the car was used for official House business.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Said to Want Tripling of Star Wars Budget
DOC.TEXT: Pentagon planners want to triple spending on the Star Wars antimissile system over the next six years, a Senate panel chairman says. Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., said Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's internal budget planning documents show a projected spending total of $58 billion for the 1992-97 period for Star Wars, known officially as the Strategic Defense Initiative, or SDI. ``The average of $10 billion a year that the secretary is requesting is far, far above what we have ever provided in previous years, even in years when we didn't have a budget crunch,'' said Exon, chairman of the Senate Armed Services subcommittee on strategic forces and nuclear deterrence. Charles M. Herzfeld, director of defense research and engineering at the Pentagon, told Exon at a hearing Wednesday that he could not discuss the budget figure openly because it was classified. Star Wars research is aimed at developing non-nuclear weapons, radars and sensors based in space and on the ground to detect and shoot down ballistic missiles. The total cost is estimated at between $55 billion and $140 billion. Herzfeld and other Pentagon officials testified that greatly increased spending on SDI was justified despite the waning threat of a superpower war. ``While the nature and scope of the threats we face are changing, we find that strategic defenses can provide a unique and vital contribution to our defense posture,'' said Stephen J. Hadley, assistant defense secretary for international security policy. The current SDI budget is $3.5 billion, and the figure has averaged $3.3 billion over the past five years. The Bush administration is requesting $4.6 billion for the coming fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, but Congress is expected to cut that sharply. Exon said he supports SDI, which was launched by former President Reagan in 1983, but sees no way Congress will approve any increases in spending for it. ``I'm sitting on the realistic side of the table,'' Exon told Lt. Gen. George L. Monahan Jr., director of the Pentagon office that administers SDI. Monahan, who is retiring at the end of the month, said substantial increases in SDI spending will be necessary if the Pentagon is to meet President Bush's goal of deciding by 1993 whether to deploy a ballistic missile defense.

DOC.HEAD: Lawmakers Pushing Columbus Dollar Coin
DOC.TEXT: If 29 senators have their way, gold-colored, 11-sided dollar coins commemorating Christopher Columbus will soon be jingling in Americans' pockets. However, the Bush administration and the congressional General Accounting Office say the coins will simply occupy space in government vaults unless Congress simultaneously moves to end the availability of dollar bills. The government could save an average of $381 million a year by minting dollar coins, L. Nye Stevens of the GAO told the Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday. But, he warned, ``We think these savings are unlikely to occur unless Congress and the administration jointly resolve not only to eliminate the dollar note but also stand up to a negative public reaction that should be fully anticipated.'' Stevens said Australia, Canada, Japan, Britain and other European nations succeeded in introducing high-denomination coins only after they eliminated the corresponding paper bills. Donna V. Pope, director of the U.S. Mint, pointed to the Susan B. Anthony dollar coin, minted in 1979 and 1980, as an object lesson. About 425 million of the coins, half of the total struck, are still sitting in U.S. Mint and Federal Reserve vaults. Nevertheless, Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., and 28 cosponsors are offering legislation authorizing the Columbus dollar, which would be slightly larger than a quarter and be 90 percent copper. It would not eliminate the dollar bill. Domenici, who represents a copper-producing state, conceded that some Americans are reluctant to change. But he said his dollar coin would win acceptance because its color and shape would clearly differentiate it from other coins. Anyone who rides a city bus, purchases a Sunday newspaper from a machine or makes long-distance calls from a pay phone will recognize the convenience of carrying a few dollar coins rather than a pocket full of quarters, he said. ``Due to inflation, the $1 bill today buys about what a quarter purchased in 1950,'' Domenici said. Taxpayers will save money, he added. The government currently prints 3.2 billion dollar bills a year at an average cost of 2.6 cents. Dollar coins would cost 6 cents each, but they would last 20 or more years in contrast with the 16-month life of the average greenback, Domenici said. Commercial banks are opposing Domenici's bill and a similar one introduced in the House by Rep. Jim Kolbe, R-Ariz., who unlike Domenici would phase out dollar bills. The American Bankers Association says it would cost more for financial institutions to handle and transport dollar coins, which would weigh 17 pounds per 1,000, as opposed to bills, which weigh 3 pounds per 1,000.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Drivers Agree to Avoid Picket Line Abuses
DOC.TEXT: Striking Greyhound drivers say they will obey a government cease-and-desist order not to shout ``vile epithets'' at replacement workers or wave threatening signs at them. A National Labor Relations Board order also prohibits the strikers from firing guns, throwing firebombs, playing ``cat and mouse'' with buses or making throat-slashing motions at strikebreakers. ``This will put the full force and authority of the federal government to work in our campaign to stop the violence against Greyhound Lines,'' the bus line's vice president, Anthony Lannie, said Wednesday. The company called the NLRB order a major development in the 3{-month-old strike. But union officials shrugged off its significance, noting they have not admitted any part of the dozens of shootings or rock-throwing incidents that have taken place during the drivers' strike. ``We don't believe there's that kind of conduct going on act this time, and furthermore, we don't believe the union is behind it,'' said Earle Putnam, an attorney for the Amalgamated Transit Union. ``We consented to this because we never condoned nor encouraged nor ratified any violence. This says we will not do what the law says we cannot do and which we never did in the first place,'' Putnam said. The NLRB approved the order on Tuesday, but it is agency policy not to publicly announce it until both parties receive it. Most of the shootings occurred during the first two months of the strike, but Greyhound officials say assaults and intimidating acts are still occurring. The bus line, which filed for bankruptcy two weeks ago, has been operating with 3,200 replacement drivers it hired. The order stems from an unfair labor practice complaint the NLRB filed against the union more than a month ago over violence in the strike. The NLRB has also filed charges against Greyhound for attempting to implement a contract before an impasse in negotiations had occurred; the company is appealing that charge. Rather than appeal the violence-related complaint, the transit union, which represents the 6,300 drivers who walked out March 2 over wages and job security, agreed to the cease-and-desist order. If violent or harassing acts can be traced back to union leaders, they will be subject to contempt of court charges and stiff fines. Specifically, the NLRB's order prohibits union drivers from: _Playing ``cat and mouse'' games with buses by shining lights at the vehicles or braking right in front of them. _Throwing rocks, concrete, bricks, bottles, cans, eggs, coffee, milk, oil, or transmission fluid at buses or replacement drivers. _Spitting on replacement workers. _Engaging in industrial sabotage, such as breaking bus doors, mirrors or windshield wipers; throwing or setting off firebombs, firecrackers and other devices at or near Greyhound terminals or garages. _Placing nails or glass in terminal driveways. _Picketing in mass so as to block terminal driveways. _Shouting ``vile epithets'' at strikebreakers or verbally threatening them or their families. _Displaying signs with pictures of coffins or hangmen's nooses aimed at intimidating replacement workers or brandishing baseball bats. _Making shooting, throat-slashing or hanging motions at replacement workers.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: A racy Macy's ad sporting football star Roger Craig in his underwear has him contemplating a new career _ as a pinup guy. The newspaper ad for Calvin Klein briefs ran Monday in the San Francisco Bay area. Since then, Macy's has been flooded with calls, a spokesman said. ``Men like it too, but women are crazy about the ad,'' spokesman Merle Goldstone said. So crazy that the ad is being pinned up in offices and on refrigerators. The San Francisco 49ers running back, Macy's and Calvin Klein are considering making the ad into a poster. Rob Morse, a columnist for the San Francisco Examiner, called Craig ``the most gorgeous man in the world'' and urged readers Wednesday to press for a poster. ``Remember, newsprint ages quickly, even if the ink doesn't rub off on your hand,'' he wrote. ``And stop that rubbing.''

Music producer Quincy Jones will launch a movie, TV, radio and record company bankrolled by Time Warner Inc. ``It's been a dream of mine to have this kind of a relationship. We'll have the support of a large company that has a sense of style and class,'' he said Tuesday. Jones said he has resisted joint development deals in the past but was attracted to Time Warner's enormous distribution system. Financial details were not disclosed, but Jones said it was a 50-50 venture. The venture plans a TV series, ``The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air,'' a comedy starring rap artist Will Smith, and also will produce Jesse Jackson's syndicated talk program, ``The Jesse Jackson Show.''

Joan Rivers kicked in $1,000 for a wedding reception that was turned into a party for the homeless after the groom-to-be got cold feet. Miss Rivers offered the money for the Saturday party when would-be bride Kathleen Gooley appeared on the comedian's syndicated talk show. Gooley, 41, stood to lose the $4,000 deposit given to the caterer, so she decided to throw a party for the homeless. However, the deposit wasn't enough to invite 150 people from shelters and drug rehabilitation centers as she had hoped. Miss Rivers and her staff decided to contribute to the party, said Stuart Krasnow, the show's producer.

Bill Cosby says he didn't mean to single out a football player with a 2.5 grade-point average during a May 20 visit to the University of Notre Dame. The entertainer discussed the incident Tuesday on ``Larry King Live,'' the Cable New Network talk show. After giving the commencement speech at Notre Dame last month, Cosby met with about 300 people, mostly black graduates and their guests. Cosby spoke of the need to strive for excellence, pointed at football player Dean Brown and asked him his average, according to school officials and students who were there. When Brown told him, Cosby responded, ``That's nothing.'' ``The point is that it wasn't about this young man only,'' Cosby said on the King show.

Police put city officials on notice that off-duty security will be hard to come by if the rap group Public Enemy is booked to play here, so the city decided against a concert by the band. Police oppose the group because of lyrics to some of their songs, said P.D. Taylor, president of the local Fraternal Order of Police. The police group voted last fall not to provide off-duty security if Public Enemy performed in the city. The city decided not to book the band for a concert this summer at Myriad Convention Center, said Pat Downes, director of public facilities. Downes said the show would have been impossible without the off-duty security officers.

Football commentator Merlin Olsen is ending his 13-year stay at NBC and taking a job at CBS. CBS announced Wednesday that Olsen will join the network this fall as a football analyst. Olsen was NBC's top analyst for many years, but his status declined last season after the network hired former San Francisco 49ers coach Bill Walsh. ``Obviously, there was a certain level of discomfort,'' Olsen said. ``But I prefer to look at the positive instead of the negative. And I think this a very good move for me.''

DOC.HEAD: Prestigious British Wine Club Woos American Wine Sellers
DOC.TEXT: The prestigious British wine fraternity that honors top-ranking wine connoisseurs is extending its cachet to Americans and other foreigners _ if they can pass a grueling four-day exam. The Institute of Masters of Wine, a staid club of British wine merchants, is actively soliciting foreign winemakers, wine stewards, teachers and others in the fermented grape business who aspire to use the coveted letters ``MW'' after their names. Nine out of 10 candidates fail the rigorous written exams and blind tastings. But for the successful few, MW is the wine world's equivalent of academia's Ph.D. The club has only 131 members and all but 14 of them are men. ``We felt that we were becoming a rather introverted little club,'' said executive director David Stevens. We would rather become an ``internationally recognized body with prestige, weight and influence,'' he said. ``We took a very dramatic decision, for us, to throw open our doors to anyone in the world who could actually come and sit and pass this exam. '' The first step was to open membership to eligible journalists and wine writers. Only one, British wine writer and broadcaster Jancis Robinson, has passed muster. Then, foreigners, including Americans, were allowed to take the exam. So far, no U.S. palate has been admitted, although eight Americans took the annual exam in London last month. Stevens wouldn't give their names, but said they included wine teachers, wine wholesalers and retailers, and sommeliers. They will learn on July 17 whether they have joined the tiny group of foreigners in this unique professional body founded in 1953: Olivier Humbrecht from the Alsace region of France, Australian wine consultant Michael Hill-Smith and winemaker Michael Brajkovich from the Kumeu River winery in New Zealand. ``I think the examination is now much tougher than it used to be, for the very simple reason that the wine industry has become far more complicated,'' Stevens said. He passed on his first try in 1961, when ``basically, if we knew about the wines of France, Germany, a little bit about sherry, port, that was about it. Now you have to know about the wines of the world.'' This year's blind taste included wines from California, Australia, New Zealand, Spain and Lebanon, plus the produce of the more traditional wine regions of France, Germany and Italy. Candidates had to identify the grapes from which the wine was made, where they were grown, and the wine's vintage. Then they had to comment on how the wine was made and aged. Whenever possible, the judges sneak in a bad wine to test their ability to detect imperfections. Stevens said he feels education standards have declined, and that many potential masters of wine are unaccustomed to writing short essays required to test their knowledge of growing and harvesting grapes and the chemistry of winemaking. ``I think that Americans are not used to an examination where they have to express themselves in the written word,'' he said. ``They are much more used to answering multiple-choice-type questions, a tick in the box. To have to produce a very long, reasoned written answer in written form they do find difficult.'' The essay questions test knowledge of all aspects of the wine industry, from planting and harvesting to winemaking chemistry, storing and maturing bulk wine, changing consumer tastes and the trend toward mergers and takeovers in the industry. The open-ended questions range from ``Are bubbles worth a premium?'' to ``The Chardonnay grape has been described as the perfect artist's palette. Discuss and compare methods used in different wine regions to produce the various styles'' and ``How much should a wine reflect the personality and aims of the producer as opposed to the character of the vineyard?''

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Mull Budget Offer From White House
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Bargaining resumes 1:30 p.m. EDT, lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Congressional Democrats return to the budget bargaining table today unhappy with a $50 billion deficit-reduction plan that the Bush administration hopes will energize the stalled talks. White House budget director Richard Darman made the proposal on Wednesday, the first to be advanced at the six-week-old budget summit. ``The administration clearly presented this so we could start negotiations,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, ranking Republican on the Senate Budget Committee. Domenici said the plan will save $440 billion over the next five years. He called it a ``good starting point'' in efforts to shrink a budget gap that administration and congressional experts believe is swelling beyond earlier expectations. But Democrats were not enthusiastic. ``We have a good long way to go,'' said their lead bargainer, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. Democratic negotiators met privately following Wednesday's negotiating session and called Darman's proposal inadequate, said a participant in the talks who asked not to be identified. The plan was seen by some Democrats as differing little from the $37 billion in savings that President Bush proposed in January in his fiscal 1991 budget. Bush's spending plan has been declared obsolete by Democrats and Republicans on Capitol Hill. Fiscal 1991 begins Oct. 1, just more than three months from now. ``I'd compare (Darman's plan) that to building a new room onto a house that's already collapsed,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. According to officials involved in the talks, the administration proposal relies on $20 billion in new taxes and other revenues, $18 billion in reductions in benefit programs such as Medicare, and $6 billion in defense cuts. It also includes $4 billion in domestic program reductions and $2 billion saved by making lower than expected interest payments on the national debt. The administration provided few details on where the savings would come, participants said. Democrats say they believe at least $55 billion in savings are needed next year, and $500 billion to $600 billion over the next five years. The red ink grew again on Wednesday. Darman told negotiators he now believes next year's budget shortfall will be $159 billion unless action is taken. If no action is taken, $86 billion in cuts in most government programs would occur Oct. 1 under the Gramm-Rudman law. That amount is considered intolerable by most lawmakers and White House officials. Gramm-Rudman requires the president and Congress to reduce next year's budget gap to $64 billion. If they miss that target by more than $10 billion, the law imposes cuts in federal spending. Last month, Darman projected next year's deficit at $138 billion. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office estimated the 1991 shortfall at $164 billion on Wednesday. All figures excluded the government cost of covering the collapse of the savings and loan industry. Those expenses could drive next year's deficit to about $230 billion, CBO and the White House agree.

DOC.HEAD: House Committee Approves Measure to Repeal Insurance Antitrust Exemption
DOC.TEXT: Consumer groups hope election-year politics will help them overcome insurance companies' lobbying power and win congressional repeal of the industry's exemption from antitrust laws. The House Judiciary Committee bolstered their effort Wednesday, approving 19-17 a bill to subject insurance companies to federal antitrust lawsuits for the first time since 1945. Three of the committee's 22 Democrats _ Reps. Dan Glickman of Kansas, Bruce Morrison of Connecticut and Edward Feighan of Ohio _ voted with all 14 Republicans in opposing it. The bill would remove the industry's exemption from federal antitrust laws under the 1945 McCarren-Ferguson Act, which turned the regulation of insurance companies over to state governments. Policyholders who could show that states are not actively regulating the industry could sue insurance companies and their agents for price-fixing and other anticompetitive practices. ``Private individuals, local governments and businesses of all sizes have found their premiums skyrocketing and their coverage severely restricted,'' said Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, the committee chairman. ``Congress can no longer ignore the widespread economic dislocation caused by unreasonably high premiums or policies that are unavailable at any price.'' In addition to price-fixing, damages could be sought for the following anticompetitive practices: _Allocating territories among competing companies. _Monopolization. _Forcing consumers to purchase insurance they don't want so they can buy the kind they do want. An example is requiring the purchase of a homeowners' policy in order to get auto insurance. Consumer groups seeking the legislation for the past 15 years acknowledged they face an uphill fight. But they voiced optimism that the committee vote opens the way for a House floor fight that will draw public attention to the issue. ``This represents an important breakthrough,'' said Robert Brandon, vice president of Citizen Action, a grassroots consumer organization claiming 2 million members. ``It demonstrates that an informed and aroused public can break the insurance industry's stranglehold over legislators.'' Linda Lipsen, legislative counsel for Consumers Union, predicted the bill will become a major election-year issue once it reaches the House floor. ``Behind food and shelter, insurance is the single largest expenditure of the year for the average consumer,'' she said. ``Just like the gun lobby, the insurance lobby is no longer being perceived by Congress as invincible.'' The bill would allow insurance companies to continue sharing raw data on claims. But after a five-year transition period, it would greatly weaken companies' reliance upon the Insurance Services Office, a New York-based industry organization that now ``advises'' what rates should be charged. A similar bill was approved by the panel's economic and commercial law subcommittee two years ago but died there under an intensive industry lobbying effort. Democrats said they hope to bring the new version to the full House in late summer or early fall. Although similar legislation has been introduced in the Senate, industry lobbyists say they are counting on Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Howell Heflin, D-Ala., both members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, to prevent it from reaching a floor vote there. ``If this bill is enacted into law, it may prove disastrous for consumers and small insurance companies alike,'' said Lowell Beck, president of the National Association of Independent Insurers. ``Every litigated claim would subject to additional antitrust counts. Legal costs, which by necessity would be passed on to consumers, would soar.'' Lipsen disputed that claim, citing a report by the General Accounting Office showing that workers' compensation insurance rates fell by 30 percent in Michigan after its legislature in 1982 repealed a state antitrust exemption for such coverage.

DOC.HEAD: Legislation Calls for Tougher Penalties in Crime Against Women
DOC.TEXT: A former New York model whose face was slashed by razor blades says ``the stigma of victimization'' haunts her more than the actual memory of the attack four years ago. ``In the scope of things, those cuts to my face that night became almost insignificant except as a reference point,'' Marla Hanson told the Senate Judiciary Committee on Wednesday. The comment came at a hearing on legislation sponsored by committee Chairman Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., calling for tougher penalties for violence against women. It would make gender-related crimes a violation of civil rights, entitling victims to sue for damages. The bill also would: _Double the minimum penalties for rape on federal property from six to 12 years and from nine to 18 years for rape that involves injury, weapons or kidnapping. A convicted rapist would have to pay his victim for medical, psychological or rehabilitation costs and lost income. _Provide $300 million in grants to combat gender-related crimes. _Create a national commission on violence against women. The number of rapes has increased four times faster than total crime over the last decade, according to committee figures. A woman is beaten every 18 seconds and raped every six minutes, the committee said. The committee also heard from Nancy Ziegenmeyer, a Grinnell, Iowa, woman who was abducted and raped in 1988. She said police treated her well but that prosecutors were overworked and she was hurt emotionally by an impersonal criminal justice system. ``The crime against my body and my person became a crime against the state,'' she said. ``I became just a witness for the state of Iowa and a case number. It was a crime against the state. It no longer was a crime against me.'' Ms. Hanson and Mrs. Ziegenmeyer, who testified in an effort to draw attention to the problem, said they saw little that Congress could do to cut down on such crimes but that women could be better treated by the system. They called for advocates to ensure that victims understand the court process. Female victims often suffer harsh treatment in the court system, said Linda Fairstein, chief of the sex crimes prosecution unit in the Manhattan district attorney's office. ``I agree wholeheartedly with Nancy and Marla there is a true need within the system for advocates working with both the prosecutors and the victims,'' she said. Ms. Hanson, a 29-year-old student at New York University, underwent extensive plastic surgery to diminish the scars she suffered. The attack occurred after Ms. Hanson rebuffed advances from her landlord. ``It seems in this society the term innocence implies some sort of guilt _ and nowhere is that attitude more apparent than in our current judicial system,'' she said, telling the committee that defense lawyers tried to make it seem that she was a ``woman of loose morals.'' Ms. Hanson's landlord and two other assailants each were given the maximum five- to 15-year sentence. Mrs. Ziegenmeyer's attacker was sentenced to life in prison with no possibility of parole on first-degree kidnapping charges.

DOC.HEAD: Says PLO Acquiescence Still Necessary for Peace Talks
With PM-Bush Rdp Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Despite the suspension of U.S. talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Secretary of State James A. Baker III says Israel still needs the acquiescence of the PLO to find a partner for peace talks. Baker, whose recommendation for a suspension of the 18-month dialogue was approved and announced by President Bush on a political trip to Alabama, defended the decision even while admitting it would hurt moderate Arabs. ``We really could not let our pursuit of peace stand in the way of our commitment to fight terrorism,'' Baker said late Wednesday en route to East Berlin for talks on German unification. ``A resort to terrorism would undermine any peace process that was unfolding,'' Baker said before a refueling stop here. And yet, he said the 18-month dialogue that Bush suspended over an aborted attack on Tel Aviv three weeks ago contributed the to U.S. effort to get Israelis to talk to Palestinian Arabs. And, Baker said, the suspension ordered by Bush because PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat did not disavow the attack or punish the perpetrators ``could have an adverse impact'' on Egypt and other moderates, including some Palestinians. Baker stressed they will keep trying to persuade Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's government to approve U.S. terms for talks with Palestinians. ``We were not seeking a dialogue between Israel and the PLO,'' Baker said. But, he said, ``everybody recognizes that without PLO acquiescence there won't be a dialogue for Israel. They have been seeking to develop one for 22 years (since the 1967 Mideast war) and none has come forward. That points up the way in which this dialogue could contribute toward progress toward a peace process.'' The last Israeli government, also headed by Shamir, refused to accept Baker's formula for talks in March and then collapsed. The new government formed by Shamir has laid down even stiffer terms for talking to Palestinians. But senior U.S. officials on Baker's plane said the formula would not be changed. ``We're not prepared to embrace ideas that are non-starters,'' said one official who spoke on condition of anonymity. The U.S. break with the PLO, long sought by Israel, could put pressure on Shamir to go along with Baker's formula, which includes participation in the talks of Palestinians deported from the West Bank. ``We've not got a formal answer to our question,'' a U.S. official said. ``Now if we get a no, what is the reason for it? OK?''

DOC.HEAD: Two Convicts Captured After Escaping From Prison in Helicopter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with word that both inmates recaptured, additional details. Picks up 6th pvs, `The Bell...'
DOC.TEXT: A convicted murderer and another prisoner who broke out of a maximum-security prison in a daring helicopter escape were recaptured Wednesday night, authorities said. Robert Ford, 32, and convicted robber David Thomas, 24, were plucked out of the exercise yard in Kent prison, about 50 miles east of Vancouver, in Monday's escape. A prison guard was shot in the leg during the escape. The two were arrested without incident on Echo Island, a small, heavily forested island in the middle of Harrison Lake, said Sgt. Sid Slater of the Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Echo Island, visible from this tourist town east of Vancouver, is about nine miles north of the prison. About 10-15 police with dogs stayed on the island after the capture and patrol boats were deployed in case a third man, the accomplice who helped the pair escape, was also on the island, Slater said. Prison spokeswoman Diane Brown said Ford was serving a life sentence for first-degree murder and that Thomas was serving an eight-year term for robbery. The Bell 206 helicopter used in the Monday escape attempt and its pilot, Fred Fandrich, were hijacked from Valley Helicopters Ltd. Frandrich was released soon after the hijacking. It was Ford's second failed escape attempt. In March 1989, Ford and two other men escaped from a prison in Victoria, British Columbia, while awaiting trial. They were captured 11 days later. Al Hadvick, a representative for the Public Service Alliance of Canada, said about 20 guards at Kent prison staged a strike Wednesday to protest the handling of the escape. Ken Peterson, an official at Kent, said 40 reports had been filed by prison staff on Ford. He said the Charter of Rights and lack of evidence prevented prison officials from segregating Ford. Peterson said prison officials had received staff reports that Ford might have been planning a prison break prior to his escape and added that officials were aware that Ford had a helicopter pilot's licence. Hadvick said corrections officials had submitted reports that Ford had been exploring possible escape routes and was once timed by another prisoner as he sprinted from one area of the prison to another.

DOC.HEAD: Government Agrees to Release up to $6 Million in Noriega Assets
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors have offered to release up to $6 million from Manuel Noriega's frozen accounts to let him pay for his defense. Panama's new government immediately warned it will lay claim to the former dictator's assets. The deal Wednesday with Noriega's lawyers could end weeks of wrangling over $20 million frozen in accounts around the world after the U.S. invasion of Panama _ money the defense in the drug trafficking case said it needs to proceed. The move also would avoid a showdown over potentially embarassing details of payments by the CIA and other U.S intelligence agencies to the former Panamanian leader. ``This avoids distracting litigation and premature presentation of evidence that would only sidetrack us from the real issues,'' said U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen. Noriega's chief attorney, Frank Rubino, who had threatened make the CIA payments public after the collapse of a previous compromise under which the government was to pay Noriega's lawyers, said he was happy with the new deal. ``I think the American people should be thrilled that their taxes are not funding Noriega's defense,'' Rubino said. He denied the government was trying to avoid embarassment, saying prosecutors simply wanted ``a good trial, a fair trial.'' However, one potential roadblock for the deal was a $5.3 billion racketeering suit against Noriega announced at the hearing Wednesday on behalf of Panama. Panama's attorney Gregory Craig said the lawsuit will allege murder, grand theft and extortion by Noriega. He said it is being filed so that ``no irreparable damage be done to those funds that rightfully belong to the Panamanian people.'' But U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler warned Craig he will not let the lawsuit interfere with the criminal trial, set to begin in January 1991. Under the arrangement to free some of Noriega's assets, the government will ask European nations that froze some of 27 Noriega accounts at the request of the United States to release them to Hoeveler.
