Some of the accounts were seized by other judicial districts in the United States, and Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan said judges there and in Europe will have to approve the deal. Rubino said the money is deposited in about half a dozen European countries. Under the agreement, the total to be released will be between $4.5 million and $6 million. Defense attorney Steven Kollin estimated the defense will cost $5 million and said the government is prepared to spend close to $40 million to convict Noriega. Wednesday's deal was foreshadowed last week when the judge criticized the freezing of Noriega's accounts. The judge said the government must either prove that the money was drug profits, as it claimed, or release it to the defense. Noriega's lawyers had threatened to quit unless they got paid. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. troops Jan. 4, is being held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami on charges of taking $4.6 million in bribes to protect the Colombian cocaine trade. In addition to the racketeering lawsuit, two news photographers injured by U.S. gunfire during the invasion of Panama sued Manuel Noriega for $3 million on Wednesday, saying he is to blame for ``letting loose the dogs of war.'' Sygma photographer Patrick Chauvel of France was shot in the abdomen and Reuters photographer Malcolm Linton of Britain was shot in the leg on Dec. 15 outside a Panama City hotel. In the lawsuit, they claim Noriega is responsible for their injuries because he provoked the invasion.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Lower
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,087.27, down 0.49 points or 0.0015 percent, on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: What Mandela Had to Say
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Excerpts from remarks by African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela during his appearances Wednesday around New York.
DOC.HEAD: Upon arrival at Kennedy International Airport:
DOC.TEXT: ``It is an honor and a source of tremendous joy and strength for my wife, our delegation, to be received with such a rousing welcome by the people of this city ... to be received by the masses of the people who have throughout these years set the tempo for the immense support which we, in our struggle against racial oppression, have received from here. It is indeed a source of great hope.''

``Our simple message, in all these countries, is that the sanctions should be maintained. We are saying so because sanctions were introduced for the purpose of dismantling apartheid, and are making sure that every South African _ black and white _ is able to determine his own future. It is no use to demand that apartheid is scrapped. ... What brings about changes in politics is the type of action which you are prepared to embark upon in order to bring about those changes.''

``We have, throughout our political struggle, attached importance not only in the goals that were set for ourselves, but also as far as the methods which we must use. ... It is because of the importance which was attached to methods of political action, that today we can say with confidence that we can see the light at the end of the tunnel.''

``We regard our visit here as of extreme importance, and we are looking forward to meeting President Bush, whose invitation we are honoring. We look forward to a discussion with him in which I will press him on the latest political developments, and of course ask him to continue to maintain sanctions.''
DOC.HEAD: At a rally, Boys and Girls High School in Brooklyn:
DOC.TEXT: ``To enjoy the support of the youth, the future leaders of this country and the world, cuts down my age almost by 25 years. I sincerely feel very strong and encouraged, because if in our struggle we receive the support of the youth of the world, then our cause can never fail, can never be lost.''
``One of the requests we'd like to make to you is that the young people of this area should raise funds, so that our children can get facilities to continue their studies under better conditions.''

``We asked those students (in Toronto) to help to raise funds ... One young lady, who has a beautiful face, a sound head and a good heart, gave me a brooch. And when I looked at it, written across it were the words, `Students for students.' We thanked her because she understood the message.''
DOC.HEAD: At a City Hall ceremony:
DOC.TEXT: ``For our people, New York has a special meaning and even fascination. I'm therefore very pleased to receive the key to the city of New York. It is, I believe, in recognition of the heroism and courage of the oppressed people of South Africa. Our people have made enormous sacrifices in the struggle to liberty. They are ready to make even greater sacrifices if need be.''

DOC.HEAD: New Combination of Drugs Approved for Advanced Colon Cancer
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a new combination drug treatment that has been shown to prolong survival for patients with advanced stages of colon cancer. The therapy combines levamisole, a drug previously approved only for eliminating intestinal parasites in animals, with fluorouracil, already approved for treatment of several types of cancer. FDA officials said Wednesday the combination of the two drugs in patients who have undergone surgery for colon cancer that has spread to nearby lymph nodes has been shown to reduce tumor reccurence and death in some patients. Colon cancer that has spread to lymph nodes is classified as stage 3, a category that applies to about 21,000 of the 110,000 Americans diagnosed with colon cancer each year. About 40 percent live for five years or more after surgery, the FDA said. The combination therapy was tested in two clinical trials sponsored by the National Cancer Institute that involved about 1,700 patients who had undergone surgery for stage 3 colon cancer. Researchers found that the treatment reduced the death rate for these patients by about one-third and the tumor-recurrence rate by about 40 percent. They don't know, however, how the five-year survival rate will be affected since they have not followed these test patients that long yet, said FDA spokeswoman Eva Kemper.
DOC.HEAD: Ohio Congressman Collapses In Office
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, is in Walter Reed Army Medical Center for treatment of a kidney stone. ``His legs kind of went out from under him,'' said Louise Hilsen, Eckart's press secretary, explaining his collapse Wednesday in his office. Eckart was examined by a doctor and emergency medical team on duty at the Capitol and then taken to Walter Reed, where he was admitted around 1 p.m., Hilsen said. ``He is resting uncomfortably,'' she said. ``He is in a great deal of pain.'' Eckart, 40, had no previous kidney problems, she said.
DOC.HEAD: Automakers, Insurers Clash On Copyrighting Auto Part Design
DOC.TEXT: Automakers and insurers disagree over copyright protection for product designs. The auto industry urged Congress on Wednesday to approve legislation that would prohibit independent manufacturers from copying a part's original design for a decade after it first appears on the market. The bills would protect consumers from shoddy imitation parts, auto lobbyists told the House Subcommittee on Courts, Intellectual Property and Administration of Justice. ``Imitation sheet metal parts are often of lesser quality in fit, finish and durability,'' said Kenneth W. Myers of Ford Motor Co. He spoke on behalf of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, which represents the Big Three U.S. automakers. Opponents, led by insurers, said the legislation was designed to squelch competition in the lucrative replacement parts industry, which generated $52 billion in sales in 1988. The price of parts will soar if the bills are passed, they said. ``American consumers will have to pay hundreds of millions of dollars a year in monopoly profits to ... auto manufacturers and they will get nothing in return,'' said C.A. Ingham, vice president of State Farm Insurance Co.

DOC.HEAD: Remains Returned for Burial
DOC.TEXT: The remains of eight Aborigines have been returned to their communities after years on display in British, French and Belgian museums. Aboriginal activist Michael Mansell and Aborigine Karno Walker were met by elders and community representatives from around Australia when they arrived with the remains at Sydney Airport on Wednesday night. Mansell said the remains, which included parts of eight bodies, would be given to their original communities and ``finally laid to rest'' in burial ceremonies. He said lobbying for other remains still in overseas museums would continue. ``Some institutions need prompting from the Australian government. It has to step behind us to stop our moves being frustrated,'' he said. Mansell and the Federation of Aboriginal Land Councils had fought for five years to have the remains returned to communities around Australia, and not to museums here.

DOC.HEAD: Major Earthquake Hits Iran, At Least 130 Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: COMBINES urgent series. Minor editing. ^By MARTIN MARRIS
DOC.TEXT: A major earthquake devastated cities and villages in northern Iran early Thursday. State media said at least 130 people were killed and 1,650 injured as buildings crumbled onto them. The official Islamic Republic News Agency (IRNA) said the quake caused ``massive destruction,'' triggering landslides that blocked main roads and hampered rescue efforts. Rescue workers struggled to pull victims from the rubble. IRNA said the death toll was expected to climb as hundreds of people were missing. The Geophysics Center at Tehran University said the quake measured 7.3 on the Richter Scale. The U.S. Geological Survey measured it at 7.7 on the scale. IRNA said the quake struck at 12:30 a.m. while most people were either sleeping or watching World Cup soccer on television. It quoted the Geophysics Center as saying aftershocks continued for about two hours. Tehran Radio said 50 people were killed and more than 700 injured in the city of Zanjan, 190 miles northwest of Tehran. It said 500 people were killed or injured in and around the village of Hir in the same region. It said several area villages were ``destroyed.'' IRNA said an unspecified number of people also were killed and injured in the Caspian Sea port city of Rasht 175 miles northwest of Tehran. ``The exact number of casualties and the extent of losses were still unknown,'' it reported. IRNA reported roads blocked by landslides and said a request had been sent to the Interior Ministry for medical teams and heavy lifting machinery. The agency said rescuers and relief teams had set up headquarters in Rasht. IRNA said the quake also shook Tehran, sending panicked people into the streets. There were no reported casualties in Tehran. The earthquake struck in the Caspian about 15 miles off the Iranian coast, said Russ Needham, a geophysicist with the U.S. Geological Survey National Earth Information Center in Golden, Colo. The Geophysics Center at Tehran University said the quake was centered 125 miles northwest of Tehran. Needham said that preliminary data put the epicenter 210 miles northwest of Tehran and 160 miles south of Baku, an oil port and capital of the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan. He said there was ``a good possibility of casualties and damage'' in southern Azerbaijan. The opposition Mujahedeen Khalq claimed the government was under-reporting the casualties and damage. ``Thousands of people were killed or wounded,'' Ali Safavi, a spokesman for the group, said by telephone from the group's base in Baghdad, Iraq. His reports, quoting the group's sources inside Iran, could not be independently confirmed. The earthquake that struck San Francisco in October measured 7.1 on the Richter scale. It left 67 people dead and caused damage estimated at $7 billion. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake with a magnitude of 7 is capable of widespread, heavy damage while an earthquake measuring 8 is capable of tremendous damage.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains, Stock Prices Edge Lower
DOC.TEXT: The key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange erased its early gains and closed marginally lower Thursday, while the dollar edged up against the Japanese yen. The dollar closed at 154.60 yen, up 0.62 yen from Wednesday's 153.98-yen finish. It opened at 154.28 yen and ranged between 154.25 yen and 154.63 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average fell 0.49 of a point, or 0.0015 percent, ending the day at 32,087.27. The index ended the early session with a 38.89-point gain before falling back in the afternoon. ``Although the index rose earlier when investment trust companies were buying, it gradually fell as trading lost direction,'' said Tomoyuki Morimoto, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. The weaker yen and a decline in government bond prices also discouraged participants, he said. The benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 87.28 points from Wednesday's close of 87.42, boosting the yield to 7.125 percent from 7.095 percent. In currency dealing, the dollar continued to rise after showing strength in overseas markets overnight, dealers said. They said some participants bought the dollar because of political uncertainties in the Soviet Union, while others sold the currency for technical adjustments. Hard-line Communists have made it clear they will try to replace President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as leader of the Soviet Communist Party at a party congress set for early July.

DOC.HEAD: Anger Surrounds AIDS Conference
LaserPhoto FX1
DOC.TEXT: The world's biggest convention on AIDS began under siege by thousands of angry demonstrators frustrated that many of them are likely to die of the disease before scientists learn to control it. Police said 80 demonstrators were arrested Wednesday, and speakers at the opening ceremonies in the evening repeatedly alluded to the protesters. While conference participants were entertained by the San Francisco Gay Mens' Chorus in the heavily guarded Moscone Center, a crowd outside chanted: ``We're here. We're queer. And we demand access.'' About half the estimated 50,000 gay men in San Francisco are infected with the AIDS virus, epidemiologists say. ``The anger and frustration that surrounds this conference and pushes into it comes from seeing loved ones die,'' Mayor Art Agnos told the conference. ``I know, because I have gone through the same experiences, and I am doing so now with people I love.'' The Sixth International Conference on AIDS drew an estimated 12,000 researchers, doctors, social workers and other AIDS professionals, along with 1,800 reporters and thousands of activists. More than 100 groups, including the International Planned Parenthood Foundation, boycotted the meeting in opposition to an immigration policy that allows foreigners infected with the AIDS virus to be barred from the United States. ``The conference organizers also oppose the U.S. immigration policy in the strongest possible terms,'' the conference chairman, Dr. John L. Ziegler, told the gathering. While AIDS specialists generally sympathized with demonstrators' frustration, many resented disruptions like one that occurred at an AIDS pharmaceutical meeting earlier Wednesday. About a dozen members of the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power ran through, shouting and tossing leaflets. After a few minutes of arguing over an ACT UP member's attempt to seize the floor, the invited speakers left and talked by closed-circuit TV from another room. Many doctors were upset. ``They think that practicing physicians are the enemy. This will hinder the exchange of useful information,'' said Dr. John Weiser of Minneapolis. Dr. June E. Osborn, chairman of the National Commission on AIDS, cautioned that anger ``can be a powerful source of raw energy, but it must be transformed into resolve in order to be useful.'' In an effort to avert trouble, Peter Staley, an ACT UP member from New York, was invited to give one of the opening speeches. He attempted to lead the delegates in an anti-Bush administration chant using a conservative estimate of the worldwide AIDS toll: ``300,000 dead from AIDS. Where is George?'' Few participated. ``On my side, the level of anger and frustration is reaching such a point that attitudes claiming that all of you are uncaring and in it for greed are now widespread,'' Staley said. The magnitude of the challenge was clear in a report by the National Academy of Sciences about the likely course of the epidemic. It said that while new infections appear to be leveling off in gay men, the virus is spreading rapidly among crack smokers, heavy drinkers, women and teen-agers. ``We believe the picture of AIDS and HIV infection in the foreseeable future is one of a continuing toll of sickness and death for a steadily broadening profile of individuals,'' said one of the authors, Dr. Don C. Des Jarlais of Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York. There were also reminders of science's rapidly building understanding of AIDS and the human immunodeficiency virus. At a symposium, Dr. Luc Montagnier of the Pasteur Institute in Paris, suggested tiny bacteria called mycoplasma might work with HIV, the AIDS virus, to kill cells. ``There are shortcomings in the idea that HIV causes all the signs of AIDS,'' said Montagnier, a discoverer of the virus. Preliminary studies in his laboratory suggest treatment of AIDS patients with antiviral drugs in combination with drugs that attack mysoplasma might alleviate some of the worst symptoms of the disease. Dr. Jay A. Levy of the University of California at San Francisco noted the recent discovery that white cells called suppressor cells make a protein that holds virus-infected cells in check. Identifying this substance should provide a new antiviral drug. Experiments in chimpanzees also show that a vaccine against HIV may be possible. ``In this decade, we have come a long way in our understanding of HIV infection, and our direction now seems much better defined,'' Levy said. ``Where we are on the path to conquering AIDS, however, is still uncertain. But we have begun to see the horizon, and we will get there.''

DOC.HEAD: Opera Thrilled to Host Last Performance
DOC.TEXT: The Australian Orchestra says it's honored to host the final performances of Dame Joan Sutherland, but watching the last show will be a costly proposition. Ms. Sutherland, 63, announced in London on Wednesday that the Australian Opera's performance of ``Les Huguenots'' in September will be the swan song of her 40-year career. All eight performances already are sold out. Tickets for the final show on Oct. 2 were snapped up at the beginning of the year and a premium seat cost $390 (U.S.). She was to have brought down the curtain for the last time at London's Covent Garden in December and January with Strauss' opera ``Die Fledermaus,'' but changed her mind due to the heavy demands of singing the part of the vivacious Rosalinde. Her husband, conductor Richard Bonynge, said Wednesday during a break in the Sydney rehearsals for ``The Gipsy Princess'' that ``Die Fledermaus'' was ``too hard on the legs _ a killer for her.'' ``It's a long, demanding role, involving dancing and costume changes,'' he said. ``She is on stage for the entire first act, most of the second and all of the third. ``By contrast, `Les Huguenots' is one of her old party pieces. She's on for one act and a bit in a five-act opera. Joan wanted to go out on top and not tarnish the public's memories of her earlier performances in `Fledermaus.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Daughter Unshaken in Belief That Mother Was Murdered
LaserPhoto SK1
DOC.TEXT: Time has not stopped the tears or shaken Judy Bradley's belief that a murderer ended her mother's life five years ago. Now, new witnesses and an exhumation and autopsy have authorities re-evaluating what they thought was the natural death of Thelma Lillian Blodgett. Life itself had shown no signs of slowing the tiny, graying spitfire known around the neighborhood as Aunt Tillie. If she feared the ex-convicts and rowdies around her apartment in South Salt Lake, she didn't let on. The 4-foot-11 woman often was in the thick of things, upbraiding drug users, refereeing a brawl or lending money to a neighbor pleading hard luck. ``Actually, it scared a lot of us, but my mother was feisty,'' Bradley said. ``Guys would fight in the parking lot and she'd go out there and grab them by the ear and tell them to knock it off. ``My mother could get scared, but she wouldn't let anyone else know it. She was feisty right up until the day she died.'' She died on July 11, 1985. Bradley was convinced her mother did not go peacefully. ``Things were just not right,'' she said. A South Salt Lake police report indicates Blodgett died in her bathroom in the afternoon. Finding no marks on the body or suspicious circumstances, officers told Bradley her 69-year-old mother apparently had a heart attack. ``I said, `I'm telling you right now somebody killed her.' I argued with all of them, and believe me that house was full of police officers,'' Bradley said. One of them, Detective Sgt. Jim Foster, said police followed up when Bradley phoned later that night to report some of her mother's belongings missing. But a medical examiner concluded Blodgett died of natural causes. New evidence suggests Bradley was right, investigators say. On June 11, Blodgett's body was exhumed and an autopsy performed by a new medical examiner, Dr. Todd Grey. He changed the cause of death to ``undetermined'' and promised a further report in about a week from today. Investigators said the exhumation order was obtained after they talked with witnesses who had not previously come forward. ``Homicide cases are like that. You'll hit a brick wall, then somebody decides to talk about it,'' said Jim Bell, chief investigator for the medical examiner. Investigators said their new information involves Daniel Troyer, a Utah State Prison inmate awaiting trial on charges of murdering 88-year-old Ethel Luckau of Salt Lake City in 1988. Troyer, who has a prior conviction for the rape and beating of a 66-year-old woman, was questioned in 1988 about the deaths of four elderly woman, including Blodgett and Luckau. But police came up with few leads in all but the Luckau case. Defense attorney James Valdez insists his client had nothing to do with Blodgett's death or the deaths of any of the other women police have questioned him about. ``The problem is, any time an elderly woman dies of suspicious circumstances, they're all the time automatically considering Danny as a suspect,'' he said. The attorney did not know of any new evidence investigators may have against his client, and police will not say. The renewed interest came as a surprise to Bradley. Tears still flow freely when she thinks of her mother, as she has every day since that morning she met her for coffee, left for a half hour and returned to find her body. ``You relive it every day. I know I want them to find her killer. It'll give me some relief, but it won't make it easier,'' she said. Her days are spent at home, taking care of an old friend immobilized by a stroke. The two get by on Bradley's widow's pension and his Social Security and veteran's benefits. The ordeal has drained her of energy and ambition at age 49. But it hasn't quite snuffed the spark of the renegade, who like Tillie grew up fast, ran wild as a teen-ager and married ``too many'' times. ``They better find that guy because sooner or later I will if it takes the rest of my life,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Taiwanese Defector Singer Deported From China: Report
DOC.TEXT: A popular folk singer deported back to his native Taiwan for criticizing Beijing's crackdown on dissent says Chinese officials gave him a choice: prison or the return to Taiwan. ``I chose to leave,'' Hou Dejian, 34, was quoted as saying by the United Daily News. Taiwan officials said Hou had returned to Taiwan on Wednesday by fishing boat and that he was being questioned by authorities. Hou defected from Taiwan in 1983, saying he needed to seek his roots. Liu Peng-chun, deputy director of the Exit and Entry Bureau, said the singer would be allowed to resettle in Taiwan because he was fleeing political suppression. Hou and two other dissidents disappeared in Beijing on May 31 just hours before they were to issue an open letter to Chinese leaders calling for the release of political prisoners. The other two _ university newspaper editor Gao Xin and former university lecturer Zhou Duo _ resurfaced earlier this week in Beijing, with Gao saying he spent the two weeks ``vacationing'' under police supervision. In an interview with the United Daily News, Hou said he was deported by Chinese authorities after being detained 10 days in Beijing for his public criticism of the bloody crackdown of the pro-democracy movement last year that left hundreds of civilians dead. ``I had tried to persuade them (Chinese officials) into accepting good reasoning and accepting dissidents who held different opinions,'' Hou said. ``My efforts were a complete failure.'' He said he was placed on a patrol boat in the southern Chinese port of Fuzhou on Monday and transferred to a Taiwanese fishing vessel that brought him back to the offshore island. Hou's father was soldier and one of the 2 million followers of the Nationalist government who retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to communist forces on the Chinese mainland. Hou was a commercially established singer before, during a 1983 visit to the Communist mainland, he decided to stay. The darling of the government, he was allowed to keep living like a star, with two homes and two cars, one a maroon Mercedes Benz. The skinny, chain-smoking Hou is famous among Chinese on the mainland, Taiwan and Hong Kong for his Bob Dylan-influenced songs about social concerns, such as the endangered pandas, and about the worries of youth. But he became known to Westerners when, in the final days of China's student democracy movement, he and three friends began a hunger strike in Tiananmen Square to protest martial law. Many students were already leaving the square out of fear, and the hunger strike infused the movement with new spirit. When troops were called in to crush the pro-democracy movement on June 3-4, the four negotiated safe passage out of besieged Tiananmen Square for the few thousand remaining student protesters. Hou then hid in the Australian Embassy in Beijing for more than two months until the Chinese government promised he would not be arrested. After he left the embassy, he was one of the few Chinese to continue to publicly call for democratic reform.

DOC.HEAD: Discovery of Lion-Headed Monkey Could Aid Conservation Efforts
DOC.TEXT: A new species of monkey with a lion's head and a striking gold and black coat has been discovered in an unlikely place _ a highly urbanized part of Brazil, scientists say. The black-faced lion tamarin, as the new monkey is called, is a golden squirrel-sized monkey with black face, forearms and tail, and a big, bushy mane. It was discovered this spring, researchers said Wednesday. ``It's quite remarkable, because it's almost like finding something in the suburbs of Los Angeles,'' said Russell Mittermeier, president of Conservation International in Washington. It is only the fourth species of lion tamarin known. It will be the highlight of a meeting on lion tamarins to be held in Brazil beginning today. The discovery of the monkey ``complicates conservationists' jobs because we have to be concerned with another species in another habitat,'' said Charles Snowdon, a zoologist and psychologist at the University of Wisconsin. On the other hand, he said, ``It may be important for getting better ideas about how to conserve all species of lion tamarins.'' The new lion tamarin was found by two biology students who had just taken their first jobs as professors, Lucia Lorini and Vanessa Guerra Persson. They were collaborating with Dante Martins Teixera of the National Museum in Rio de Janeiro. The discovery ``is biologically important and an important conservation challenge as well,'' said Benjamin Beck, associate director of the National Zoo in Washington. Further studies of the animals' habitat and their relation to other lion tamarins should be conducted soon, he said. When Mittermeier learned of the discovery, he immediately committed $30,000 toward such studies and toward protection of this highly endangered new species. The black-faced lion taarin was discovered on the island of Superagui, south of the city of Sao Paulo, in the Brazilian state of Parana. Parana is one of Brazil's most developed areas, with only 3 percent of its original forest cover remaining, Mittermeier said. Part of the island is a national park, Mittermeier said, but the black-faced lion tamarin was found only in another part of the island, he said. Preliminary surveys suggest that only a few dozen of the black-faced lion tamarins have survived, Mittermeier said. Three other species of lion tamarins are known, the most famous of them the golden-lion tamarin, which has been bred in captivity at the National Zoo and elsewhere around the world. It has been reintroduced into a reserve in Brazil. All are members of the genus Leontopithecus. The new lion tamarin was named Leontopithecus caissara after the coastal fishermen, or caicaras, who live and work on the island where it was found. All of the lion tamarins are endangered, primarily because the coastal Atlantic forest of Brazil, their sole habitat, has nearly disappeared under the crush of a burgeoning human population. Researchers must find out exactly how many black-faced lion tamarins remain, exactly where and how they live, what they eat and what other animals live in the same places, Beck said.

DOC.HEAD: Temple Dig May Reveal Much About Ancient Culture
DOC.TEXT: A 4,000-year-old temple believed to honor a goddess of healing is being unearthed in Iraq and may shed light on ancient medicine and other aspects of life in Babylonian times, archeologists say. Digging began in January on the relatively untouched structure in Nippur. Nippur was the religious heart of Mesopotamia and the site of many temples, but archeologists said they were surprised by the size of this temple. Diggers have only uncovered about a sixth of the temple's foundation, estimated to be 100 yards long and 40 yards wide, and already they have discovered baked clay figurines in the shapes of humans and dogs. The temple, believed to honor the goddess Gula, may shed light on Babylonian politics, economics, medicine and social structure, said McGuire Gibson, archaeology professor at the University of Chicago's Oriental Institute. ``We really still don't understand a lot about Mesopotamian culture,'' he said Wednesday. Mesopotamia, the area between the Tigris and Euphrates rivers in what is now Iraq and Syria, was the site of several ancient civilizations beginning some 8,000 years ago. Much of what is known about those times comes from clay tablets, the equivalent of modern-day letters. Remnants of other temples in Nippur and elsewhere have been examined piecemeal and have often been disturbed by diggers who have removed important artifacts, archaeologists say. Findings from the dig could supplement information from clay tablets and show ``not what people say they did, but what they actually did,'' said Harvey Weiss, an archaeology professor at Yale University who was not involved in the dig. Gibson and his colleagues hope to find new insights into Babylonian medicine. ``One figurine shows a man clutching his throat; another shows a man holding his stomach,'' he said. ``They're obviously showing Gula where it hurts.'' The dog figurines may have been left to honor the goddess, since dogs were associated with Gula, Gibson said. There was a highly developed system of health care during the period in which the temple existed. Doctors prescribed herbs. When the herbs didn't work, magicians performed exorcisms or other spiritual intercession, but that information is based largely on information from clay tablets, said William Biggs, a University of Chicago professor who studies such tablets. The best possible discovery would be an archive of medical texts, which might have been stored in the temple, Biggs said. ``That would be tremendously important because most of the medical texts we have are from 800 years later,'' he said. Gibson said he first found a corner of the temple in 1973, but shifting sands prevented excavation. Digging is at a lull during the hot summer months, but Gibson said he will return to the site in January. Archaeologists from the Oriental Institute have been digging in Nippur for 40 years under an agreement with Iraq, Gibson said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down, Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The Japanese yen weakened against almost all major currencies in Tokyo today, as stocks erased early gains and ended the day almost unchanged. The dollar closed at 154.60 yen, up 0.62 yen from Wednesday's 153.98-yen finish. It opened at 154.28 yen and ranged between 154.25 yen and 154.63 yen. ``Only the yen was weaker,'' said Toru Kanai, a foreign exchange analyst with New Japan Securities Co. He said market players bought European currencies, especially the West German mark and British pound, as well as the dollar, against the yen for technical adjustments. ``There has been no specific reason to buy the yen recently, and that is why the currency's getting weaker,'' Kanai said. About $10 billion changed hands in spot trading, up from Wednesday's $6.9 billion. On the Tokyo Stock Exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average fell 0.49 points, or 0.0015 percent, ending the day at 32,087.27. The index, which gained more than 100 points at one point in early trading, ended the morning session up 38.89 points before falling back in the afternoon. Traders attributed the index's slide to the weaker yen and government bond prices, which discouraged participants and made trading directionless. Despite some arbitrage buying _ to take profits from price gaps between the spot and futures markets _ toward the end of the afternoon session, the index failed to strengthen because ``the majority of market players stepped off to the sidelines,'' said Kozo Hasunuma, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co. Volume on the market's first section was estimated at 400 million shares, unchanged from Wednesday. In bond dealings, benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds closed at 87.14 points, down from Wednesday's close of 87.42. Their yield was 7.155 percent, up from the previous day's 7.095 percent.

DOC.HEAD: 80 Arrested in Demonstrations at AIDS Conference
With PM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: AIDS activists jumped over police barricades and blocked traffic in demonstrations that led to about 80 arrests on the opening day of the Sixth International Conference on AIDS. The demonstrators Wednesday were demanding greater efforts to fight AIDS and wider access to experimental drugs. ``If you were going to die, if your death sentence was two to three years, wouldn't you be fighting and saying, `Get off your butt and help me stay alive?''' Victor Phillips of Billings, Mont., shouted through the screen mesh of a police bus. Most of those arrested were charged with interfering with police officers, a misdemeanor, authorities said. The conference drew an estimated 12,000 researchers, doctors, social workers and other AIDS professionals, along with 1,800 reporters and thousands of activists. AIDS activists have converged on San Francisco for the conference and the city's annual Gay Pride march this weekend. Paul Feldman of the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP, estimated the number of activists at a couple thousand. Feldman said most of the 40 ACT UP U.S. chapters were represented Wednesday, along with members from 25 foreign chapters. A conference sponsored by the pharmaceutical company Hoffman LaRoche was disrupted when G'dali Braverman, a member of New York ACT UP, climbed onto the stage to decry the lack of access to the experimental drug DDC. Some members of the audience yelled ``Get out! Get out!'' Others shouted, ``Let him speak!'' The panel, led by Dr. Jerome Groopman of Boston's New England Deaconess Hospital, walked out. The conference resumed with the speakers addressing the audience from another room over a video system in the auditorium. The audience of doctors and researchers had mixed feelings. ``How are you suppose to respond?'' asked David Russell, a Boston doctor who treats AIDS patients. ``I see their point, but we're here to try to learn so we can help.'' Later, several hundred demonstrators marched to barriers surrounding the Moscone Center, carrying signs reading, ``Their System, Their Profits, Our Lives.'' ``We're here. We're queer. And we demand access,'' they chanted. After hearing speakers from New York, Los Angeles, Mexico and Chicago, members of the crowd began rattling the barricades and jumped over. Police in riot gear used nightsticks to rap the fingers of those shaking the barricades. There were several bloody knuckles but no other injuries.

DOC.HEAD: Delivery Boys and Wall Streeters. Mandela Charms Them All
With PM-Mandela, Bjt
LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: Delivery boys and Wall Streeters. Mothers and grandmothers. Blacks and whites. They mixed and cheered together during Nelson Mandela's historic visit to their city. The South African freedom fighter who spent 27 years behind bars in his struggle against apartheid stepped off a plane Wednesday and into a hero's welcome. Ticker tape cascaded onto his bulletproof ``Mandelamobile'' during a parade up Broadway. Students at a Brooklyn high school shouted ``Man-del-a! Man-del-a!.'' He got the key to the city. Mandela made people laugh and made them weep. He smiled and waved and enchanted the politicians along with the throngs. ``Nelson! I named my son after you,'' shouted a tearful Uhuru Williams of Rochester, accompanied by the 3-year-old boy at City Hall. The 71-year-old Mandela smiled at her from the stage. ``There are few really great heroes left,'' said Martin McDonnough, of suburban New York City. ``This is not a Nixon or a Bush but someone who was in jail 28 years of his life and suffered and stood up for his beliefs.'' ``Just look around, it's white-black-white-black-white-black,'' businessman Tom Kellerhals said of the parade crowd. ``Sometimes the answer is in front of us.'' In Brooklyn, students at Boys and Girls High School shouted as Mandela arrived in a motorcade after landing at Kennedy Airport. At the parade, the emotional peak of Mandela's first day in the United States, Derrick Fuller shouted, ``The greatest freedom fighter ever!'' as Mandela and his wife, Winnie, passed by in the flatbed truck outfitted with a glass bubble. Riding with the Mandelas were Gov. Mario Cuomo and Mayor David Dinkins. Fathers hoisted sons on their shoulders and women thrust forward uncomprehending babies as if they were cameras. Leslie Anderson of Plainfield, N.J., took the day off to see the man she called a legend. ``I was too young to see Martin Luther King and Malcolm X. He's the last of the great black heroes,'' she said. ``We don't live in apartheid. But it's here. It's real,'' she added. ``New York is a prime example. Think of Bensonhurst,'' where a black teen-ager was murdered by a white mob last year. Standing a few feet away was Fred Marks, a white businessman who also had come out to see Mandela. ``I think any man who spent 27 years in jail deserves a look,'' he said. A father and son guitar duo sat under a tree nearby, playing the blues. ``Me and my father wrote a little something about Mandela and Dinkins meeting, about the Mandelas in New York,'' said Ted Williams Jr. ``It's happy. It's nice. You can do the chicken dance to it.'' Many who skipped work to see Mandela declined to be interviewed for the record, but one man agreed to appear on television. Asked what he would tell his boss if he was spotted, he said: ``I'm gonna say two words: Nelson Mandela.'' Sean Smith, a foreign currency options broker, saw irony in the parade's location. ``This is the biggest laughable thing that ever happened,'' he said, ``that Wall Street supported apartheid and turned around and threw a ticker-tape parade.'' Not everyone was impressed with the visit. Wayne Moore squatted as he shined the shoes of a well-dressed man at a Broadway corner. ``Shine 'em up!'' he yelled as he buffed. ``Shine em up!'' ``I heard Mandela was coming down today, so there'd be a big crowd and I'd make more money,'' Moore said. ``Do I think he could change my situation? Kind of hard to think that.''

DOC.HEAD: PLO Calls U.S. Cut in Dialogue A Blow to Peace Process
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with comment today by PLO official. Pickup 10th graf `Hilal said...'
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-Bush Rdp, Bjt ^By MONA ZIADE
DOC.TEXT: A senior PLO official said today that the U.S. suspension of its dialogue with the group struck a blow to peace efforts and will encourage Israel to come down harder on the Palestinian uprising. Suleiman Najab, a member of the PLO's ruling Executive Committee, described the move by President Bush on Wednesday as a ``flagrant defiance of the Palestinians, Arabs and world peace.'' In Jerusalem, an aide to right-wing Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Wednesday that the U.S. decision ``removed a major obstacle'' to peace. Bush said he suspended the 18-month-old dialogue because the Palestine Liberation Organization failed to forcefully condemn an unsuccessful May 30 terrorist attack against Israel. The dialogue began after PLO chairman Yasser Arafat renounced terrorism and accepted Israel's right to exist. Bush had urged Arafat to disavow the assault and to discipline the PLO faction that sent two speedboats filled with fighters toward a Tel Aviv beach. The boats were intercepted by Israel and four guerrillas killed and 12 captured. Najab said in an interview in Baghdad, Iraq, that Bush's decision will ``encourage Israel to commit more crimes and massacres against our people in the occupied territories.'' The PLO official spoke this morning after a pre-dawn meeting of the 15-member Executive Committee. Najab and other committee members were in Baghdad for a meeting on recent developments in the Palestinian issue and to discuss the recent formation of the new right-wing Israeli Cabinet. In Tunis, Salah Khalaf, regarded as the PLO's second-in-command, was quoted Wednesday by the French news agency Agence France-Presse as saying Bush's move would ``freeze peace efforts and reinforce extremist forces'' in the Middle East. Jamil Hilal, who heads the PLO information department, said in a telephone interview from Tunis, where the PLO has its headquarters, that the suspension of the dialogue ``can be judged only as an unfriendly and colonial move. ... It's a blow to the peace process and a provocation to Arab states.'' Hilal said he expects the PLO, in retaliation for the suspension of talks, to call on Arab nations ``to apply economic sanctions against the United States. I expect the uprising in the occupied territories to escalate.'' Avi Pazner, a top aide to Shamir, praised Bush's decision to end the dialogue. It's ``an important and positive decision as far as the peace process in the area is concerned,'' he said in Jerusalem. ``The PLO was a major obstacle to peace and now that obstacle is removed.'' In the occupied West Bank, Jamil Tarifi, a pro-PLO Palestinian leader who has been named as a possible peace negotiator, condemned the U.S. move. ``Anyone who wants to talk to the Palestinians must talk with the PLO,'' he added.

DOC.HEAD: Community Mourns Together, Prepares to Recover Together
DOC.TEXT: After six days of cleaning up from flash floods, about 900 residents gathered beneath menacing skies to mourn 22 people killed in the flooding, which also left 11 people missing. Townspeople sang hymns, said prayers and held each other close Wednesday during a 45-minute memorial service at their high school football field. Children cried aloud; adults wept quietly. ``Friends and neighbors, please don't hush your babies. Let them cry, let them sing, let them play,'' Gov. Richard Celeste said. ``In these sometimes beautiful, sometimes hard hills along the Ohio River that we call home, be sure there is a special place in heaven for those family members we remember tonight,'' the governor said. ``But let us build a special place for those here who survive with pain. I love you. God bless you.'' Twenty-one uniformed members of the Shadyside Volunteer Fire Department, who have been searching for victims and clearing wreckage, received a standing ovation as they walked onto the field single file. The Army Corps of Engineers today was to begin removing about 15 acres of flood debris from the Hannibal locks and dam, about 25 miles downstream from Shadyside. The list of missing had dwindled to 11 _ four local residents who coroner's investigator Chuck Vogt said were likely dead and seven out-of-towners who would be harder to account for. ``It hurts us all. You got to remember, we're a family here,'' Vogt said. ``We may not be a close one sometimes, but we are a family. And we'll help each other and recover from this. In a few weeks, all these government agencies will be gone and we'll be on our own again.'' In the stands, relatives of the dead sobbed as the Rev. Charles Brewer of First Presbyterian Church read a roster of those killed and missing. Two roses rested on the pulpit _ a red one for adults, a yellow one for children. Janet Polivka, whose 13-year-old daughter, Kerri, died in the flood, held a woman seated beside her and wept bitterly as the crowd sang ``Amazing Grace.'' Vogt, a lifelong Shadyside resident who has worked 16- to 20-hour days since the night of the flood to help recover and identify bodies, stood alone behind reporters. He crouched at the edge of the field and fought back tears. One hour before the service, Vogt identified the 22nd flood victim as Stephen Gatten, 9, who had lived along Wegee Creek. His body was found Wednesday in the Ohio River two miles downstream from the creek. Stephen's brother also was killed in the flood, and their mother was among the missing.

DOC.HEAD: Girl Who Rode Out Flash Flood Pays Respects to Baby Sitter
With PM-Flash Flood
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old who rode a wall of water that destroyed her home and clung to debris in the Ohio River for seven hours said she had one last thing to say to her baby sitter, who died. ``I'll just tell her `I love you,''' Amber Colvin said Wednesday night before she and her mother visited a funeral home in nearby Shadyside to pay respects to the family of 13-year-old Kerri Polivka. Kerri and Amber were alone at the Colvin home along Wegee Creek, just south of Shadyside, when a flash flood wiped out most of their neighborhood. At least 22 people were killed after 5{ inches of rain fell in about 3 hours June 14 onto the hilly coal fields whose runoff feeds into Wegee and Pipe creeks. ``Water started coming into the house, the walls started to break and things started to float,'' Amber said. ``We saw water all over the house. Kerri was screaming and running around, and I told her to keep calm, but she said, `I can't, I can't. I'm going to die.''' The girls climbed into a bathtub in hopes of using it as a boat, but it broke in two as the swift water tore the house apart, Amber said. She said Kerri hit her head on the tub and sank. She twice tried to grab Kerri by the hair and pull her out of the water, but went under herself each time. She said she could feel the house being washed down the creek before it broke apart. She floated away from it and grabbed onto a log and some wooden shingles. She paddled to shore before dawn Friday, about six miles downstream from where her home had been. ``I'm supposed to start swimming lessons next week. I can doggie paddle a little, but I only had to do that once,'' she said. Her father, Dennis Colvin, 47, said he did not believe he would see Amber alive. ``I'd gone down there after the water went down enough and there was just a hole where the house was,'' he said. ``I'd resigned myself to it. I didn't lose hope, but I kept looking at it with reality.''

DOC.HEAD: 44 Arrests as Hundreds Demonstrate at Lumber Plant
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Forty-four ``Redwood Summer'' demonstrators were arrested at a lumber mill in a protest against logging practices they say endanger California's old forests. About 350 took part in the protest at Louisiana Pacific on Wednesday, the first day of a summer-long series of demonstrations by environmentalists who have come to California from around the country. The demonstrations are modeled on the Freedom Summer of 1964, during which civil rights activists converged on Mississippi. Many of those arrested Wednesday marched onto company property and approached officers so they could be taken into custody. Deputy Sheriff Leona Mendenhall said most were issued citations for trespassing and released. The rally was organized by Earth First!, which is known for tactics such as standing between loggers and trees. The group renounced its practice of driving spikes into trees to make them useless as lumber after sawmill workers were injured by broken saws. Mainstream environmental groups, including the Sierra Club, have refused to take part in Redwood Summer and have disavowed the tactics of Earth First! Redwood Summer organizers are demanding an end to what they say is excessive clear-cut logging, and cutting of virgin redwood trees. The demonstration was largely peaceful, with only sporadic name-calling from passing motorists and between protesters and lumber mill employees. ``We've got to save what's left of the forests,'' said David Solnit, 26, a carpenter from San Francisco. ``They (Louisiana Pacific) are acting like outlaws and we need to take direct action.'' Duane Plant, a lumber worker who carried a sign denouncing ``environmental terrorists,'' said that the Louisiana Pacific had engaged in proper cutting techniques and that the protesters didn't understand how the industry works. Samoa is about 275 miles north of San Francisco. In Sierra County, about 250 miles southeast of Samoa in the Sierra Nevada, Sheriff Lee Adams said two Sacramento men were arrested after reports of shooting near a logging site near Downieville. No one was hit. Adams said investigators were trying to determine if the shots were an attempt to halt the logging. He said the two men were apparently not involved with any anti-logging organization.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Apartheid is doomed. South Africa shall be free. The struggle continues.'' _ Nelson Mandela, after he arrived in New York to a hero's ticker-tape parade up Broadway.

``The anger and frustration that surrounds this conference and pushes into it comes from seeing loved ones die. I know, because I have gone through the same experiences, and I am doing so now with people I love.'' _ San Francisco Mayor Art Agnos welcoming the Sixth International Conference on AIDS to his city.

``We really could not let our pursuit of peace stand in the way of our commitment to fight terrorism.'' _ Secretary of State James A. Baker III, on the U.S. decision to suspend talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization until Yasser Arafat denounces a recent foiled PLO attack on an Israeli beach.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms in Midwest, Heat in Southeast
DOC.TEXT: Cloudy skies early today signaled more thunderstorms in the central Plains and parts of the Midwest. The Southeast had more sweltering heat in store after record-breaking highs Wednesday in parts of Florida and Georgia. Temperatures were expected to remain high in those states and in Arkansas. Rain and thunderstorms continued Wednesday night in Louisiana, Georgia, Florida, Arkansas, Missouri, Kentucky, Tennessee, Illinois, Wisconsin, Michigan, Virginia, Maryland, Pennsylvania, New York state, New England, North Dakota, South Dakota, Minnesota, Nebraska, Wyoming and Montana. A tornado touched down Wednesday near Margate, Fla., but there were no reports of injuries or damage, the National Weather Service said. Heavy thunderstorms were expected today in the central Plains and parts of the Midwest. Kansas storms Tuesday night had some Witchita residents doing without power late Wednesday. Statewide, at least 30 people were injured. The heat in Georgia forced a ban on watering in Atlanta, where authorities cut water service to 1,000 or more homes for several hours Wednesday to avert a crisis at hospitals. The high Wednesday in the Lower 48 states was 116 degrees in the California cities of Thermal and Palm Springs. DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Slightly, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose slightly in steady trading today, although traders said they did not expect it to break out of its narrow range. Gold rose slightly. ``The dollar has gathered some strength from (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev's threats to resign and by the likelihood that U.S. interest rates will remain steady for a while,'' one dealer in Milan said. Some traders said much of Wednesday's euphoria connected with the prospects of the British pound's introduction this year into the European exchange rate mechanism has faded. The pound had benefited for several days from the speculation. ``People are taking a more realistic view of the timetable, which isn't likely to be before the end of this year,'' a trader in Milan said. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.62 yen to a closing 154.60 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 154.87 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.6823 West German marks, up from 1.6785 _1.4163 Swiss francs, up from 1.4155 _5.6500 French francs, up from 5.6405 _1.8875 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8878 _1,233.25 Italian lire, up from 1,231.00 _1.1728 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1723 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.7221, compared with $1.7225 late Wednesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $350.10 an ounce this morning, up from 349.15 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $350.20, up from $347.25 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.80 to close at a bid $351.65. Silver rose in London to a bid price of $4.85 an ounce, from Wednesday's $4.82.

DOC.HEAD: Baker in Berlin Holding Talks with Germans Before Unification Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III headed for back-to-back talks today with the foreign ministers of the two Germanys to go over military and legal questions raised by impending unification. On Baker's agenda was a proposal by West Germany and France to provide economic aid to the Soviet economy. The help is designed to assist Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in his perestroika program, with the hope the Kremlin leader would drop his objections to NATO membership for a united Germany. But a senior U.S. official said the Bush administration had not decided whether to support the proposal, whose details were not immediately available. He said there was ``a distinct possibility'' that the United States would not take part. The West German government several months ago took the lead in offering to help Gorbachev cope with his economic woes. The Bonn-based newspaper Die Welt reported today that West Germany plans to give Moscow more than $3 billion in credit to support development of an open market. Baker's separate meetings with foreign ministers Markus Meckel of East Germany and Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany were to deal with the NATO issue and also procedures for the Big Four Allies of World II _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ to relinquish their control of Berlin. Baker, who arrived in Berlin on this morning, also will meet separately with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze on Friday. He is in Berlin for two days of ``two-plus-four'' talks that bring together the four victors of World War II and the two Germanys, who are set to merge their economies July 2 and may hold all-German elections in December. French President Francois Mitterrand said Tuesday he would ask the United States and five other major industrial democracies to consider extending financial and technical aid to the Soviets at an economic summit in Houston next month. Baker, officials said, also was weighing other assurances to allay Moscow's concerns over a united Germany's membership in NATO. Officials said those assurances included issuance of declarations by NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact designed to reflect the lowering of East-West tensions and the prospective withdrawal of tens of thousands of U.S. and Soviet troops from Europe. Gorbachev's economic problems are apt to be compounded when East Germany is absorbed by West Germany. There are an estimated 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany. Some would stay for a transitional period under a U.S. proposal Baker took up with Shevardnadze in Copenhagen. But the Soviets would be limited to no more than 195,000 soldiers in all of Central Europe, including what is now East Germany, under a treaty being negotiated in Vienna by NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The return of the troops would strain the Soviet budget both in terms of housing them and finding jobs for those mustered out of the service as part of a cutback of 500,000 men promised by Gorbachev in December 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Government Trying To Overturn Decision To Put VOA Station On Hold
DOC.TEXT: Cabinet ministers hope to reverse a decision delaying construction of a Voice of America radio relay station for a two-year study of bird migration, communications officials said today. The National Planning Board voted Tuesday to commission the study of bird migration patterns before making a final decision on the $300 million project. The relay station, designed to transmit VOA broadcasts to Eastern Europe and Africa, would be located in the Arava desert area on the southeastern tip of Israel. Twice a year, large numbers of birds fly over the Arava in their trips back and forth between Africa and the northern hemisphere. Israeli environmentalists opposing the VOA transmitter say it would disturb the migrating birds. The United States and Israel signed an agreement in 1987 to build the transmitter for the U.S. government-run Voice of America. The project is expected to create hundreds of jobs and give an economic boost to the sparsely populated Arava area. U.S. officials expressed disappointed by the decision to delay construction. ``The issue of possible damage to migrating birds from short-wave transmitters has been well-studied,'' a U.S. Embassy statement said. ``The reasons for implementing the agreement signed by our two nations in 1987 remain valid,'' it said. ``Events in Eastern Europe and elsehwere have underscored the major role international radio can play in fostering democracy.'' Communications Ministry spokeswoman Naama Henig said her ministry, the Foreign Ministry and Cabinet Secretary Eliyakim Rubinstein are working out a strategy to overturn the National Planning Board decision, which passed by a vote of 8-6 with one abstention. She said one possibility was to call for a new vote on the subject, noting that only 15 members of the 31-member panel were present for Tuesday's vote. But she said the initiative must come from a National Planning Board member, and that no request for a new vote had been made. The board, which includes representatives of 11 government ministries, must approve all major national construction projects.

DOC.HEAD: Tigers Ready All-Out Attack On Jaffna Fort; Army Firms Grip On East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with 1,400 dead, gov't rushing reinforcements to north, adds details thruout. EDITS to trim. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels launched heavy attacks on northern military installations today and the government rushed in reinforcements for what could be a decisive battle in Sri Lanka's civil war. More than 1,400 combatants have been killed since the separatist conflict in the country's north and east exploded into full-scale war again 10 days ago, the government said. No figures were given for civilian casualties, also believed to be high. Additional soldiers were sent by air and sea to the northern city of Jaffna to bolster defenses at two naval bases, a military airfield and an army garrison, said Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne. He refused to give figures. Tamil Tiger rebels today attacked the bases, airfield and garrison with rocket-propelled grenades, automatic weapons and suicide squads of guerrillas carrying explosives, Tamil sources said on condition of anonymity. The sources said the militants were mustering men and weapons for an all-out onslaught on Jaffna Fort, where the largest military garrison in the region is located. Jaffna, a rebel stronghold, is on the northern tip of this island nation and 200 miles north of the capital Colombo. The government claimed to have recaptured all major towns in the east this week. ``Right now we have liberated the entire eastern province which includes the districts of Ampara, Batticaloa and Trincomalee,'' minister Wijeratne told reporters in Colombo. He said that despite the fighting, the government is determined to go ahead with political moves to grant greater political and administrative autonomy to the Tamil minority in the north and east. ``We regard the fighting as a minor aberration. The political process will go on,'' Wijeratne said. The government appealed to foreign governments for urgent medical assistance. Government forces, under orders to crush the rebels ``wherever they exist,'' were using helicopter gunships and bombing runs by ground support planes to defend the northern bases, military officials said. The 200-year-old Dutch fort in Jaffna has been under severe pressure from the dominant Tamil Tiger rebels since fighting broke out between the rebels and government troops on June 11. The Defense Ministry says several attacks on the fort have been repulsed. About 150 troops and police defend the 55-acre stronghold. The latest round of fighting broke out June 11 after a Tamil resident in the eastern town of Batticaloa complained he had been manhandled by Sinhalese police. Tamil tigers then overran a police station and combat escalated from there. Sri Lanka's Tamils make up 18 percent of the country's 16 million people. The Sinhalese make up 75 percent of the population. Military officials, including Defense Secretary Gen. Cyril Ranatunge, said that since June 11, 800 rebels, 278 policemen and 219 troops have been killed. They did not say where or when the deaths occurred. In addition, at least 500 policemen who surrendered to the rebels are missing. Officials say civilian casualty figures are unknown but also high since the military relied on air attacks to neutralize rebel positions in populated cities in the north and east. Rebel statements issued by their London office claim that more than 100,000 Tamils and Moslems have fled their homes in the region this month. The Tamil rebels are fighting for autonomy in the northern and eastern portion of the Indian Ocean island nation. The mainly Hindu Tamils say they are discriminated against by the Buddhist Sinhalese majority. The rebels had taken control of most major towns of the region after Indian troops trying to enforce a peace agreement withdrew in March. The pullout, made at the request of President Ranasinghe Premadasa, followed the Indians' unsuccessful 32-month attempt to disarm the Tamil Tigers. At least 11,000 people have been killed since Tamil militants began fighting for an independent nation in 1983. In 1987, India brokered a peace accord between the two sides and sent a force to disarm the rebels. Fighting ensued and the Indian troops were withdrawn in March of this year.

DOC.HEAD: Judges Postpone Trials, Hold Protests To Demand Reforms
DOC.TEXT: French judges, barred by law from striking, postponed trials and staged protests across France today in an unprecedented walkout organized to demand more autonomy and better working conditions. The ``day of national action'' marked the first coordinated protest by French judges on behalf of their profession. A majority of the 6,000 judges participated, and only urgent criminal cases were heard in several cities. The judges say the judiciary has been degraded by inadequate facilities, budget restrictions and an excessive workload. The three unions of judges, usually divided by political differences, all supported the one-day protest. One of them, the left-wing Syndicat de la Magistrature, called on members to strike in defiance of a 1958 statute, while the moderate and rightist unions advised members to find some legal way of expressing discontent. In Paris and other major cities, judges abandoned their chambers to attend union rallies. ``Justice for the courts of justice,'' read a banner at a protest attended by robed judges in Strasbourg. Union leaders contend that the workload for judges has increased steadily even though France now has fewer judges for its 56 million people than in 1914, when the population of 39 million was served by 6,600 judges. The unions also have demanded statutory reforms to lessen executive branch control over the judiciary. Also, they have complained about a government-backed amnesty law which requires judges to drop charges against various politicians involved in alleged fundraising scandals. The protests took place despite an appeal Wednesday from Justice Minister Pierre Arpaillange, who asked that court operations not be disrupted. He promised that the government would adopt a major courthouse construction and renovation program to start by next year. Michael Joubrel, president of the moderate Union Syndicale des Magistrates, said the protest was not aimed at the Justice Ministry. ``It's not the courts that will be held hostage, but the Ministry of Finance, which possesses the means of improving justice,'' he said. Although the protesting judges contend that the government should allocate more on the court system _ it now gives 1.36 percent of the national budget _ they are not specifically demanding a pay raise. Most judges currently earn the equivalent of between $30,000 and $60,000 annually. The only previous coordinated protests by judges, according to French newspapers, were organized to denounce disciplinary actions taken against colleagues.

DOC.HEAD: Contest Winner's Luxury Car Too `Ritzy' for His Hometown
DOC.TEXT: A man who won a year's use of a $30,000 Lincoln Town Car said thanks but no thanks _ the luxury sedan may suit urban commuters but doesn't fit the rugged lifestyle in his remote hometown. ``This is battered, rusty pickup truck country,'' said Bruce Cain, 33, an accountant in the town of about 500 residents 190 miles northeast of Anchorage. ``Between frost swells and holes in the road and temperatures that can reach minus 50 in the winter, a Town Car would be a bit impractical _ and eccentric,'' he said ``It's too ritzy for Glennallen,'' said his wife, Shirley. Use of the car was a prize in an Alaska Airlines promotional game. ``It just doesn't fit the lifestyle,'' Cain said. ``What would that car look like after an entire year up here? I drive $500 pickups.'' Budget Rent A Car Corp., which would have provided the car, instead sent Cain a check. The amount was not disclosed. ``Everything worked out nicely,'' said Budget spokeswoman Ellie Bennett. ``Bruce didn't want the car and we weren't too optimistic about its long-term health.''

DOC.HEAD: Weather Blamed for Delay in Burma Poll Results
DOC.TEXT: Final results of last month's election in Burma will be delayed because bad weather has hampered access to remote areas, Burmese state radio said. Official results through Wednesday show the opposition National League for Democracy taking 396 of the 485 seats in the National Assembly. The May 27 poll was the first multiparty election in three decades. Some Western diplomats in Rangoon have said the military government may be intentionally delaying the final results because of a reluctance to hand over power. The government said before the election that it would take up to three weeks for the final results. Rangoon Radio on Wednesday broadcast a statement issued by the Elections Commission saying it was awaiting results from five remote constituencies in the far northern states of Sagaing and Kachin. A transcript of the broadcast was seen in Bangkok today. ``Although efforts have been made to obtain reports about the elections from those townships with the help of military helicopters, weather conditions have so far prevented the trips,'' the commission's statement said. It said messengers had been sent by land, ``but there have been delays because of mudslides on mountain roads and because some bridges have been washed away.'' ``As soon as they are obtained, the commission will resume announcing the names of the candidates elected,'' it said. The statement did not say how long that would take. Foreign diplomats said the polling appeared to have been conducted fairly but was preceded by the detention of thousands of dissidents. Many Burmese distrust the military government. Soldiers killed thousands of people demanding democracy in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Skepticism Greets Claim of 10-Million-Year-Old Human Ancestor
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `The analysis...', to drop extraneous word.
DOC.TEXT: Scientists today said an apelike creature that lived 10 million years ago may be the earliest known direct ancestor of humans. The claim met sharp skepticism from experts who said they were unconvinced by the researchers' anatomical analysis of a remnant of the creature's skull. ``I don't believe for a minute'' that the beast is a direct human ancestor, Peter Andrews of the Natural History Museum in London said Wednesday in a telephone interview. The analysis also implies that ancestors of humans may have started evolving away from ancestors of chimps and gorillas millions of years earlier than many scientists believe. It is presented in the British journal Nature by L. de Bonis of the University of Poitiers in France, G. Bouvrain and D. Geraads of the University of Paris, and G. Koufos of the University of Thessaloniki in Greece. The fossil, found last September in Greece, is thought to be 9 million to 10 million years old. It represents a previously known animal called Ouranopithecus macedoniensis. The fossil includes the right part and a portion of the left part of an adult's face, plus the upper jaw with most of the teeth, the researchers said. They said the fossil's anatomy suggests that Ouranopithecus macedoniensis appeared on the human branch of the evolutionary tree after that lineage split from the ancestors of gibbons, orangutans, gorillas and chimpanzees. That would make it a direct ancestor of humans. The researchers also suggested that the human lineage may have started evolving away from the ancestors of chimps and gorillas as long as 12 million years ago. Other scientists have put that split at 5 million to 7 million years ago, said Lawrence Martin, assistant professor in antholopology at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. Martin, who has studied other fossils from Ouranopithecus macedoniensis, said he is ``absolutely sure'' the new study is wrong in assigning the beast to the human lineage. Martin said he puts the beast further back in evolution, before the human lineage started evolving away from ancestors of chimpanzees and gorillas.

DOC.HEAD: All-Night Republican Speechmaking in the House
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 11th graf, `The chief... to fix spelling of `hordes' on second reference
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans kept the House in session all through the night, ``just like a telethon,'' to talk about drugs and tough punishment for users and other proposals for combatting crime in America. The speeches began at 7:15 p.m. Wednesday and continued until after 8 a.m. as member after member took the lectern to address a nearly-empty House chamber. But television cameras broadcast the session to a nationwide audience over C-Span, the congressional cable channel. One participant, Rep. Robert Livingston of Louisiana, described the all-night session as being ``just like a telethon.'' Indeed, some of the members propped before them a poster with the hand-lettered words ``Crime Watch'' and a telephone number for Americans to call as the night wore on to report crimes in their cities. ``That number again is 202-224-3121,'' was heard more than once as members urged watchers to call. Before it started, Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., called the session ``total nonsense'' and a ``politically motivated activity'' because ``we are going to pass a major crime bill this year.'' There was no indication how many people called, or how many were watching the all-night show, which began after the House had concluded the day's regular legislative business. Shortly after 2 a.m., Rep. Jack Fields of Texas was agreeing with several earlier speakers that more jail cells for drug users was the answer and said they should be uncomfortable places that are ``hot in summer and cold in winter.'' He said mosquito-infested regions of Texas and Louisiana would be good places for prisons _ and that inmates should not be given insect repellent. He also said it might be a good idea for them to be housed in tents _ tents with holes in them. Rep. Jim McCrery of Louisiana said cocaine is sometimes smuggled across the Mexican border concealed in red cans purported to contain tomatoes. ``The chief threat to our security in the 1990s may well come from hordes of red tomato cans rather than hordes of red communists,'' he said. Rep. Susan Molinari of New York criticized Gov. Mario Cuomo for opposing the death penalty. At 6 a.m. _ sounding like a telethon host _ she announced, ``We now shift coasts'' and turned the program over to Rep. Dana Rohrabacher of California. The No. 2 House Republican, Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia went live on NBC's ``Today'' at 7:09 for a network finale. ``I'm glad the speaker made the commitment ... that he is willing to bring up the bill,'' Gingrich said on ``Today.'' ``So maybe we have made some progress during the night but we are determined if necessary to do this again in July or August to continue to make the point that the Democratic leadership, after a year of holding up the president's crime and drug package, owes it to the American people to bring it to the floor of the House,'' Gingrich said. In an apparent preemptive response to the Republicans' talkathon, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jack Brooks, D-Texas, announced in advance that comprehensive anti-crime legislation will be considered next week by the panel's subcommittee on crime. The crime bill would expand use of the death penalty for federal crimes including presidential assassination, strengthen controls over chemicals needed to manufacture certain drugs and toughen criminal sanctions on those distributing anabolic steroids.

DOC.HEAD: Cutting Off Debate With PLO May Encourage More Violence
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 3rd graf from end, bgng, Besides advancing ... to restore full first references to Pelletreau and Balaoui
DOC.TEXT: In punishing the Palestine Liberation Organization for violence, the United States may have opened the door to even more violence. Even President Bush recognized that irony when he announced his decision to suspend the 18-month U.S. dialogue with the PLO. Bush said Wednesday the United States must respond to the PLO's violation of its pledge to renounce terrorism _ the magic words that led the Reagan administration in its waning days to lift a 13-year ban on direct talks with the PLO. And Bush promised that as soon as the PLO condemns the thwarted May 30 attack by PLO guerrillas on Israel's coast, the United States will resume the talks. Nonetheless, analysts agree the suspension of the talks has badly damaged the tentative results of the low-level dialogue conducted in virtual secrecy in Tunis, where the PLO has its headquarters. ``This will make the radicals and all those who oppose peace, strong,'' said Faisal Husseini, one of the leading Palestinian nationalists in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Assistant Secretary of State John Kelly told a House panel Wednesday that cutting off dialogue with the PLO will harm the Middle East peace process, adding, ``It may herald a period of time in which there is more violence and more terrorism.'' Bush, asked whether he was worried about playing into the hands of PLO hardliners, said, ``Yes, I am concerned about that.'' And Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who recommended the suspension, acknowledged it would hurt moderate Arabs. The president said he recognized the frustration among Palestinians at the slow pace of the dialogue, but he cited achievements. ``On balance, we believe that these exchanges contributed to progress in the peace process,'' he said in announcing his decision. ``I think things are better because we've had the dialogue.'' Analysts say the dialogue proved to Americans that the PLO was the only representative of the Palestinian people and therefore vital to the success of Arab-Israeli peace talks. U.S. influence also got the PLO to accept negotiations with its archenemy, Israel. ``We were just starting to drive the demons out of each others' eyes,'' said Richard Murphy, the leading Mideast official in the Reagan administration. For Palestinians, long shunned in the West as terrorists bent on the destruction of Israel, the dialogue provided a modicum of legitimacy. And it showed Palestinians that U.S. foreign policy was not warped by its support for the Jewish state, Murphy said in an interview. U.S. officials said last summer they were closer to arranging talks between Israel and the Palestinians than ever before. The plan advanced by Baker would have brought together Israeli officials and Palestinians whose participation was approved by the PLO. The talks, to be held in Cairo, would have set up elections among the 1.7 million Palestinians under Israeli occupation. For the mainstream of the PLO, which includes some factions radically opposed to the dialogue with Israel, the acceptance of talks with Israel was a major concession. ``We lose sight of the fact that Arafat did something we predicted no Palestinian would do,'' Bush said. But Israel balked at accepting some of the proposed Palestinian negotiators because of their anti-Israel activity. The United States appealed for help last summer from Egypt _ the only Arab country which has made peace with Israel. Besides advancing the peace process, the other U.S. objective in the dialogue was to bring about an end to PLO terrorism. U.S. Ambassador Robert Pelletreau often would bring up suspected terrorist incidents with a PLO official named Hakam Balaoui, and ask for explanations. The State Department cited results, reporting to Congress that while 30 border and rocket attacks were launched by Palestinian groups against Israel since December 1988, there was no evidence any were authorized by the PLO Executive Committee. But ultimately, the suspension of the dialogue was prompted by the very obstacle that prevented direct talks with the PLO since its inception in 1964 _ terrorism.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Ruth Sinai has covered the Middle East and foreign affairs in Washington for The Associated Press for seven years.

DOC.HEAD: Fireworks Safety Tips
With PM-Fireworks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version also ran for Thursday AMs.
