DOC.TEXT: Atlantis' five astronauts on Thursday successfully completed a test that simulated an engine start and cut off moments before liftoff, NASA said. The shuttle is scheduled for a secret military mission in mid-July. NASA spokeswoman Lisa Malone said the two-day drill went smoothly. The countdown clock was stopped at four seconds before the mock liftoff. On Monday, Atlantis was moved from the hangar to the launch pad previously occupied by Columbia. Columbia was returned to the hangar last week for repair of a hydrogen leak that has delayed the shuttle's astronomy mission until at least mid-August. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration plans to conduct a special tanking test on Wednesday, partly filling Atlantis' external tank with super-cold liquid hydrogen to make sure there are no leaks. A similar test was performed on Columbia a week after a hydrogen leak was detected during fueling for a May 30 launch. A launch date for Atlantis will be set at the conclusion of a two-day flight readiness review on June 28 and 29.

DOC.HEAD: Midway Docks After Shipboard Blasts Kill Two, Injures 16
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4 grafs for graf 8, `He said...' to UPDATE with identity of those killed. Pick up 9th graf pvs, `But he...'
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. aircraft carrier Midway docked at its home base today after two shipboard explosions killed two crew members and injured 16 others, nine seriously, officials said. ``Midway is safe and seaworthy in all respects,'' Rear Adm. Lyle Bull, commander of the Battle Force 7th Fleet, told about 100 reporters aboard the 67,000-ton ship a day after the blasts. ``The safety of the ship was never in jeopardy,'' Bull said shortly after the ship moored at the U.S. naval base in Yokosuka, 30 miles southwest of Tokyo. The commander stressed there was no danger to the ship's weapons area from the explosions in a 12-by-12-foot storeroom for firefighting and other emergency equipment on the fourth deck, about six decks below the flight deck. Aside from the nine seriously injured, who were flown to hospitals ashore, seven injured crewmen were treated on the ship, the Navy said. Bull said the casualties occurred when a firefighting crew investigated smoke coming from the storeroom shortly before noon Wednesday. The first explosion occurred when they opened the hatch and entered, he said. For two of the sailors, ``death most probably was instantaneous,'' Bull said. They had earlier been listed as missing. The Pentagon identified the two dead today as Ulric Patrick Johnson of Martinez, Calif., and Jeffrey Allan Vierra of Nevada City, Calif. Johnson, 20, was a mess management specialist and had been inducted into the service in December 1987. Vierra, also 20, was a fireman and had been inducted into the Navy in September 1988, the Pentagon said. The names of those injured were not released. Bull said the room was near a pipe for the ship's catapult system containing steam at 850 degrees Fahrenheit, and ``water sprayed on the bulkhead turned to steam, that's how hot it was.'' But he declined to speculate on the cause of the explosion or whether it was related to the steam pipe. He said the cause still was under investigation. While Bull acknowledged there was smoke before the explosion, he said there was no proof a fire occurred. Cmdr. Mark J. Stull, public affairs officer for U.S. Naval Forces Japan, had said earlier that a fire in the storeroom had been put out shortly after midnight Wednesday. Bull said the first explosion occurred at about 12:30 p.m. Wednesday, the second at 1:15 p.m: ``It was confined to a small area. There was no rocking of the Midway.'' He said the Midway, scheduled to remain at sea another two weeks, returned to port early ``to give the crew a rest and to replenish our fire-fighting equipment. We did not have to come in but there was no reason to stay out.'' Outside the base's gate, about 50 anti-nuclear demonstrators chanted ``Don't let the Midway land here,'' and ``Don't let in nuclear weapons.'' Eight wore sashes identifying them as victims of the U.S. atomic bombings of the Japanese cities of Hiroshima and Nagasaki in 1945. Earlier, about 20 Japanese demonstrators from three citizens groups and the Greenpeace environmental organization held signs protesting the U.S. military presence in Japan. About 12 protesters tried to enter the base but were blocked by Japanese police and U.S. Marines. After a few minutes of shoving and shouting, the police locked arms, pushed the demonstrators back and locked the metal gate. Critics contend U.S. ships have brought nuclear weapons into Japanese ports despite a Japanese ban against them. As a matter of policy, the United States refuses to comment on the location of its nuclear weapons. Japan is the only country that has experienced nuclear attacks, and many Japanese still have misgivings about the presence of 50,000 U.S. troops and armaments. City officials had demanded the Midway be barred from returning until its safety had been confirmed and cause of the incident clarified. The Midway fire was the second serious Navy accident since a series of incidents last fall that resulted in 14 deaths. The Midway, part of the 7th fleet, carries a crew of 4,500 and 62 aircraft and has two steam catapults, used to launch planes from the flight deck. The 1,000-foot carrier was commissioned in 1945 and is the Navys's oldest in active service, although it has been extensively modernized. The incident occurred as the Midway participated in a joint exercise 125 miles northeast of Yokosuka with the Japanese Maritime Self Defense Force. Stull said it was not known whether the exercise would continue. In the last major fire aboard a U.S. warship, a pre-dawn blaze broke out May 8 on the guided-missile destroyer USS Conyngham during routine operations in the Atlantic about 100 miles southeast of Norfolk, Va. One crewman was killed and 18 were injured in the fire, which broke out in the engine room, officials said. The cause is under investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Belgian Farmers Demonstrate, Surprise Prime Minister In Barber Shop
DOC.TEXT: Farmers angry about a price freeze on their products used tractors to block cities across southern Belgium on Thursday, and about 150 invaded a barber shop where the prime minister was getting a haircut. More than 1,000 farmers left their farms at sunrise in their tractors. By mid-morning, they had blocked main roads and access to at least a dozen cities. Most were prevented from reaching Brussels and European Community headquarters by police. However, 150 farmers on foot managed to slip through police controls and surprised Prime Minister Wilfried Martens in a barber shop about three blocks from his Brussels office. ``I am the son of a farmer and the eldest of five sons,'' Martens told them, according to the Belgian news agency Belga. ``I know your work. I lived and worked for a long time on a farm. I sympathize with you.'' He was cheered by the farmers who discussed their problems with him for a few minutes before leaving. The farmers complained to Martens that they have to pay more for what they buy but earn less from selling their produce because of an EC farm price freeze introduced to reduce the EC farm budget. By late morning, 400 tractors from southern Belgium were reported by Belga to be heading for Brussels. Police stopped 200 tractors in the Brussels' suburb of Waterloo but another 200 blocked traffic in Wavre, southeast of the capital. More than 100 invaded Namur and 90 blocked Brussels' main southeastern express motorway access. The center of Charleroi was blocked by 70 tractors while others caused traffic jams in Mons, Tournai, Ath, Huy , Marche and other places. In Bastogne, hundreds of farmers besieged the town hall, where the minister in charge of agriculture for the area was meeting with other local officials.

DOC.HEAD: Revamped ``Today'' Show Has Slight Ratings Increase
DOC.TEXT: NBC's revamped ``Today'' show had a slight ratings increase in its first week, but ABC's ``Good Morning America'' won the morning Nielsen race for the 24th straight week. Separately, ABC said that Joan Lunden, the permanent co-host on ``Good Morning America'' since 1980, has signed a five-year contract to continue on the show. Her salary was not disclosed. Lunden joined ``Good Morning America'' in 1976 as a reporter and temporary co-host. ``Good Morning America'' averaged a 4.0 rating last week, easily beating ``Today,'' which averaged a 3.3, according to A.C. Nielsen Co. figures released Thursday. ABC won despite the wide attention given to last week's return of former ``Today'' host Joe Garagiola to NBC's show on a three-day-a-week basis. The ratings for the new-look ``Today'' was up two-tenths of a point from the previous week. The perenially third-place ``CBS This Morning'' averaged a 2.3 rating. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Praises Bush's Rupture With PLO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Senate committee resolution, quote. Picks up 2nd graf pvs, ``I hope
DOC.TEXT: A Senate panel passed a resolution today that praised President Bush for suspending talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization and spelled out conditions for resumption of the dialogue. The 13-1 vote in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee reflected the widespread support that Bush has garnered on Capitol Hill for his action on Wednesday. Only Sen. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H., voted against the resolution, which has over 40 co-sponsors. The resolution, which now goes to the Senate floor, demands that PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat expel Abu Abbas from the organization, renounce all forms of terrorism and recognize Israel's right to exist. It also commended Bush. Sen. Connie Mack, R-Fla., said the PLO broke the trust that the United States placed in it by allowing terrorism. ``That trust cannot and must not be restored without concrete actions that irrevocably demonstrate that the PLO has abandoned terrorism once and for all,'' he said. Lawmakers said the next move was Arafat's. ``I hope that the PLO will take the steps necessary to allow resumption of the dialogue based on the commitments undertaken'' by it in December 1988, Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said Wednesday. Bush earlier in the day called a halt to the 18-month-old dialogue with the PLO because the umbrella group failed to condemn forcefully enough an aborted terrorist attack in Israel on May 30. The attack was thwarted when Israeli defenders intercepted the guerrillas, killing four and capturing 12. Abu Abbas, a member of the PLO executive committee, claimed responsibility for the attack. Mitchell called Bush's action a ``correct decision'' and others joined in praise. ``The ball is in the PLO's court,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan. ``It must unequivocally condemn the recent terrorist attack. It must discipline those responsible, starting with Abu Abbas.'' By suspending talks with the PLO, Bush avoided a possible confrontation with Congress over proposed legislation that called for a cutoff of the U.S.-PLO dialogue. ``If the president had not suspended the dialogue with the PLO, that would have been tantamount to giving terrorist elements within the organization a green light to renew their attacks on civilians,'' said Sen. Joseph Lieberman, D-Conn. Today, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee passed a resolution commending Bush for his action. The vote was 13-1. The measure also spells out conditions the PLO must meet if talks are to resume. Those conditions mirror the ones set out by Bush. John Kelly, assistant secretary of state for the Middle East, said at a House hearing that the decision could spark a wave of violence in terrorism in the Middle East, possibly undermining prospects for peace. But Lieberman said the ``failure to suspend the talks would result in more violence, not peace. Acts of terrorism must be met with a strong response.'' Rep. Larry Smith, D-Fla., one of Israel's staunchest supporters in Congress, said he was concerned that Bush might try to reinstitute the U.S.-PLO dialogue without waiting for substantive policy changes from the Palestinian group. To prevent such as occurrence, Smith proposed legislation to set strict terms for the PLO to meet before talks resume. ``The PLO can't go back to their old ways,'' added Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. Rep. William Broomfield of Michigan, the senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said Bush's decision was ``the only one he could have made under the circumstances.'' ``America must let Arafat know that the PLO can't talk peace and wage war at the same time,'' Broomfield said. ``President Bush was wise to suspend rather than terminate the talks. Arafat should know that the United States is still willing to cooperate in the search for peace, but not under the barrel of a gun.''

DOC.HEAD: Defense Attys: HUD Defendant Gave Most of Stolen Money to Charity
DOC.TEXT: Lawyers for the woman dubbed ``Robin HUD'' are disputing prosecutors' contentions that she gave to charity only $1.1 million of the more than $6 million she stole from the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Marilyn Louise Harrell, whose sentencing was scheduled Friday, pleaded guilty in January to stealing government property and failing to report income for taxes. The 46-year-old Temple Hills escrow agent gained the moniker ``Robin HUD'' by federal investigators because she claimed she gave most of the embezzled money to charities. But prosecutors have contended Harrell donated only $1.1 million to charities and spent most of the rest on herself, her family and her businesses. In documents filed Wednesday in U.S. District Court, Harrell's attorneys said the amount she spent to help others totaled more than $5.1 million. The papers, however, show the total includes $155,956 that went to members of Harrell's family, $183,000 for taxes and hundreds of thousands of dollars poured into numerous businesses to the benefit of friends, relatives and business associates. ``I cannot and will not deny that her family did benefit,'' said attorney Anthony R. Gallagher, who represents Harrell. ``But certainly (the bulk of the money) did not go to Marilyn Harrell and her family.'' Based on the charitable giving and Harrell's cooperation with investigators, Gallagher will urge U.S. District Judge Herbert F. Murray to sentence her to 16 months in prison. Federal prosecutors intend to argue for a 46-month term.

Here, at a glance, are highlights of actions taken Thursday by the Supreme Court.
POLITICAL PATRONAGE
The court dealt a devastating blow to political patronage today, ruling that government employers generally may not base hiring, transfer and promotion decisions on someone's party affiliation. By a 5-4 vote, the justices said refusing to hire, transfer or promote people for politically partisan reasons in most cases violates their constitutionally protected freedoms of speech and association. The court said partisanship may play a role in such employment decisions only when political affiliation is an appropriate requirement for carrying out a job, such as a high-level policy adviser. The cases are Rutan vs. Illinois Republican Party, 88-1872, and Frech vs. Rutan, 88-2074.
POLICE SEARCHES
The court expanded police powers by allowing them to search a home when they are let in by someone they mistakenly believe has authority to consent to a warrantless search. In a 6-3 ruling in a case from Chicago, the justices said evidence from such searches may be used in court as long as police, at the time of the entry, reasonably believe the person who granted them access shared authority over the premises with the owner. The case is Illinois vs. Rodriguez, 88-2018.
LIBEL
The court reinstated a former wrestling coach's lawsuit against an Ohio newspaper, ruling that allegedly libelous statements in the case can be treated as assertions of fact, not merely opinion. But the 7-2 ruling did not appear to reduce significantly the free-speech protections from libel law that opinion traditionally has been given by the nation's courts. For the first time, the court said the Constitution's First Amendment does not require a special, separate privilege for stated opinions. The decision makes clear, however, that the fact-opinion distinction will remain important in libel cases, and courts may continue to throw out lawsuits that seek damages for someone's stated opinions. The case is Milkovich vs. Lorain Journal Co., 89-645.
GAS
The court generally barred states and energy consumers from bringing federal antitrust suits against energys producers accused of conspiring to fix prices. In a 5-4 ruling, the justices said only direct purchasers of energy _ in this case utility companies _ may file such suits. The case is Kansas vs. Utilicorp United Inc., 88-2109.
SOCIAL CLUBS
Non-profit social clubs may not gain a federal tax advantage by deliberately incurring losses from selling food and drink to non-members, the Supreme Court ruled today. The court ruled unanimously that the Portland Golf Club in Oregon may not use such losses to offset investment profits. The Internal Revenue Service had said a decision in its favor would mean a federal revenue gain of at least $4 million nationwide. The case is Portland Golf Club vs. Commissioner of Internal Revenue, 89-530.

DOC.HEAD: House Creates Three-Hour Traffic Jam
DOC.TEXT: A 165-year-old French Creole style house being moved to a museum blocked traffic for more than three hours because it was too wide to clear the railings on an overpass. State police Lt. Tim Brunett said traffic Wednesday backed up about five miles on Louisiana Highway 1, from Port Allen to Brusly, until workers got the house high enough to clear the railings. Traffic started moving again about 3:30 p.m. The Aillet house was being moved from its original site, north of Brusly, to the West Baton Rouge Historical Association's museum in Port Allen, where it will become a permanent exhibit. Gerry Daigre, a Dow Chemical U.S.A. spokesman, said the company donated the house, which is held together by wooden pegs rather than nails and has cypress weather boards.

DOC.HEAD: Lightning Bolt Sets Siberian Oil Tank Farm on Fire
DOC.TEXT: A lightning bolt ignited a reservoir at an oil station in Siberia on Thursday and started a fire that spread to at least four of the station's 24 tanks, the Tass news agency reported. Tass said 28 fire engines were fighting the fire at the Karkateyevy station near Nefteyugansk, Tass said. That is in the Tyumen oil region of Western Siberia. The reservoirs at the station contain a total of 380,000 tons of oil, Tass said. ``The danger is still great,'' I. Kimstan, head of the fire-fighting directorate of the Russian Interior Ministry told Tass. Strong winds were making it difficult to contain the fire, which had spread to 22 acres, he said.

DOC.HEAD: White House Offers Assistance to Iran Following Earthquake
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 1st graf to make it today, sted Thursday
DOC.TEXT: The White House offered humanitarian assistance to Iran today after a devastating earthquake that the state media said killed at least 1,900 people and injured nearly 5,000. ``We are saddened by the damage and the loss of life,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. He said a message of condolence had been sent to President Hashemi Rafsanjani. `We are also expressing our willingness to provide appropriate humanitarian assistance should it be requested,'' Fitzwater said. The messages was delivered to Iran by another, unidentified country since the United States does not have diplomatic relations with Tehran.

DOC.HEAD: Kemp Participates in Groundbreaking for Homeless House
DOC.TEXT: In a setting of boarded-up windows, peeling plaster and bare cement floors, Housing Secretary Jack Kemp took part Thursday in groundbreaking ceremonies for renovation of a once-elegant apartment building into housing for the homeless. Kemp said the Department of Housing and Urban Development, which he heads, was not involved in the project, scheduled to open next April as Lazarus House, ``but we would like to be.'' ``Lazarus House represents a remarkable private, nonprofit partnership committed to creating decent, affordable and drug-free housing,'' Kemp said. The project is intended to provide apartments for about 80 formerly homeless people at a rent of around $240 a month. It is being undertaken by Samaritan Inns, a nonprofit program designed to combat the causes of homelessness. David Erickson, president of Samaritan Inns, said the building was erected in 1910 by Harry Wardman, a prominent Washington builder who was also responsible for the British Embassy. The building opened as a 56-unit apartment called Hawkins Court. Erickson said the building deteriorated in the late 1970s and the last of the tenants moved into public housing in 1982. Since then, the building has been vacant. Samaritan Inns purchased it in 1988. The organization has raised more than $2 million of the estimated $3.7 million cost of renovating the 43,000 square-foot building, Erickson said. He said much of the design and construction work was being donated. Catherine Hammonds, a neighborhood activist who spoke at the ceremony, said the neighborhood has been plagued in recent years by drugs, crime and litter. ``For years, people told me this building was going to be renovated,'' she said. ``I would say, `No, it's not going to happen.' I am indeed glad to see something positive happening.'' Samaritan Inns, established in 1986, operates three other transitional residences for homeless men and women in Washington. Its goal is to help them ``overcome their homelessness and return to the mainstream of society,'' it said in a statement distributed at the ceremony. The statement said the program ``targets homeless men and women who are motivated and able'' and the residents ``will be challenged by a social services staff to participate in programs that help them become productive and independent members of society.'' It said the program will be self-supporting.

DOC.HEAD: Native Dances Aimed at Putting Indian Couch Potatoes on Their Feet
DOC.TEXT: Tribal drums and native dances are replacing the pop tunes and disco gyrations of aerobic workouts in an effort to get American Indians to exercise the way their ancestors did. ``Traditionally, everyone _ young and old _ used to dance all night during tribal celebrations,'' said Rebecca Thomas, community health director with Nevada's Indian Health Service. ``A lot of these dances and songs are kind of lost,'' Thomas said Wednesday. ``It's good that we can bring them back.'' Thomas, of the Duck Valley Indian Reservation in Owyhee, just south of the Idaho line, spoke as a group of 85 American Indians bounced and flexed through a workout paced by rhythmic chants and beating drums. The first-of-its-kind routine eventually will be captured on a 40-minute exercise video aimed at older Indians. ``This is motivating. You have to look at where people are from and what's important to them,'' said video coordinator Betty Dodson, associate director of the Geriatric and Gerontology Center at the University of Nevada, Reno. Violet Hooper, a 39-year-old Shoshone from the remote Yomba Indian Reservation in southern Nevada, said the program works for her. Before, ``I'd just fall asleep in a chair,'' she said. ``Now, when I sit down, I don't feel like I can just sit there. I have to keep moving.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinians March to Protest Halt in U.S.-PLO Dialogue
With AM-Mideast-PLO, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Masked Palestinians chanting ``No to America!'' marched through cities of the occupied West Bank on Thursday to protest the suspension of U.S. talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization. In annexed Arab east Jerusalem, stone-throwing Palestinian women and masked youths clashed with riot police after an Arab was killed there in an earlier protest over the U.S. decision. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir urged the United States to permanently end talks with the PLO. Shamir, who initially expressed elation, toned down his response to President Bush's announcement Wednesday that the dialogue would be suspended. Bush made the decision because the PLO failed to condemn an attempted raid on Israel on May 30 by a Palestinian faction. ``I hope that the suspension will not be temporary but instead will open a new chapter in relations between the United States and the Middle East,'' Shamir said on Israel radio. He said Washington's determination to fight terrorism would not be clear until it cut its dialogue with the PLO permanently. Israel objects to any PLO involvement in peace efforts, claiming the organization is a terrorist group bent on destroying the Jewish state. Israel has been pushing the United States to end its dialogue with the PLO since it began in December 1988 after PLO chief Yasser Arafat renounced terrorism. Israeli newspapers and analysts said Bush's action Wednesday could mean more American pressure on Israel to forge a new peace strategy. Defense Minister Moshe Arens said Israel did not feel pressured to come up with a reciprocal peace gesture. Protests over the U.S. move broke out Thursday in several West Bank cities. In Nablus, the West Bank's largest city, dozens of Palestinians marched though the crowded market chanting, ``No to America! No to Israel! Yes to the PLO!'' At least one of the marchers carried a pistol and others covered their faces with checkered Palestinian kefiyyeh scarves, one witness said. An anti-American march also was reported in the West Bank town of Tulkarem. In east Jerusalem's Silwan section, 20-year-old Said Mohammed Fatafta was killed by riot police Wednesday night during a protest that began after news of the U.S. decision spread. Police said he was shot when a patrol was attacked by about 25 masked Palestinians armed with chains, iron bars and stones. Palestinian women and masked youths took to the streets Thursday to protest the death. Black flags of mourning and outlawed Palestinian flags fluttered from rooftops of the hilly Silwan area and nearby Abu Tor. The main street of Silwan was blocked with boulders and wrecked cars. The walls were painted with anti-American slogans such as ``The Americans are our biggest enemy.'' ``Mohammed, don't worry, we'll teach the Jews a lesson,'' read another, with a gun painted next to it. A police helicopter hovered overhead and riot police fired tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse the rioters. Three Arabs were treated for rubber bullet injuries and released, said doctors at east Jerusalem's Mukassed Hospital. Fatafta was the 718th Arab killed by Israelis in the 30-month-old revolt against the Israeli occupation. An additional 225 Palestinians have been murdered by other Arabs, most on suspicion they collaborated with Israel. Forty-five Israelis have been slain by Palestinians in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Economic Growth 2nd Slowest in 3{ Years
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy advanced at its second slowest pace in 3{ years from January through March, the government reported Thursday. Analysts said they expect only modest improvement for the rest of the year. But the economists said any future growth would be fueled in large part by exports after a fall off in consumer spending, which had been a driving force for the economy through much of the economic expansion. The Commerce Department said the gross national product _ the nation's total output of goods and services _ grew at a revised 1.9 percent annual rate in the first quarter. At the same time, the department revised a price index tied to the GNP to show an annualized inflation rate of 6.4 percent for the quarter. The department said half of that increase was due to rising food and energy prices caused by unusual winter weather and analysts predicted prices would decline during the remainder of the year. If the GNP and inflation reports are combined with other, more recent economic indicators, ``the economy is in pretty good shape, although nobody's talking about a boom,'' said Michael K. Evans of Evans Economics, Inc., a Washington forecasting firm. ``Considering some of the recession forecasts we heard earlier in the year, that's not at all bad,'' he added. A recession generally is defined as two consecutive declines in the GNP and has not occurred since 1981-82. Nevertheless, the economy is growing slower than the 3.0 percent gain of 1989 and the 4.4 percent advance of 1988. ``The picture is one of sluggishness,'' said economist Cynthia Latta of DRI@McGraw-Hill, a Lexington, Mass., forecasting organization. ``Sluggishness today, and tomorrow, and probably for several months to come.'' The first-quarter GNP was up from the 1.1 percent annualized rate in the final quarter of 1989. that was the slowest advance since a 0.8 percent gain in the summer of 1986. The department said a larger export total than had been reported was the largest factor in revising the first-quarter GNP from the meager 1.1 percent gain it had calculated last month. It originally had projected in April that growth during the period had been 2.1 percent. Exports increased 12.8 percent during the period, while imports grew only 3.0 percent. ``Exports are keeping the recovery alive,'' Evans said. Consumer spending, meanwhile, was revised from a 2.4 percent increase reported last month to just 1.6 percent in Thursday's report. ``The lower consumption is consistent with the other news about consumers,'' said Ms. Latta, noting earlier government reports that retail sales have declined for three straight months through May, the first time that has happened since the fall of 1981 during the last recession. Retail sales represent about half of overall consumer spending, which itself accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. The various changes left the GNP, after adjusting for inflation, totalling $4.193 trillion after the first three months of the year.

DOC.HEAD: They Might Not Know Art, But They Know What They Like To Tax
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Dollar figures are Canadian
DOC.TEXT: The wood carver who created Percy the black-ringed New Jersey seagull was no artist, say tax officials who levied a stiff import duty on the wooden decoy. Richmond lumber dealer Clark Robertson received Percy as a gift from a customer. The customer had carved the bird out of leftover Alaska yellow cedar that was shipped by Robertson. Robertson balked when Revenue Canada said he owes $73.37 in duty and taxes on the bird. After receiving the assessment in early May, he wrote the agency to protest, saying he'd tried to appraise the bird by comparing it to other hand-carved gulls but couldn't find one ``that even remotely resembles Percy.'' Robertson put the cost of the wood between $5 and $7.25. ``Our customer is a hobbyist, who carves for sheer enjoyment. By the appearance of the decoy, I suspect it may well have been one of his initial attempts, as it was absolutely lousy,'' he wrote. ``As a matter of fact, it is so bad that the only good part of the whole scenario is that it scared away all those nasty crows that have been frequenting our back garden.'' Exactly, replied the government: Original sculptures and statuary signed by the artist are exempt from duty and taxes, but ``statuettes and other ornaments of wood'' are not. ``It appears clear to us in Ottawa that your friend is not a bona fide artist and as such the proper tariff and duty rates were charged you,'' wrote Revenue Canada officer Gaston Gingrass. Gingrass included some forms for Robertson to appeal the levy, but when Robertson got all the paper, each of which had six carbon copies, he said he won't pursue the matter. He did offer to ``surrender this apparition to Her Majesty the Queen'' via Revenue Canada. There's been no reply, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Experts See German Unification Harming U.S. Economy
DOC.TEXT: German unification will drive up U.S. interest rates and slow economic growth here but the adverse effects will be offset somewhat by greater demand for American exports, economic experts told Congress on Thursday. The United States will see ``higher interest rates for quite some time'' because of greater global competition for capital triggered by efforts to rebuild East Germany and the other Eastern European nations, said C. Michael Aho, director of economic studies at the Council on Foreign Relations. ``In the near future, the investment-starved economies of Eastern Europe are likely to begin soaking up funds like a dry sponge,'' Aho told the Joint Economic Committee. ``In a world of higher real interest rates, the United States, as the world's largest debtor nation, borrowing $300 million a day internationally, would be in a vulnerable position.'' With the U.S. economy already sluggish, the need to boost U.S. interest rates to attract foreign capital will mean ``America's economic woes may be aggravated by having to pay more to balance its books.'' Aho cited studies showing a 1 percent rise in world interest rates would slow U.S. economic growth by 0.4 percent in the first year and 0.6 percent in the second year _ a significant drop given the sluggish 1.9 percent U.S. growth rate so far this year. But Stephen Cooney, director of international investment for the National Association of Manufacturers, said higher interest rates would be partially offset by stronger demand for American exports. He said rising demand for American products in Western Europe has translated into 1 million new jobs in this country since 1985 and the demand should continue, particularly for capital goods such as computers and heavy machinery needed to overhaul Eastern Europe's manufacturing sector. Aho said dramatic changes in Eastern Europe would also increase pressure on American lawmakers to boost taxes and cut federal spending as a way of cutting the federal budget shortfall and thus reducing America's demand for foreign capital. Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International, said joining East and West Germany wouldn't do that much harm to other economies because West Germans have strong resources to fund the unification. But Hormats warned that West Germany may have to divert some of those resources to the Soviet Union to bargain for Kremlin acceptance of a united Germany in NATO. Hormats said the Bonn government may be called on to subsidize continued East German exports to the Soviet Union, to help with emergency shipments of consumer goods there and to pay a portion of the cost of building civilian housing for returning Red Army troops.

DOC.HEAD: Error on Gravestone Puts Veteran on Wrong Side of Civil War
DOC.TEXT: A new tombstone was supposed to honor William Lindley Wilcox for his Civil War service with the Union army, but a government error branding him a Confederate upset some descendants. ``It sure is goofed up. ... He was a Union man and he was fighting the Confederates. He would have really had a fit,'' said Wilcox's great-granddaughter, Doris Wilcox-Balmer of Chicago. The error on Wilcox's new tombstone was discovered this past Memorial Day by an ex-soldier who became suspicious about the Confederate marker while placing flags on veterans' graves at Prairie View Cemetery. Some people bothered by the mistake questioned whether Wilcox's history would have been altered permanently had the error not been caught. The government has already agreed to replace the marker. ``This is a rather glaring error,'' said state Rep. Leo Hamilton, whose district includes Hallie. ``A wrong date or wrong month could occur. The wrong army is not too common.'' Wilcox, a corporal in Company E of the First Wisconsin Cavalry, died in 1899. The government issued a flat marble gravestone to honor his Civil War service. Over the years, the tombstone in the tiny northwestern Wisconsin village of 1,220 people weathered, making it difficult to read. In 1986 the cemetery's caretaker ordered a new one from the government's monument service, according to Myron Olson, Chippewa County veterans service officer. Erected in 1988, the new marker, made of granite and valued at $83, contained most of the right facts about Wilcox's life _ born Feb. 8, 1827, died Oct. 7, 1899, entered the military Nov. 2, 1864, released July 29, 1865. But instead of listing the soldier in the U.S. Army, the gravestone put him in the Confederate States Army, Olson said. While putting flags at veterans graves before Memorial Day, Veterans of Foreign Wars Post 1038 Commander Jim Gustafson spotted it, figuring something was wrong about a Wisconsin man fighting for the Confederate Army. His curiosity put officials to work, including a call to Hamilton who has since contacted U.S. Rep. Dave Obey. Ms. Wilcox-Balmer said some of her relatives were quite upset by the mistake. She said the error wasn't caught by the family because an aunt who regularly visited the soldier's grave died in early 1988 just before the new marker was installed. Olson said he could understand if Wilcox's descendants were offended. ``When you make the kind of sacrifice you do in going to war, you believe in the side you are fighting on. So, it is pretty grave to be depicted on the other side,'' he said. George Gulas, an administrator for the Monument Service of the National Cemetery System within the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs, called the mistake an ``honest error'' that would not tarnish Wilcox's contribution to his country. The clerk processing the order for the engraver ``probably didn't put information in the computer right,'' Gulas said in a telephone interview from Washington, D.C. ``There have been a couple of them before. All the clerks aren't that familiar with the Civil War,'' Gulas said. ``There are a lot of Confederates buried in northern states. It is not unusual.''

DOC.HEAD: Bennett: South American Anti-Drug Effort Won't Become Another Vietnam
DOC.TEXT: Drug policy director William Bennett launched a pre-emptive strike Thursday on critics who say more U.S. military aid for battling South American cocaine traffickers could entangle this country in a Vietnam-like war. Increased law enforcement and military assistance for Colombia, Peru and Bolivia ``is not an American invasion,'' Bennett said in a speech to the Center for Strategic and International Studies. ``It is not an escalating military intervention,'' Bennett said. ``But military assistance in all three of the Andean nations is necessary to achieve a level of security that law enforcement personnel alone cannot provide.'' Bennett stressed that U.S. personnel will not participate in anti-drug operations. ``We will not do it for them. They must do it for themselves,'' Bennett said in response to growing expressions of concern by some lawmakers and others that stepped-up U.S. military assistance could involve American forces in guerrilla fighting. But he conceded there was a danger that more American lives could be lost. ``This is a dangerous enemy and we cannot expect to fight this battle unscathed and come out of it unblemished.'' ``When we sent military trainers or (Drug Enforcement Administration) agents or State Department personnel to the Andean region, we expose them to certain risks,'' Bennett said. ``But we need them there to give the governments a fighting chance and encourage them to take tough actions of their own.'' ``If we want to help keep drugs out of America, then we need to support those countries that are working on the front line against drugs,'' Bennett said. Colombia, Peru and Bolivia are receiving $230 million worth of aid for anti-drug efforts. The Bush administration has proposed increasing that to $430 million next year. Editorial writers and columnists have questioned whether plans to send U.S. military advisers to train Latin American forces will lead to American involvement in a Vietnam-style war, particularly in Peru where the leftist Shining Path guerrillas control much of the cocaine-producing areas. On Wednesday, Rep. Peter Kostmayer, D-Pa., the acting chairman of a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee, said he had ``grave doubts about the militarization of the Andean anti-narcotics effort. ... ``Are we getting the United States involved through the back door in fighting guerrilla wars?'' Kostmayer said. Bennett conceded that ``a serious effort'' against drug traffickers in Peru will inevitably lead to fighting with the leftist Shining Path guerrillas. ``Peruvian authorities know that they cannot fight cocaine at the source without at the same time providing a measure of security from Shining Path terror,'' Bennett said. Bennett said ``the very mention of military assistance'' causes ``hand-wringing among certain members of the press and Congress'' who ignore the fact that ``the cocaine business is a very dirty and often deadly business.'' ``If these efforts are caricatured as another Vietnam, an American invasion or involvement in a foreign war, then we risk crippling a series of strengthened relationships that our president and the president's of the Andean region have recently forged,'' Bennett said.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Bombings Up 25 Percent in 1989, Drug Bombings Almost Doubled
DOC.TEXT: The number of bombings nationwide increased 25 percent last year as drug-related bombings almost doubled, a government report says. ``These are largely bombings related to turf wars or disagreements within certain factions involved in narcotics trafficking,'' said Jack Killorin, a spokesman for the Treasury Department's Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms. He was referring to the leap in drug-related bombings. Firearms still are responsible for most drug-related violence, Killorin acknowledged Wednesday. But he added: ``Nobody at ATF likes the trend of almost exponential growth in the use of explosive devices as a weapon in the drug wars.'' Drug-related bombings last year totaled 64, almost double the 33 in 1988, according to a draft of the ATF explosives incidence report of 1989. There were only five such attacks in 1987, the first year ATF counted drug-related bombings. In those three years, 18 people have been killed in drug-related bombings, 13 of them in 1989, the report said. In addition, 56 people have been injured, 17 of them last year. ``I don't think there's any question but the street level of activity in narcotics is becoming increasingly violent,'' Killorin said. Meanwhile, the total number of criminal bomb attacks, for all reasons, increased by 25 percent, from 1,108 in 1988 to 1,384 last year. The 1989 total was 59 percent higher than the 871 in 1985. Adding in attempted bombings, last year there were 1,699, a 28 percent increase over the 1,332 in 1988. Last year's total was 54 percent higher than the 1,103 in 1985. Thirty-three people were killed and 305 injured last year in bomb attacks. Since 1985, the number of people killed has ranged between 29 and 43. Last year represented a high for the number of injured, which had ranged from 182 to 283 in the previous four years. Among motives for bomb attacks, drug issues ranked third, the report says. Vandalism was first, followed by revenge, then drug disputes, labor disputes, homicide or suicide, protest, extortion and insurance fraud. Killorin noted that some bombings had several motives. Bombings listed in the report include explosive as well as incendiary devices. The difference, said Killorin, ``is the difference between a hand grenade and a Molotov cocktail.'' The numbers cover bombings either investigated by the ATF or reported to the ATF by other law enforcement agencies. They do not include accidental, non-criminal explosions. The report shows that in addition to last year's 64 drug-related bombings, there were 17 attempted bombings. Total drug-related bombings and attempts in the past three years were 81 last year, 38 in 1988 and seven in 1987, the statistics show. The drug-related attacks include 11 on Detroit's north side that injured five people and ``appear to be part of a `turf war' between narcotics trafficking organizations,'' the report says. Attempted bombings included a plot by two St. Louis drug dealers who were angered by the Pike County, Mo., sheriff's strict enforcement of narcotics laws. They allegedly tried to recruit an undercover deputy sheriff to help kill his boss. ``They decided to blow up the sheriff in his official vehicle to set an example for other law enforcement officers in the area,'' the report says. The two men face state and federal charges.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Approves Increase in Airline Liability Payments
DOC.TEXT: Airlines would have to increase liability payments to passengers who die in crashes under treaty protocols approved Thursday by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The protocols to the Warsaw Convention, created in 1929, would raise to $130,000 the per-passenger limit on liability regardless of circumstances of the crash. The current limit is $75,000 per passenger, except in cases when an airline is found guilty of willful misconduct. The vote was 11-2, with Sens. Joseph Biden, D-Del., and Paul Simon, D-Ill., opposing the protocols. The protocols have been fought by lobbying groups representing trial lawyers. Biden is chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee. Despite passage of the protocols, a stiff fight is expected on the Senate floor where the measures have failed twice before.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Steve Martin says he learned early in his career that an audience pays more attention to the billing than the performance. ``If you're the opening act and you're better than the headliner, it doesn't matter,'' Martin said in an interview in July's Gentlemen's Quarterly. ``They're there to see the headliner. You just don't exist.'' Relying on billing ``relieves the audience of the necessity of having to make a decision about you,'' he said. Martin said he adopted his trademark white suit when he was doing stand-up comedy to get noticed so he could climb to the top of the marquee. ``I knew my physical stuff was important and white would just make it stand out,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: version moving on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Former tennis superstar Bjorn Borg's elegant seaside home will be seized and sold to the highest bidder if he doesn't pay more than $1 million within a month, court officials said Thursday. Bailiffs visited Borg's home in a Stockholm suburb Wednesday to assess its value. ``They were not let in because nobody was home,'' said Bjorn Edgren, a senior court official. Borg reportedly was in Italy to watch World Cup soccer action with his Italian wife, Loredana. He was given an extension until July 20 to pay the debt. ``Then we can use a locksmith,'' Edgren said. The house would then be sold at auction. The $1.1 million debt owed by Borg's former business partner Lars Skarke was personally guaranteed by the 1970s-era tennis star. Skarke was managing director of Borg's clothing company that collapsed last year. Borg's lawyer, Henning Sjostrom, said the debt payment was being arranged from Italy but had been delayed. He said Borg planned legal action against Skarke aimed at getting the money back. The retired tennis great also is negotiating with creditors of his failed company to pay off million of dollars in outstanding debts.

Armed with golf clubs rather than a gun, the actor who portrays ``Twin Peaks'' FBI Agent Dale Cooper has joined his hometown's war on drugs. Actor Kyle MacLachlan will appear at a celebrity golf tournament Saturday to raise money for local drug-fighting efforts. MacLachlan plans to bring Lara Flynn Boyle, a co-star on the ABC-TV series, and other actor friends to the tournament at the Yakima Country Club. Country singer Reba McEntire is the featured performer at a fund-raising concert for the cause in the SunDome on Friday. Organizers hope to raise about $50,000 for city anti-drug programs.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Version moved on financial wires
DOC.TEXT: William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., suffered a separated pelvis during a horseback riding accident at his ranch, his office said Thursday. Seidman underwent successful surgery after Wednesday's accident, an official in his Washington, D.C., office said. Details of the accident were not disclosed. He was listed in satisfactory condition at St. Vincent Hospital, a nursing supervisor said. Seidman came to New Mexico to speak to the New Mexico Bankers Association and to participate in an FDIC management conference. His office said he was making an overnight visit to his ranch before returning to Washington. Seidman has said he plans to retire June 30 from his jobs as head of the FDIC and chairman of the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency created by Congress to rescue the savings and loan industry.

DOC.HEAD: Ectopic Pregnancies Increasing at `Epidemic' Rate, CDC Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EDT, time set by source
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Ectopic pregnancies _ the dangerous development of fetuses outside the womb _ are increasing ``at epidemic proportions,'' with 88,000 cases a year, federal health experts warned Thursday. The national Centers for Disease Control said the estimated 88,000 U.S. cases in 1987 _ the latest year for which statistics are available _ marks a 19 percent increase in one year and more than a doubling in a decade. The CDC report was issued three days after a study in the Journal of the American Medical Association said women who have had chlamydia are more than twice as likely as other women to have ectopic pregnancies. The JAMA study used 1985 statistics. Chlamydia and other sexually transmitted diseases can cause pelvic inflammatory disease in women, which is believed to be the chief cause of ectopic pregnancies. ``If a woman has an infection of the fallopian tubes, they can become blocked or scarred, and the ovum does not get transferred to the uterus _ it implants outside the womb,'' said Dr. Hani Atrash, chief of the Pregnancy and Infant Health Branch at the CDC. Pelvic inflammatory disease ``does not explain all the increases,'' he said, noting other studies implicating factors such as smoking and stress. Ectopic pregnancies have increased about fourfold since 1970, when national case surveillance began, the CDC said. The 1970 rate was 4.5 per 1,000 reported pregnancies, compared with 16.8 in 1987. ``The increases are of epidemic proportions,'' Atrash said, adding that the steady, two-decade increase is more than would be expected simply from better reporting. Previous studies have reported that the rates are highest for women over age 30 and for minority women. Ectopic pregnancies killed 30 American women in 1987. While a relatively small number, they accounted for a tenth of all maternal deaths in this country, Atrash said. If detected early, ectopic pregnancies can be ended surgically, ending the danger to the mother.

DOC.HEAD: Father Guilty in Children's Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A 29-year-old man was convicted Thursday of first-degree murder in the deaths of his four children, who drowned when the family car sped into the Detroit River last year. A Wayne County Circuit Court jury, in its third day of deliberations, also convicted Lawrence DeLisle of the attempted murder of his wife, Suzanne. He faces a mandatory life prison term for the convictions. DeLisle, of Lincoln Park, had claimed a leg cramp caused him to jam his foot down on the accelerator. Some residents watched as the family's station wagon, with DeLisle, his wife and their children sped down a street through a barrier and flipped into the river. Killed were the DeLisles' children, Bryan, 8; Melissa, 4; Kathryn, 2; and Emily, 8 months. DeLisle and his wife surfaced and were rescued by boaters. Prosecutors were unable to present the jury with evidence of a purported confession by DeLisle after Judge Robert Colombo ruled police officers had coerced the suspect. Police have said DeLisle told investigators he was in debt and wanted to end his ``burdens.'' Residents near where the car went into the river in the Detroit suburb of Wyandotte reported seeing DeLisle driving in the area before the Aug. 3, 1989, wreck. Mrs. DeLisle testified that she and her husband tried to pull her husband's foot off the accelerator as their car sped toward the river. She also testified that she had forgotten to tell police earlier that the couple managed to pull his foot about an inch from the accelerator, which she said then stuck. The car came to rest in 27 feet of water. Mrs. DeLisle said she and her husband were poor swimmers and were unable to save the children. Defense attorney Frank Eaman accused investigators of ignoring mechanical defects in the car and DeLisle's history of cramps in efforts to blame someone for the children's deaths.

DOC.HEAD: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson Treated For Bacterial Infection
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson spent a restful night in a hospital and was responding Thursday to antibiotic treatment for a bacterial infection, a church spokesman said. Benson, 90, was listed in serious but stable condition in the intensive care unit of LDS Hospital, where he was admitted Wednesday, said spokesman Don LeFevre. ``His attending physician says he is `much better' today, but he is being carefully observed,'' LeFevre said. ``The doctor would not speculate as to the length of his hospital stay.'' The cause and extent of the infection were not immediately available, he said. Benson, who served as U.S. agriculture secretary under then-President Eisenhower, was named president of the 7.3-million member Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints in 1985. LeFevre said Benson was treated at LDS Hospital May 12 after a dizzy spell. He had attended the church's 160th Annual General Conference on April 5-6, but appeared weak and did not address the conference. Benson received a electronic heart pacemaker in 1986 after episodes in which his heartbeat rhythm slowed.

DOC.HEAD: Two Buses On Way to World Cup Collide; One Dead
DOC.TEXT: Two buses, one of them filled with English soccer fans going to a World Cup match, collided Thursday and at least one person was killed and 22 were injured, the British Embassy said. Two crash occurred before the England-Egypt match. ``We think all of these (dead and injured) are British,'' said embassy spokeswoman Kay Coombs. The accident occurred near Monastir, a small town 12 miles north of Cagliari, where the match was played. Ms. Coombs said at least one of the buses was bringing English fans to the game. She said the dead man was aboard the English bus. She said 22 people were injured, and half were believed to have sustained extensive injuries. The accident occurred on the main road linking the southern coastal city with the northern part of the island. English fans were converging on Cagliari for the crucial Group F World Cup match. Defeat for either team almost guaranteed elimination from the tournament.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Sustains Bush Veto of Hatch Act Revisions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 6th graf to ADD original House vote; picks up 6th graf pvs bg'ng, The legislation ...
DOC.TEXT: The Senate, by two votes, today upheld President Bush's veto of a bill to broaden the political rights of 3 million government workers. On a 65-35 vote, lawmakers refused to revise the 51-year-old Hatch Act to remove prohibitions on campaign activities for federal and postal employees. A two-thirds majority was needed to enact the bill into law over Bush's objections. The vote gave Bush an unbroken string of 12 victories in veto showdowns with the Democratic-led Congress. At the White House, presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We are pleased that that vote was sustained. We felt that it incorrectly politicized the civil service.'' The House voted Wednesday to override the veto by a 327-93 margin, well above the two-thirds needed to override Bush's veto of the bill last Friday. The House had originally passed the bill by a vote of 334 to 87. The legislation would have allowed federal workers, for the first time in five decades, to attend political conventions and caucuses as delegates _ on their own time _ and speak at rallies on behalf of candidates. It also would have removed a ban on government workers holding offices in local, state or national political organizations or soliciting donations from co-workers for federal employee and postal union political action committees. The president vetoed the bill last Friday, saying it ``would inevitably lead to repoliticizing the federal work force'' and ``destroy its essential political neutrality.'' There was no immediate word on whether congressional sponsors would seek to write a bill more to the president's liking. The bill originally passed the Senate on a vote of 67-30. Bush won his veto fight when three original Republican supporters _ Alfonse D'Amato of New York, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Trent Lott of Mississippi _ supported his veto. In addition, the White House picked up the support of Republican Sens. Pete Wilson of California and Kit Bond of Missouri. Both had missed the vote in May. All 55 Senate Democrats voted to override Bush's veto. Just before the vote, Senate GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas issued an appeal to his colleagues to support Bush, saying supporters of the bill wanted only to give more power to federal employee unions ``to raise more money to give to Democrats.'' He said the law was enacted in 1939 ``as a remedy to gross patronage abuses in the federal government.'' ``The only diffence now is that, because of the Hatch Act, these abuses are under control,'' he said. ``Without it, we'll be right back where we started from. It probably won't happen overnight, but it will happen.'' Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., a supporter of the bill, attributed the loss to White House pressure to maintain Bush's perfect veto record. ``I regret that the merits are being overshadowed to extend the president's unbroken string of vetoes,'' Kennedy said. ``It's time to end the second-class status of federal workers in American democracy. One senior Republican, Ted Stevens of Alaska, who voted for the original measure, announced he would continue to support the bill. ``For the first time, I am asking the Senate not to sustain the veto of this president,'' said Stevens. ``It's time that our federal employees be made first-class citizens.'' ``It ... would convert the present rule that partisan politicking by federal civil servants is prohibited, into a presumption that such partisan campaigning should be encouraged,'' he said. Stevens said he met with Bush's advisers to attempt to forge a compromise, but was rebuffed by administration officials who he said ``are caught up in the belief that government workers are overwhelmingly Democrats.'' ``That's just not true,'' Stevens said. ``States such as mine, Colorado and California with large ... federal work forces repeatedly elect Republicans.'' The Senate approved the bill by a potentially veto-overriding 67-30 vote in May with unanimous support from the 54 Democrats. Since then, former Rep. Daniel Akaka of Hawaii, who supports the bill, has filled a 55th Democratic seat in the Senate vacated in April by the death of Sen. Spark Matsunaga. The closest Bush has come to allowing Congress to enact a law over his objections was last July, when 34 senators by a single vote upheld his veto of a bill to impose conditions on his sale of FSX jet fighter technology to Japan. ``We've been very lucky,'' Bush told a White House audience recently. ``We may take one on the chin. ... But generally, the Republican side has stayed together.'' However, 84 Republicans, or nearly half of the GOP minority in the House, including party leader Robert Michel of Illinois, bolted from the administration Wednesday to support the Hatch revision override.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives' Dream of Gigantic Germany Crushed by Poland Guarantee
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A decision by both German states to guarantee Poland's existing borders is a crushing setback for millions of Germans who dream of reclaiming their old homelands. East German lawmakers overwhelmingly approved such a guarantee Thursday, and West German lawmakers were poised to follow suit. The declarations promise that a united Germany will not seek to reclaim former lands carved away by the Allies after World War II and ceded to Poland. The territories _ East Prussia, Silesia and Pomerania _ now comprise one-third of Poland. While German unity to most of the world is the merger of East Germany with its Western neighbor, other Germans say it will not be complete until those old lands are also returned. ``You wouldn't believe how many phone calls we get these days,'' said Michael Lohr, a spokesman for the Bonn, West Germany-based League of Expellees. ``People literally break down on the phone, crying.'' Lohr's group is the umbrella for 30 organizations with 2 million members who have ties to the former lands. They hold gatherings and festivals annually to mark their history and regional culture. Despite the resolutions, Lohr said there was nothing to prevent the issue from being raised again after a united German parliament is chosen, perhaps as early as December. ``It cannot be the end because these are not legally binding,'' he said. But it was with a note of finality that West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, in a speech to West German supporters, reaffirmed his grudging support of such a resolution. ``There are many people in our country who will be deeply moved and distressed by the statement given here today,'' Kohl said. ``They have strong emotional bonds with the country of their forefathers. On a day like this they can feel nothing but grief.'' Hitler's Germany invaded Poland in September 1939 and, under an agreement with the Soviet Union, the Poland was split down the center between the two countries. Six million Poles died during the war. About half of them were Polish Jews who were exterminated in concentration camps spread throughout the country. After the war, the three German areas west of the Oder-Neisse River were ceded to Poland to compensate for an even larger section of eastern Poland kept by the Soviets. Lohr said an estimated 10 million West Germans and about 4 million East Germans trace their roots to the three regions, which are still home to about 800,000 ethnic Germans. Polish and Red Cross estimates of the number of ethnic Germans are much lower. ``Our position was to keep as much of German territory as possible and if it wasn't possible to keep any one of these eastern provinces, we would like to see tougher negotiations,'' he said. Lohr said if the lands cannot be reclaimed, he said his group wants Germans from the region, or their heirs, to be able to reclaim their old property in the region. He said the resolutions, as written, would ``give away these territories unconditionally.'' The resolutions passed by both Parliaments call on Poland to guarantee the cultural and legal rights of ethnic Germans. Kohl, who bases much of his political support on elements who believe Germany has a right to the territories, caused a furor for months before he finally said in March that he would agree to support Poland's current borders. The guarantee was demanded by nations victimized by Germany's history of hunger for other lands. It is a symbolic promise the new Germany will not become like the old one. ``The German-Polish border is final,'' said West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher. ``Without finality of the Oder-Neisse border there will not be peace in Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Angered Gorbachev Accuses Critics of Slander
LaserPhotos MOSB1,2
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev accused his hard-line critics of slander Thursday and faced the prospect that one of them would be elected head of the Russian republic's Communist Party. Gorbachev was put on the defensive for a third day when a Leningrad economist claimed he did not obtain party approval to switch the Soviet Union to a market economy. ``To consider that this idea and program dropped from the sky, or that somebody is undertaking an overnight coup to change our course, that is slander,'' Gorbachev told the Congress of Russian Communists. A nationwide broadcast showed him angrily waving his hand in the air as he spoke. Numerous conservatives at the meeting, which began Tuesday, have attacked the 59-year-old Kremlin chief's political and economic reforms. The hard-liners have indicated they will try to replace Gorbachev as party leader at a national party congress starting July 2. Gorbachev also might have to deal with a conservative party leader in Russia, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. Nearly all the seven candidates announced Thursday for first secretary of the Russian party are conservatives. Four of them gave election speeches, and the front-runner appeared to be Ivan Polozkov, one of Gorbachev's critics and one of Boris Yeltsin's unsuccessful opponents in the race for the presidency of the Russian republic. Polozkov, the 55-year-old party chief of the southern Russian region of Krasnodar, received the most applause. At the urging of delegates, he was allowed to speak at least three times longer than the other three candidates who addressed the delegates. Polozkov has called for strict party discipline, condemned informal political groups, complained tht older party members are not respected and cracked down on cooperatives _ private businesses introduced by Gorbachev. In a speech Wednesday, he blamed the party's falling credibility in part on Gorbachev's reform program and said, ``The crisis is not just in the Communist Party, but above all in its leading bodies.'' On Thursday, Polozkov portrayed himself as a moderate intent on saving the party ``from reprisals on the inside from the left and right.'' He denied he opposed democratic forces or cooperatives. Gorbachev did not comment on the candidates for Russian party chief but did shoot back at hard-liners who accuse him of taking the party out of the decision-making process. He cited numerous meetings of the party leadership where officials decided on the need for radical economic reform, including a market economy. ``Don't be suspicious that something is being done secretly to turn the rails and move the country in the direction of capitalism,'' Gorbachev said. ``These attempts are rotten, improper, made by people who seek a completely different goal from ours, which is to find new forms of life and make the lives of people better,'' he said. The audience, 2,700 delegates to the founding congress of a Russian Communist Party, applauded briefly. Gorbachev was alluding to a complaint made Wednesday by prominent conservative Yegor Ligachev, who said Gorbachev made crucial decisions without consulting the Politburo, the Communist Party's 12-man ruling body. His complaints underscored conservative concern that Gorbachev has shifted power from the party to newly elected legislative bodies, and to the new post of president _ a title Gorbachev holds along with national party leader. The changes mean that Gorbachev may now be strong enough to remain the Soviet leader even if he no longer heads the Communist Party. There has been speculation for months that he planned to step down from his party post and exercise his power as president. The 2,700 Communists of the Russian congress will be the majority of the 4,700 delegates at next month's national party congress. Reformers have complained they were bypassed in the selection of delegates. Among the other candidates for Russian party chief is Alexander Melnikov, a hard-line Communist from Siberia who demanded Tuesday that Gorbachev resign as general secretary. Other candidates are Valentin Kuptsov, head of a party Central Committee department; Oleg Shenin, party chief of Krasnoyarsk, Oleg Lobov, second secretary of Armenia's Communist Party; and Nikolai Polovodov, a Leningrad worker. The only known progressive candidate is Vladimir Lysenko, a leader of the radical Democratic Platform group.

DOC.HEAD: House Launches Flag-Burning Debate _ Speaker Rules Out Second Round
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Top 7 grafs new to update with fresh quotes; pick up 3rd graf pvs, The House. Debate is now going on. Vote may not come before 6 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: The House today brushed aside last-ditch delaying efforts and pushed toward what Speaker Thomas S. Foley said would be this year's only vote on a constitutional amendment against flag burning. ``A tough choice, a choice that we would have hoped to have avoided,'' said House Majority Leader Richard A. Gephardt, D-Mo., who opposes an amendment. ``We simply cannot protect the flag and refuse to erode the Bill of Rights at the same time.'' A Supreme Court decision June 11 threw out a federal law passed last year against desecration of the American flag and rekindled debate over a constitutional amendment that was sidetracked last year. The proposed amendment would allow the federal government and the states to ban burning or other desecration of the American flag. Critics of the amendment expressed increasing confidence that it would not win the two-thirds support it would need for approval. Sen. Joseph R. Biden Jr., D-Del., told a hearing of his Senate Judiciary Committee that ``the House is going to defeat this amendment.'' Foley told reporters that ``whatever happens today is the final action.'' ``We're not going to go around and around and around and around,'' the Washington Democrat told a morning news conference. The House voted 231-192 to press ahead with five hours of debate followed by a vote on the amendment despite appeals for more time for lobbying by the American Legion, the Veterans of Foreign Wars and Amvets. Lawmakers said it did not necessarily reflect sentiment for the amendment. Emotional appeals to patriotism and warnings against tampering with the Constitution's guarantee of free speech rang out in the chamber as the House debate got under way. A panoramic picture of the Iwo Jima Memorial showing Marines hoisting the flag over Mount Suribachi was brought to the floor beside a photo of a flaming flag in Central Park, where ``the gooks and the goons held it up in open rebellion,'' said Rep. James Quillen, R-Tenn. He afterward defined ``gooks'' as ``people who don't care.'' ``Are we so fragile as a nation that we cannot rise above such cheap tactics'' as flag burning, asked Rep. David E. Skaggs, D-Colo. ``What assurance is there that this excision in the Bill of Rights, once breached, would not lead to others?'' Foley appeared to rule out a suggestion by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., even if the House rejected the measure the first time around the Senate could approve it and send it back, possibly in modified form. ``We will vote today on this matter for the final time this session,'' Foley told a morning news conference. On Wednesday, he said some of the measure's supporters had given way to ``crass political opportunism'' and would ``hurt their own cause by that kind of egregious political snickering.'' As the intensity picked up Wednesday, supporters promised to carry on their campaign even if the amendment is defeated on the House floor. ``If they think this issue goes away on Friday, they have no comprehension of what's going on out there,'' said Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia. ``And I expect that if we do lose, you'll see more anger and outrage than if we win.'' Backers and opponents of the amendment said it likely would not muster the necessary two-thirds margin in the House. President Bush said Wednesday in Huntsville, Ala., that a ``carefully drawn amendment to make burning of the American flag a crime'' is needed because the flag is a unique symbol. Republicans on Capitol Hill, however, grumbled that the White House should have done more one-on-one lobbying. Democratic leaders have been campaigning against the amendment on grounds that it would undermine the constitutional guarantee of free speech. The amendment would allow the federal government and the states to ban burning or otherwise desecrating the American flag. To become part of the Constitution, the amendment needed 289 votes in the House and 67 in the Senate plus ratification by 38 state legislatures. In the Senate, Democratic Whip Alan Cranston of California said his count was 54 in favor, 29 opposed and 17 on the fence. Meanwhile, former federal Judge Robert Bork was testifying today before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the proposed amendment. The House planned six hours of debate followed by a vote on the amendment. After that, the lawmakers planned to vote on a simple statute that would ban flag burning. The amendment was debated heavily last year after the Supreme Court struck down a Texas law that banned flag burning. But lawmakers ultimately passed a law to ban flag burning instead of a constitutional amendment. The Supreme Court last week declared the statute unconstitutional, rekindling debate over the constitutional amendment. House debate took on an acid tone Wednesday as Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y., told critics that in pushing for a quick vote they were ``gagging 10 million veterans through this nation'' and ``kowtowing to ilk like the Communist Youth Brigade.'' Democrats objected and Solomon eventually apologized. The remarks were stricken from the record. The sharp words, however, underlined the intensity of emotions in the House over the issue. Foley, asked about Gingrich's remarks, said some sponsors ``are concerned, apparently, about the political issue and the political opportunities they think this represents.'' ``I don't think the American people are going to respond favorably to that,'' Foley said. ``What I don't think they are going to appreciate and support is crass political opportunism, a kind of wringing their hands gleefully and saying, this is where we are going to clean up.'' Veterans' groups had sought to mount a grassroots lobbying campaign for the amendment but were caught off guard by the swift move to whisk the bill to the House floor. ``We fail to see why it is so necessary to rush this legislation to a vote on Thursday,'' said Walter G. Hogan, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
At Least 10,000 Killed As Quake Levels Entire Towns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines urgent series, restores byline, trims. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: At least 10,000 people died today in an earthquake that jolted northern Iran, demolishing scores of villages and towns and burying thousands in the rubble of their homes, an official announcement said. A statement by the Iranian Cabinet, released after an emergency evening session, said the ``sad, painful and horrible tragedy has so far claimed 10,000 lives and left thousands of others wounded.'' The announcement, carried by the Islamic Republic News Agency, placed all government organizations ``on full alert'' and ordered an air bridge set up between Tehran and the stricken areas to evacuate survivors. Landslides obstructed the mission of rescuers on the ground, and bad weather was hindering airlift operations by helicopters, IRNA said. It said many people were still buried in the debris, and that several hundred Revolutionary Guards were flown from Tehran after nighfall to join rescue teams. The White House sent condolences to the Iranian leadership, and expressed willingness to offer ``appropriate humanitarian assistance should it be requested.'' The Geophysics Center at Tehran University said the quake measured 7.3 on the Richter scale of ground motion. The U.S. Geological Survey measured it at 7.7. The Tehran center recorded 12 aftershocks after the early morning quake, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The quake struck at 12:30 a.m., when most people were either sleeping or watching World Cup soccer on television. IRNA quoted the Geophysics Center as saying it was centered 125 miles northwest of Tehran, near the Caspian Sea. The quake also rattled the bordering Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, slightly damaging some old buildings in its capital of Baku but causing no casualties, the Soviet news agency Tass said. The temblor killed at least 1,600 people and injured 3,600 in Iran's Zanjan province, and killed 300 and injured more than 1,000 in Gilan province, IRNA said in dispatches monitored in Cyprus. It said the dead included at least 1,000 people killed in one large village in Zanjan province, Ab-Dar, the agency said. At least 88 people were killed in Qazvin just 80 miles northwest of Tehran. It was not immediately clear where the thousands of other deaths occurred. IRNA said homes crumbled and landslides loosed by the shock were blocking main roads, hampering rescue efforts. The mountainous, largely agricultural provinces have a combined population of 2.7 million and the news agency said several villages near the 100,000-resident provincial capital of Zanjan were destroyed. Tehran residents said the quake shattered windows and sent people fleeing into the streets. They reported no casualties or serious damage in the capital. President Hashemi Rafsanjani declared three days of mourning and ordered all state organs to be ready to aid in the relief efforts. Spiritual leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei flew to the area and called the quake a divine test. ``The bereaved and other people should pass this test with pride through their patience, endeavor, cooperation and assistance,'' he said in a radio dispatch monitored by the British Broadcasting Corp. IRNA said an unspecified number of people were killed and injured in the Caspian port city of Rasht. It said houses collapsed in the Gilan province capital of 189,000 people, which is 175 miles northwest of Tehran. The agency said the ``exact number of casualties and the extent of losses were still unknown'' and that rescuers and relief teams had set up headquarters in Rasht. Scenes shown on state television and monitored in Cyprus showed young men frantically clawing at debris from pancaked concrete buildings. Occasionally, they carried away a victim on a stretcher. Bulldozers cleared larger pieces of debris. Women in black chadors camped out in the city's public squares, afraid to return to their homes. A dam south of Rasht burst, flooding the surrounding area, IRNA said. Three U.S.-made C-130 transport planes shuttled between Tehran and Rasht to carry the injured to hospitals in the capital, it said. State-run Iran Air ordered special flights to carry the injured. Russ Needham, a geophysicist with the U.S. Geological Survey's National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo., said the quake was centered in the Caspian Sea about 15 miles off the Iranian coast. Needham said preliminary data put the epicenter 210 miles northwest of Tehran and 160 miles south of Baku. The region is prone to earthquakes. A quake registering 6.9 on the Richter scale struck nearby Soviet Armenia Dec. 7, 1988, killing 25,000 people. The previous worst quake in Iran itself, registering 7.7 on the Richter scale, hit eastern regions of the country on Sept. 16, 1978, also killing 25,000 people. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. An earthquake with a magnitude of 7 is capable of widespread, heavy damage while an earthquake measuring 8 is capable of tremendous damage.

DOC.HEAD: Gunmen Attack State Council, 1 Dead, 2 Wounded
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Four gunmen, including two in army uniforms, opened fire Thursday on a meeting of the governing Council of State, killing a union activist and wounding two politicians, witnesses said.
