The attack occurred in a hotel courtyard where the 19-member council was meeting with union, political and business leaders to deal with a wave of violent crime. The assailants burst into the courtyard and sprayed the group with M-16 rifle fire, according to witnesses and independent radio reports. Two attackers wore army uniforms and two wore civilian clothes, the reports said. A truckload of soldiers arrived at the hotel, in a mainly residential area of Port-au-Prince, about a half-hour later. The civilian council governs alongside President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot. She was not present at the meeting and her office had issued no statement by late afternoon. Witnesses and Radio Antilles identified the dead man as union activist Jean-Marie Montes. Council member Serge Villard was wounded in the stomach and Emmanuel Mani, a member of the socialist National Progressive Party, was wounded in the thigh, the reports said. Both were hospitalized. The apparent involvement of soldiers raised concerns about the army's intentions as Haiti moves toward what would be its first democratically elected government since independence from France in 1804. The presidential election is scheduled for September. ``It is horrible,'' said Rene Theodore, leader of the Haitian Communist Party. ``It doesn't seem the government can cope with the situation ... If the problem is not resolved, it is difficult to hold elections with serenity.'' Haiti's last indendepently run elections, on Nov. 29, 1987, were aborted when thugs supported by the army shot and hacked to death at least 34 voters at polling stations. The Army High Command pledged to support Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot when was appointed president in March to replace Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. Avril fled into exile after widespread protests in this country of 5.3 million against his military government. But skeptics have questioned the willingness of the ill-disciplined and corrupt force to relinquish privileges gained over many years. Many have asked why security forces have not done more to try to stop the crime wave, in which 13 people have been killed in Port-au-Prince since Tuesday. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot has made no public statement since Monday, when she said illness had forced her to cancel a scheduled meeting with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar in New York. The president and the Council of State, which has veto power over her decisions, have been in a dispute over her appointment of Marie Violene Legangneur as finance minister. Council members regard Legangneur as a sympathizer of the 29-year dictatorship of Jean-Claude ``Baby Doc'' Duvalier, who fled into exile in 1986, and of his late father, Francois ``Papa Doc.'' The council has said it will not approve any electoral law signed by the finance minister. The law is necessary to hold general elections. Haiti, the first republic of former slaves, gained independence from France in 1804 and has since been governed mostly by repressive military rulers.

DOC.HEAD: Georgian Parliament To Bypass Blockade Against Lithuania
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of Soviet Georgia has decided to ignore President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's embargo on Lithuania and begin trading with the Baltic republic, Tass reported Thursday. Another Soviet republic, Moldavia, already has taken similar action. The president of the Russian republic, Boris Yeltsin, has called for an end to the embargo, and he has discussed direct trade with Lithuanian officials. Lithuania declared independence March 11, and Gorbachev cut off all oil, most natural gas and many raw materials shipments to the republic to try to force it to back down. Last week, under growing domestic pressure to end the economic sanctions, the Soviet government restored 15 percent of the republic's natural gas needs. The Georgian parliament also recognized ``the right to self-determination and the political will of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia and all union republics to create truly sovereign states,'' said Tass, the official Soviet news agency. The parliament also expressed readiness to establish direct inter-state political and economic relations with them. Georgia's action supporting the three Baltic states came Wednesday in a special legislative session, where the parliament created a commission to work on restoring its own independence. Georgia is southeast of the Baltics in the Caucasus Mountains. While the Baltics were occupied by the Red Army and forcibly annexed to the Soviet Union in 1940, Georgia was occupied and lost its independence in 1921. Neither Georgia nor the three Baltic republics has a population of more than 6 million. Tass said the Georgian parliament also approved a bill allowing alternative labor to military service. Avoiding the Soviet army draft has become a strong concern in many republics, partly because of deadly hazing practices. In addition, many young men do not want to be called into action to put down domestic ethnic violence or harrass independence governments, as the army has been called upon to do in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Government Sees Farm Income Improving
DOC.TEXT: The outlook for farmers continues to improve this year, according to new income estimates released Wednesday by the Agriculture Department. Sales of farm commodities ``are showing some unexpected strength, so income prospects have brightened'' since the last 1990 forecast was issued three months ago, the department's Economic Research Service said in its outlook report. ``Strong hog prices and firming coarse grain prices are behind the improvement,'' the report said. Coarse grains include corn, sorghum, oats and barley. Overall, the ``net cash income'' of farmers was forecast at $55 billion to $59 billion this year, up $1 billion from the range indicated since March. Last year's net cash income was about $54 billion, and the record was $57.2 billion in 1988. As used by the agency, net cash income ``measures the value of commodities sold in a calendar year plus government payments, less out-of-pocket costs.'' Some commodities may have been produced in earlier years and stored until marketed. In another method of accounting, the report said ``net farm income'' may be in the range of $47 billion to $51 billion, a $2 billion increase from the earlier 1990 forecast. Last year's was $49 billion, a record. Net farm income is used to measure the value of agricultural production, whether sold or stored, in a calendar year plus government payments, minus all costs, including depreciation and other allowances.

DOC.HEAD: Some Predict Mandela Fever Won't Cool Boston Racial Tensions
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
By STEPHANIE SCHOROW
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Mandela fever now grips Boston, but what happens after the Free South Africa T-shirts sell out and the last chorus of ``We Shall Overcome'' is sung? Longtime anti-apartheid activists say Nelson Mandela's one-day visit Saturday could have a positive effect on a city often wracked with racial tensions, most recently during the highly publicized Stuart murder investigation. But some warn that the ovations and oratory that will greet the African National Congress leader do not substitute for real change _ either here or in South Africa. Boston is Mandela's second U.S. stop. His itinerary includes a stop at the predominantly black Madison Park High School, a motorcade through the Roxbury section, a luncheon at the John F. Kennedy Library and a rally on the Boston Esplanade. ``He has a message of making a non-racial society,'' said Mel King, a former state representative and mayoral candidate. ``It seems to me it will encourage the people who want to build a non-racial community.'' Mandela, released in February after 27 years in prison in South Africa, is on a six-week tour of 13 countries to raise money for ANC and encourage countries to keep pressure on the white-minority South African government. ``He's a tremendous figure for young people, an extraordinary opportunity to meet a contemporary hero,'' said Margaret Burnham, chairman of the Fund for a Free South Africa. To many American blacks the 71-year-old Mandela ``represents what could have been,'' said state Rep. Byron Rushing, who has backed anti-apartheid legislation. Mandela is similar in age to what Malcolm X or the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. would have been, had they lived, he noted. ``Most Americans feel a kind of moral leadership vacuum. Everybody's hero is dead. Here's a live one. That's what you see in this big ovation,'' Rushing said. Rushing, however, said it would be a mistake to think Mandela's sudden popularity would translate into domestic changes. ``That is a cop-out. Things happen because people organize and persevere,'' he said. The significance of the red carpet treatment for Mandela lies in the implication that for the first time the black community has shaped American foreign policy, Rushing said. Mandela's is a political, not spiritual, mission, he said. ``People are trying to make this into a pope's visit,'' he said. ``It's not.'' Racial conflicts rocked Boston during the late 1960s and early 1970s over court-ordered busing to integrate public schools. Most recently, tensions were heightened in fall when Charles Stuart told police a black mugger jumped in his car in Boston, shot his pregnant wife dead and wounded him. After the white businessman apparently committed suicide in January, prosecutors said Stuart himself plotted to kill his wife and concocted the mugger story. Longtime anti-apartheid activist Richard Clapp said Mandela's visit could be part of a healing process among Boston ethnic groups. ``This is a person who's a beacon around the world for resistance to unjust regimes,'' he said. But Sadiki Kambon, director of the Black Community Information Center, predicts the majority of people at the Madison Park School and along the motorcade will be black and the majority of those attending the Esplanade concert _ featuring Paul Simon, Jackson Browne and Bobby McFerrin _ will be white. ``I don't believe his visit is going to affect the racial tensions in this city one way or another,'' Kambon said. Yet Mandela's visit retains deep significance for African-Americans. ``Just his mere presence is an inspiration, especially to young people,'' Kambon said.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Calls For Adequate Severance Pay For Enlisted Men And Women
DOC.TEXT: A soldier with more than seven years' service and a family to support doesn't want a handout but does need adequate severance pay and health benefits as the military scales down, Pentagon advisers said on Wednesday. Recent debate over significant reductions in President Bush's $303.3billion budget has focused on Air Force fighter wings, Army divisions, Navy ships and base closings. But the Pentagon's senior enlisted personnel advisers, in testifying before the Senate Armed Services Committee on a bill to provide increased and special benefits to those involuntarily separated from the military, put faces on the reduction numbers. ``Spouses and even some of the children are becoming uneasy with the future outlook,'' Army Sergeant Maj. Julius W. Gates told the panel on manpower and personnel. Duane Bushey, master chief petty officer of the Navy, said the overriding concern among enlisted sailors let go after more than five years on the job is not an improvement in their education benefits but enough separation pay. ``At that point they're looking to survive. They want to put meat and potatoes on the table. Most with a family are looking to feed the family,'' Bushey said. Gates said Army personnel ``are not asking for free handouts or welfare, but the quality soldiers subject to force reductions want some form of separation pay and need some form of transitional medical care.'' Later in the day, Senate and House Democrats introduced legislation that will assist the nation's communities that have been dependent on the defense buildup of the 1980s as they adjust to a reduced military spending. Touted by House Majority Leader Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., as a plan ``to move our economy from a Cold War footing to a new era of vitality,'' the bill would create a high-level federal office to assist defense adjustment, provide grants to communities to start adjustment planning and require advance notification to communities, workers and businesses of planned cuts. The legislation eases the change from a ``war-oriented economy to a peace economy,'' Rep. Ron Dellums, D-Calif., a member of the House Armed Services Committee, told reporters. Last month, Sens. John McCain, R-Ariz., and William Cohen, R-Maine, introduced legislation that would ease the pain for military personnel _ especially enlisted men and women in uniform _ from the cuts in defense spending. Severe budget constraints and the easing of the Soviet threat to the West has prompted a loud, long call in Congress for slashing defense spending. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney argued on Tuesday that House and Senate plans to cut the budget would force layoffs of a third of the 3.1 million military and civilian workers on the Pentagon's payrolls. The Senate bill is a package of severance pay, health benefits, relocation and job counseling for those forced out of the service with more than seven years' experience and before they are eligible for retirement. The current Pentagon system provides separation pay at 10 percent of annual basic pay times the number of years of service for officers who have five or more years of service. The amount of pay is capped at $30,000. The Senate legislation would raise the cap to $83,500. The Pentagon on Wednesday proposed its own plan that is similar to the Senate bill but would affect personnel with five years of service who are on active duty at the time the bill is enacted. ``We have a personnel crisis of nearly unprecedented proportions,'' McCain said at the hearing. Army officials told the panel that the service is planning a reduction of 20,000 soldiers in the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 and 35,000 soldiers per year after that. Cuts greater than that would force the Army to layoff mid-career officers and noncommissioned officers. Navy officials said budget cuts in fiscal 1991 will result in a reduction of 494 officers and 5,207 enlisted personnel. However, the cuts will come through reduced accessions and not involuntary separation. The Marine Corps said it has no plans for such layoffs while the Air Force did not provide estimates.

DOC.HEAD: Deficit Spending This Year Far Ahead of 1989 Pace
DOC.TEXT: Federal deficit spending totaled $151.68 billion in the first eight months of fiscal 1990, 34 percent ahead of the overspending pace for the same period a year ago, the Treasury Department reported Thursday. Deficit spending in May was $42.55 billion, following a record surplus a month earlier during income tax time, the department said. Many analysts now believe the deficit could top $200 billion by the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30. The imbalance also was well above the $100 billion target set by the Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law. ``This just puts more pressure on Congress and the White House to come up with a credible budget plan,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., money market research director for Dean Witter Reynolds, Inc., in New York. ``The smoke and mirrors just won't help any more,'' he added. White House and congressional leaders currently are negotiating a package of budget cuts and increased revenues designed to meet the $64 billion Gramm-Rudman deficit target for fiscal 1991 that begins Oct. 1. The Bush administration budget last January projected the 1990 deficit to be $123.8 billion, although officials admit it will be revised upward because of the unexpected costs of the savings and loan bailout, increased interest rates and less-than-expected revenue because of a sluggish economy. The Congressional Budget Office in March projected the deficit at $159 billion. April's record surplus of $42.52 billion, due to a surge in income tax payments, had followed a record $53.34 billion deficit in March. Revenues in May totaled $69.21 billion, down 2.7 percent from the comparable month last year. Spending, on the other hand, rose 15.9 percent to $111.76. The outlays included $7.27 billion by the Resolution Trust Corp., the government agency charged with bailing out the savings and loan industry. Revenues for the first eight months of fiscal 1990 totaled $667.13 billion, up 4.1 percent from the same period of 1989. Spending totaled $111.76 billion, a 15.9 percent increase over the first eight months of the last fiscal year. The biggest spending categories, as usual, were the military, Social Security and other programs for the Department of Health and Human Services, and interest on the national debt. Military spending totaled $25.56 billion in May and $192.42 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $286.79 billion for the entire fiscal year. Social Security payments amounted to $20.57 billion for the month and $158.81 billion for the year so far. They are projected to total $244.59 billion for the year. Other HHS payments including Medicare and Medicaid totaled $16.75 billion during May and $126.21 billion thus far. They are projected to total $191.17 billion in fiscal 1990. Interest on the national debt amounted to $21.65 billion for the month and $168.15 billion so far this year. It is projected to total $254.85 billion for the entire year.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Again Updates Number Wounded in `Friendly Fire'
DOC.TEXT: The Pentagon revised its figures again Thursday on the number of soldiers accidentally wounded by their comrades in the Panama invasion, reducing the number by one. It was the second time this week it has dropped the count. On Tuesday, Pentagon spokesman Pete Williams said 16 out of 310 soldiers wounded in action were hit by so-called ``friendly fire,'' but Williams said Thursday that additional study has revealed that actually 15 men out of 311 wounded in the invasion were hit that way. On Monday, the department had said 19 of some 324 soldiers wounded in action had been accidentally wounded by their comrades. Williams said a review of videotape taken by an Air Force AC-130 gunship does show an incident of possible friendly fire involving another 21 U.S. Army soldiers during the Dec. 20 military operation. But the spokesman said it still is ``impossible to determine'' whether their injuries came from the fire of the gunship's cannon or mortar fire from the Panamanian Defense Forces. The video, taken at night in the area of the battle for the Panamanian Defense Forces headquarters at the Commandancia ``doesn't show impact. You can't tell a lot'' from the video, Williams said. ``We have been analyzing the tape and continue to do so,'' he added. Williams said the Pentagon stands by its initial count that two _ and perhaps three _ U.S. servicemen had been killed by friendly fire during the Panama operation. The third case was still under study, Williams said. The spokesman said he believed those families that requested to know the circumstances of their relatives' deaths had been informed whether or not if involved friendly fire, but some families asked not to be given such information. The Pentagon's disclosure of the dead and wounded from friendly fire was prompted by a Newsweek magazine report that nine U.S. soldiers had been killed by their comrades and that more than 60 percent of those wounded had been hit by friendly fire.

DOC.HEAD: Doctor Says Hopkins Medical School Tried to Block His Talk
With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An AIDS-infected doctor who sued Johns Hopkins medical school accused the school Thursday of trying to block him from delivering a speech at the international AIDS conference. Dr. Hacib Aoun said the school filed an injunction to prevent him from delivering a speech that dealt in part with discrimination he said he had suffered at the hands of Hopkins. Paul Rosenberg, vice president and general counsel for the Johns Hopkins Health System in Baltimore, said, ``We did in fact seek guidance of a court with respect to Dr. Aoun's speech.'' He responded to Aoun's charges through a statement released by a Hopkins spokeswoman. Aoun is a Venezuelan doctor who contracted AIDS in 1983 when a tube of a patient's blood broke in his hands and cut his finger. He was then a doctor in training at the Johns Hopkins Hospital. Although Hopkins says Aoun had distinguished himself in his career, his contract was not renewed after he was diagnosed with AIDS in 1986. He filed a lawsuit that led to a bitter confrontation and ultimately was settled in December 1987. He did not return to Hopkins. Details of the settlement were kept secret as a condition of the settlement. Aoun has since lectured and written on the tragedy of AIDS discrimination. In a moving speech Thursday at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, he said his experience was a nightmare. ``We had to sue the hospital to get health benefits,'' he said. Such actions as Hopkins' attempt to deny benefits ``send a terrible message to health workers,'' he said. That was the speech that Hopkins had attempted to block, Aoun said. ``It wasn't to prevent him from speaking,'' Rosenberg said. ``We actually wanted to see his speech.'' Last week, Hopkins officials asked the conference's program director, Dr. Robert Wachter, for a copy of Aoun's speech. Wachter told Hopkins he didn't have a copy, according to Hopkins spokeswoman Marion Glick. ``He said the request would have to go to Dr. Aoun,'' Glick said. A judge reviewed the legal filing by Hopkins and required Aoun to slightly modify his speech before delivering it, Rosenberg said. Hopkins sought a copy of the speech to determine whether Aoun was violating the secrecy agreement in the lawsuit settlement, Glick said. ``We never saw his speech and we don't know what modifications were made to his speech,'' said Glick. ``The judge did all of that.'' ``We have never had any intention to restrict Dr. Aoun from discussing policy issues related to AIDS, HIV testing, health care or benefits for HIV infected persons,'' Rosenberg said in his statement.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Leaders Back Sanctions, Give $200,000 to Mandela
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. religious leaders on Thursday gave $200,000 and a hero's welcome to Nelson Mandela, who responded by calling them his ``comrades in arms'' in the battle to dismantle apartheid. ``From a theological perspective, I do think that God raises up giants of the faith for society, and I think this is one that God has raised,'' said Presiding Bishop Edmond L. Browning of the Episcopal Church. The gathering of more than 100 church leaders, representing Protestant, Catholic, Orthodox, Jewish and Muslim groups, cheered loudly as the 71-year-old deputy president of the once-banned African National Congress called upon South African leaders ``to confess the sins they have committed.'' Mandela, who was released Feb. 11 after a 27-year imprisonment, said churches have played a decisive role in the anti-apartheid fight. ``You are our comrades in arms, you are our brothers and sisters. We feel perfectly at home with you,'' Mandela told the gathering sponsored by the National Council of Churches, the nation's largest ecumenical organization. Mandela asked church leaders to keep up pressure on the South African government, referring to economic sanctions as ``one of the prices we are prepared to pay'' to bring about democratic rule in South Africa. In addition to giving $200,000 to the ANC, the religious leaders Thursday approved a document entitled ``The New York Declaration'' calling for continued support of U.S. government sanctions against South Africa and for the release of all political prisoners. ``I will do everything in terms of my office to influence the president,'' said Browning, the spiritual leader of the denomination of which President Bush is a member. ``I don't think we can remove sanctions until the people of South Africa are free.'' Bush, scheduled to meet with Mandela next week, reiterated Wednesday that the United States will continue its sanctions until South Africa meets certain requirements, including the release of all political prisoners. Bishop John Ricard of the Archdiocese of Baltimore, representing the U.S. Catholic Conference, said Mandela's presence vindicates years of church pressure on the South African government, including the divestment of its own holdings in companies doing business there. ``I think, right now, the role of the churches is to help the African National Congress and Mr. Mandela develop the infrastructure'' that will be needed once apartheid is dismantled. Several Moslem and Jewish leaders joined to honor the anti-apartheid leader despite their differing views of Mandela's support for the Palestine Liberation Organization and his comparison of the struggle of Palestinians to that of black South Africans. ``We have something in common. We cannot separate,'' said Dawud Assad, president of the Council of Masajid of North America. ``To us he is a great hero.'' Mohamed Khan, president of the Islamic Congress of the United States, said, ``The principle that Mandela is standing up for is an Islamic principle: equality and justice.'' It is also a Jewish principle, said Rabbi Alexander Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations. ``Our faith has always taught us until all human beings are free, no one is free,'' he said. Schindler, who noted the black nationalist leader also has supported Israel's right to exist within secure borders, said his presence was a symbol of Jewish support for Mandela and the desire of American Jews to strengthen their alliance with blacks in the fight for civil rights. ``The man is an unusual spirit, an incandescent spirit in our generation,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Detectives: NYC Park Shooting May be Linked to Zodiac Gunman
DOC.TEXT: A note found near the victim of a pre-dawn shooting in Central Park on Thursday may link the attack to a ``Zodiac'' gunman who claimed to have shot three men, police said. A passerby notified police shortly after 5 a.m. that a man had been shot in Central Park. The victim, described only as a black man in his 20s, was hospitalized in critical condition with a gunshot wound to the chest, authorities said. A note was found nearby, said a police source speaking on condition of anonymity. The note's contents were not revealed, but the source said it led detectives to believe the Zodiac gunman may be linked to the Manhattan shooting. All four shootings occurred on Thursdays and before dawn. The gunman, in three cryptic notes referring to the signs of the Zodiac, claimed responsibility for three shootings since March 8. Two were in the same Brooklyn neighborhood, one in an adjoining Queens neighborhood. Although the gunman's notes indicated he had murdered his victims, the wounded men, two Hispanics and a white, survived. Detectives found the first note near the body of a man shot on May 31; the two other notes were mailed to the New York Post and the CBS's ``60 Minutes.'' The notes began ``This is the Zodiac,'' and contained the phrase ``The twelve sign will die when the belts in the heaven are seen,'' police said. The notes contained accurate descriptions of the victims, as well as the times, dates and places they were shot. Chief of Detectives Joseph Borrelli said that the gunman is not believed to be the man who, calling himself ``The Zodiac,'' claimed responsibility for as many as 40 killings in a series of notes sent to San Francisco-area newspapers from 1968 to 1987. The San Francisco Zodiac was never captured. A psychological profile of the New York gunman indicates he is a man of limited education, with a desperate need for attention. He probably lives alone or is a loner and may be unemployed, the police profile suggests.

DOC.HEAD: Controversial USDA Nominee Now Working for Federal Crop Agency
DOC.TEXT: James Cason, who was rejected last year by the Senate for a top job in the Agriculture Department, is working as deputy manager of the Federal Crop Insurance Corp., the agency said Thursday. Last November Cason, 35, asked the White House to withdraw his nomination as assistant secretary for natural resources and the environment. Cason's withdrawal effectively ended an eight-month battle over his nomination between President Bush and environmentalists, who were supported by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee. Opposition was led by the Sierra Club, National Wildlife Federation, Wilderness Society, League of Conservation Voters and National Audubon Society. The groups alleged Cason's record in several top Interior Department positions during the Reagan administration showed favoritism toward development of public lands, despite environmental concerns. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who cleared Cason for the new $79,200-a-year USDA job, had strongly supported the nomination and had characterized the opposition as ``both misguided and unfair.'' The Federal Crop Insurance Corp., which provides subsidized insurance to farmers to help protect them from losses due to drought and other natural disasters, said Cason joined the agency on May 6.

DOC.HEAD: NATO Summit to Look at Ways to Build New Security Order in Europe
DOC.TEXT: NATO leaders will consider practical ways of building a new order to guarantee peace in Europe at next month's summit, an alliance official said Thursday. NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner said that as the Western alliance moved away from a strategy based on confrontation with the Warsaw Pact, it would seek to include the Soviet Union as a ``full partner in the new order.'' The July 5-6 summit of NATO leaders in London comes at a time when the alliance is seeking to change its role to reflect the rapid moves toward German unification and the relaxing of East-West tensions following the democratic upheaval in the Soviet bloc. Woerner told the Anglo American Press Association of Paris that new security arrangements for Europe had to be developed within existing institutions, such as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the European Community. But he also called for an increased role for the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe (CSCE), which includes the United States, the Soviet Union, Canada, and East and Central European countries. Woerner said the NATO leaders at their summit would discuss setting up within the CSCE framework a verification center for arms control and a crisis solution center. Woerner also said there could be more regular meetings of the CSCE foreign ministers and heads of government and the establishment of a small secretariat. The CSCE process was established at a meeting in Helsinki, Finland, in 1975. Asked whether he thought a European Security Council should be established as part of this process, Woerner said he thought such a body might be set up later after European nations had some experience with the kinds of problems that developed. He said there was no need for any European code of conduct because it was already contained in the agreement that emerged from the Helsinki conference. The 1975 Helsinki Accords covered military security, economic cooperation and human rights issues. ``We have to make (the Helsinki agreement) a binding commitment,'' he said. ``We are all too tempted to speak about institutions when it is more important to emphasize ... human rights, freedom of expression, protection of minorities, the rule of law.'' Woerner, a former West German defense minister, said it was vital for a unified Germany to be a full member of NATO and its integrated military structure but with special arrangements to cover Soviet security concerns. He said the Soviets had been offered a lot of tangible security guarantees to drop their opposition to a unified Germany being a member of NATO. ``There is no reason for them to feel threatened,'' Woerner said. ``The Soviet Union needs partners and friends. Where else better to find them than in a satisfied, peaceful, stable Europe?'' He said developments the past year in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe had reduced the threat of surprise conventional or nuclear attack by the Soviets on NATO members. But he said the Western military alliance still was necessary because of the risk of instability in the Soviet Union, which remains the main military power on the Eurasian landmass. In reply to a question, Woerner said there was no need to extend NATO's area of operations to include such areas as the Middle East, although its members had cooperated there on an individual basis during the Iran-Iraq war. He said there had been no request that NATO consider playing a role in the Middle East.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Kills Spoils System
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 3 grafs after 5th graf pvs, Only Puerto, with reaction, comments.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court ordered an end to political patronage Thursday, ruling that federal, state and local government jobs generally may not be awarded based on party affiliation. The justices, by a 5-4 vote, said constitutionally protected rights are violated when people are denied government jobs, promotions or transfers because of politically partisan reasons. The decision reinstates a lawsuit by three Illinois residents against Gov. James Thompson and the state's other Republican leaders. The suit says Thompson has made party allegiance a requirement for 68,000 state jobs. While the ruling applies to all levels of government, city and county governments may feel the biggest impact because most federal and state government jobs are covered by civil service merit systems that have made patronage obsolete. Only Puerto Rico filed a ``friend-of-the-court'' brief to defend use of a patronage system. ``We're delighted,'' said Robert H. Chanin, a lawyer who represented the National Education Association in urging the justices to stamp out patronage. Chanin predicted little impact for federal jobs but added, ``It will have an impact at the state level. There are probably 40 states that have some type of comprehensive merit system, but perhaps as many as 10 states and Puerto Rico don't have such systems or have slippage in their merit systems. They rely primarily on what amounts to a patronage system.'' ``Our general, gut reaction is that the most impact will be in local governments _ among county and municipal employers,'' he said. ``It could affect a great number of jobs.'' The high court said partisanship may play a role in deciding who gets a government job only when political affiliation is an appropriate requirement, such as for high-level policy advisers. In a landmark 1976 ruling and a 1980 sequel, the high court significantly weakened political patronage, sometimes called the ``spoils system.'' Those rulings prohibited government employers from firing anyone _ even some policy-making and confidential government workers _ solely because of their political affiliation unless party loyalty is a requirement for effective performance. But those decisions dealt only with firings. Before Thursday, the court never had said that partisanship could not play a role in hiring, transfers and promotions as well. ``To the victor belongs the spoils that may be constitutionally obtained,'' Justice William J. Brennan wrote for the court. ``The First Amendment prevents the government, except in the most compelling circumstances, from wielding its power to interfere with its employees' freedom to believe and associate, or to not believe and not associate,'' he said. The Constitution's First Amendment protects freedom of speech and association. Brennan was joined by Justices Byron R. White, Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun and John Paul Stevens. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Antonin Scalia, Anthony M. Kennedy and Sandra Day O'Connor dissented. Scalia wrote for the four, ``The court simply refuses to acknowledge the link between patronage and party discipline, and between that and party success.'' ``It is self-evident,'' Scalia added, ``that eliminating patronage will significantly undermine party discipline; and that as party discipline wanes, so will the strength of the two-party system.'' The court also struck down government bosses' patronage powers in laying off and rehiring public employees. A federal appeals court had upheld the Illinois patronage policy in hiring, transfers and promotions but banned such considerations in layoffs and rehirings. It said layoffs are too similar to firings. In the Illinois case, two men and a woman who said their job status suffered because they did not vote in Republican primaries or give money to the party sued the governor, the state GOP and the heads of several state agencies. Cynthia Rutan said she had repeatedly been denied promotions to supervisory positions in the state Rehabilitative Services Department because she did not support Republican candidates. Franklin Taylor, an equipment operator, said he had been denied an Illinois Transportation Department transfer to another county because party officials opposed the move. James Moore said the state Corrections Department has refused to hire him since 1978 because he could not get the backing of key GOP leaders. The three sued for more than $1 billion in damages. Their suit also seeks to shift control of the state employment system to a court-appointed federal receiver. Lawyers for Thompson and state GOP leaders had argued that hiring political allies stimulates good government because the employee is likely to appreciate the job and, in turn, serve the public well. In other decisions, the court: _Ruled 5-4 in a case from Kansas and Missouri that states and consumers may not sue over alleged price fixing by energy producers. _Ruled 6-3 in a Chicago case that evidence obtained by police in a warrantless search of a home may be used in court if the officers were admitted by someone they reasonably, but mistakenly, believed had the authority to consent to the search. _Reinstated a former high school wrestling coach's 15-year-old libel lawsuit against an Ohio newspaper. The court said the allegedly libelous statements could be treated as assertions of fact, not opinion. But its 7-2 ruling did not appear to reduce significantly the free-speech protections courts traditionally have given to statements of opinion.

DOC.HEAD: Congress Fails to Override Bush Veto for 12th Straight Time
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 15th graf pvs, Thirteen Republicans, and 17th graf, The White, to show that not all Senate Democrats voted in May vote
DOC.TEXT: The Senate failed by two votes on Thursday to override President Bush's veto of a bill to broaden the political rights of millions of government workers. The 65-35 vote on the Hatch Act _ two short of the two-thirds majority needed to override _ marked the 12th time in 12 tries that Bush has prevailed over Congress in veto confrontations. Three Republicans who originally voted for the bill switched sides to support Bush on the veto vote. All 55 Senate Democrats voted to override the veto. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We are pleased that that vote was sustained. We felt that it incorrectly politicized the civil service.'' The president vetoed the bill last Friday, saying it ``would inevitably lead to repoliticizing the federal work force'' and ``destroy its essential political neutrality.'' The House, with nearly half of its Republicans bolting the administration, voted 327-93 on Wednesday to override Bush's veto. The legislation would have allowed 3 million federal and postal workers to, on their own time, attend political conventions and caucuses as delegates and to speak at rallies on behalf of candidates. It also would have removed a ban on federal workers holding offices in local, state or national political organizations or from soliciting donations from co-workers for federal employee and postal union political action committees. The workers would still have been prohibited from taking leaves of absence to seek elected public office or soliciting campaign contributions from the general public or on behalf of a specific candidate. One sponsor, Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., said after the vote he would try to extend the Hatch Act prohibitions on political activity for federal workers to presidential appointees. Senate GOP leaders portrayed the bill during the debate on override as an election-year bonanza for Democrats. Democrats ``want to get this bill passed before this election,'' said Minority Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. He said federal employee and postal union political action committees funneled 88 percent of their campaign contributions in the 1988 election to Democrats. ``The PAC heads of the Letter Carriers and others (unions) want more power to raise more money to give to Democrats,'' Dole said. ``That's how it works around here: money is power.'' Vincent Sombrotto, president of the 315,000-member Letter Carriers union, said Bush's ``strong-arm tactics'' to get Republicans to switch their votes ``places him in the same league as the world's most oppressive dictators.'' Thirteen Republicans had joined Senate Democrats in passing the bill by a potentially veto-overriding 67-30 majority in May. Sens. Alfonse D'Amato of New York, Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico and Trent Lott of Mississippi switched Thursday to support Bush's veto. ``It would subject employees to subtle coercion to join associations and to contribute, and I don't think most federal employees want to be solicited by campaign organizations or PACs,'' said Domenici. The White House also gained the support of Republican Sens. Pete Wilson of California and Kit Bond of Missouri. Both had missed the vote in May, along with one Democrat. Democrats attributed the loss to White House pressure on Republicans to maintain Bush's perfect record of overpowering Congress in veto showdowns in his first 17 months in office. ``All of us regret that the merits of this struggle were overshadowed by partisan appeals to preserve the president's unbroken string of consecutive vetoes sustained by Congress,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass. Pryor said he planned to immediately seek to extend Hatch Act prohibitions on campaigning to the hundreds of White House staff employees and presidential political appointees now exempt from the law. ``The government secretary who types letters should have at least the same rights as the Secretary of Labor for whom she works,'' Pryor said, noting Cabinet members frequently appear as draws at political fund-raisers. ``That federal employee who cannot stuff envelopes on his own volition can, in effect, now be required to write a partisan political speech for his boss, the agency head,'' Pryor said.

DOC.HEAD: Cherry Production Down
DOC.TEXT: Poor weather has sharply reduced this year's production of both tart and sweet cherries, the Agriculture Department said Thursday. Production of tart cherries is expected to be down 19 percent from the 1989 harvest to an estimated 224 million pounds. That would also be 5 percent less than the drought-damaged 1988 harvest. In Michigan, the largest producer, tart cherry production is expected to be down 8 percent from last year and 3 percent below the 1988 crop, the department said. ``Unseasonably warm weather in March got the crop off to a fast start,'' the report said. ``However, temperatures dropped and were below normal through much of April and May.'' The cold, wet weather during bloom ``discouraged bee activity, which caused poor pollination'' and a poor set of fruit, it said. High winds took many blossoms off the trees. Major states were forecast at: Colorado, 1 million pounds, up from 500,000 last year; Michigan, 175 million, down from 190 million; New York, 20 million, down from 31 million; Oregon, 7 million, down from 15 million; Pennsylvania, 3 million, down from 6 million; Utah, 14 million, down from 24 million; and Wisconsin, 3.8 million, down from 8.2 million. The crop of sweet cherries was forecast at 152,000 tons, down 22 percent from 1989 and 18 percent below the 1988 harvest. Department officials say sweet cherry production in the western states is mostly quoted by the ton, while eastern practice favors pounds. Since most production is in the West, the agency reports sweet cherries in tons. Sweet cherry production forecasts were reported for: California, 17,000 ton, down from 26,000 last year; Idaho, 2,000, down from 2,700; Michigan, 20,000, down from 25,000; Montana, 275, up from none reported last year; New York, 1,100, down from 1,350; Oregon, 50,000, down from 53,000; Pennsylvania, 200, down from 700; Utah, 1,600, down from 1,700; and Washington, 60,000, down from 84,000.

DOC.HEAD: NRC to End Regulation of Some Low-Intensity Radioactive Waste Disposal
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission has agreed to end controls on the disposal of some low-level radioactive wastes and materials at nuclear plants, hospitals and laboratories, officials said Thursday. The revised policy, scheduled to be announced next week, is likely to prompt a flood of requests from producers of such wastes that they be allowed to dispose of them the same way as conventional garbage. The commission has been grappling for years with a revision of federal requirements for low-level radioactive wastes and materials. Currently all such items must be given special handling and may be discarded only in special waste disposasl facilities. But according to sources in environmental organizations and on the commission staff who spoke on condition that their names not be used, a majority of the five commissioners agreed in recent weeks that wastes emitting radiation below a certain level should no longer be regulated by the agency. The commissioners approved the revised policy by indicating approval on the policy document, so-called notation voting, and planned no formal vote in an open meeting, agency officials said. Joe Fouchard, a commission spokesman, confirmed that a majority of the commission had approved the new policy and that details would be announced next week. He said the policy would establish a procedure to consider requests to exempt wastes from federal controls, but provided no figures on what the cutoff would be. In early 1989, the commission proposed that any radioactive wastes exposing a person to no more than 10 millirems per year should be exempt from special treatment requirements. The electric utility industry has proposed exempting materials emitting twice that amount. A chest X-ray from modern apparatus could be expected to yield an exposure of about 20 millirems. Typical exposures in the United States from background radiation, including cosmic rays and radioactive rocks, are about 200 millirems to 300 millirems per year. Jonathan Becker, who has followed the issue for Public Citizen, a Washington-based environmental and consumer group, said that the revised policy would allow as much as a third of the low-level radioactive wastes to be dumped into conventional landfills and through normal sewer systems. ``These efforts to deregulate the disposal of nuclear wastes illustrates the NRC's and the nuclear industry's inability to dispose of their radioactive garbage in a safe, sensible manner,'' said Becker. He estimated that the nuclear industry, hospitals and laboratories could to save $82 million a year because of reduced disposal costs. The utility and nuclear industries have argued that radiation from these wastes is too low to pose a health threat. ``The associated risks, if any, are quite small compared to other actual risks an individual faces every day,'' John J. Kerney, a member of the health physics committee of the Edison Electric Institute, wrote the commission.

DOC.HEAD: Value of Arms Sales to Third World Down 50 Percent, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Major suppliers like the United States and the Soviet Union have seen the value of their arms sales to Third World clients drop more than 50 percent in recent years, according to a new study by Congressional Research Service. The total value of arms deals with the Third World was $29.3 billion in 1989, down from $61.4 billion in the peak year 1982, said the study by the congressional agency. A copy of the study was made available to The Associated Press this week. Saudi Arabia and Iraq have been, by a wide margin, the top Third World arms buyers from 1982 to 1989, accounting for 14.6 percent and 14.1 percent, respectively, of the weapons transfers. The United States accounted for 26 percent of the arms sales agreements with the Third World, but its total deals fell from $9.3 billion in 1988 to $7.7 billion last year. The U.S. figures only include government-to-government sales agreements, excluding commercial sales for which the data is incomplete, the report said. But this exclusion does not affect the United States' ranking among other arms suppliers, it added. The value of U.S. commercial arms deliveries in fiscal 1989 fell to $1.61 billion from $3.3 billion the previous fiscal year, according to State Department figures. The Congressional Research Service study said France suffered a massive decline in its arms sales agreements, which dropped from $3.2 billion in 1988 to $300 million last year. West Germany, on the other hand, increased its sales from $83 million in 1988 to nearly $1.3 billion in 1989. The report attributed the decline to several factors. Third World clients are still absorbing massive arms deliveries they ordered in the 1970s and 1980s, and aren't buying expensive new weapons. Their purchases in recent years have included a greater proportion of spare parts and ammunition _ less costly than aircraft, tanks or ships. Secondly, many Third World countries are burdened by heavy debt and unwilling or unable to buy as many weapons as they did. Even oil-rich nations have cut back on some arms purchases as oil prices have dropped. Also, the end of the 8-year Iran-Iraq war in 1988 has reduced orders from the two combatants, which accounted for a large part of the massive increase in arms sales in the early and mid-1980s, the study found. The value of Soviet arms deals, which accounted for 38.4 percent of the weapons transfers to the Third World, fell from $14.7 billion in 1988 to $11.2 billion in 1989. In addition to a drop in demand, the decline in Soviet arms sales could also reflect a Kremlin decision to cut back its support for Third World clients who cannot pay in hard cash. Still, in 1989 the Soviets were the major supplier to eight of the 10 top Third World arms recipients, the study said. They were: Afghanistan, Angola, Vietnam, Syria, Iraq, Libya, Cuba and India. Iran's major supplier was China while Saudi Arabia's was Britain. Arms deals with Afghanistan more than tripled from 1982 to 1989, to $8.6 billion. Angola and Vietnam increased their arms purchase agreements 37 percent and 12 percent, respectively, in the same period. Syria's purchases declined 56.4 percent, Iraq's were down 43.4 percent and Libya's fell 30.3 percent, the report said. India posted a massive increase in the value of arms deliveries, up from $6.8 billion in the period 1982-85 to $13 billion in 1986-89, the report said. Its author, Richard Grimmett, noted that the decline of East-West tensions and the resulting cuts in defense spending by the world's major powers could increase competition among arms manufacturers to sell to the Third World to compensate for lost domestic markets.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Kill at Least 42 People in Turkish Coastal Provinces
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with at least 42 killed, details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A flood triggered by a violent rainstorm claimed at least 42 lives and left nine people missing in Turkey's northern provinces, the semi-official Anatolia news agency said Thursday. The seven-hour storm on Wednesday swept through the Black Sea coastal provinces of Trabzon and Giresun and hit Gumushane province, causing an estimated $150 million damage to homes, businesses and cropland. Anatolia reported 38 died in Trabzon and nine were missing. Floods also claimed three lives in Giresun and one in Gumushane. Public Works Minister Cengiz Altinkaya earlier told Anatolia that officials feared the death toll would increase because rescue teams had not yet reached several villages. Rescue teams on Thursday ferried 60 injured people from Akcaabat township to Trabzon, a city on the Black Sea, Anatolia said. Fifteen bridges collapsed, five others were heavily damaged and highways were blocked. Floods damaged communication and power lines in the area. At least 200 houses were still under water in Trabzon, newspapers reported. Government authorities seized privately owned trucks in the area for transportation of relief aid. Trabzon Gov. Enver Hizlan said a landslide blocked a river, diverting it into the Catak township. Authorities were trying to reach Catak by air, he said. Turkish television showed cars filled with water and people rowing boats in muddy waters covering the streets. Meteorologists said the rainfall was the worst in the region in 20 years. President Turgut Ozal and Premier Yildirim Akbulut flew to Trabzon on Thursday to supervise rescue operations. The Turkish Red Crescent sent tents and food to Trabzon, Anatolia said.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Prepares For War Against Medfly
DOC.TEXT: The Agriculture Department announced plans Thursday to prepare an environmental impact statement on the control of Mediterranean fruit flies. It was a signal that USDA is digging in for the long haul in a war against the medfly, a pest that poses a threat to the nation's commercial fruit and vegetables. ``If established on the U.S. mainland, agricultural losses of over $800 million annually could result,'' the announcement said. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said his agency is cooperating in two medfly eradication programs in California and Florida. But he said aerial application of bait laced with the pesticide malathion has met with considerable public demand for environmental analysis, especially in California. Glosser said that medfly control is emergency in nature and must be implemented quickly when an infestation is found. Thus, he said, it is important that an environmental statement be prepared so it will be in place for future medfly eradication programs. As a first step, the agency is asking for comments from the public, government agencies and the private industry about issues that should be addressed in the statement, he said. After review, USDA will schedule public meetings to gather fuirther comment. The comments can be submitted by Aug. 21 _ an original and three copies _ to Michael Werner, Deputy Director, Environmental Documentation, Biotechnology, Biologics and Environmental Protection, APHIS, USDA, Room 828, Federal Building, 6505 Belcrest Road, Hyattsville, Md. 20782. Refer to Docket No. 90-108.

DOC.HEAD: Legislation Announced to Toughen Aviation Security
DOC.TEXT: Senators on an anti-terrorism commission announced legislation Thursday to appoint security managers at high-risk airports and to require a system for notifying passengers of terrorist threats. The measure goes beyond Bush administration proposals for dealing with air terrorism. But sponsors said they expected unanimous support for the actions originally proposed by the presidential commission that looked into the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103. Representatives of some relatives of victims of the December 1988 bombing over Lockerbie, Scotland, said they support the legislation, which is to be introduced Friday. But a lawyer for another relatives group said it falls far short of what is needed. The Lockerbie bombing, blamed on unidentified terrorists, killed all 259 people aboard the London-New York flight and 11 people on the ground. ``It's essential that we proceed,'' said Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., a member of the now-defunct presidential commission. ``The terrorists are not giving up, and we can't either.'' ``It can no longer be business as usual with the FAA (Federal Aviation Administration) and the airlines,'' Lautenberg told a news conference on the Capitol lawn. Lautenberg and fellow commission members Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., and Rep. James Oberstar, D-Minn., all said they expected strong bipartisan support and Bush administration backing for the bill, which is subject to change as it moves through Congress. The Senate bill, to be matched by a similar House measure next week, would give special FAA managers responsibility for security at airports where terrorists are considered likely to operate. It also would require the FAA and the FBI to assess the security threat to domestic airports and set up security screening of mail and cargo. The bill would prohibit selective notification of government employees when there is a threat and would order that guidelines be set up for notifying the public when there is a credible threat against a flight. George Williams, representing one group of victims' relatives, told the news conference the bill would cover most relatives' concerns and he added, ``God speed this legislation.'' Michael Lemov, a Washington lawyer representing a rival relatives group, told reporters before the news conference that the legislation fails to create a public oversight board recommended by family members and sets up too many hurdles before the public can be notified of a threat. Lemov said Congress should create a separate agency to handle the aviation terrorist threat. Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner and FAA Administrator James Busey announced several initial steps to meet commission recommendations last week, including the appointment of top officials in the department to oversee aviation security. Skinner, at a speech Thursday, said he expects to submit to President Bush a full response to the commission report in July.

DOC.HEAD: Three Defense Post Nominees Approved
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Armed Services Committee approved on Thursday three of President Bush's nominees to top defense posts, including the choice of Lt. Gen. Carl W. Stiner to head the Special Operations Command. By a vote of 12-0, the panel sent to the full Senate the nomination of Gen. Michael J. Dugan as Air Force chief of staff, Adm. Frank B. Kelso as chief of Naval Operations and the selection of Stiner. The Senate is expected to approve the choices without dissent. The nomination of Stiner got caught up in a debate between Congress and the Defense Department over the role of Special Operations in intelligence gathering and civilian oversight of the elite unit formed in April 1987. ``It may well be that this senator feels that that issue is going to have to be resolved prior to such time as this committee completes the work on your nomination,'' Sen. John Warner of Virginia, ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee, said last month at Stiner's confirmation hearing. Warner and Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the panel, also expressed concerns about a proposal calling for elimination of civilian oversight of intelligence activities by Special Operations. Gen. James J. Lindsay, commander of the Special Operations Command, made the proposal in a memorandum to Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. In a telephone interview Thursday, Warner said he raised his concerns over the participation of the head of Special Operations in intelligence gathering and the issue has ``now been resolved.'' ``I spent a considerable amount of time analyzing this nomination not only in terms of the individual, but the general oversight of this important and vital segment of security forces,'' Warner said. The Republican senator also sought _ and received _ a letter from Powell describing the reasons for Stiner's nomination. In the end, Warner joined with other lawmakers in voting for the nomination.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Case Against CIA Skyjacker
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Thursday dismissed a 26-year-old skyjacking case against a man who argued the CIA ordered him to hijack the plane to Cuba as a cover to infiltrate that nation's intelligence service. Reinaldo Lopez-Lima ended up spending 24 years in Cuban prisons before he was released and returned to the United States in 1987. For two years he lived quietly outside Washington, D.C., ignored by federal prosecutors, but then was arrested on a 1969 indictment in the case. U.S. District Judge Kenneth Ryskamp ruled the government failed to give the 50-year-old defendant a speedy trial. ``I believe the government's conduct in this case can only be described as draconian,'' Ryskamp said. ``It's puzzling to the court why it is pursuing this.'' The judge noted Cuba offered to return Lopez-Lima in 1972, but the U.S. government refused. The defendant said he was thrilled to end his long ordeal but worried the Immigration and Naturalization Service will move to deport him. ``I'm very happy. I'm going to celebrate tonight,'' he said after the ruling. ``The only thing I'm afraid of now is that the INS will take some action against me.'' Diane Cossin, spokeswoman for the U.S. attorney's office, said prosecutors will decide in a few weeks if they will appeal the dismissal. According to the indictment, Lopez-Lima and Enrique Castillo Hernandez held a gun to pilot Richard Lee Wright and forced him to fly to Cuba from Key West in a small plane in February 1964. The plan, Lopez-Lima said, was to convince Castro's government that he and Hernandez were CIA defectors. Once inside Cuba, they were supposed to assist anti-Castro forces. Lopez-Lima and Hernandez landed in Cuba but failed to win the Cubans' confidence and wound up in jail. Lopez-Lima stayed in Castro's prisons and work camps for 24 years; Hernandez was imprisoned for 16 years before returning to Miami in the 1980 Mariel boatlift. He was later slain. Lopez-Lima won a major victory in a pretrial hearing two weeks ago when Ryskamp allowed him to introduce evidence of his CIA connections and the agency's authorization for operations that included hijackings. The judge cited a 1955 national security order that gave broad powers to the CIA, including the right to break U.S. laws. That order was repealed in 1981. Ryskamp also said Lopez-Lima made a good case of why he should be allowed to testify that he was working for the CIA when he hijacked the plane. According to CIA records, the people named in Lopez-Lima's court documents as having sanctioned the hijacking worked for the CIA at the time, Ryskamp said. The government conceded Lopez-Lima's CIA contacts were valid but said he wasn't instructed to hijack a plane to Cuba because his contacts had no authority to give such an order.

DOC.HEAD: Business Leaders See World Trade Accords as Summit Goal
DOC.TEXT: World business leaders told President Bush on Thursday that the main aim of next month's seven-country summit should be to ensure a successful end in December to four years of global negotiations on trade. The long-term talks among 100 countries are known as the ``Uruguay round.'' They are stalled by a deadlock between the United States and the 12 governments of the European Economic Community over cutting subsidies on farm products. These subsidies cost taxpayers and consumers in the United States and other industrial countries an estimated $245 billion a year. ``I think he (Bush) accepts that the deadlock should be broken in Houston,'' said Joseph E. Connor, chairman of Price Waterhouse World Firm and a leader of the group that went to the White House. ``At least that was the message we were trying to convey to him, that if it is not broken, then there is hardly time for the (governments) ... to conclude the round in December, and we do believe the round must conclude in December.'' Bush meets in Houston, Texas, July 9 to 11, with the leaders of Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy, Canada and the Europoean group. The Reagan and Bush administrations have insisted on a pledge eventually to get rid of farm subsidies that directly affect world trade. The Europeans want a deal on all kinds of support for farm products. The negotiations also aim at accords on other important issues, including the trade in services, from air travel to zoo keeping. Services now provide more jobs in the United States and other advanced countries than traditional manufacturing. ``Governments must be under no illusion that, without substantial and substantive liberalization of market access and reform of the multilateral rules which govern world trade and their extension to new areas, business will simply not consider the Uruguay round a success,'' said the statement given to Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Political Experts Question Impact of Patronage Ruling
With AM-Scotus Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Political observers question whether the U.S. Supreme Court's ruling on patronage hiring in Illinois would succeed in uprooting the old rule: To the victor belong the spoils. The court cleared the way for trial of a federal lawsuit filed on behalf of three Illinois residents who claimed that a patronage system run by Republican Gov. James R. Thompson's administration had prevented them from being hired, promoted or transferred in state jobs. In the past, Thompson has acknowledged giving preference to Republicans in state hiring when choosing among equally qualified candidates; he maintains the practice ensures that his policies are carried out. After Thursday's ruling, he denied the lawsuit's claims and declared that the matter will have to be settled in court. ``I think this will strike a severe blow at whatever is left of political parties in America,'' he said. Mary Lee Leahy, a lawyer and Democratic Party activist who filed the lawsuit, said the ruling would free state employees from concerns about how their political activity _ or lack of it _ would affect their jobs. ``The patronage system just isn't going to be, certainly not as we know it,'' she said. ``The average state employee is going to be free to do or not do what he or she wishes politically.'' But other observers were skeptical about the ruling's potential impact. Paul Green, a professor of political science at Governors State University in University Park, said a smart politician ``will always find a way to get around any procedure that the court or the Legislature will place upon him.'' He added: ``This will just make it a little more difficult to put your people in.'' Officials in other states pooh-poohed the possible effects, too. Andrew Crane, executive director of the Massachusetts Ethics Commission, said: ``There is not a consensus about whether patronage is appropriate or not. ... Many people have said it's inappropriate. Many other people say what is wrong with hiring political supporters if they are qualified for the job.'' Illinois labor officials noted that the union contract covering state employees bars consideration of political factors in promotion, but enforcement depends on employees' willingness to blow the whistle on violations. ``Unless there is someone there to protest, it's still going to continue to go on,'' said Henry Bayer, associate director of Illinois Council 31 of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees. A total of 68,268 employees are under the governor's control, according to the state comptroller's office. Both parties in Illinois have a long track record of political hiring. ``When you go back to the first governors of Illinois, the first mayors, patronage has played an important role,'' Green said. In Cook County, which includes Chicago, a consent decree to bar politically motivated hiring has been in effect since 1979. The ban is known as the ``Shakman decree,'' after Chicago lawyer Michael Shakman, who challenged the patronage system operated under the late Chicago mayor, Richard J. Daley. But political observers say the Shakman decree effectively ``locked in'' many of the patronage workers who were installed in government jobs by the county's Democratic organization before the decree took effect. ``To some extent, you might have a situation where people would be protected in their current jobs, and that might hurt a future administration since Thompson has had the chance to make these appointments for 14 years,'' said David Everson, a political scientist at Sangamon State University in Springfield.

DOC.HEAD: Former Bingo Lobbyist Says He Gave Cash To Several State Lawmakers
DOC.TEXT: A former bingo lobbyist testified Thursday that he gave $32,000 in cash to Gov. Ned McWherter's 1986 campaign and thousands more to state legislators debating changes in the law. James V. Long, testifying in the federal conspiracy and gambling trial of Democratic state Rep. Tommy Burnett and two co-defendants, said he didn't disclose the gifts, as required by state law. Long, testifying under a plea bargain, was the government's first major witness. McWherter, who was speaker of the Tennessee House when the gifts were allegedly made, was vacationing in Florida and unavailable to comment, said spokesman Ken Renner. Renner said a quick review of the Democratic governor's financial disclosure records showed Long contributed less than $4,000 to McWherter's gubernatorial campaign. However, the spokesman didn't rule out the possibility Long may have concealed some donations. Burnett, 47, is charged in a 10-count indictment with illegal gambling, conspiracy, mail fraud and perjury. His co-defendants, Knoxville bingo operator Virginia Hurst and Columbia businessman E.E. Shutt, are accused of illegal gambling and conspiracy. Long said the cash gifts ranged from $6,000 to Democratic state Sen. Jim Lewis to $100 to $200 to Democratic Lt. Gov. John Wilder. Lewis said he received contributions from Long, but said all came through normal, proper channels. ``Jim Long said he gave me $6,000? No,'' Lewis said. ``He gave me $400 at a fund-raiser. I was selling $100 tickets, and he bought four. ``Jim Long did buy my supper occasionally and Jim Long had given me at one time maybe $500, aside from the $400, at another fund-raiser. But that's the most he gave me,'' Lewis said. Long, who was also named in the indictment, has pleaded guilty to setting up and running illegal bingo games. ``I knew the money I was making was illegal. All the money I was spending was illegal, and I didn't report it,'' said Long. He claimed that in 1986 he made $150,000 to $250,000 from bingo. Long told defense attorney Bob Lynch under cross-examinationhe was just following unwritten ground rules for lobbyists when he gave the legislators cash. ``I didn't change the rules when I came to Nashville, I just followed along,'' he said. Long was the fourth prosecution witness in the case. Long pleaded guilty earlier this year in U.S. District Court in Nashville and Memphis and in a state court in Memphis for his role in setting up and operating illegal bingo games. He testified Thursday that his plea bargain calls for him to receive no more than five years in prison on each charge, with most of the sentences to run simultaneously.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Early AIDS Treatment Prevents Illness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `The demonstrations ...,' to UPDATE with 50 protesters arrested.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX4
DOC.TEXT: Quick treatment with the drug AZT in the earliest stages of AIDS infection can significantly slow the lethal disease, according to research presented Thursday at the Sixth International Conference on AIDS. The study appears to provide the strongest evidence yet that early intervention can stall the emergence of AIDS in people infected with HIV, the AIDS virus. ``We have to come to the conclusion that the greatest advantage has to accrue with early intervention,'' said Dr. Margaret Fischl. ``It has to occur as early as possible in HIV infection.'' Fischl, a researcher at the University of Miami, pioneered the use of AZT in people who already have AIDS. However, most infected people are still outwardly healthy. So Fischl and other teams around the country have been exploring the risks and advantages of giving the medicine before AIDS infection reaches its final stages. The conference opened Wednesday amid angry protests by thousands of demonstrators frustrated over the slow pace of progress in controlling the disease. The demonstrations continued Thursday as several hundred protesters marched by government offices in San Francisco's Civic Center. About 50 protesters were arrested after they blocked a busy intersection. Another group rushed into the lobby of a building housing the state insurance commissioner, but left a short time later without incident. Fischl's recommendation is likely to be controversial. During the past year, some researchers have begun to question whether AZT, the only approved AIDS drug, should be reserved for use during the later stages of the disease. The medicine interferes with the reproduction of HIV. When given to people with AIDS, the drug loses its punch within two or three years as the virus becomes resistant to it. Some doctors believe that if given early in the disease, AZT will be powerless to slow the disease once AIDS develops. Fischl's conclusions were based on patients who were infected with HIV but had not developed any major symptoms of AIDS. Two hundred received placebos for a year and then switched to AZT for eight more months. Two hundred fifty-one others took AZT for the entire period. She found that significantly fewer progressed to AIDS if they got the drug without delay. Several other reports presented Thursday focused on how the infection is transmitted. Dr. Nancy Padian of the University of California, San Francisco, found that women who have sex with AIDS-infected men are 12 times more likely to catch the virus than are men who are sexually exposed to infected women. Her research, based on 58 male sex partners of infected women and 269 women partners of infected men, supports the widely held belief that the virus spreads more ``efficiently'' from men to women than from women to men. During her study, only one man caught the virus from his female sex partner. This couple reported having intercourse without condoms more than 1,000 times over seven years. Among other research presented: _Dr. Rachel Royce of the University of California, Berkeley, reported circumstantial evidence that cigarette smoking may speed up the development of AIDS in people who are already infected with HIV. The study, based on 1,000 infected gay men, found that smokers were almost twice as likely as non-smokers to develop AIDS or die over 4{ years. _HIV-infected mothers run a high risk of passing the virus to their babies before birth. Now, a Soviet study has found that infected babies can also pose a hazard to their uninfected mothers. Dr. Irina Kuznetsova from the Central Research Institute of Epidemiology in Moscow reported on babies who got infected from contaminated needles in hospitals. They found that 11 of 18 women who breast-fed their infected babies contracted the virus. They attributed this to cracks in the mothers' nipples that allowed the virus to enter their bodies. _Dr. Tom Peterman from the U.S. Centers for Disease Control reported that bisexuality appears to be an important source of AIDS infection in the Army. He and Army researchers reviewed 43 soldiers who developed AIDS infections. Twenty-one admitted to high-risk activities, and of these 18 said they had sexual contact with other men. Most of these men had sex with women, as well.

DOC.HEAD: US Urges American Travelers To Mideast To Be Cautious
DOC.TEXT: The State Department, in a follow-up to President Bush's suspension of the U.S. dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, Thursday urged Americans traveling to the Middle East and elsewhere to exercise ``extra caution.'' Deputy spokesman Richard Boucher attributed the advisory to rising tensions in the area but said he was not aware of any specific threats. He said it was possible that the tension might increase as a result of Bush's announcement but he stressed that there were other reasons for the warning as well. He recalled that on May 31, the day after the abortive attack by the Palestine Liberation Front on beaches near Tel Aviv, the Department had said it was concerned about tensions in the region and that terrorists had threatened to attack American citizens or interests.

DOC.HEAD: Victims Remembered in Series of Services
DOC.TEXT: A minister, eulogizing one of eight people slain in gunman's rampage at an auto loan office, asked mourners Thursday why bad things happen to good people. ``Tragedy is not God's will,'' the Rev. Dennis Bratton said, answering his own question at the funeral of Denise Sapp Highfill, the 36-year-old wife of a police detective. ``God is just as outraged by this as we are.'' There were few other answers. Police said they still don't know why James Edward Pough, 42, burst into the General Motors Acceptance Corp. office Monday and began firing. He also wounded five others before killing himself. Pough, who had a history of criminal violence and whose car had been repossessed by GMAC, still owed the finance company $6,394 on it, The Florida Times-Union reported Thursday. A state lawmaker said a bill would be drafted plugging the loophole in Florida law that allowed Pough to legally buy firearms despite his criminal record. The law's weakness ``can't be tolerated,'' said Rep. Ron Silver. Although Pough pleaded guilty to aggravated assault in 1971 in the shooting death of another man, adjudication was withheld, allowing him to legally purchase weapons after serving his five-year probation. A motorcade of 200 cars, including about 25 police vehicles, left the church headed Mrs. Highfill's burial at Oaklawn Cemetery. The funeral was one of six held Thursday. Other services were held for slain GMAC employee Lee Simonton, 33; Janice David, 40; Barbara Duckwall Holland, 45; Cynthia Perry, 30; and Julia White Burgess, 42. Services will be Friday for Sharon Louise Hall, 45 and arrangements are pending for Drew Woods, 38. Mayor Tommy Hazouri said a citywide memorial service will be held Friday at the Jacksonville Convention Center and GMAC is planning a service Saturday. The five wounded in the shooting are still hospitalized, but doctors expect them to survive. GMAC will close its Baymeadows office where the seven workers and a customer were slain. It plans to move into temporary quarters and open a permanent office in Jacksonville in six to nine months, officials said. The Times-Union quoted sources saying GMAC notified Pough of the amount he owed but never pursued collection. ``It was a business decision, and beyond that, I'm not discussing it,'' said Patricia Molloy, a GM spokeswoman. Pough bought a 1988 Pontiac Grand Am for about $9,700 in September 1988 and financed it through GMAC, but state records do not indicate the finance charges. GMAC has a policy against releasing company records. In January, Pough voluntarily surrendered the car because he was having trouble making the payments. When GMAC took the car back, it was sold Feb. 22 to a Gainesville car dealer, the newspapers said. GMAC notified Pough in March that he still owned $6,394.

DOC.HEAD: Perrier Trying To Regain U.S. Market It Lost During Recall
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `U.S. distributor...,' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comments from Perrier spokeswoman. Picks up 7th graf, `Experts say...' Also moving on business wires. Hellen is cq in 5th graf.
DOC.HEAD: LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Perrier is back. But whether the French bottled water will recapture its once sparkling position in the U.S. market isn't clear.
