Hotels and restaurants, the staple of Perrier's sales, stopped carrying the water when benzene contamination forced the company to recall it worldwide on Feb. 9. Many haven't taken it back. ``None of our customers want it. I think the recall really frightened people,'' said Mark Schachern, manager of the Washington Square Bar and Grill in San Francisco. Some distributors and industry officials say Perrier has received a tepid reception from hotels and restaurants since it was reintroduced in the United States in late April. The return included a $25 million advertising campaign and such publicity events as a give-away of cases of the familiar pear-shaped bottles in New York's Central Park and Rockefeller Center. ``There's still a certain amount of reluctance on the part of many hotels and restaurants,'' said Hellen Berry of Beverage Marketing Corp., an industry trade group. ``Many customers are happy with what's been substituted.'' Perrier Group of America Inc., based in Greenwich, Conn., said it had no concrete sales figures for the year. But company spokeswoman Jane Lazgin said, ``We are right on target for where we should be at this time.'' Lazgin admitted that the response from restaurants since the reintroduction hasn't been what the company hoped it would be. ``We are working hard to regain our accounts. But it won't be a quick fix. We have a lot of work to do,'' she said. Experts say Perrier probably has done better at recapturing lost shelf space in supermarkets because it was able to offer its other brands _ Poland Spring, Calistoga and Arrowhead _ as alternatives. Perrier distributors agree, but admit that many customers still are reluctant to take Perrier back. The Pepsi-Cola Buffalo Bottling Corp. in Buffalo, N.Y., a Perrier distributor, is sending its salespeople to supermarkets it once served in the Buffalo area to help boost customer confidence. ``We feel we owe it to them to meet face to face and explain that it's O.K. to take Perrier back,'' said manager Scott Pastor. Pastor said his Perrier customers now number less than the 800 restaurants and supermarkets he had before the recall, but he declined to be specific or release recent sales figures. Source Perrier SA recalled its water from worldwide distribution after tests showed traces of naturally occurring benzene, a cancer-causing chemical, in its product in several countries. The contamination stemmed from improper filtration of the water, the company said. Its absence from the American market was a blow to Perrier, which built the U.S. sparkling mineral water market nearly from scratch in the 1970s, said Berry of the industry group. In 1989, Perrier posted U.S. sales of $102 million. That accounted for 4.4 percent of the industry's $2.3 billion in U.S. sales. The company has put the cost of the recall at $78 million. Berry said competitors took advantage of Perrier's absence to increase their own market share. ``We're in places we never were before,'' said Sandy Klinzman, a spokeswoman for Evian Waters of France, which also is the parent company of Saratoga Bottled Mineral Water. Klinzman claimed sales of Evian and Saratoga water increased dramatically this year, but declined to release any figures. ``Anytime you have a major player like Perrier gone everyone benefits,'' she said. There are about 450 water bottling plants in the United States producing more than 600 different labels of drinking water, natural water and spring water, according to Bevmark Inc., a Los Angeles-based consulting firm. In addition, there are about 50 brands of imported waters, Bevmark said.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Weathery On Summer's First Day
DOC.TEXT: Summery weather prevailed for much of the nation Thursday, the first day of summer, but thunderstorms and rainshowers were scattered from the Southeast to the southern Plains and across upper Midwest. Strong, slow-moving thunderstorms threatened local flooding in parts of south-central Tennessee, northern Alabama, northwest Arkansas and northeast Oklahoma. In Alabama, lightning strikes knocked out electric power in Blountsville and Brooksville, and lightning destroyed a house and caused many other fires near Snead. At noon, rainshowers and thunderstorms were scattered from the northwest two thirds of New York, across northern Maine, southwest Pennsylvania, the southern and central Florida Peninsula, from southeast Tennessee across northwest Georgia and Alabama, along the Louisiana coast and the central Texas Gulf Coast. Rainshowers and thunderstorms also reached from west central Mississippi across the northwest third of Arkansas into eastern Oklahoma, as well as southeast Colorado, northeast New Mexico and the Texas Panhandle, the Oklahoma Panhandle and northwest Oklahoma, western Kansas, much of Nebraska, Iowa, southern South Dakota and eastern Wyoming. Rainshowers and thunderstorms reached from northern Minnesota across northwest Wisconsin and upper Michigan, as well as along the central coast of Oregon. Heavier rainfall during the 6 hours ending at 2 p.m. EDT included more than 2 inches at Fayetteville, Ark., and two-thirds of an inch at Columbus, Miss. High temperature records for the day were set in Augusta, Ga., where the 102-degree high broke the record of 102 set in 1924, and in Charleston, S.C., where the 100-degree reading beat the 1988 mark by three degrees. The low temperature for the Lower 48 state Thursday morning was 33 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 50 degrees at Casper, Wyo., to 110 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Talks End for Week, Little Progress
DOC.TEXT: Bush administration officials and congressional leaders ended budget negotiations for the week Thursday with both sides saying they had accomplished little. ``What I'm fearful of is we're in some kind of stalemate,'' said Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, one of the Republican negotiators, as the sixth week of the closed-door sessions ended. The $50.7 billion deficit-reduction package that the White House presented on Wednesday, the first proposal of the talks, went over badly with Democrats. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., called it ``deficient.'' House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif., called it ``inadequate.'' And it prompted Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn., of the Senate Budget Committee to distribute an analysis that called it ``a fiscal morning of the living dead.'' That was a reference to the plan's similarity to the rejected budget President Bush presented in January. ``We're in a negotiation,'' White House budget chief Richard Darman said of the Democratic criticisms. ``Everybody understands that.'' During two bargaining sessions Thursday, Democrats attacked the latest White House plan and administration officials defended it. But Democrats did not offer a proposal of their own, and some of them insisted that the administration come back with a more serious proposal. ``The ball lies semi-deflated in the president's court,'' said Sasser. The administration plan claims $444 billion in savings over five years. It relies heavily on cuts in benefit programs like Medicare. Democrats say more savings are needed, and argue that deeper reductions in defense are needed. The talks are scheduled to resume Monday.

DOC.HEAD: New Polish Ambassador to Washington Named
DOC.TEXT: Poland named Kazimierz Dziewanowski, a longtime opposition journalist as its new ambassador to the United States on Wednesday, the state news agency reported. Dziewanowski, 59, was assistant editor of Soldarity's weekly newspaper, Tygodnik Solidarnosc, in 1981 when the weekly was edited by Tadeusz Mazowiecki, now Poland's prime minister. The ambassador-designate also participated in talks in 1989 that led to the legalization of Solidarity and the holding of largely democratic elections in Poland. President Wojciech Jaruzelski nominated Dziewanowski to the post, according to the PAP news agency. Dziewanowski succeeds Jan Kinast, who has served as ambassador to Washington since March 1988 when Poland and the United States restored full diplomatic relations following a five-year interruption. Dziewanowski said in an interview Wednesday evening that he expects to take up his post sometime in mid-July. ``I think it is very important to try to change the image of our embassy in Washington because it was not a very good image. I am not for making any accusations, but it was so, and now we would like to change it,'' he said. He said he planned to work in two directions to improve Poland's image. ``The first is American public opinion, Congress, mass media, intellectual circles and so on; and the second is (with) Americans of Polish descent. ``We would like very much to get into close contact with them and to help to improve things which were done very badly in the last 40 years. This is very important,'' he said. Dziewanowski joked that he was a little daunted by the assignment. ``If you would like to know the truth, I would say that between the Vistula and the Potomac you could hardly find another man as frightened as I am now. This is a very important job.'' But he added that along with other new appointees to the embassy staff, he expected to be able to improve Poland's image.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Allows Ex-Nazi to Stay in United States
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department said Thursday it will allow a man who admitted being a Nazi SS guard at a concentration camp during World War II to remain in the United States because of his rapidly declining health. On Wednesday, an immigration judge ordered the deportation of Albert Ensin, 68, of Stoughton, Mass., after he admitted at a hearing that he was an SS guard at Auschwitz-Birkenau concentration camp between 1941 and 1943. But the Justice Department said it will allow Ensin, who suffered a series of debilitating strokes, to stay. At the deportation hearing before a U.S. Immigration Court judge in Boston, Ensin also admitted that he participated in the mass persecution of concentration camp inmates. A native of Lithuania, Ensin entered the United States in 1975 as a refugee but never became a U.S. citizen.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
At Least 25,000 People Killed in Earthquake in Northern Iran
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to combine urgent series, a0756-a0760-a0762, with minor editing to trim and conform. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX3, TOK17
DOC.TEXT: An earthquake shattered northern Iran early Thursday, killing at least 25,000 people and injuring tens of thousands, Iranian officials announced. The quake shortly after midnight Thursday demolished scores of villages and towns and buried thousands of people in their homes. The Iranian mission to the United Nations, which released the casualty toll, said it would likely rise further as rescuers reached more remote areas. The earthquake was at least as bad as the quake registering 7.7 on the Richter scale that struck Iran on Sept. 16, 1978, killing at least 25,000 people. The temblor measured 7.3 on the Richter scale of ground motion, the Geophysics Center at Tehran University said. The U.S. Geological Survey, however, measured it at 7.7. At least a dozen aftershocks shook the region within two hours after the quake. The earthquake struck at 12:30 a.m. and was centered 125 miles northwest of Tehran, near the Caspian Sea, the official news agency IRNA reported. It shook buildings and shattered windows in Tehran, but apparently caused no deaths in the capital. In the neighboring Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, the temblor slightly damaged some older buildings in Baku but caused no casualties, the Soviet news agency Tass said. The Iranian Ambassador to the United Nations, Kamal Kharrazi, told Cable News Network that Iran badly needs medical equipment, blood, blankets and medicine. ``I understand that international organizations are trying their best to bring some of this equipment and medicine.'' Scenes shown on state television and monitored in Cyprus showed young men frantically clawing at debris from flattened concrete buildings in Rasht, 175 miles northwest of Tehran with a population of 189,000 people. Occasionally, they carried away someone on a stretcher. Bulldozers and cranes lifted away larger pieces of debris. Earlier Thursday, a statement by the Iranian Cabinet said the ``sad, painful and horrible tragedy has so far claimed 10,000 lives and left thousands of others wounded.'' The announcement carried by the Islamic Republic News Agency placed all government organizations ``on full alert,'' and ordered an air bridge set up between Tehran and the stricken areas to evacuate survivors. Landslides blocked rescuers on the ground, and bad weather hindered helicopters trying to airlift supplies and victims, IRNA said. Many people remained buried in the debris, it said, and several hundred Revolutionary Guards were flown from Tehran after nighfall to join rescue teams. Iran's spiritual leader, Ali Khamenei, called the disaster a ``divine test'' and urged the bereaved residents of the stricken provinces ``to pass this test with pride through patience and cooperation.'' More than half of those killed and injured Thursday were in Zanjan province. The second-hardest hit was Gilan province, IRNA said in dispatches monitored in Cyprus. The victims included at least 1,000 people killed in one village in Zanjan province, Ab-Dar, the news agency said. Also killed were 768 people in Qazvin just 80 miles northwest of Tehran. In Zanjan alone, 73 villages and towns were affected, IRNA said. Many were leveled. IRNA said the quake triggered landslides that blocked main roads. Dozens of rescue vehicles, including trucks carrying food supplies and ambulances, were stuck on the roads, it said. Telephone lines and electricity and water supplies were cut in Zanjan and Gilan, which have a combined population of 2.7 million. Communications with Tehran from the outside world also were difficult. In Ab-Dar, the televison showed mountains of rubble, which a speaker said were all that was left of apartment buildings. They appeared to have been shaken off their foundations, collapsing like a deck of cards. The camera zoomed in on a stuffed rabbit and a shoe lying in a street carpeted with dust. Women in black chadors flanked by weeping children camped out in public squares, afraid to return to their homes in case of aftershocks. A dam south of Rasht burst, flooding the surrounding area, IRNA said. Hospitals appealed for blood donations and helicopters and transport planes delivered thousands of tents and blankets. They also carried rice, tea, sugar, cheeses and canned food to the area, IRNA said. Three U.S.-made C-130 transport planes shuttled between Tehran and Rasht to carry the injured to hospitals in the capital, it said. State-run Iran Air ordered special flights to carry the injured. Khamenei and President Hashemi Rafsanjani flew to the area to supervise relief operations. Rafsanjani declared three days of mourning and ordered all state agencies to be ready to provide help. The United States offered humanitarian assistance to Iran and President Bush sent a message of condolence to Rafsanjani. The message was delivered to Iran by another, unidentified country since the United States does not have diplomatic relations with Tehran. The region is prone to earthquakes. A quake registering 6.9 on the Richter scale struck nearby Soviet Armenia on Dec. 7, 1988, killing 25,000 people. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. A reading of 7 on the scale indicates a major earthquake capable of widespread heavy damage. Eight is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage.

DOC.HEAD: Man Arrested After Missing Girl's Mother Forced Grand Jury Probe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `Phelps was...,' to CORRECT that jail in Adel sted Perry, UPDATE with bail set at $100,000.
DOC.TEXT: A man faces an extradition hearing after being charged with kidnapping in the 1987 disappearance of a 9-year-old girl whose mother forced a grand jury investigation. David C. Phelps, 26, a longtime suspect in the case, was arrested in Perry, Iowa, on Wednesday night, special prosecutor James D. Smith said Thursday. Phelps, a former Norfolk resident, was indicted Tuesday. ``As far as I'm concerned the grand jury was somewhat conservative but I understand why,'' said Joyce Cutshall, whose daughter Jill remains missing. ``But it means there will be a trial and everything that happened to Jill should and will, I feel, be told in the end of it.'' Jill disappeared Aug. 13, 1987, from this northeast Nebraska prairie city about 110 miles northwest of Omaha. She had been waiting alone on the steps of her baby sitter's home in Norfolk. Her clothes were found in a wildlife area three months later. The case attracted national attention, including a report on CBS's ``60 Minutes.'' Thousands of fliers with Jill's picture have been distributed throughout North America. Frustrated by what she considered lax police work, Ms. Cutshall began a petition drive and forced a grand jury investigation. Under state law, a court is required to convene a grand jury if presented with petitions from at least 10 percent of the county's voters who participated in the last gubernatorial election. Ms. Cutshall needed 1,024 signatures and collected 1,471. A Madison County grand jury began work April 30. Phelps was being held in the Dallas County Jail in Adel, pending an extradition hearing, which may be held as soon as Monday, Smith said. Bond was set at $100,000. In an interview Thursday, Ms. Cutshall said she is ``99 percent sure'' that her daughter is dead, but hoped the indictment and a trial would lead to further investigation into her daughter's whereabouts. ``It's a daily thought for me. I know Jill is very, very near to me _ within a 20-mile radius of me _ and knowing that there are people who know where she is at and I don't is becoming very, very frustrating,'' she said. Ms. Cutshall said has no doubt that her petition effort was worth it. ``In retrospect, a couple of months ago, I looked back at what I did and I was kind of surprised ... I was real surprised,'' she said. She said it was the only thing she could do for her missing daughter. ``That was my last avenue, my last road to take,'' she said. A private investigator who has worked on the case for two years promised to continue to search for Jill. ``This means the fight has just now really started,'' said Roy Stephens, director of investigations for the Omaha-based Missing Youth Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Dog Biscuits Arrive At Statehouse
DOC.TEXT: A truckload of dog biscuits from California arrived Wednesday at the Statehouse in a protest of what critics call substandard commercial dog kennels in Kansas. More than 100 protesters gathered at the Capitol steps as the yellow rented truck, with a sign reading ``No More Puppy Mills'' on the side, pulled up. ``We have brought a message to the governor and state attorney general of Kansas,'' said organizer Ellen Katzman of Sonora, Calif., as she opened the back of the truck. Each box of dog biscuits in the truck was stamped with ``No More Puppy Mills.'' ``We will not tolerate any more sick dogs coming into California pet shops from the state of Kansas,'' she said. ``Anytime you ship a sick puppy to the state of California you ship grief and you ship heartache,'' she told the crowd. ``Puppy mills'' is the term used by animal-rights activists for commercial kennels that ship sick dogs and cats to out-of-state pet stores. California animal-rights activists' war of words with Gov. Mike Hayden and Attorney General Bob Stephan escalated last week when Stephan said the complaints about so-called puppy mills in Kansas were coming from ``bozos from California.'' Stephan said Tuesday the issues were being obscured by the rhetoric. ``I accept part of the blame for this because I spoke in anger,'' he told a news conference. He also obtained a search warrant for a kennel that he said was not up to state standards, but denied that the crackdown was prompted by the protests from California. Delivery of the 40 boxes of dog biscuits was prompted partly by a Kansas law passed this year that spells out penalties for people who trespass on animal research facilities to take pictures. The Californians say the law protects puppy mills, but Stephan says it does not apply to commercial kennels.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Study Finds Less Channel-Switching on Networks Than On Rivals
DOC.TEXT: The three major networks, which have steadily lost audiences to cable since 1980, released a CBS study Thursday that shows viewers in four cities stay tuned to network TV 2{ times longer than to cable. The reaction from a leading cable industry group was immediate. ``I think they're trying to discredit cable as a growing and important source of programming for viewers,'' said Robert Alter, president of the Cable Television Advertising Bureau. Made public by the new Network Television Association, the study of prime-time viewing in the week of Nov. 6-12 last year was based in part on Nielsen data from 702 homes in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Philadelphia. The study analyzed viewing of the three networks, Fox Broadcasting, and six major cable networks _ the USA Network, the Family Channel, ESPN, MTV, and Ted Turner's Cable News Network and TBS Superstation in Atlanta. It found that viewers, including those with remote-control channel switchers some call ``zappers,'' are apt to change cable channels almost three times more than they do network channels. ``I think zapping is a fact of life ... but it happens a lot less on network television than on cable _ that's what the study shows,'' said Tom Delaney, CBS' director of marketing research. He spoke at a news conference held by the network association, formed by CBS, NBC and ABC in April to represent them in their battle to keep viewers and advertisers from defecting to cable and independent stations. CBS' four-city study said that uninterrupted viewing of networks averages 27 minutes per tune-in, compared to 19 minutes for Fox stations and 11 minutes for cable. The study will be sent to advertisers in a bid to convince them that their commercials are more likely to be seen on the networks. The study's release comes as advertisers prepare for so-called ``upfront'' buying of television time for next season, with advance purchases of network time expected to reach $4 billion. The networks will be competing with cable for advertisers in the upfront market, and ``that's really the impetus of the release of that study,'' said Alter. He said cable has become a major player in that market. Four years ago, it earned $40 million in pre-season sales, he said. Last year, he added, the figure was $500 million, and this year ``will be a record upfront'' for cable, with $750 million to $800 million in sales projected.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Condemns Bush's Decision to Suspend Dialogue
DOC.TEXT: PLO leaders said Thursday the United States was hostile to Palestinians, and urged Arab action against Washington's suspension of the U.S.-PLO dialogue. A statement by the PLO executive committee said President Bush's decision ``will encourage Israel to pursue its repressive practices against the Palestinian people and increase their crimes and massacres in the ocupied territories. ``The dialogue was a step forward on the road to peace and its suspension will reduce the U.S. role in the Middle East peace process,'' the statement said. The statement was the Palestine Liberation Organization's first official response to Bush's announcement Wednesday that the 18-month-old talks had been suspended. It was issued after a meeting of the 15-member Executive Council in Baghdad, the Iraqi capitalm called to discuss developments on the Palestinian issue and the formation of a new right-wing Israeli government. In Jerusalem, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir praised Bush's action and urged the United States to end the dialogue permanently. Bush said he suspended the talks because the PLO did not forcefully condemn an unsuccessful May 30 seaborne terrorist attack against Israel. In their statement, the PLO leaders said U.S. Middle East policy reflected ``a total bias'' in favor of Israel, which constitutes ``a major challenge to the Arabs.'' ``Arabs are required to face up to the American challenge and to implement resolutions adopted at the last Arab summit conference in Baghdad last month,'' it said. That was a reference to summit resolutions calling on Arab states to re-evaluate their political and economic relations with other countries on the basis of their policies toward the Palestinians. The U.S.-PLO dialogue began after PLO chairman Yasser Arafat met long-standing U.S. conditions for talks by renouncing terrorism and accepting Israel's right to exist. Since then, the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia has met regularly with PLO officials at the organization's headquarters in Tunis. Bush had urged Arafat to condemn the seaborne assault and discipline the PLO faction that sent the two speedboats filled with fighters to a Tel Aviv beach. The boats were intercepted by Israeli soldiers, who killed four guerrillas and arrested 12. There were no Israeli casualties. The attack was carried out by the Palestine Liberation Front led by Mohammed Abbas, better known as Abul Abbas, who planned the 1985 hijacking of the Achille Lauro cruise liner, in a disabled American was killed. Arafat denied PLO responsibility for the seaborne raid. The executive committee said the movement remained committed to Arafat's December 1988 renunciation of terrorism and that there was no evidence Abbas' group planned to attack civilian targets. Bush called the PLO response was ``not sufficient,'' but said the United States was prepared to resume the dialogue immediately if the PLO condemned the raid and disciplined Abbas. In its latest statement, the PLO executive committee reiterated its earlier position on the May 30 raid. It said only the Palestine National Council, or parliament-in-exile, which elects the executive committee, could decide whether to expel Abbas. ``The Palestinian leadership had taken a responsible and clear stand on the coast operation,'' the committee said in its five-page statement, ``but despite that, the U.S. administration took the decision to break off the dialogue, uncovering its true hostile policies toward the Palestinian people. ``This is clear evidence that Israel and its branches inside the American administration still control the decision-making process.'' The PLO leaders expressed surprise that Washington was making an issue of an attempted raid in which no Israelis were hurt, ``while it maintains silence toward Israeli crimes against Palestinians.'' In the Israeli-occupied West Bank, masked Palestinians chanting ``No to America!'' marched through cities Thursday to protest the U.S. decision. In annexed Arab east Jerusalem, stone-throwing Palestinian women and masked youths clashed with riot police after an Arab was killed there in an earlier protest over the U.S. decision. Shamir said Washington's determination to fight terrorism would not be clear until it cuts its dialogue with the PLO permanently. ``I hope that the suspension will not be temporary but instead will open a new chapter in relations between the United States and the Middle East,'' Shamir said on Israel radio. Israel objects to any PLO involvement in peace efforts, claiming the organization is a terrorist group bent on destroying the Jewish state.

DOC.HEAD: Iran Earthquake Caught Victims Asleep in Fragile Homes
With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The earthquake that devastated Iran early Thursday took tens of thousands of lives because people were asleep in fragile homes built on flood plains, an earthquake expert said. ``Most casualties from earthquakes are caused by something falling on top of you,'' said Russ Needham, a geophysist with the U.S. Geological Survey that monitors ground motion around the world. The quake hit at 12:30 a.m. in Iran, when most of the people were in their homes, Needham said Thursday in a telephone interview from Golden, Colo. At least 25,000 people died and thousands were injured in the quake, which demolished scores of villages and buried thousands of people in the rubble of their homes, Iranian officials said. Needham said most structures in that area are built of a ceramic-type brick or adobe that collapses easily. ``It's very similar to what we had in Armenia,'' he said of the Dec. 7, 1988, earthquake that killed about 25,000 people. A Soviet parliamentary report later blamed the high number of fatalities on shoddily built buildings. The Armenian quake was measured at 6.9 on the Richter scale, but Thursday's earthquake shook the earth with a magnitude of 7.7. The shock wave traveled through the mountainous section of coastal Iran where most of the buildings are built on a flood plain of loosely deposited soil that shifts in an earthquake and allows structures to collapse, he said. The 7.7-magnitude quake was the largest ever recorded in that area, where two major plates of the earth's crust meet, Needhams said. ``Iran is in a very active seismic region,'' he said, and that there have been many smaller quakes. Twelve earthquakes greater than magnitude 7 have occurred in Iran during the last 30 years, Needhams said. A quake of magnitude 7 is considered a major earthquake, capable of widespread, heavy damage in populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Fear Owl Decision Will Be Too Weak
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS 1 graf after 6th graf pvs, bgng: The announcement, to UPDATE with White House comment.
DOC.TEXT: Environmentalists expressed concern Thursday that the Bush administration would fail to give enough protection to the rare spotted owl when it announces its plans Friday under the Endangered Species Act. ``I think the Forest Service is under incredible pressure to do less than the right thing,'' said Frances Hunt of the National Wildlife Federation. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service has set an announcement for Friday on its plans for protecting the spotted owl. A decision to make the rare, two-foot-tall brownish bird a ``threatened species'' could close millions of acres of forest in northern California, Oregon and Washington to logging, at a potential cost of tens of thousands of jobs. Such a decision _ widely predicted by environmentalists, industry officials and members of Congress _ would make it illegal to harm any of the estimated 3,000 to 5,000 pairs of surviving owls or destroy their critical habitat without government approval. The announcement is expected to cap a bruising battle between environmentalists who favor maximum protection for the owl, and the timber industry fearful for its own future. The actual plans for protecting the owl are expected to be drawn up by the Forest Service and other government agencies. White House deputy press secretary Stephen Hart said that if the owl is declared threatened, the White House will monitor the development of plans to protect it. ``Our goal is that the plan be balanced between protecting the owl and saving jobs,'' Hart said. Environmentalists call the decision as an important precedent in a larger fight over protection of the Northwest's oldest forests, because the Forest Service earlier decided the health of the owl is a good indicator of the overall condition of the forests themselves. The decision has been expected since a panel of government scientists announced in April that current forest management plans are inadequate to ensure the spotted owl will survive the next 100 years. The scientific committee led by Forest Service biologist Jack Ward Thomas determined the owl has lost about two-thirds of its habitat since 1800. It recommended more than 3 million acres of previously unprotected forests _ an area nearly as large as the state of Connecticut _ be set aside to save the owl from extinction. The controversy continued as the formal announcement neared. ``My sense is that the listing ... will raise as many questions as it answers in terms of the immediate implications of what people are supposed to do,'' said Mark Rey of the industry's American Forest Resource Alliance. A Fish and Wildlife spokesman, Phil Million, said the formal documents are in the possession of agency director John Turner. He declined to comment on whether it had been reviewed by White House staff. ``Somebody said it is over 400 pages,'' he said. Six Northwest congressman asked President Bush last week to delay the anticipated listing's effective date until Oct. 1 so the industry and federal agencies would have time to sort out the ramifications of the ruling. But environmentalists said such a delay would undercut efforts to protect the owl. ``Our fear basically is that would allow business as usual to continue for the next few months. That would result in the loss of important spotted owl habitat,'' said Ms. Hunt. ``A delay seems inconsistent with what the'' Endangered Species Act ``is trying to do,'' said Bill Reffalt of The Wilderness Society.

DOC.HEAD: The Next Flag Battle Will Be Fought With TV Spots
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Updates throughout to include House vote, additional debate
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: They can see it now: campaign commercials, spawned by the flag debate, aimed straight at them. It begins, said Sen. Bill Bradley, D-N.J., with an opponent saying the issue is not patriotism but judgment. ``Then comes the graphic 30-second commercial, featuring an unsavory, bearded lowlife burning a flag, and clearly implying that a particular senator is less than patriotic because he chose to preserve freedom over a constitutional amendment,'' said Bradley, a runaway favorite for re-election, nonetheless concerned about the impact of his decision to oppose an amendment against flag burning. ``The 30-second TV spot can cut both ways,'' said Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., R-Wis. and one of the leading House supporters of the amendment in Thursday's debate. ``I can see some liberal PR man starting a 30-second spot with the Bill of Rights going up in flames.'' Those political worries, and more like them, underlie the debate about the flag and the Constitution, and they are arguments the House could not settle with its vote Thursday against an amendment to permit laws against flag burning. The roll call was 254-177, a majority but 34 short of the two-thirds required. But Senate advocates of an amendment already had vowed to force a vote there _ pointless legislatively, but not politically. It takes two-thirds in each house of Congress to send a proposed amendment to the states for ratification. The speaker of the House, Rep. Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., said the amendment vote on Thursday would be the last in that branch. ``We're not going to go around and around and around and around,'' he said. But the issue has, ever since the Supreme Court ruled just a year ago that flag burning was permissible under the First Amendment to the Constitution. That invalidated 48 state laws against it and ignited the debate; President Bush pushed an amendment, and congressional Democrats passed a law forbidding flag burning instead. The court overturned that this month and the amendment was revived. The 1990 replay never had quite the emotional impetus of the 1989 original, even though a Gallup poll this month showed two-thirds of the public in favor of a constitutional ban on flag burning. Looking at those numbers, Republican campaign strategists figure they have an issue that will last. Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the minority whip, said it was not an issue that would go away soon. He said if an amendment isn't sent to the states _ 38 would have to ratify _ in 1990, it will come up again next year. That way, he said, Republican congressional candidates who favor an amendment could demand that their opponents announce positions on a flag-protection amendment in the next session of Congress. ``I don't think this debate is going to end,'' Gingrich said Thursday, shortly before the amendment was turned down. ``I am confident that this debate is going to go on for a long time.'' Democratic opponents called Republican tactics the politics of fear and intimidation, and said voters will see through it. But that is more hope than assurance; nobody is certain how the issue will play in the campaign ahead. That's why the debate has been waged on two levels. One is about the flag, the court, the Constitution and freedom of speech. The other, as Bradley said, ``is about pure politics.'' Because it is, wary Democrats provided a fallback, insurance vote, on another measure, this one to ban flag burning intended to incite violence. The court already has overturned one federal statute, and the outlook for this one would be dubious. But the bill and a companion measure in the Senate nonetheless give opponents of the amendment a way to vote for flag protection _ a vote they can tell their constituents about.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: US Offers Humanitarian Aid To Iran
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to reflect higher death toll, 25,000
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Iran-Quake, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The United States offered humanitarian aid to Iran on Thursday and expressed sadness over the loss of life in the earthquake that struck the northern part of the country. U.S. officials said the offer was not intended as a political signal to Iran but was a gesture of support for the victims, said Iranian officials to include more than 25,000 dead and tens of thousands injured. State Department deputy spokesman Richard Boucher said Iran has contacted the U.N. Disaster Relief Office to ask for assistance. The United States has not had diplomatic relations with Iran for 10 years and holds that country partially responsible for the continued detention of American hostages by pro-Iranian elements in Lebanon. The U.S. offer of assistance was to have been relayed to Iranian authorities by the Swiss Embassy in Tehran, which handles U.S. interests in Iran. As of late Thursday, U.S. officials said that because of the time difference, they had no confirmation the offer had actually been delivered to Iranian authorities. In any case, they said, no response had been received from the Iranian government. The officials said a U.S. offer of aid following a previous natural disaster in Iran was turned down. ``We are saddened by the damage and the loss of life,'' said White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater. He said a message of condolence had been sent to President Hashemi Rafsanjani.

DOC.HEAD: Health News from Centers for Disease Control
DOC.TEXT: Federal health officials said Thursday they can't explain the return of encephalitis to central California last year, after reports of such viral infections ``had virtually disappeared.'' An outbreak of St. Louis encephalitis _ a mosquito-transmitted arbovirus _ caused 28 cases between August and October in the lower San Joaquin Valley of California, the national Centers for Disease Control reported. ``During the 1970s and 1980s, reports of these arboviral infections had virtually disappeared from the Central Valley,'' the CDC said. ``The reasons for the disappearance and subsequent recurrence ... are unclear.'' ``Especially perplexing'' was the absence of cases of Western equine encephalitis, which is transmitted in the West by the same mosquito, the CDC added. Encephalitis is an inflammation of the brain. Nationwide, the CDC reported 108 cases of various types of arboviral encephalitis last year. Other types include Eastern equine encephalitis and La Crosse encephalitis.

Federal health officials estimated Thursday that 4,000 infants each year become chronically infected with hepatitis B virus because their mothers are infected at the time of delivery. ``More than 90 percent of such perinatally acquired ... infections can be prevented,'' through treatment and vaccination as soon as possible after birth, the Centers for Disease Control said in its weekly report. Transmission from mothers to infants at birth ``is one of the most efficient modes of spread of hepatitis B,'' the CDC said. Out of some 10,000 expectant women seen at Atlanta's Grady Memorial Hospital between July 1988 and June 1989, 85 were positive for hepatitis B, the CDC reported. ``Health education efforts must be directed at (hepatitis B) positive mothers to emphasize the importance of hepatitis B prevention,'' the CDC said. The CDC in 1988 recommended hepatitis testing for all pregnant women, and immediate vaccinations, if needed, for their babies. It is estimated that 25 percent of the infants who become chronic hepatitis B carriers will die of liver cancer or cirrhosis. Hepatitis B, transmitted chiefly via blood, is one of the two most common forms of hepatitis, a serious inflammation of the liver. Some 25,000 cases occur each year in the United States.

Nearly 3 percent of people tested in one survey showed signs of infection with viruses that prompted a crackdown on imported research monkeys earlier this year, government health officials reported Thursday. ``The 2.5, 3 percent is higher than we thought it would be,'' said Dr. Kenneth Herrmann of the Division of Viral Diseases at the Centers for Disease Control. Blood tests for infection with filoviruses _ the family of viruses that includes the deadly Ebola virus _ were conducted in the wake of an Ebola-like outbreak in research monkeys imported from the Philippines to Virginia, Pennsylvania and Texas last winter. At least 42 people exposed to such monkeys have now tested positive for infection with filovirus, the CDC said Thursday. But where filoviruses such as Ebola and Marburg virus have killed hundreds in outbreaks in Africa and Europe, no such illness has been reported this time in the United States. Out of 449 random adult blood tests, 12 _ or 2.7 percent _ were positive for previous antibodies against filovirus, the CDC said. The tests were conducted among outpatients at primary-care health facilities. The 12 positive results are unexplained, but suggest ``that there may be other agents _ filoviruses or other viruses _ that cross-react with the filovirus that we're concerned about in the monkeys,'' Herrmann said. The CDC earlier this year pulled the registrations of three of the nation's largest monkey importers and imposed new restrictions after the outbreak in groups of animals in Virginia and Pennsylvania.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Claim Government Inaction
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto FX10
DOC.TEXT: Fifty AIDS activists were arrested Thursday after a march that wound by government office buildings to protest what demonstrators said was government inaction in the prevention and treatment of AIDS. The second day of demonstrations, held in response to the Sixth International AIDS Conference, ended when a small group of activists sat down in a busy intersection after setting fire to a pile of placards. After issuing a warning, police in riot gear surrounded the group and arrested protesters on charges of remaining at the scene of an unlawful assembly. Eighty people were arrested on Wednesday near the Moscone Center, the site of the AIDS conference. Thursday's protests, which took place about a mile from the AIDS conference, focused on complaints over lack of government funding and programs in the San Francisco area. Speakers criticized reliance on the so-called San Francisco model, a system of volunteer programs praised and studied as a model for AIDS patients. Demonstrators carried signs reading, ``San Francisco AIDS Model Built on a Fault'' and replicas of dollar bills with bloody hand prints. ``The San Francisco model was developed by people who care, but they are being overwhelmed,'' said Harvey Maurer, a member of the city's AIDS-ARC Vigil. Jean Harris, a legislative aide to city supervisor Harry Britt, criticized city officials for relying on volunteers rather than developing and funding programs for early prevention and treatment of AIDS patients. ``We are dying and the people up there haven't gotten off their butts,'' she said as the march stopped outside City Hall. Outside the Department of Public Health, Bonnie Ferguson, whose group Prevention Point distributes clean hypodermic needles to addicts, complained the program has received little other than praise from Mayor Art Agnos. ``Art's been kind to Prevention Point in his public statements, but we have not been able to get one sterile cotton ball or one alcohol prep out of him,'' she said. The marchers blocked another intersection by a state office building for a time, passing dollar bill posters back and forth to symbolize what they said has been a case of passing the buck by local, state and federal officials. A small group ran into the lobby of the building that houses the state insurance commissioner's office to protest what they said was a lack of state action on insurance discrimination against AIDS patients. They left a short time later without incident.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Allied Border Crossing Ready for Removal Friday
DOC.TEXT: Checkpoint Charlie, the famed Allied border crossing by the Berlin Wall, was to be hauled away Friday. U.S. Army Sgt. Lorn Walsh late Thursday stood sentry for the last time by the little white shack, rendered unnecessary by the thaw in East-West relations. ``This is a nice way to end my military service ... to be here when they take it down,'' said Walsh, 23, a military police officer who leaves the army in six weeks to study for the priesthood. A huge crane hung over the small house in the middle of the narrow street that leads to East Berlin, where a sign in English, German, Russian and French says: ``You are now leaving the American sector.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and their colleagues from France, Britain and the two Germanys were to preside over a ceremony marking the checkpoint's removal Friday. The envoys from the German states and the four World War II Allies that divided them were in East Berlin to discuss the international aspects of German unification. Since East Germany overthrew its Communist government last fall and the German borders were opened, Checkpoint Charlie has become as superfluous as the crumbling Berlin Wall. With huge sections of the Berlin Wall being ripped down daily, U.S. officials decided two weeks ago to remove Checkpoint Charlie. The border crossing was the scene of stirring escapes and heartbreaking captures as East Germans tried flee to the West, breaking through East German control stations just 20 yards away from the Allied checkpoint. East Germans once manned their side of the checkpoint with emotionless effiency, closely scrutinizing travel documents and creating a palpable tension. Thursday night, they merely waved Westerners through their side of the checkpoint, although some tourists demanded their documents be checked.

DOC.HEAD: Gay, Bisexual Men Returning To High-Risk Behavior
With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: AIDS educators are alarmed by reports that homosexual and bisexual men are lapsing back into sexual behavior that could kill them. At the Sixth International AIDS Conference on Thursday, several programs were announced to help the gay community avoid a second, even larger wave of deadly infection. Almost 20 percent of gay and bisexual men surveyed had abandoned safe-sex practices at least once, according to studies being presented to the Sixth International AIDS Conference by researchers from the Center for AIDS Prevention Studies at the University of California-San Francisco. Ten years into the epidemic, educators say they are facing a community increasingly weary with the burden of maintaining the massive changes in their lifestyle, a community grieving for the carefree days forever lost. ``People changed because they were scared to death,'' said Maggie Reinfeld of the Gay Men's Health Crisis in New York, which has created the nation's first program for confronting the relapse problem. ``Safer sex gets a lot tougher when you have to live with it over your whole life. Fear turns into denial, because nobody can live their whole life in dread of a disease.'' The American Foundation for AIDS Research announced it has awarded $in opposition party, the left-leaning Social Democrats, criticized the treaty, saying it fails to adequately protect East Germans who face economic hardship in the transition from socialism to a free market. But their chairman, Hans-Jochen Vogel, told the Bundestag a majority would approve the treaty. Failure to do so would be too much of a shock to East German expectations and could lead to ``uncontrollable developments,'' he said. The leftist Greens Party argued against passage, saying the treaty would not bring the two Germanys closer together, but would create newer and deeper forms of division by making East Germany a dependent institution. Some experts predict up to 2 million East Germans could lose their jobs as outmoded government-owned factories and businesses try to compete. More than a third of the enterprises are expected to close and there are fears of social unrest. The economic merger treaty comes after months of work following the collapse late last year of East Germany's Communist government and the opening of the Berlin Wall. East Germany elected a non-Communist government in March. Kohl acknowledge recognition of Poland's current Western border was painful for many Germans. Nonetheless, he said: ``Either we affirm the present boundary, or we lose the chance of German unity.''

DOC.HEAD: EPA Says It, Not Industry, Will Evaluate Health Risks at Superfund Sites
DOC.TEXT: The Environmental Protection Agency will take over evaluation of health risks at all Superfund hazardous waste sites because industry is underestimating risks too often, according to an agency report to Congress released Thursday. In addition, the agency said it will require all regional offices to consult headquarters if they want to simply contain waste on a site rather than treat it or remove it. The Superfund subcommittee of the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee, chaired by Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J., had requested the report, primarily to examine whether industry-financed cleanups were using containment, generally easier than other actions, more than they should. ``The first concern is that there continues to be substantial inconsistency in the calculation of risks, including assumptions used such as land-use scenarios and routes of exposure, and in how the data is organized and presented,'' EPA's report said. Some risk assessments prepared by private parties ``tend to underestimate the risk posed by a site, in many cases requiring a redraft'' by the EPA's regional office, it said. The risk assessments primarily try to estimate health dangers from the site before cleanup, but increasingly they are being used to estimate what risks would remain after various cleanup options. Lautenberg praised EPA's decision to take over the assessment work, rather than leave it in the hands of whoever is conducting the cleanup _ EPA, states or private industry. ``That's where you're really calculating where the cleanup has to go _ what's the risk to people in the communities. We ought not to leave that to parties responsible for pollution in the first place,'' he said. In terms of cleanup decisions at a given site, EPA found ``the study did not demonstrate great differences in remedies selected'' by the federal government or the polluter. ``We found reasons based on differences in the sites rather than differences in who was doing the cleanup,'' said Bruce Diamond, director of EPA's Office of Waste Programs Enforcement, at a hearing of Lautenberg's subcommittee. Among those disagreeing with his interpretation were Lautenberg and several environmental groups. ``Generally speaking, where the government finances the investigative cleanup study, ... cleanups use treatment at a higher rate than where responsible parties pick up the tab,'' Lautenberg said. Donald Strait of the Natural Resources Defense Council said the overall treatment rate is 71 percent where government pays for cleanup studies, compared with 61 percent when industry picks up the tab. Joel S. Hirschhorn, president of the consulting firm Envirosearch-East who studied Superfund in detail when he was an analyst with the congressional Office of Technology Assessment, said the different interpretations arose from different definitions. For example, he said EPA counts treatment technology whenever it is used, but only counts land disposal, or containment, when it is the sole method used.

DOC.HEAD: House Rejects Constitutional Amendment to Protect American Flag
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with new quotes, vote breakdown, action on statute. Drops last 4 grafs to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: The House on Thursday rejected a constitutional amendment to protect the American flag from desecration, heeding opponents who said it would risk damage to the Bill of Rights. The 254-177 tally left the amendment, which was supported by President Bush, 34 votes short of the two-thirds majority required to amend the Constitution. Republicans voted 159-17 for it, Democrats 160-95 against. The vote followed a sometimes impassioned day of debate featuring more than 100 speeches, including a rare address by the speaker of the House, Rep. Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. ``We should not amend the Constitution of the United States to reach the sparse and scattered and despicable conduct of a few who would dishonor the flag and defile it,'' said Foley, who also cast a rare speaker's vote to register his opposition to the amendment. By tradition, the speaker does not normally engage in debate or vote. Countered Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill.: ``Let us take the flag out of the gutter where the counterculture has dragged it and is smearing it. We have 10 amendments that guarantee us all sorts of rights. How about one amendment that gives us a duty?'' Foley told reporters that Thursday's vote would be the last one on the amendment this year in the House, but Republicans promised to keep the issue alive. ``I am confident this debate is going to go on for a long time,'' Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., told the chamber. Asked about the Bush's efforts on behalf of the amendment, Gingrich said ``it was very hard for the president in two days to override the speaker.'' Supporters of the amendment, backed by veterans' groups seeking more time to lobby, had tried to delay Thursday's vote until next week but were defeated 231-192. Rep. Rep. G.V. Montgomery, D-Miss., the chairman of the House Veterans Committee and the amendment's prime Democratic sponsor, said of the proposal, ``I think we owe it to the brave Americans who have died for this country.'' But Rep. David Obey, D-Wis., decried the attempt to modify the First Amendment. ``When I look around the politicians today, I see more people who remind me of Daffy Duck than Thomas Jefferson,'' he said. The strength of the opposition was larger than expected and was aided by the unexpected support of some conservatives. ``Up until 24 hours ago, I was a sponsor of this amendment,'' said Rep. Tim Valentine, D-N.C. ``But over the rhetoric of the past few days, I finally heard the voice of my own conscience.'' The amendment read, ``The Congress and the states shall have power to prohibit physical desecration of the flag of the United States.'' It was first proposed in 1989 after the Supreme Court ruled that flag burning was a form of protected free speech. The issue was revived last week when the court rejected last year's attempt to pass an anti-flag-burning law that the court could accept. After the vote on the amendment, the House also rejected a new statute _ not a constitutional amendment _ to ban flag burning. The bill, narrowly drawn in hopes of avoiding court rejection, would impose fines and jail terms for people who burn flags to promote violence or who burn flags on federal property or belonging to the federal government. Republicans voted overwhelmingly against it after their leadership called it a ``fig leaf'' to protect Democrats who opposed the constitutional amendment, and it lost 236-179. The Senate is expected to vote next week on the amendment, which would require a two-thirds vote in both chambers, and approval by 38 of the 50 states, for ratification. Foley said the House would not vote again this year. Regardless of the outcome on Capitol Hill, Republicans promise to raise the issue in this fall's campaign. The House majority leader, Rep. Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., acknowledged the political tightrope members were walking. Several members decorated their speeches with flags and other props. Rep. Gary Ackerman, trying to highlight the difficulty of enforcing legislation to protect the flag, held aloft a wide variety of household items and gags decorated with the stars and stripes. ``How about American flag napkins,'' he said, holding one. ``What if you blow your nose in one. Have you broken the law?'' Although Ackerman said he was not trying to trivialize the debate, Rep. James Inhofe, R-Okla., said he was offended. Most Republican speakers supported the amendment; the bulk of opposition came from Democrats. There also was a noticeable generational tilt in the debate. House Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill., a decorated World War II veteran, co-sponsored the amendment and called it ``a measured, prudent, limited thoughtful approach to the problem.'' ``Surely this is something different from the `assault on the Bill of Rights' some critics say it is,'' he said. Rep. James H. Quillen, R-Tenn., another World War II vet, used photographs of the famed Iwo Jima flag raising and of a flag-burning protest in New York's Central Park to dramatize his support for the amendment. But Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich., a Vietnam veteran who said he would ``never forget the sacrifices that have been made so that our flag can fly proudly and freely,'' was a leader of the opposition. ``In 200 years of our history, these basic freedoms have never been amended, never. And if we start now, who knows what freedoms will be next? ... Where will it end?'' he asked.

DOC.HEAD: Amendment's Foes, Backers Make Their Cases With Props
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2nd graf with vote
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Flag Burning, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Flags were waved; the Bill of Rights was held aloft; even some red, white and blue pantyhose were displayed Thursday as members of the House spoke for or against a proposed constitutional amendment against flag burning. Members voted for the amendment 254-177, well short of the two-thirds majority required. Rep. James H. Quillen, R-Tenn., portrayed the issue as one of patriotism versus anti-patriotism with a pair of stirring poster-size photographs. One showed Marines raising the flag on Iwo Jima in World War II. The other was a Vietnam-era flag burning in New York's Central Park. Rep. Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas, carried a flag to the lectern to show his support for the proposal. Later, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., held up an even larger flag as he spoke in opposition to the amendment. A copy of the Bill of Rights was displayed by Rep. Ben Jones, D-Ga., who said he would vote against the flag amendment to protect those constitutional freedoms. Rep. Gary Ackerman brought a box of props to illustrate his speech on the inherent difficulty of enforcing legislation to protect the flag. He held up, one at a time, a hat, socks, pantyhose, a paper plate and a bathing suit _ ``I'll spare you the athletic supporters'' _ all decorated with the stars and stripes. ``How about American flag napkins?'' he asked, holding one. ``What if you blow your nose in one? Have you broken the law?,'' he said to the laughter of his colleagues. Ackerman said he was not trying to trivialize the debate. But Rep. James Inhofe, R-Okla., said he was ``offended personally'' by Ackerman's examples. As the debate went on inside, about 30 demonstrators on the Capitol lawn protested the amendment. An equal number of police officers kept watch. Most demonstrators were from a group called the Vietnam Veterans Against the War-Anti-Imperialist. ``The big mouths in there _ We're challenging them to a debate,'' declared Dave Blalock of Highland Park, N.J., jerking his thumb toward the Capitol Dome.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Rebels Capture Careysburg, Entryway to VOA Station
DOC.TEXT: Panicked Monrovians scrambled to get on planes and cars leaving the city Thursday, a day after rebels captured a town 15 miles northeast of the capital. The fall of Careysburg gave the rebels control of an entrance to the U.S. government's Voice of America transmitter for Africa. The transmitter is about 1 mile from the settlement. No Americans were at the huge radio relay station Wednesday when rebels seeking the ouster of President Samuel Doe attacked and within hours seized the town, according to Western diplomats and Careysburg residents who fled to Monrovia. Careysburg is a settlement of gracious houses styled after the southern U.S. plantation mansions. Careysburg was built by the freed American slaves who founded this West African nation in 1847. The rebels have been advancing toward the capital since late December. On Thursday, fist fights almost broke out at the small Spriggs Payne airfield among passengers who elbowed their way aboard two chartered planes heading east for Abidjan, the capital of neighboring Ivory Coast. The exodus west by road to Sierra Leone has been slowed by a fuel shortage. On Thursday, hundreds of cars were lined up outside gas stations in Monrovia and people fought to buy fuel, which has nearly doubled in price. The rebel advance comes a few days before a second round of peace talks between the warring parties is scheduled to begin in Freetown, Sierra Leone. After a first round earlier this month, the rebels signed an agreement pledging to ``exercise self-restraint in the use of military force.'' Church sources said a delegation of Christian and Moslem leaders mediating the talks met Thursday with Doe at his Atlantic oceanside mansion in Monrovia. ``We're not optimistic,'' one church leader. He said Doe dwelled on concessions he has made, including a promise not to stand for re-election at polls scheduled in October 1991. The Liberian leader has refused to concede to a rebel demand that he resign, saying it would leave a dangerous power vacuum. There had been a lull in the fighting, after government troops chased rebels from the headquarters of the U.S.-managed Firestone rubber plantation and adjoining Robertsfield International Airport, 35 miles east of Monrovia. In late May as the rebels advanced, airlines stopped flying into Robertsfield, Liberia's main airport. The Spriggs Payne airfield has been beseiged by hundreds of people fleeing the city aboard chartered flights. Nearly half of Doe's 17 Cabinet members have fled the country. Government sources said the president this week ordered Cabinet members to return or lose their positions, but did not get a satisfactory response. The insurgency, led by Charles Taylor, began in December and has since escalated into a tribal conflict. Most rebels come from the Gio and Mano tribes, while government supporters are mostly Krahns and Mandingos. Doe himself is a Krahn. Rebels accuse Doe of corruption and rights abuses. Doe took power in a violent 1980 coup that ousted the American descendents, who historically monopolized power and discriminated against indigenous Liberians.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Flag Burning a0822
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of the proposed amendment to the Constitution that failed to win the required two-thirds majority vote of the House on Thursday: ``The Congress and the states shall have power to prohibit physical desecration of the flag of the United States.''

DOC.HEAD: Barry Lawyer Hammers at Credibility of Key Prosecution Witness
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry's attorney on Thursday revealed inconsistencies in statements by a key government witness in the mayor's drug and perjury trial and accused him of lying to save himself from a long prison term. But Charles Lewis, completing his testimony after three days on the stand, stuck to his story that he and Barry smoked crack cocaine together in the nation's capital and the Virgin Islands. ``You care for yourself,'' Lewis said when defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy compared his statements to investigators. ``That's exactly it,'' Mundy said. ``If you would lie (to the grand jury) in January 1989 to save Marion Barry, a man who is not a particular friend, you would surely lie in August 1989 to protect Charles Lewis ... and a lot of other people who are closer to you, wouldn't you?'' ``No, I wouldn't,'' Lewis responded. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to three felony counts of perjury, one misdemeanor count of conspiracy and nine counts of cocaine possession. Lewis testified in his three days on the witness stand that he shared drugs with the three-term mayor repeatedly between 1986 and 1988. A convicted drug dealer, Lewis is facing sentencing on drug-related charges in his native Virgin Islands. Mundy attacked Lewis' credibility, saying the witness had several times told investigators one thing and jurors in the trial another. The defense attorney read from Lewis' testimony to a grand jury last year that Barry visited Lewis at a Washington hotel one night after a Monday Night Football game had ended. Lewis alleged this week that the mayor was there earlier, during the game, using crack cocaine. If the earlier testimony is true, Barry ``wouldn't have been there at all on the 19th ... Would he?'' Mundy said. ``Marion Barry was there that Monday night,'' Lewis told Mundy. Lewis said another contradiction between his grand jury statements and trial testimony _ on where he and Barry allegedly discussed drugs at one point _ resulted from a ``misunderstanding'' by the court reporter at the grand jury. Mundy also said Lewis' testimony suggested a third person may have been present when he and Barry allegedly smoked crack in Lewis's hotel room on Dec. 22, 1988. Lewis said that implication was a ``mistake ... There was no security, no one else.'' Lewis also agreed with Mundy's suggestion that he was not close friends with Barry, but said the two felt ``comfortable'' together. Barry ``felt comfortable with me and I felt comfortable with him on those short occasions'' when they used drugs, Lewis told said Mundy. The federal probe of Barry began when city police aborted an attempted undercover drug buy from Lewis when they discovered Barry was in Lewis' Washington hotel room in December 1988. Lewis said Wednesday that he and Barry ``agreed to get our stories straight'' after the mayor's visits to Lewis became public and that Barry asked him to lie to police about their alleged drug use. After Lewis testified, a bellhop at the Washington hotel where Lewis and Barry allegedly used cocaine supported some of Lewis' testimony. The bellhop said he saw Barry arrive at the hotel on three of the four days Lewis has said the mayor visited him. Police found traces of cocaine on the desk and nightstand inside Lewis' hotel room on Dec. 23, 1988, according to a document introduced into evidence by prosecutors. Defense attorneys agreed to the contents of the record. Lewis is cooperating with the government in its case against Barry as part of a plea bargain agreement resulting from separate drug charges in the nation's capital.

DOC.HEAD: Committee Says Cold War is Won, Cuts Military Foreign Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs, The assistant, with 2 grafs to reflect meeting completed.
DOC.TEXT: A House committee on Thursday approved a $15.8 billion foreign aid bill that begins shifting America's emphasis from military to economic help, declaring: ``The West has won the Cold War, and we have a right to say so!'' But the measure won approval by the Appropriations Committee only after Rep. David Obey, chairman of the foreign aid subcommittee, agreed to restore $144 million to military aid accounts as the price of Republican support for the package. Other major disputes over U.S. aid to El Salvador, to Cambodian rebels and to international population control agencies were deferred until the measure goes to the full House, expected to be next week. The panel, citing diminished East-West tensions, diverted roughly $400 million in military aid to refugee aid, children's programs and development assistance for countries from Eastern Europe to Africa and Latin America. Obey, D-Wis., called President Bush's request for $5 billion in military aid, an increase of $300 million over the current level, ``particularly quaint, given the changes in the world.'' The committee's report claimed victory in the Cold War and accused the administration of proposing a ``sleepwalker's budget.'' Instead, the panel approved just over $4.6 billion in military aid to friends and allies around the globe, $144 million more than Obey's subcommittee had voted last week. To win GOP support, Obey also agreed to provide $50 million for the World Bank, just less than half of what Bush had asked. Obey has fought what he sees as the practice of giving money to international lenders which ends up going to bail out large commercial banks from loans made to Third World countries. And in another concession to the White House, the panel agreed to raise aid ceilings for three countries which host U.S. military bases. Turkey would get $430 million, up $30 million from the earlier version of the bill; Greece would be increased from $280 million to $301 million; and Portugal would go from $90 million to $95 million. All remained substantially below current-year levels. Although Republicans agreed to advance the bill to the full House, the administration still had major problems with some of its provisions. At the top of the list were its restrictions on aid to El Salvador. The bill would withhold half of next year's expected $85 million in military aid; the fate of the money would depend on progress in peace talks between the government and leftist rebels who have waged a 10-year civil war. The assistant secretary of state for the hemisphere, Bernard Aronson, met late Thursday with key lawmakers of both parties to begin forging a compromise bipartisan policy toward El Salvador that could be substituted for that part of the bill. Participants said Aronson brought a counterproposal to the meeting, calling for similar conditions on the U.S. aid money but restricting a smaller proportion of it, perhaps 25 percent to 30 percent. But Democrats were coming under pressure from liberal members to hold the line and make no concessions to the administration. Another fight loomed over a section barring any aid to the non-communist resistance coalition in Cambodia that includes the Khmer Rouge, the group believed to have massacred some 1 million Cambodians when it ruled Cambodia in the 1970s. About $7 million a year in U.S. humanitarian aid now flows to the resistance coalition, which is fighting the Vietnamese-installed government of Cambodia. The United States supports the faction of Prince Norodom Sihanouk and provides aid even though some of it finds its way to the Khmer Rouge, the militarily strongest part of the coalition. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., planned to fight the provision on the floor because he believes it would undermine the resistance in United Nations-sponsored talks aimed at setting up elections.

DOC.HEAD: `Black Widow' Killer Wins Reprieve From Electric Chair
DOC.TEXT: The ``Black Widow'' killer won a temporary stay of execution from a federal judge Thursday, just four hours before she was to go to the electric chair for poisoning her husband. U.S. District Judge Patricia Fawsett blocked the scheduled 12:01 p.m. execution of Judi Buenoano at Florida State Prison to hear arguments on whether the state's electric chair can malfunction and cruelly torture a prisoner. The defense contends it can, citing the state's botched execution May 4 of Jesse Tafero. Flames and smoke shot out from under Tafero's hood, and witnesses said he seemed to breathe and move after two of the three jolts he was given. Buenoano's case went before a federal court for the first time after the state Supreme Court voted 4-3 Wednesday to reject the appeal on the grounds that Florida's chair is defective. Following her 8:00 a.m. ruling, Fawsett spent the day listening to arguments, then adjourning the hearing until Friday. Ms. Buenoano's death warrant does not expire until Monday. Ms. Buenoano, 47, could become the first women executed in Florida since the state's electric chair came into use in 1924, and the 23rd person put to death in the state, and the 131st nationally, since the U.S. Supreme Court lifted its death-penalty ban in 1976. Only one woman has been executed in the United States since the high court's ruling. North Carolina executed Velma Barfield by injection in 1984 for poisoning her boyfriend. Prosecutors nicknamed Ms. Buenoano the Black Widow because of her record of trying, in most cases successfully, to kill the men in her life. She was condemned for the 1971 fatal poisoning of her husband, but was also convicted of drowning her paralyzed, 19-year-old son and trying to kill a boyfriend with a bomb. In the hearing Thursday, an execution-equipment expert testified that Florida's chair is so badly made it can malfunction and torture a prisoner at any time. Fred A. Leuchter Jr., who designs and manufactures execution systems and hardware, told Fawsett a bad electrode caused the sparks, smoke and flames around Tafero's head. ``If no modifications or changes are made ... this could reoccur in every execution that comes up, or every other one, or intermittently,'' said Leuchter. But the state argued that the smoke and flame were caused by a synthetic sponge attached to the electrode. It has been replaced and everything is in working order for the next execution, the Department of Corrections has said. Assistant Attorney General Margene Roper repeated contentions by prison officials that Tafero did not suffer and was dead after the first of three surges of electricity. Leuchter, who was dubbed ``Dr. Death'' on a recent television show featuring his execution systems, called Florida's chair a makeshift device, poorly made and maintained. He said corrosion or a break in an electrode resulted in a non-lethal charge that did not kill Tafero until he was jolted three times. Defense lawyer Jay Nickerson pointed to Ms. Buenoano, sitting at the defense table, and asked Leuchter, ``can you say that this woman when she is strapped into the electric chair ... will not experience cruel and unnecessary punishment?'' ``No, I cannot,'' answered Leuchter. The state plans to reschedule the execution as soon as any stay expired, said Jon Peck, a spokesman for Gov. Bob Martinez. ``We are fully confident that we know what went wrong in the last execution and it's been fixed,'' said Peck. Ms. Buenoano was taken from the prison in Starke to Orlando on Thursday morning on Fawsett's order, according to state Department of Corrections spokeswoman Paula Tully.

DOC.HEAD: Planetarium Opens With Fanfare and Tribute To McAuliffe
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `Sununu, who ...,' with 4 grafs to ADD Truly on comment on future of citizen-in-space program; picks up 10th graf, `Most of ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Christa McAuliffe Planetarium was dedicated Thursday as a memorial to the teacher-astronaut killed in the Challenger disaster and a way to honor her passion for motivating children to learn. ``This planetarium is more than a memorial to Christa McAuliffe ... it is more than a planetarium. It is a promise to continue the work she believed in and a promise to fulfill her dream,'' said NASA Administrator Richard Truly. About 1,500 people, including some of McAuliffe's former students and White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, attended the opening ceremony. The $2.6 million planetarium is New Hampshire's official memorial to the 37-year-old Concord High School teacher, who died with six other astronauts when the space shuttle exploded in January 1986. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration had selected McAuliffe as its first citizen in space from among 11,000 teachers who applied for the spot. ``Christa was selected because she was an extraordinary role model as a teacher and an extraordinary role model as a person,'' her widower, Steven, said Thursday. He said his wife's goal was to excite and motivate children to learn and that she saw her shuttle mission as a way to ``honorably and credibly represent classroom teachers and the debt and respect that we owe to them.'' McAuliffe and other speakers said the planetarium has accomplished those goals. At a news conference before the dedication, Truly said he'd like to see ordinary citizens return to space, but made no promises because of the backlog of missions caused by the Challenger disaster. Truly, who flew on two shuttle missions, said the experience of spaceflight ``is deserving to be shared with people who are not just like me.'' ``Right now we've got a series of important, precious, national missions to get off, and we've got our hands full, so I'm going to put that (decision) off a little bit,'' he said. He has made similar statements before. The planetarium resulted from ``the fierce pride and love of people who cared about someone and who cared about what Christa cared about,'' said Sununu, who was New Hampshire's governor when the Challenger exploded. Most of the funding for the planetarium came from the state, but there were private donations as well, including money raised by schoolchildren across New Hampshire. The planetarium, which took 18 months to build, features an interactive system that allows the audience to select by an electronic majority vote where they want to travel in the universe. It also will allow journeys into mathematics, geology, meteorology, art, the history of music or the demise of the dinosaurs. A special commission chose the planetarium from scores of suggestions for memorials to McAuliffe, including a portrait, a state holiday or a brightly lit statue atop Mount Washington, New England's highest peak. Louise Wiley of Pittsfield suggested the planetarium. She said Thursday she had envisioned a smaller planetarium in a high school that students would run. ``Never in a million years did I think it would end up like this,'' she said. ``It is a dream. We had tears in our eyes watching it.'' McAuliffe's mother, Grace Corrigan, looked on with pride. ``I'm very happy and very proud to think that something so disastrous is culminating in something so wonderful,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Vows Border Crackdown, But Proposes Lottery for Immigrants
DOC.TEXT: Mexicans who repeatedly cross the U.S. border illegally will be prosecuted instead of being shipped home, the top federal immigration official said Thursday. Immigration and Naturalization Service Commissioner Gene McNary also vowed to seek prosecution and imprisonment for people who smuggle aliens. McNary said he favors creating a lottery to allow some foreigners to enter the United States even if they don't meet existing requirements that they have relatives or jobs waiting for them in this country. But McNary said his superiors in the Bush administration might reject his lottery proposal. The commissioner, who took over the federal agency last October, spoke during a Thursday news conference and at a luncheon meeting of Town Hall of California, a civic group.
