DOC.HEAD: For Midwives, Some Things Haven't Changed Since 1920s
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Technology has changed much for midwives since Edwin W. Edwards, decades away from the governor's mansion, drove his mother down the back roads of central Louisiana to deliver babies. But Kathy Acree, one of Louisiana's seven licensed midwives, shares much with Agnes Brouillette Edwards, including the willingness to take trade when clients can't pay cash. ``She did 1,500 deliveries in her day,'' said Mrs. Acree, who has visited Mrs. Edwards, 88. ``She had notebooks with the date, the baby's name, the parents' names and what they paid her. It would usually be a dozen eggs, a chicken. One time she got some shoes for her son.'' Mrs. Acree, 40, and her partner, Alicia Abrin, charge $1,000 for a delivery _ one-third to one-quarter the cost of an uncomplicated hospital delivery. The husband of one woman who couldn't pay cash landscaped the yard of the Acree house; another painted two rooms. The money or barter covers prenatal care, delivery, and two appointments after birth. Mrs. Acree teaches clients how to sterilize sheets, towels and baby clothes by baking them in the oven _ a technique Mrs. Edwards used to sterilize bandages and gauze pads, according to her daughter, Dorothy Isbell of Baton Rouge. ``You're talking about the days before antibiotics, you're talking about the days before blood transfusions, you're talking about the days when Cesarean section was fraught with hazards,'' said Mrs. Acree. ``Those midwives as a result became very skilled at breech deliveries, at twin deliveries, at triplet deliveries _ because they had to. ``I would do a breech if it was coming and I just had to do it _ but I don't feel comfortable doing them. I just don't have the experience.'' Unlike Mrs. Edwards, Mrs. Acree carries IV equipment, anti-hemorrhage drugs, oxygen, local anesthetics and special suction and resuscitative devices. Both women studied under physicians, although Mrs. Edwards' studies were informal. ``Her mother before her was a midwife, and she taught her some of what she knew,'' said Mrs. Isbell, who said Mrs. Edwards was recovering from double pneumonia and not able to talk to a reporter. ``To my knowledge, she never had any formal training. She learned from doing.'' This didn't mean that she ignored what doctors could teach. ``She had a very good relationship with the doctors in town. ... They taught her what they knew and she read some of the books that they had,'' said Mrs. Isbell. Mrs. Acree, who has a bachelor's degree in speech and hearing therapy, began her midwifery studies with an obstetrician. When she began training 10 years ago, midwives could get licensed by passing a written test, but the law was revoked in 1980. A law passed in 1984 and revised in 1986 requires 30 hours of courses needed to become a registered nurse and clinical training by a physician or licensed midwife before a written test is taken. The clinical training includes 100 prenatal visits, helping with 25 births and delivering at least 15 babies, examining 25 newborns, sewing up five lacerations and observing at least five high-risk births. Mrs. Acree said that, like most modern midwives, she decided to help women have their babies at home after she'd had a baby in a hospital. ``That birth really left me with some questions about the way women were treated in childbirth,'' she said. ``They didn't allow fathers in the labor and delivery area, it was a big ward, you had your baby by yourself, they took the baby to the nursery right away and you never saw your baby unless you asked.'' Hospitals have answered demand by setting up ``birthing rooms.'' ``It's nice to say `Oh, we have this birthing room, you can have a homelike delivery.' But if you go in and you still are forced to labor strapped to a fetal monitor with an IV in your arm, you're limited in your options _ for instance, in the positions that you want to choose to labor or give birth,'' said Mrs. Acree. When Mrs. Edwards was delivering babies, there was little question about where they would be born _ the houses in rural Avoyelles, St. Landry and Rapides parishes often were so far from a hospital that there was no choice. Today's midwives in Louisiana _ each state where midwives are licensed has its own rules _ may attend only women whose doctors have certified that their births are likely to be uncomplicated. They must have a doctor on call. Mrs. Acree said she's lucky _ many Lafayette doctors support midwives. She and her partner deliver about 50 babies a year. Midwives in other cities have had trouble finding medical backup, and one Yale-trained midwife has given up and enrolled in law school, she said. Women who seek out midwives are likely to be professionals and college graduates, ``motivated and willing to do the research and investigate alternatives.'' ``There's also the working poor _ they don't have $3,000 or $4,000 for a hospital delivery, they don't qualify for a Medicaid card, they don't have insurance,'' Mrs. Acree said. That means midwives can help reduce Louisiana's high infant mortality rate by explaining the importance of nutrition and prenatal care, she said. According to 1988 Census Bureau statistics, Louisiana has the sixth highest infant mortaility rate in the nation at 11.8 per thousand live births, compared with the U.S. average of 10.1 deaths. Mrs. Acree's experience shows attitudes may be changing even among people who can afford hospitals. ``Believe it or not, in the last two years I've delivered a lot of patients from the medical community,'' she said. ``I helped two physicians deliver their children at home, I delivered about four nurse-anesthetists, and several dozen RNs.'' One doctor was the female obstetrician who is Mrs. Acree's backup. The other, she said, was a physician whose wife insisted on having the baby at home. ``He was kind of resistant. Unfortunately, physicians are ingrained in fear. That's a basic part of their training, is to learn complications and fear,'' said Mrs. Acree. ``That's what you need a doctor for _ if everything was fine, you wouldn't need help.'' Mrs. Acree said she and Mrs. Edwards also have in common a feeling that lasts long after delivery. ``She told me that you'd go down the street, and in an afternoon you'd see a dozen kids in the neighborhood that you'd delivered. They were like your kids. It didn't matter what color they were, they were still your kids. Your baby. You had delivered them.''

DOC.HEAD: Child's Worst Reaction to Death of Parent May Be Delayed, Study Suggests
DOC.TEXT: About half the children in a study experienced their most severe reactions a month after a parent's death, but many others were hit hardest psychologically six months after the loss. A third of children in a study showed a more severe reaction at that time than at one month or 13 months after the loss, said Dr. Elizabeth Weller of Ohio State University. ``It seems these kids are kind of numb'' earlier on, she said. ``They don't know what hit them. It takes time for them to assimilate what has happened.'' The study focused on 38 children ages 5 to 12. Twenty-three had expected the death. Using interviews, Weller and colleagues looked for two dozen psychiatric symptoms at about one month, six months and 13 months after the death. The 13-month interval was chosen to avoid reactions to the anniversary of the death. About half the children showed their most severe reaction at one month. Prominent symptoms among the children at that point included sadness, irritability, impaired concentration, fatigue, low self-esteem, suicidal thoughts, loss of pleasure and fears that something would happen to the remaining parent. At six months, only sadness and irritability were noted in at least 40 percent of the children. At 13 months, no single symptom appeared in 40 percent of the children. Interviews with parents found they tended to underestimate the severity of their children's reactions, she said. Parents are overwhelmed with their own grief, and children may conceal symptoms to protect the stressed parent, she said. Weller said researchers found no way to predict which children would have their most severe reaction at six months. She described the work at the recent annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association.

DOC.HEAD: Man's `Tumor' Was Pen Fragment From Childhood Fight, Surgeons Find
DOC.TEXT: Surgeons who thought they were removing a tumor discovered the problem was actually a fragment of a ballpoint pen that lay undetected for 22 years, a report says. The patient had sought medical help for a swelling on the side of his face, near his right ear. He said it had appeared two years before and steadily grown. After X-rays showed an abnormality in a salivary gland, doctors assumed it was a benign tumor and scheduled surgery to remove it. But the operation uncovered an inch-long fragment of a ballpoint pen, and no evidence of tumor. The patient had a normal recovery and left the hospital two days later. ``After direct questioning, the patient's parents recalled a fight with his brother when he was 4 years old, during which he was punctured inside the mouth with a pen'' that now, 22 years later, was finally removed, doctors reported. Drs. Guillermo Raspall and Javier Gonzalalez of the Hospital Valle de Hebron in Barcelona, Spain, describe the case in the June issue of the Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery. The House today raced toward a showdown on a constitutional amendment to ban flag burning and Speaker Thomas S. Foley said failure to capture the required two thirds vote would doom it for the year. ``Whatever happens today is the final action,'' Foley declared at a morning news conference. ``... We're not going to go around and around and around and around.'' Emotional appeals to patriotism and warnings against tampering with the Constitution's guarantee of free speech rang out in the chamber as the House debate got under way. A panoramic picture of the Iwo Jima Memorial showing Marines hoisting the flag over Mount Suribachi was brought to the floor beside a photo of a flaming flag in Central Park, where ``the goofs and the goons held it up in open rebellion,'' said Rep. James Quillen, R-Tenn. ``Are we so fragile as a nation that we cannot rise above such cheap tactics'' as flag burning, asked Rep. David E. Skaggs, D-Colo. ``What assurance is there that this excision in the Bill of Rights, once breached, would not lead to others?'' Foley appeared to rule out a suggestion by Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., even if the House rejected the measure the first time around the Senate could approve it and send it back, possibly in modified form. ``We will vote today on this matter for the final time this session,'' Foley told a morning news conference. On Wednesday, he said some of the measure's supporters had given way to ``crass political opportunism'' and would ``hurt their own cause by that kind of egregious political snickering.'' As the intensity picked up Wednesday, supporters promised to carry on their campaign even if the amendment is defeated on the House floor. ``If they think this issue goes away on Friday, they have no comprehension of what's going on out there,'' said Republican Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia. ``And I expect that if we do lose, you'll see more anger and outrage than if we win.'' Backers and opponents of the amendment said it likely would not muster the necessary two-thirds margin in the House. President Bush said Wednesday in Huntsville, Ala., that a ``carefully drawn amendment to make burning of the American flag a crime'' is needed because the flag is a unique symbol. Republicans on Capitol Hill, however, grumbled that the White House should have done more one-on-one lobbying. Democratic leaders have been campaigning against the amendment on grounds that it would undermine the constitutional guarantee of free speech. The amendment would allow the federal government and the states to ban burning or otherwise desecrating the American flag. To become part of the Constitution, the amendment needed 289 votes in the House and 67 in the Senate plus ratification by 38 state legislatures. In the Senate, Democratic Whip Alan Cranston of California said his count was 54 in favor, 29 opposed and 17 on the fence. Meanwhile, former federal Judge Robert Bork was testifying today before the Senate Judiciary Committee on the proposed amendment. The House planned six hours of debate followed by a vote on the amendment. After that, the lawmakers planned to vote on a simple statute that would ban flag burning. The amendment was debated heavily last year after the Supreme Court struck down a Texas law that banned flag burning. But lawmakers ultimately passed a law to ban flag burning instead of a constitutional amendment. The Supreme Court last week declared the statute unconstitutional, rekindling debate over the constitutional amendment. House debate took on an acid tone Wednesday as Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y., told critics that in pushing for a quick vote they were ``gagging 10 million veterans through this nation'' and ``kowtowing to ilk like the Communist Youth Brigade.'' Democrats objected and Solomon eventually apologized. The remarks were stricken from the record. The sharp words, however, underlined the intensity of emotions in the House over the issue. Foley, asked about Gingrich's remarks, said some sponsors ``are concerned, apparently, about the political issue and the political opportunities they think this represents.'' ``I don't think the American people are going to respond favorably to that,'' Foley said. ``What I don't think they are going to appreciate and support is crass political opportunism, a kind of wringing their hands gleefully and saying, this is where we are going to clean up.'' Veterans' groups had sought to mount a grassroots lobbying campaign for the amendment but were caught off guard by the swift move to whisk the bill to the House floor. ``We fail to see why it is so necessary to rush this legislation to a vote on Thursday,'' said Walter G. Hogan, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars.

The U.S. economy is continuing to grow sluggishly although the construction sector appears to be weakening, according to a Federal Reserve survey. ``The tone of district reports suggests continued slow growth in the economy with little change in the underlying inflation rate,'' said a summary of the survey of the 12 Fed district banks, released Wednesday. The survey, completed June 8, was similar to three polls conducted earlier this year that found slow but continued economic expansion with moderate inflation.

Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. said it planned to recapitalize its RJR Nabisco Inc., an indication the giant company will not be broken up and eventually will return to public ownership. Under the tentative plan disclosed Wednesday, the New York investment firm would retire a large part of the $6 billion in junk bonds it used to buy the food and tobacco company in a record $24.53 billion buyout last year. The news sent prices of the bonds sharply higher. Kohlberg Kravis also would issue preferred stock convertible into common stock in RJR Nabisco.

General Motors Corp. has fixed a swelling problem in the plastic doors on its new Saturn model, and the first marketable car should roll off a Tennessee assembly line on schedule this summer, the company said Wednesday. GM Chairman Roger Smith has said he expects to drive the first car off the assembly line before he retires July 31. Saturn is a $3 billion project to build a car with a base price of less than $12,000 to compete directly with those made by Japanese companies.

Militant environmentalists and labor activists picketed outside a logging mill to start a series of ``Redwood Summer'' protests planned for Northern California. About 35 to 40 environmentalists and members of the International Workers of the World gathered Wednesday at a Louisiana Pacific plant to protest clear-cut logging and exportation of logs to Mexico for cheaper processing.

Chase Manhattan Corp. said its chairman would step down at the end of October, speeding a management restructuring expected to include major cutbacks in its corporate finance department. The nation's second-largest bank holding company said Wednesday its current president, Thomas G. Labrecque, 51, would replace Willard C. Butcher, 63, as chairman and chief executive officer. The change, while expected for several months, heralds further cutbacks by a major bank to cope with a severe downturn in the market for mergers, leveraged buyouts and acquisitions on Wall Street in the 1980s.

Despite the flops of the too-large Eisenhower dollar and the too-close-to-the-quarter Susan B. Anthony dollar, 29 senators are ready to gamble on Americans accepting a gold-colored, 11-sided dollar coin. Sen. Pete V. Domenici, R-N.M., appeared before the Senate Banking Committee on Wednesday to urge support for legislation he is sponsoring to authorize the minting of Christopher Columbus dollars slightly larger than the quarter. It has 28 cosponsors.

Motorola Inc. plans to establish the first global, satellite-based cellular phone system at a cost of up to $2 billion, according to a published report. The system would require the launching of a network of low-orbiting satellites that would extend cellular services into remote areas of the United States and around the world, the Chicago Tribune reported Wednesday. The system would be used by international travelers and rural residents where it would not be economical to build land-based transmitters of cellular signals.

President Bush defended his administration's prosecution of savings and loan fraud and offered an olive branch to Democrats critical of the effort. ``There has been an active prosecution under way,'' Bush told reporters Wednesday at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala. His remarks, which included an offer to work with Congress to combat fraud, came a day after he reviewed the Justice Department's anti-fraud effort with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and after his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, attacked Democrats critical of the president's handling of the S&L mess.

Scientific research is about to blow the lid off the mystery behind a common household horror: why thick soups and stews explode and splatter the inside of microwave ovens. ``It's a consumer problem: the housewife or kid comes back and here's lunch all over the inside of the microwave,'' said David W. Cable, a mechanical engineer at MetriCor Inc. in Woodinville, Wash. MetriCor, a subsidiary of Corning Inc., sells $12,000 fiberoptic sensors that are being used by Rutgers University scientists to measure temperatures and pressures of food as it is cooked in microwave ovens.

Stocks were mixed Wednesday as the market looked for direction. The Dow Jones industrial average finished up 1.74 at 2,895.30, but broader indexes were down. Treasury bond prices sank as a Federal Reserve report reinforced a belief that the government did not plan to lower interest rates anytime soon. The dollar finished higher against most other major currencies on news of political uncertainty in the Soviet Union. Gold also rose. Energy futures prices were mixed as crude oil futures continued their plunge due to oversupply; grain and soybean prices were mixed; precious metals were higher; copper declined; and livestock and pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Kohlberg Kravis Plans Recapitalization of Food and Tobacco Giant
DOC.TEXT: A Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. plan to recapitalize RJR Nabisco Inc. bolstered its junk bonds and indicated the food and tobacco company will be left intact and eventually returned to public ownership. Under the tentative plan announced Wednesday, Kohlberg Kravis would retire a large part of the $6 billion in junk bonds it used to buy the food and tobacco company in a record $24.53 billion buyout last year. The buyout firm plans to inject fresh equity into RJR Nabisco and raise bank loans to retire the bonds. Kohlberg Kravis also would issue preferred stock convertible into common stock in RJR Nabisco. The plan is likely to lower returns for Kohlberg Kravis and its investors, but it would avert the prospect of RJR Nabisco having to pay sharply higher interest rates on its junk bond debt next year. The equity injection and sale of stock also could counter any notions that Kohlberg Kravis might dismantle RJR Nabisco, as it did after with Beatrice Co. Beatrice once owned such well-known businesses as the Avis car rental company, Tropicana juice products, Hunt and Wesson foods, Samsonite luggage, Swift meats and Playtex personal products. Between its $6.1 billion acquisition of Beatrice in 1985 and this month, when the conglomerate's remaining food operations were sold, Kohlberg Kravis divested the company piece by piece. In the process, the buyout firm and its investors reaped a fat 50 percent return on their original equity investment. RJR Nabisco also has a variety of food lines and a separate tobacco business. But analysts say that while Beatrice was ripe for a breakup, RJR Nabisco is not. Beatrice ``had this and that _ a lot of things that didn't make sense to have together anyway,'' said Jack Maxwell, an analyst who follows RJR Nabisco for Wheat, First Securities Inc. in Richmond, Va. RJR Nabisco has product lines that conceivably could be pared, but Maxwell said he doubted Kohlberg Kravis would begin unloading food divisions and ``you can't sell bits and pieces of the tobacco business very well.'' Since its buyout, RJR has divested $5.66 billion in assets to pare its debt, which now stands at $22 billion. Its Del Monte canned foods and fresh fruit businesses and some foreign holdings were among those sold. But, said Maxwell, ``They've sold pretty much what they want to sell.'' In its announcement, RJR Nabisco said Kohlberg Kravis would invest an additional $1.7 billion in the company as part of the recapitalization. Analysts see RJR Nabisco returning to public ownership in the next few years. That is the route taken by another Kohlberg Kravis holding, Safeway Stores Inc. After Safeway went private in a 1986 leveraged buyout, the supermarket company began hammering away at its debt and streamlined operations. This past February, the company announced a modest initial offering of 10 million shares. RJR Nabisco also said it was negotiating new loans with banks. The company said it expected to begin enacting the recapitalization by the end of July. The plan is intended to take off the market some of RJR Nabisco's junk bonds, which declined sharply in value earlier this year. A buyback of the bonds would allow Kohlberg Kravis to sidestep provisions requiring the firm to guarantee the price of the bonds by next April. RJR Nabisco bonds rose sharply Wednesday on word of the recapitalization, gaining as much as $6.25 per $100 in face value. Kohlberg Kravis' investors mostly are large pension funds that generally do not have an active voice in the management of the companies they own, including RJR Nabisco. Officials of several funds declined to comment on what they'd like to see happen to RJR Nabisco. But several said they were satisfied with management. David Weig, executive director of the Washington State Investment Board, said he was ``absolutely happy'' with the management at RJR Nabisco and with Kohlberg Kravis. Oregon state pension officials also said they were happy. ``We have had excellent returns from these kinds of investments,'' said Sheryl Wilson, executive director of the state's retirement funds.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Plans Layoffs; General Dynamics' Bond Ratings Dropped
DOC.TEXT: The sagging defense industry has dealt another blow to the nation's top two defense contractors. McDonnell Douglas Corp. announced plans Wednesday for major layoffs to help pare at least $700 million a year from its costs, and General Dynamics Corp. had its credit rating cut by a major rating agency. The developments at the two St. Louis-based companies came one day after Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed a 25 percent cut in the nation's military spending. The proposed cuts would affect McDonnell Douglas' Harpoon and Tomahawk missiles and the F-15 and FA-18 jet fighters. General Dynamics makes F-16 fighter jets for the Air Force, M1 tanks for the Army and SSN-688 submarines for the Navy. Moody's Investors Service Inc., which downgraded General Dynamics' credit rating, said ``the manufacturers of defense platforms (planes, tanks, submarines) will be the most severely affected by reduced defense spending.'' Officials at McDonnell Douglas, the nation's biggest defense contractor, said they didn't know yet how many of the company's 127,000 workers might lose their jobs. However, sources at the company and in Washington said they had been told about 4,000 of McDonnell's 40,500 employees in St. Louis will be cut. Nationwide, the company probably will lay off 7,000 to 8,000 people, one source said. ``The hard reality is we must begin immediately to take further strong actions to reduce our costs,'' John F. McDonnell, the company's chairman and chief executive, said in a letter to employees. He added that ``to reduce costs by the desired amount will entail substantial layoffs across the corporation.'' The company will not offer voluntary retirement packages as part of the cuts, he said. McDonnell already has announced plans to lay off 4,000 workers and 3,000 contracted workers at its Douglas Aircraft Co. in Long Beach and Torrance, Calif. Douglas Aircraft, its production behind schedule on the C-17 military cargo plane and the MD-80 jetliner, has lost $306 million in the past 15 months. McDonnell said the cost-cutting plan should be in place by early August, with immediate steps being taken on overtime, travel, new hiring, consultants, advertising and support activities. The layoffs are likely to be focused on the company's salaried and administrative ranks rather than on production workers, officials indicated. Industry analyst Paul Nisbet of Prudential-Bache in New York said the layoffs are a sign of transition rather than severe trouble at McDonnell Douglas. Nisbet estimated the company has a backlog of over $50 billion in commercial aircraft orders. He predicted McDonnell's sales would reach $16.2 billion this year and $20 billion by 1992, compared with $14.58 billion in 1989. The layoffs represent ``just a shift in business from what predominantly was a military market in the '80s to a predominantly commercial market in the '90s,'' Nisbet said. ``They're just having trouble digesting it.'' In addition to programs that would be affected by the proposed defense cuts, chairman McDonnell wrote employees that the company faces ``potential serious cost problems'' on its A-12 advanced tactical aircraft, the C-17 airlifter and T-45A Goshawk trainer programs. Moody's cited sagging conditions in the defense industry in dropping its credit ratings by two notches on General Dynamics, the nation's No. 2 defense contractor. The action dropped the company's senior debt from A2 to Baa1 and its subordinated debt from A3 to Baa2. The new ratings put the bonds in the bottom category of investment grade. Fred Pastore, an associate director at Moody's, said the downgrade reflected the company's decreased amount of readily available cash as well as its vulnerability to defense cuts. Spokesman Pete Connolly said General Dynamics was disappointed with the downgrade. ``We feel we have both a strong balance sheet and a strong balance of business which will sustain us through this period,'' he said. In addition to its military business, the company owns Cessna Aircraft Co. and makes a launch rocket used to put satellites into orbit.

DOC.HEAD: Chase Chairman Stepping Down In October
DOC.TEXT: Chase Manhattan Corp. said it would appoint a new chairman as part of an early management shakeup that officials indicated would include cutbacks in the corporate finance area. Current president, Thomas G. Labrecque, 51, will replace Willard C. Butcher, 63, as chairman and chief executive officer effective Oct. 31, the nation's second-largest bank holding company said Wednesday. The change is part of a wave of cutbacks by major investment and commercial banks to cope with a downturn in the market for mergers, acquisitions and leveraged buyouts that flourished on Wall Street in the 1980s. In an interview, Labrecque said he and Butcher recommended the change to the bank's board of directors. The succession had been expected, but he said the timing was being accelerated to implement changes in corporate finance. Chase Manhattan, which ranks behind Citicorp in terms of assets, has 41,000 employees worldwide, 27 percent of them in corporate finance. ``What we really have to restructure is our corporate finance capabilities in terms of its size worldwide and the integration of it worldwide,'' he said. ``The question is the size of the infrastructure to support the level of business being done.'' ``The assumption should not be that we're getting out of the business,'' he said. ``It's anything but that.'' Labrecque declined to specify changes but said the bank would have more to say next week. Other banks that engage in wholesale lending to large corporations and corporate finance also are reducing their staff sizes. Bankers Trust New York Corp. said Monday it is cutting 10 percent of its corporate finance department, or 75 jobs. Manufacturers Hanover Corp. also is expected to reduce its domestic and foreign corporate finance operations and already has announced a restructuring of its wholesale banking business. Labrecque said Chase, which recently sold subsidiaries in the Netherlands and Belgium, planned to retain a presence in the more than 50 countries in which it now operates. He also said restructuring efforts would focus on the bank's loan problems, which contributed to a 66 percent decline in first-quarter earnings to $44 million from $132 million in the same 1989 period. The bank said its earnings were hurt by a $75 million increase in provisions for losses from bad loans, mostly because of deterioration in some U.S commercial real estate markets. The company added $225 million to reserves against possible loan losses in the first quarter, up from $150 million a year ago and $130 million in the 1989 fourth quarter. The bank said it wrote off $325 million in bad loans in the quarter, including $114 million to Third World countries, up from a total of $159 million in the year-ago period. Butcher issued a statement saying the executive change was ``a natural step in implementing an orderly management succession which has been under way since early 1988.'' He joined Chase in 1947 and was elected chairman in 1981. ``We have accelerated the process because there are a series of business challeneges requiring organizational changes that could not be implemented until the issue of management succession was resolved,'' the statement read. In addition, Chase said vice chairman Arthur F. Ryan would become president and chief operating officer of Chase Manhattan Corp. and Chase Manhattan Bank. Labrecque joined Chase in 1964 and was elected vice chairman and chief operating office in 1980 and president in 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Clorox Expands its Household Products Line with Pine-Sol, Combat
DOC.TEXT: Clorox Co., known for its bleach, has fortified its household products line with the $465 million purchase of the Pine-Sol cleaner and Combat insecticide businesses from American Cyanamid Co. Under the deal signed Wednesday, Clorox is acquiring the household products portion of Cyanamid's Shulton Group. That includes Pine-Sol, the nation's top-selling household cleaner, and Combat, the No. 2 insecticide brand. Last week, Cyanamid, based in Wayne, N.J., agreed to sell most of Shulton's toiletries business, including Old Spice, to Procter & Gamble Co. for $370 million. Cyanamid said it also would sell Shulton's Breck and Lady's Choice lines. ``The Shulton divestiture is another step in our continuing strategy to focus Cyanamid's resources on its core businesses in the medical, agricultural and specialty chemicals areas,'' said George J. Sella Jr., chairman, president and chief executive officer. Cyanamid spokeswoman Edwina G. Sanders declined to comment on the company's plans for Pierre Cardin men's cologne, its sole remaining consumer product. Shulton accounted for 3 percent of Cyanamid's operating profits last year and 12 percent of its sales of $4.8 billion, she said. The agreements with Clorox and Proctor & Gamble are subject to federal antitrust approval. Clorox, based in Oakland, Calif., said the purchase will be funded by up to $400 million in short-term debt, with the remainder in cash. C.R. Weaver, Clorox chairman, president and chief executive, said the acquisitions will boost the company's clout. He noted that Clorox had earlier acquired such brands as Liquid-plumber and Formula 409 which were established products before the purchases, giving the company an edge in marketing. ``By acquiring Combat, we avoid the sizable expense and risk involved in the development and national expansion of a new product,'' Weaver said. Combat is the No. 2 brand in the $450 million insecticide market after Raid. A 5-year agreement also gives Clorox rights to sell new household-insecticide products using compounds from Cyanamid.

DOC.HEAD: UAW Vows to Stand Firm on Minimum Employment Levels at Big Three
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union won't drop demands for minimum employment levels in exchange for improved income guarantees for most workers, union President Owen Bieber said. ``Much of the job shrinkage the companies are confronting us with is not inevitable, and we should fight it and try to reverse it,'' Bieber told the UAW's Ford Council in Indianapolis on Wednesday. Contracts covering about 500,000 active and laid-off workers at Ford Motor Co., General Motors Corp. and Chrysler Corp. expire Sept. 14. Under a Big Three proposal, the UAW would scrap a requirement for automakers to hire one new worker for every two who retire, quit or die. In exchange, automakers would have expanded income maintenance programs. Many automotive analysts have said the Big Three can't remain competitive with the number of hourly workers they currently employ. Bieber said the union acknowledges that job reductions are necessary but refused to discuss how or when the union would permit them until talks open next month. Bieber also called on Ford to reverse its growing reliance on overseas operations to develop cars it sells in North America. ``We can't embrace Ford's world car concept when it directly threatens our future,'' Bieber said.

DOC.HEAD: The Travelers Cutting Back on Auto and Homeowners Insurance in Nine States
DOC.TEXT: The Travelers Corp. says it will stop selling automobile and homeowners insurance policies in nine states where business has been slow in order to focus on more profitable markets. ``In today's competitive environment, we must preserve our capital for only the very best business opportunities and that requires increasingly higher standards of performance,'' said Ronald E. Foley, senior vice president for personal lines at Travelers. The Hartford-based company said Wednesday it will stop writing automobile and homeowners policies in South Carolina, North Dakota, South Dakota, Wyoming, West Virginia, Nevada, Idaho, Arkansas and Oklahoma. The move takes effect immediately in some states, said Richard Fly, a Travelers spokesman. Fly said the company will begin phasing out existing policies in November. He said Travelers had no figures on how many customers the decision would affect. ``Generally those states have proven to be unprofitable to us,'' Fly said. ``Our strategy for some time has been to concentrate on those states where we see the possibility for future and long-term growth.'' The company also said it has reduced the number of independent agents selling its personal insurance policies and revamped its agent commission schedule, paying them on a performance scale instead of a flat commission beginning Jan. 1. Fly said the decision will have no immediate impact on the company's staff, although the company will evaluate whether layoffs are needed as the withdrawals take place. The company said it has reduced its agent force by about 900 over the past year. Analysts predict that the changes will not have much effect on consumers in the states Travelers is leaving. ``Other insurance companies are going to be able to handle those policies with not much of a ripple in the market,'' said Alvin Parsons, vice president of the American Insurance Association, a Washington, D.C.-based insurance lobby. Travelers said earlier this year it was evaluating its homeowners and automobile businesses nationwide. The company has already withdrawn from the automobile insurance field in California, and stopped writing new policies in Pennsylvania. It said it would carefully choose customers in other states. Travelers is one of a growing number of major insurers who have decided to cut or abandon personal lines of insurance because of what they say are declining profits and increased meddling by state regulators and lawmakers. Other insurers making drastic changes include Xerox Corp.'s Crum and Forster insurance division, Aetna Life and Casualty Co., and The Hartford Insurance Group, Philadelphia-based Cigna Corp., The New Hampshire Insurance Group and Continental Corp. in New York. Travelers lost $13 million in 1989 on its personal lines business, which includes automobile and homeowners policies, Fly said. He said the nine states affected accounted for $42 million in premiums in 1989, about four percent of the company's $1.7 billion in personal lines premiums. Robert Rusbuldt, an assistant vice president with the Independent Insurance Agents of America, a lobby for independent agents, said the decision was not surprising. ``(Insurance companies) have been looking at automobile insurance as a loss leader,'' he said. ``The loss has been getting so bad in certain states that it's just not worth it anymore.'' Parsons blamed deteriorating business climates for Travelers' move. ``If you look at (the nine states) they are small markets and Travelers may have decided that it was not worthwhile writing business there,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices were modestly higher at midday Thursday, amid little substantive business. Large institutions remained sidelined and trading was sketchy even in the blue chips, dealers said. Many investors stayed away because of the Royal Ascot horse race meeting. Shortly after noontime in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 5.8 points, or 0.2 percent, at 2,377.0. Volume was a light 257 million shares at midday, compared with 229.6 million shares at the same time Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Slowdown In Domestic Air Travel Noted, Despite Worldwide Growth
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 2nd graf to make it `will' sted `with.' This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: After years of seeing strong growth in the number of passengers flying around the United States, the aviation industry is trying to figure out why air travel is actually down in some key markets. Despite the slowdown, now in its third year, industry groups still predict that strong growth will create a critical demand for new airports and more runways by the end of the century. Air travel within the United States increased only 1 percent in 1989 while the number of passengers boarding international flights from U.S. airports went up 11 percent, the Airport Operators Council International said in a report Wednesday. Travel was up 13.8 percent in Pacific Rim countries and 7 percent in Europe. An accompanying report by the Partnership for Improved Air Travel said aviation's contribution to the economy hit nearly $600 billion in 1989, a 13.8 percent increase over the last study, which covered 1987. But most of the growth was in commercial aircraft manufacturing, rather than in domestic airline operations. Jobs, payroll and other economic factors involving the manufacture of airliners went up 22 percent over the two years, the report said. Aviation's share of the gross national product has remained steady at 5.6 percent, said the partnership, a wide-ranging group of industry and aviation-interest groups set up to ensure that U.S. aviation meets future demands. The reports by the partnership and the airport operators were released at a joint news conference. George Howard, president of the airport operators group, blamed slow overall economic growth, higher fares and the impact of the Eastern Airlines strike for the stalled growth in domestic passengers. He said inadequate capacity at larger airports also may be suppressing the growth in traffic as they simply run out of room for additional flights. ``There is evidence of a shift in the growth of traffic to smaller airports where capacity, while still a large concern, is still somewhat more available,'' Howard said. The airport group released its annual traffic report of each of the world's major airports. It showed three of four airports in the highest-density markets _ New York's Kennedy and LaGuardia and Washington's National _ actually lost traffic in 1989. The fourth, Chicago's O'Hare, showed only a 0.6 percent increase but remained the world's busiest airport with just over 59 million passengers boarding flights last year, the report said. Dallas-Fort Worth surpassed Los Angeles and Atlanta for second place. Atlanta's Hartsfield Airport fell to fourth from second, primarily because of the strike against Eastern, which uses Atlanta as a hub, Howard said. New York, with three major airports, continued to be the world's most heavily traveled market, followed by Chicago and London. Federal Aviation Administration figures compiled by the airport organization showed 415.6 million emplanements for domestic flights in 1989, 414.2 million in 1988 and 415.5 in 1987. Aviation officials indicated they did not expect the growth to be so flat, but they pointed out the still significant increase in enplanements since 1983 when they totaled 290.7 million. ``Our traffic results for 1989 might indicate a slight weakening in the growth rate of aviation for the year, but we foresee a 61 percent increase in passenger traffic by 2000,'' Howard said. He said the airport group predicts that 76 percent of all U.S. air travelers will face delays if the capacity of the nation's system of airports is not increased.

DOC.HEAD: Swiss Worry European Economic Reforms Will Isolate Them
DOC.TEXT: Switzerland, for centuries an island of peace in troubled Europe, is increasingly haunted by fears of isolation in an emerging super-continent. The wealthy country has traditionally regarded itself as a ``special case,'' treasuring its much-vaunted neutrality and stability that has helped attract capital from all over the world. But as the newly democratic states of Eastern Europe look toward the 12-nation European Community for economic deals and political cooperation, Swiss leaders do not hide their worries about being left out. ``It would be like being the only one in a school class not invited to join the soccer team,'' said Franz Blankart, Switzerland's chief negotiator in talks on European integration. Pressure for full EC membership is increasing from companies anxious to share the economic benefits promised by the removal of trade barriers at the end of 1992. At the same time, however, there are loud warnings from conservative groups that EC membership would jeopardize Switzerland's independence and its system of direct democracy under which the people have the final say on all key legislation. The government says it's not ready to join the EC. Instead it is engrossed in complex talks aimed at a far-reaching agreement between the powerful Community and the six-nation European Free Trade Association. Switzerland, Austria, Norway, Sweden, Iceland and Finland are members of the loosely knit EFTA. Austria already has applied for EC membership, swallowing fears for its neutrality. The talks with the Community are meant to lead to the creation of the European Economic Space, EES, providing for the free movement of goods, people, capital and services among the 18 European countries and creating a market of 350 million people. Of all the EFTA members, Switzerland is the most dependent on the EC for trade. According to government figures, 57 percent of Swiss exports went to EC countries last year, and 74 percent of Swiss imports came from the EC. But the path toward creating a super European market has been rocky. Swiss demands for exemptions from certain provisions demonstrate the problems that would beset an application for full Swiss membership of the Community. For example, the government wants to keep the right to limit the influx of foreigners into a land where some 15 percent of the 6.5 million population are non-Swiss. Full EC membership would rule this out. Switzerland also could be forced to change its system for holding national referendums. The EC also has objected to giving Switzerland and others in the European Free Trade Association an equal say in the decision-making process, increasing speculation that the negotiations will end in failure. The Swiss government says in such an event there would be two scenarios: a go-it-alone policy or full EC membership. ``The go-it-alone policy for me is an unrealistic solution,'' says Swiss Foreign Minister Rene Felber. ``The consequences would be isolation, which would be unbearable for a land in the middle of Europe with all our economic, cultural and social connections.'' The powerful farming lobby doesn't share this concern. It is opposed to EC membership, fearing a drop in agricultural prices and an opening of markets which are currently protected. By contrast, a government report has said that business concerns would, on the whole, benefit from EC membership. Experts say this is especially true of medium-sized companies. The largest Swiss banks and multinationals like Nestle S.A. already have secured footholds throughout the EC. Economics Minister Jean-Pascal Delamuraz says EC membership is a long-term option but dismisses pressure for an immediate application as ``premature.'' A pro-EC grouping of politicians, businessmen and publishers plans to launch a proposal on Community membership to gain the 100,000 signatures required under Swiss law for a national referendum. A vote in favor of the proposed constitutional amendment would force the government to open formal talks with the EC. One group opposed to joining the EC, the Action for an Independent and Neutral Switzerland, says the country will lose out in the European integration process and its democratic traditions will suffer. ``Freedom and independence until death,'' reads one of the more extreme slogans at a recent meeting of the group. Political leaders do not underestimate the influence of the group's movement and still flinch at memories of voters' rejection in 1986 of a proposal to join the United Nations. Officials refuse to speculate on what will happen if a national referendum throws out the proposed EC-EFTA accord. ``There is more fear of isolationism now (than 1986),'' contends Felber. ``We have to be optimistic. We have to believe we are European.''

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Powerful Business Alliances Under Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Trade talks scheduled for June 25-26
DOC.TEXT: For Japanese, the word ``zaibatsu'' conjures up images of sacrifice and dedication to the lost cause of global domination during World War II. The zaibatsu _ huge holding companies that funded and armed Japan's war effort _ were dismantled more than 40 years ago. But the even more powerful business alliances that arose in their place are coming under fire both at home and abroad for some of their business practices. Those alliances, which have helped make Japan one of the world's biggest economic powers, have become a prime target in trade negotiations with the United States. Talks in Tokyo scheduled for Monday and Tuesday are expected to produce an agreement on curbing business practices that U.S. officials say exclude outsiders and unfairly control markets. The zaibatsu, which had included Mitsui, Mitsubishi, Yasuda and Sumitomo, launched modern industry here in the late 19th century. Their descendants span industries ranging from real estate to precision instruments. The Japanese remain uncomfortably aware of the latent power of these corporate behemoths. In 1945, the zaibatsu controlled a quarter of the nation's capital, half its financial sector and at least a third of its heavy industry. The six largest groups still account for about one-quarter of both the assets and sales of all non-financial firms, according to the Fair Trade Commission, Japan's anti-monopoly watchdog. Major deals by two of the biggest of the groups _ Mitsubishi and Mitsui _ recently raised speculation that the zaibatsu was being resurrected. The outcry began when the Mitsubishi Group announced plans in March for cooperation with West German aerospace and auto conglomerate Daimler-Benz AG. The tie-up was seen as a bold move to further fortify Japan's top trader and defense contractor. An announcement April 10 of a merger between Mitsubishi Mining and Cement Co. and Mitsubishi Metal Corp., two group firms divided after the war, raised further apprehensions. ``The New Nationalism of the Mitsubishi Zaibatsu,'' trumpeted AERA, a weekly magazine of the Asahi newspaper. ``Mitsubishi's `Zaibatsu Resurrection' _a Dangerous Gamble,'' said the Tokyo Shimbun, one of several newspapers that criticized the move. The Mitsui Group also raised eyebrows with a merger between Mitsui Bank and Taiyo Kobe Bank _ a combination that formed the world's second-largest bank in terms of deposits. Mitsubishi officials vigorously denied any attempts to re-establish their zaibatsu. ``Those claims are absolutely untrue,'' said Mitsubishi spokesman Hiroshi Ogawa. Not just former zaibatsu companies are coming under fire. Today, there are about 150 major industrial groups in Japan, according to Toyo Keizai, an authoritative financial publishing house. The groups are loosely identified as ``keiretsu,'' or affiliations _ corporate families bound by mutual shareholdings and other financial ties, as well as cooperative business strategies. ``The zaibatsu are like dinosaurs ... there aren't any. But the keiretsu are a tricky problem,'' said James C. Abegglan, a business consultant and professor at Sophia University in Tokyo. Some keiretsu are grouped around banks. Others group subcontractors around major manufacturers, like Sony Corp. and Matsushita. Retailers, in turn, are linked to producers with ties that ensure stable, trustworthy business relationships. Many economists believe that without keiretsu, the nation's entire just-in-time system of production and supply, the key to its competitiveness in world markets, would fall apart. ``If the Japanese are told they must abandon this sort of approach, the very vitality of Japanese corporations will be seriously damaged,'' said economist Iwao Nakatani of Osaka University in western Japan. Japanese rewrote anti-trust rules to allow firms to have cross holdings to protect desirable firms from hostile takeover bids. Former zaibatsu companies tend to keep about 30 percent of their shares in crossholdings, the Fair Trade Commission says. ``These long-term, lasting relationships make the Japanese system more efficient,'' said Abegglan, the Sophia University professor. But some smaller group members are beginning to chafe at the price of corporate kinship. Businessmen, speaking confidentially, say big-name firms at the top of the manufacturing pyramid squeeze their smaller subcontractors mercilessly. ``Once you're part of an industrial group, you have no secrets. Your bank is the group's bank, and your company's financial details are available on request to senior group members,'' one president of a small group of electronics firms told ``Business Tokyo'' magazine. ``The Japanese subcontractor isn't in love with his parent company. He's just tied to it by tradition and the threat of losing his business,'' he said. Foreign firms criticize large manufacturers for establishing exclusive outlets for their own products, offering retailers rebates and other incentives to sell items at listed prices and penalizing stores that sell at a discount or carry other brands. On June 6, the Fair Trade Commission issued new guidelines that prohibit manufacturers from pressuring discount shops that sell goods at below manufacturer-recommended prices. The commission also has said it will tighten controls on bid-rigging and price-fixing and raise penalties for illegal cartels. Finance Ministry officials say they also are discussing wider requirements for financial disclosure of dealings among keiretsu members. Wider disclosure would give shareholders more control over their investments. Fuller disclosure is one of the changes Texas oilman T. Boone Pickens has been demanding in his own battle against keiretsu. Pickens owns the largest share in Koito Manufacturing Co., a major auto parts maker linked to Toyota Motor Corp. He has been demanding, so far unsuccessfully, a say in the firm's management. Industry and government officials say they don't intend to dismantle the industrial groups. But they are clearly coming under stricter scrutiny. The key issue, said economist Nakatani, is how to preserve the system that works so well for Japan while opening it to outsiders. ``The keiretsu need to consider the feelings of outsiders,'' said Nakatani. ``They've always done things for the sake of Japanese and excluded foreigners. ``Now they are multinational companies and they can't afford to ignore the rest of the world.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, June 25

DOC.TEXT: The stock market was mixed today, continuing the erratic pattern of Wednesday's trading. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 9.41 to 2,885.89 in the first half hour of the session. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 6 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 481 up, 398 down and 562 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 20.12 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said traders seemed uncertain about where the market might get any inspiration to extend its spring rally. While interest rates and inflationary pressures have been ebbing in recent weeks, nothing has happened to fulfill hopes that the Federal Reserve might adopt a more stimulative credit policy. Indeed, Fed officials have suggested they are still inclined to stay with a relatively restrictive approach. This morning the Commerce Department reported that the gross national product grew at a 1.9 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation and seasonal factors, in the first quarter of the year. The figure, revised upward from a previous estimate of 1.3 percent, was seen as confirming evidence that the economy keeps growing sluggishly. Among actively traded blue chips, Johnson & Johnson rose | to 65\; Philip Morris gained ] to 43~; Dow Chemical was unchanged at 61[, and International Business Machines lost ] to 117|. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .05 to 195.79. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was down .25 at 360.56. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 1.74 to 2,895.30. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 8 to 7 on the NYSE, with 667 up, 767 down and 559 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 137.42 million shares, against 134.93 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Tile Maker's Company Continues An Art
DOC.TEXT: The deep-set colors and intricate Mexican designs of pressed concrete tile once could be found in homes and buildings all over San Antonio. Thanks to a childhood fascination of designer Bill Demaree, the art form that began to vanish with the advent of linoleum and carpet is making a vibrant return as demand for the matte tiles spreads across the continent. Demaree, a self-employed designer hit hard by the sluggish Texas economy, set out five years ago to find artisans to make the unusual tile, which features colored, geometric designs. Demaree had been intrigued with the tiles as a child, when he spent hours on the floor of his family's San Antonio home studying the old cement pieces. ``I decided to go to Mexico and see if there was anybody left who knew how to make them,'' he said. ``It was about a three-year period in doing the research.'' In San Luis, Demaree came upon craftsmen trained by older family members to make tiles. Demaree fondly refers to them as ``the masters.'' ``There are some people that somehow don't even think about it. It is part of their being,'' said Demaree, who now runs a 23-worker tilemaking factory in San Luis and an apprentices' school he established. ``These people grew up and learned from their father, their uncle, what have you.'' Demaree said the tile making dates to 1726, when it is believed Vatican artisans created the first pressed concrete tile. The tiles were used for wall decorations in Vatican chapels. Early molds were made of wood and hammering was used instead of hydraulic pressing, which came into use in the 1840s. Demaree said use of the tiles followed the production of portland cement. At one point San Antonio boasted the second-largest portland cement plant in the United States, and the tiles were widely used here. The peak of pressed tile production in the United States lasted from about 1900 to 1928. San Antonio's Bexar County Courthouse, built in 1891, used the tiles on its floors. Most of it remains in good shape. But the Depression, World War II and the growing popularity of linoleum and carpeting led to a decline in U.S. tile use. The tiles remained popular in Mexico, where solid-colored pieces often are found in the floors of low-cost housing. Demaree said basically nothing about tile making has changed since the 1840s, except that color quality gradually has improved. Craftsman use two types of concrete _ portland cement for the tile base and white portland to create colors. Cement of precisely the right consistency must be poured into a mold at exactly the right depth to prevent colors from running together when the mold eventually is pulled out. Tile makers smooth the backs of the pieces with a straightedge and then use hydraulics to apply air pressure of 3,000 pounds per square inch for three or four seconds to two heavy metal plates that sandwich the tile. The hydraulic pressure bonds the sections of cement together for strength. As much as 10 percent of the tiles don't survive the 28-day process, which includes drying the pieces overnight then submerging them in water for days. The tiles range in size from 3 inches by 3 inches to 1 foot by 1 foot. Prices range from $3 to $12 per square foot. Different tile patterns have names like Saltillo Star, Arabesque, Lattice, Victoria and even Bahama Mama. About two years ago Demaree joined with San Antonio-based Materials Marketing Corp. to sell the product, which he ships to San Antonio for the company to farm out to distributors. Materials Marketing, which also sells other products from Mexico, has been peddling the tiles for about a year through 60 distributors in the United States and Canada. A few other craftsmen and companies in the United States are showing interest in selling the tiles, but Materials Marketing claims its operation is the biggest. Sales figures are not yet available.

DOC.HEAD: Nation's Economy Grew at 1.9 Percent Annual Rate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs with corporate profits after 12th graf pvs `The various ...' This also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's economy grew at a 1.9 percent annual rate from January through March, the second slowest quarterly advance in more than three years, the government said today. The Commerce Department said the increase in the broadest measure of the nation's economic health _ the gross national product _ was up from the 1.1 percent rate in the final quarter of 1989. That had been the slowest advance since a 0.8 percent gain in the summer of 1986. At the same time, inflation as a price index tied to the GNP rose 6.4 percent at an annual rate. It was an improvement from the 6.7 percent increase reported last month and the 6.5 percent advance originally reported in April. The inflation rate was the highest since it raced ahead at an annual rate of 7.7 percent in the final quarter of 1981. However, most economists attributed the jump in the January-March period to the adverse effects of unusual winter weather and predicted prices would decline during the remainder of the year. The new GNP figure for the first quarter approached the 2.1 percent gain in the department's original estimate in April. That estimate was lowered last month to 1.3 percent. Most economists had expected little change from the May figure. The economy advanced 3.0 percent in 1989, down from 4.4 percent a year earlier. Despite the slower growth, most economists believe the economy will continue to skirt a recession, generally defined as two straight declines in the GNP. In fact, the Federal Reserve released a survey on Wednesday indicating the economy continued to grow sluggishly through the first part of June, although recessionary pockets were found in some sectors. The first-quarter growth rate was less than the Bush administration's 2.4 percent estimate earlier this year. To meet that goal, the economy would have to spurt ahead 2.6 percent at an annual rate during the remaining nine months. Commerce said the improvement in today's report was due mainly to $6.8 billion more in net exports than previously thought. At the same time, consumer spending was $5.3 billion less than estimated last month. The various changes left the GNP, after adjusting for inflation, totalling $4.193 trillion after the first three months of the year. In a companion report, the department said after-tax profits of U.S. corporations were up a revised 1.1 percent in the first quarter after rising 2.8 percent in the final three months of 1989. It originally reported that profits had risen only 0.2 percent. Corporate profits had fallen during each of the first three quarters of last year, including a 1.1 percent drop during the comparable months of January through March. In its report on Wednesday, the Fed said its survey of its 12 district banks ``suggests slow growth in the economy with little change in the underlying inflation rate.'' The survey, completed on June 8, shows that the manufacturing sector remains flat but is showing signs of improvement in some areas including some strengthening in the sluggish automobile industry. The construction industry, on the other hand, has ``been edging downward in recent months in most districts and indicators of future construction suggest further softening,'' the survey found. The manufacturing and construction sectors have felt the brunt of the Fed's tight-credit policies as the central bank sought for more than a year to stem inflation by slowing the economy without tilting it into a recession. The Fed survey found ``very little growth, if not a decline, in real consumer spending for durable and non-durable goods this quarter from last.'' Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and has been a driving force for the economy for much of the last eight years. ``Recent behavior in retail sales and reports from retailers in several districts indicate that sales have been slow in recent months and are expected to remain so in the short term,'' the summary said. Retail sales, representing about a half of overall consumer spending, slid in the final month of the first quarter and continued to fall for two more months. It was the first time that has happened since the fall of 1981 during the last recession. The survey found indications of continued growth in capital goods industries, another area of strength in recent months. ``Prospects for a good harvest this year should be improved as a result of ample rainfall in previously drought-stricken regions of the country,'' the survey found, ``but cool, wet weather has delayed planting by as much as several weeks.'' The survey results were similar to the three previous polls conducted this year that found slow but continued economic expansion with moderate inflation. The latest was conducted by the Cleveland district bank for use at the July 2-3 meeting of the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee which establishes U.S. monetary policy.

DOC.HEAD: Lightning Bolt Sets Siberian Oil Tank Farm on Fire
DOC.TEXT: A direct lightning strike ignited a reservoir on a Siberian oil tank farm and spread to 22 acres by Thursday evening, Tass reported. At least four of the oil station's 24 tanks were ablaze, and 28 fire engines were fighting the fire at the Karkateyevy station near Nefteyugansk, Tass said. That is in the Tyumen oil region of Western Siberia. The reservoirs at the station contain a total of 380,000 tons of oil, Tass said. ``The danger is still great,'' I. Kimstan, head of the fire-fighting directorate of the Russian Interior Ministry told Tass. Strong gusts of wind threaten to spread the fire further and he said he fears that water in the oil could boil and burst the tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Against ICC Rate Policy
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today stripped the Interstate Commerce Commission of its authority to relieve shippers of their legal obligation to pay carriers less than their official rates. The justices, by a 7-2 vote, said the ICC policy violates the 103-year-old Interstate Commerce Act. The act requires carriers to file rate schedules with the commission, showing how much is charged for services. Once such a rate schedule is filed, a carrier cannot charge more or less than what it states. But the commission, which regulates interstate trucking and has the authority to approve or disapprove tariff proposals, adopted a policy in 1986 that carved out an exception. The policy stated that it was an unreasonable billing practice for a trucking company to first charge a customer a negotiated rate and later seek to recover the difference between that rate and the filed rate schedule. Quinn Freight Lines, a subsidiary of Maislin Industries, shipped 1,081 truckloads of steel for Primary Steel, based in North Haven, Conn. The rates Quinn charged Primary for the shipment were lower than the rate schedule Maislin had filed with the commission. After Maislin filed for bankruptcy protection in 1983, its auditors determined that Quinn had undercharged Primary by nearly $188,000. Maislin sued Primary in federal court in Kansas City to collect the money. U.S. District Judge John W. Oliver referred the dispute to the ICC, seeking a determination as to whether Primary should be forced to pay. The commission ruled that it would be ``an unreasonable practice'' to require Primary to pay for the difference between the negotiated and filed rates. On the basis of that finding, Judge Oliver dismissed Maislin's suit and the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal. Today's ruling reinstated the suit. ``Although the commission has both the authority and expertise generally to adopt new policies when faced with new developments in the industry,'' Justice William J. Brennan wrote, ``it does not have the power to adopt a policy that directly conflicts with its governing statute.'' Brennan said that if the commission wants to use its policy, ``it is the responsibility of Congress to modify or eliminate'' those provisions in the Interstate Commerce Act now preventing such use. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and John Paul Stevens dissented. The case is Maislin Industries vs. Primary Steel, 89-624.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Stronger, Gold Sluggish
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with late European rates and prices plus early afternoon New York quotes.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mostly stronger against other currencies in Europe today. Gold advanced, but traded sluggishly because of a broad lack of interest. The dollar continued rising against the West German mark and the Japanese yen after moderate losses at the start of the week. But dealers said dollar activity still was generally directionless and action was limited to range trading. Political and economic uncertainties over the Soviet Union, Eastern Europe and the unification of East and West Germany helped to underpin the dollar, they said. Dealers also said the market was waiting for Friday's report on U.S. durable goods to confirm impressions of an economic slowdown. Worries that a slower U.S. economy will soon translate into lower interest rates has been cited as a factor that may influence the dollar. The pound continued to climb on speculation that Britain will join Europe's exchange rate mechanism this year. In London, the British pound rose to $1.7255 from $1.7225 late Wednesday. In early afternoon trading in New York, the pound was quoted at $1.72475. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's levels, were: 1.6795 West German marks, up from 1.6785; 1.4150 Swiss francs, down from 1.4155; 5.6385 French francs, down from 5.6405; 1.8885 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8878; 1,231.00 Italian lire, unchanged; and 1.1748 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1723. Selected rates for the dollar at 1 p.m. in New York included: 1.6785 West German marks; 154.765 Japanese yen; 1.41385 Swiss francs; 1,230.25 Italian lire; and 1.17525 Canadian dollars. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.62 yen to a closing 154.60 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 154.78 yen. Gold rose in London to a late price of $350.25 a troy ounce, up from $349.15 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $350.50, up from $347.25 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.80 to close at $351.65. Silver bullion rose in London to a late price of $4.84 a troy ounce, up from $4.82 late Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Sluggish California Market Brings Out the Gimmicks in Home Sellers
LaserPhoto, Graphic in AP Access under CALRESALES
DOC.TEXT: Hey buddy, want a free Rolls-Royce? All you do, see, is buy this mansion in Brentwood: brand new, pool, spa, sauna, stupendous views, five bedrooms, seven baths, maid's quarters, three quarters of an acre. Just $3.8 million, $1.1 million off the original asking price. We'll also throw in a convertible 1990 Corniche III at no extra charge. That deal, outlined this month in a Hollywood Reporter advertisement, is an extreme example of a host of home-sales gimmicks in expensive California areas, where reality has hit realty after a remarkable boom in sales and prices in the late 1980s. ``We've never seen as many incentives as now,'' said Mike Silverman, a veteran Beverly Hills broker who has sold houses for celebrities like Judy Garland and Pia Zadora. ``All the brokers are scratching their heads. Everyone has been spoiled by all of these good years.'' During 1988 and much of 1989, home prices soared at a clip of more than 20 percent per year in areas like San Francisco, Los Angeles, Orange County, Ventura and Santa Barbara. In many cases, all a broker had to do was list a house to sell it, usually at a premium price. Now, despite booming price increases in cheaper inland areas, the median price of a California home actually fell to $197,107 in April 1990 from $201,034 in April 1989, according to the California Association of Realtors. There's a glut of homes on the market, too. In the San Fernando Valley section of Los Angeles, for example, the Realtors' group said 13,561 homes were for sale in May, a 56 percent jump from last year. The average sales price was $306,400, but only the under-$300,000 market was still hot, the trade group said. No one has suggested that residential property values will plummet as they have in the Northeast recently or the oil states a few years back. But observers such as Norman Katz, a thrift consultant with Grant Thornton's MCS Associates, believe home prices might fall 15 percent below their peak. Responding to the slowdown, developers have been cutting prices. They're also paying closing costs, picking up months of house payments, or offering ``trade-in'' programs to help sell a buyer's old home. Some buyers are even getting free vacations, fully furnished homes or upgrades. Brokers who list expensive properties for sale are offering luxury cars and $10,000 bonuses to agents who close deals. Incentives aside, many experts say now is a good time to buy a home. California's economy remains strong and housing prices are poised to rebound since builders are starting fewer projects, lessening the risk of an oversupply. For now, though, the biggest job is getting would-be buyers through the front door. Stephen Ellis, the broker who's giving away the Rolls with his five-bedroom mansion, said lowering the price didn't seem to work. ``Maybe the idea of the Rolls will get somebody else up here. I just want to get my money out,'' he said. Ellis said he began building that home for his family five years ago, but hassles with the city over its construction delayed it so long that his twin daughters are nearly college age. Now, $3.5 million later, his 7,000-square-foot dream home is too big for just a couple, he said. Ellis said his Rolls-Royce gimmick has generated no serious offers so far. But Silverman, the Beverly Hills broker, said he's been able to peddle luxury homes by offering offbeat perks. He'll fly buyers around in helicopters, cater meals, and pay round-trip tabs to New York and Hawaii to sell homes. He gift-wrapped one house, and swears another sold when a hungry buyer went to an open house because it had a free lunch. ``It gives a little pizzazz to the promotion,'' Silverman said. ``I read an ad that said: `For sale. Important fish tank. Included with the fish tank is a three-bedroom house.' ``It's like when you get junk mail. Some people put some really extraordinary copy on there that will make you open it.'' Not everyone is a fan of such pizzazz. ``The best incentive is to price the house right,'' said Fred Sands, the founder of California's largest one-owner real estate brokerage. ``For a while there, you could price a house 30 percent over market value, and in six months prices would catch up. You can't do that now.'' Sands said he discourages most incentives. ``Gimmicks are gimmicks. They're mainly to make the sellers feel good,'' he said. ``The biggest incentive is to drop the price.'' ``A lot of times it just makes people suspicious,'' Kay Pick, a Silverman agent, said of incentives. ``They figure there must be something not quite right about the deal.'' Sands agent Thelma Orloff, who has sold luxury homes in Los Angeles for decades, said promotional deals are nothing new, but they've picked up recently as the market has cooled. Even Rolls-Royce giveaways were tried before, with varying degrees of success, she said. Mrs. Orloff said one popular gimmick these days is offering already furnished houses. ``I have sold three big houses, around $6 million each, with them furnished,'' she said. ``Of course you've got to like the furniture before you'll buy the house. But a lot of people don't want the hassle, they want instant house: Just add people.'' Silverman sat poolside recently during an open house _ lunch provided, of course _ at the home actors Cornel Wilde and Jean Wallace built in the Trousdale Estates section of Beverly Hills 30 years ago. Realtors dropped by to examine the house, nibbling chicken and pineapple chunks as agent Pick explained that the 4,000-square-foot home, listed at $2.95 million, was being sold by the children following the actors' deaths within the past year. They traded stories of incentives offered to get sales closed: a Mercedes Benz here, a $10,000 bonus there, round-trip tickets to anywhere in the world. Real estate agents with weak franchises or overextended businesses can be maimed or killed in such a market, Silverman said. The most notorious case involved Mike Glickman, who built an empire of 1,800 agents in the San Fernando Valley during the boom years. He declared personal and corporate bankruptcy this month at age 30.
