DOC.HEAD: Supreme Court Rules On Suits Against Energy Producers
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Thursday generally barred states and energy consumers from bringing federal antitrust suits against energy producers accused of conspiring to fix prices. In a separate decision, the Court stripped the Interstate Commerce Commission of its authority to relieve shippers of their legal obligation to pay carriers less than their official rates. In the price fixing case, the justices said in a 5-4 ruling that only direct purchasers of energy _ in this case utility companies _ may file such suits. The court ruled against Kansas and Missouri officials who accused a natural gas pipeline and five natural gas producers of illegal price fixing. The attorneys general of 32 states had urged the high court to permit such suits. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, writing for the court, rejected arguments that states or residential customers should be permitted to sue because utilities lack incentive to go to court since they can pass on any overcharges to their customers. ``Utilities ... have an established record of diligent antitrust enforcement,'' Kennedy said. ``History makes us quite hesitant to take from the utilities the responsibility for enforcing the antitrust laws.'' Also, he continued, ``Consumers may lack the expertise and experience necessary for detecting improper pricing by a utility's suppliers.'' Kansas and Missouri officials said in their suit that energy producers conspired to inflate the price of the gas sold to utilities and that the alleged overcharges were passed on to consumers. Supporting the appeal by Kansas and Missouri were Alaska, Arkansas, California, Colorado, Connecticut, Florida, Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kentucky, Louisiana, Maine, Maryland, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Nebraska, Nevada, New Hampshire, New Jersey, North Carolina, Ohio, Oregon, Pennsylvania, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Utah, Virginia, Washington, West Virginia and Wisconsin. The case is Kansas vs. Utilicorp United Inc., 88-2109. Separately, by a 7-2 vote, the justices said the ICC policy requiring carriers to file rate schedules with the commission violates the 103-year-old Interstate Commerce Act. Once a schedule is filed, a carrier cannot charge more or less than what it states. But the commission, which regulates interstate trucking and has the authority to approve or disapprove tariff proposals, adopted a policy in 1986 that carved out an exception. The policy stated that it was an unreasonable billing practice for a trucking company to first charge a customer a negotiated rate and later seek to recover the difference between that rate and the filed rate schedule. Quinn Freight Lines, a subsidiary of Maislin Industries, shipped 1,081 truckloads of steel for Primary Steel, based in North Haven, Conn. The rates Quinn charged Primary for the shipment were lower than the rate schedule Maislin had filed with the commission. After Maislin filed for bankruptcy protection in 1983, its auditors determined that Quinn had undercharged Primary by nearly $188,000. Maislin sued Primary in federal court in Kansas City to collect the money. U.S. District Judge John W. Oliver referred the dispute to the ICC, which ruled that it would be ``an unreasonable practice'' to require Primary to pay the difference between the negotiated and filed rates. Judge Oliver then dismissed Maislin's suit and the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals upheld the dismissal. The Supreme court ruling reinstated the suit. The case is Maislin Industries vs. Primary Steel, 89-624.

DOC.HEAD: Weekly Production Down
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 237,103 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 237,623, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 222,795 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 145,014 cars this week, compared with 144,492 a week ago and 141,086 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 92,089, compared with last week's 93,131 and last year's 81,709. Canadian automakers were to build 27,418 cars this week, up from 26,634 a week ago and up from last year's 22,836. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 22,524, compared with 23,533 a week ago and 21,731 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Grains, Soybeans Mixed in Sluggish Trading
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher in subdued trading Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading in corn futures was thin in reaction to the abrupt collapse in prices late Wednesday. ``After (Wednesday's) action, people were relunctant to take a position in corn,'' said Joel Karlin, an analyst with Research Department Inc. Concerns over a potential drawdown in corn stockpiles helped boost long-term corn futures. Nearby futures were pressured by weather forecasts, which call for normal temperatures over the next six to 10 days and below normal precipitation. Soybeans futures were slightly higher on the possibility of additional export business due to the continuing port strike in Brazil. Prices were also helped by a lack of farmer selling by South American growers, Karlin said. Wheat prices were boosted by expectations of increased export business and concerns about the quality of the soft red winter wheat crop. There were reports the U.S. Agriculture Department is finding reduced test weights in the winter crop, an indication of lower quality and reduced yields due to excessive precipitation. At the close, wheat was 3 cents to 3} cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.38\ cents a bushel; corn was \ cent to 3 cents lower with July at $2.85 a bushel; oats were a \ cent to 1 cent lower with July at $1.40\ a bushel, soybeans were 4{ cents to 6{ cents higher with July at 6.03 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Manhattan, inc. and M Magazine Merging
DOC.TEXT: The owners of the New York business magazine Manhattan, inc. and the men's fashion magazine M said Thursday the publications would merge, with the first issue due in September. The new magazine will be called M inc. and is expected to sell for $3, the cover price that M and Manhattan, inc. each sell separately for now. ``This merger combines the lifestyle features of M with the business orientation of Manhattan, inc.,'' said Michael Coady, president of Fairchild Fashion and Merchandising Group, which launched M in 1983. Coady said the readership ``will deliver the best upscale male democraphics in publishing today.'' D. Herbert Lipson, chairman of Metrocorp, Manhattan, inc.'s publisher, said the merger makes sense from the point of view of readers and advertisers. ``It brings together all interests of the successful, well-heeled man, and it combines two groups of advertisers whose demographic targets are similar,'' he said. A joint announcement said Lipson will be president of M inc. and Jane F. Lane, currently M magazine's editor in chief, will be the editor. The present editor of Manhattan, inc., Clay Felker, will serve as editor at large and will work with Ms. Lane to develop the magazine. The staffs of the two magazines will be joined and located at the offices of Fairchild, which is a division of New York-based Capital Cities-ABC Inc. Patricia J. Matson, a Cap Cities-ABC spokeswoman, said all operations of the two magazines will be reviewed over the next few months. She couldn't say whether any staff cuts are anticipated. The base circulation rate for the new magazine has been set at 200,000. The average circulation at launch is expected to be 245,000. Currently M has a circulation of 160,000 and Manhattan, inc.'s is 115,000. Financial terms of the deal weren't disclosed. The announcement said all ad contracts will be honored at the current rates. Some other Fairchild titles include Women's Wear Daily and W. Metrocorp, which began Manhattan, inc. in September 1984, also publishes Boston Magazine and Philadelphia Magazine.
Stock prices turned upward near the close of an erratic session today. In the last few minutes of trading, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 10.15 at 2,905.45.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Europe's First Stock Exchange Opens in Budapest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs, President Bush...with 3 new grafs to UPDATE with further detail, Breeden remarks. Picks up 6th graf pvs, A stock...
DOC.TEXT: The first stock exchange in post-Communist Eastern Europe opened Thursday in Budapest, 42 years after it was closed by Communist authorities. Officials hope the fledgling Budapest trading floor will boost market-oriented economic reforms and become the stock exchange center for all of Eastern Europe. On its first day, the exchange reported 58.1 million forints, more than $900,000, worth of trading in the 41 listed companies. Prime Minister Jozsef Antall, in a telegram from West Germany where he is on an official visit, said the Budapest Stock Exchange as ``an important institution of a market economy.'' Richard C. Breeden, chairman of the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, presented the exchange with a new bell modeled after one used for years to open trading on the New York Stock Exchange. Breeden also read a letter from President Bush that said in part: ``Free and competitive markets are an essential attribute of a free economy. They also represent an important element of a democratic society. The re-establishment of the Budapest Stock Exchange is thus a milestone in the continuation of democratic developments in Hungary, and it should encourage strong economic growth for the future.'' On sale to mark the opening was a special English-language edition of Toezsde Kurir (Stock Market Courier) that was launched earlier this year. A stock exchange first opened in Hungary in 1864 but was closed in 1948 when Communists came to power after World War II. ``Until the '80s it was heresy to even suggest anything of the sort,'' said Hungary's interim president, Arpad Goencz, alluding to Communists' description of a stock market as the ultimate symbol of capitalism. Even before democratic change swept Eastern Europe last year, Hungary tended toward reform. The Communist authorities set up a market for state-guaranteed bonds in 1983 and an embryonic stock market was created two years ago. That gave Hungarian financial experts training officials hope will make Budapest the best candidate as a center for a Eastern European exchange. In March, a key government act on the stock exchange and securities took effect, giving the market a legal framework. But financial experts said the stock exchange still has a long way to go before it establishes itself on the international market. Finance Minister Ferenc Rabar said at the opening ceremony that the exchange ``does not in itself solve the problem of the liberalization of the economy.'' He said ``we have much to do yet in that regard.'' In a recent article in the economic weekly Heti Vilaggazdasag, the stock exchange executive president, Ilona Hardy, said the exchange will need to increase the number of listed companies. ``To operate well, there is a need for considerably more securities, especially publicly issued shares ... a working infrastructure, well-trained stock-market experts and ... a new type of investment-oriented attitude,'' she said. ``The situation in Hungary today and the present situation of the securities market are not optimal conditions for the development of a stock market, but at the same time the stock exchange can make a significant contribution to the development of the market,'' Hardy said. The exchange's main aim is to achieve reprivatization of the country's inefficient, state-owned enterprises by allowing companies to sell shares to meet their capital needs. At a trial exchange that met three times a week, volume was low, with 5 million forints to 20 million forints ($77,000 to $300,000) worth of shares trading hands. Eva Farago, head of the exchange's financial department, said one factor hindering the exchange is that the Hungarian currency cannot be converted freely into foreign currencies. But she said the lack of convertibility is counterbalanced by guarantees that foreigners can repatriate their dividends in hard currency. Rabar said Hungary wants to make the forint convertible by the end of 1991 or early 1992. That would mean a major devaluation of the Hungarian currency, which presently is pegged at 63 forints to the dollar.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets To Get $3 Billion Credit To Support Economic Reform
DOC.TEXT: Leading West German banks plan to pump more than $3 billion into the struggling Soviet economy, officials said Thursday, as the government in Bonn seeks the Kremlin's go-ahead for German unity. Otto Lambsdorff, leader of the Free Democratic Party and a former economics minister, confirmed the deal in an interview with Deutschlandfunk radio in Cologne. The credit of 5 billion West German marks, or $3.1 billion, was negotiated by Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank, two of West Germany's largest, with the Soviet Union's Foreign Trade Bank. The credit aims to help the Soviet transition from a centrally planned economy to a market economy, an effort that is similar to reform plans in other East bloc countries. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has told the Soviet people that a transition to a market economy is needed in order to further plans for radical restructuring of the Soviet system. But the Soviets have balked at introducing real price reform and making the ruble a convertible currency, a move that would make the country more attractive for foreign investors. West Germany has indicated its willingness to broaden economic cooperation with the Soviet Union as part of shaping future relations with a united Germany. Bonn also would like to see Moscow drop bitter objections to NATO membership for the joined country. The Soviet Union stands to lose one of its key economic partners as East Germany unites with West Germany. Many of the East German firms with which the Soviet Union traded are likely to go bankrupt once the two Germanys merge their currencies on July 2. Others that survive will have their products priced in the new expensive marks. East Germany in the past has supplied Soviet industry with high technology, including optics and computers, industrial components and consumer goods. The future of trade agreements already concluded between the Soviet Union and East Germany is unclear, but West Germany has indicated a willingness to take over at least part of the existing obligations. West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher told his Soviet counterpart Eduard A. Shevardnadze in talks in Muenster earlier this week that Bonn was prepared to further develop relations on a full scale. West German Finance Minister Theo Waigel is expected to inform the appropriations committee of West German parliament on the terms of the credit at a session in Bonn on Friday. Committee approval is required for the government-guaranteed loan, but it is expected to pass easily. West Germany hopes that economic assistance will make it easier for Moscow to accept the loss of its East German ally, in addition to membership of a united Germany in the NATO alliance. Like other East bloc countries attempting to undo the chaos created by decades of central planning, the Soviet Union needs massive injection of foreign capital. Soviet borrowing has increased in the last several years as the country develops a greater need for credit. But at the same time its ability to repay is dropping. ``The need for credit is a sign of a critical economic situation. The Soviet Union must have credit because domestic savings are not great enough to carry out the great restructuring they have in mind,'' said Klaus-Peter Schmidt of the Institute for World Economy in Kiel.

A late round of buying enabled the stock market to post a small gain today. Analysts said traders seemed uncertain about where the market might get any inspiration to extend its spring rally. While interest rates and inflationary pressures have been ebbing in recent weeks, nothing has happened to fulfill hopes that the Federal Reserve might adopt a more stimulative credit policy. Indeed, Fed officials have suggested they are still inclined to stay with a relatively restrictive approach. This morning the Commerce Department reported that the gross national product grew at a 1.9 percent annual rate, after adjustment for inflation and seasonal factors, in the first quarter of the year. The figure, revised upward from a previous estimate of 1.3 percent, was seen as confirming evidence that the economy keeps growing sluggishly.

DOC.HEAD: FDIC Chief Hurt in Horse Riding Mishap
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. was in satisfactory condition at a Santa Fe hospital Thursday after being injured in a horse riding accident at his ranch near the city. William Seidman underwent surgery late Wednesday to repair a separated pelvis and that his doctors reported the surgery was successful, his office in Washington said. A nursing supervisor at St. Vincent Hospital would not release any information other than Seidman's condition. Seidman asked hospital officials for a facsimile machine and a telephone to conduct business while he recovers from the injuries, FDIC communications director Alan Whitney said. Seidman was in New Mexico to speak to the New Mexico Bankers Association and to participate in an FDIC management conference in Santa Fe. His office said he was making an overnight visit to his ranch before returning to Washington. Whitney said Seidman was injured early Wednesday when he was thrown from his horse at his ranch near Wagon Mound in northeastern New Mexico. He said the horse began to buck and Seidman's boot got tangled in a stirrup when he tried to dismount. Seidman, 69, a one-time polo player, was given the horse by his children, who operate the ranch and a ranch supply company. Seidman has said he plans to retire after June 30 from his twin jobs as head of the FDIC and chairman of the Resolution Trust Corp., the agency created by Congress to rescue the savings and loan industry.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Rebound
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices staged a modest rebound Thursday as bargain hunters snapped up contracts following this week's sharp decline in prices. The contract for August delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, rose 19 cents to settle at $16.94 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The September contract gained 5 cents but other contract months were unchanged to slightly lower. Oil prices had fallen sharply earlier this week. Analysts said several factors helped support prices. Bob Baker, senior energy analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said a handful of British and Norwegian oil platforms have been taken out of service for routine maintenance while a number of U.S. refineries which had been out of service have begun operating. ``That's adding to the demand at refineries while we have production restraints,'' Baker said. Oil prices had been depressed following reports of exceptionally high crude oil stocks. In addition, market players have been disappointed the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has not come down harder on members who violate production quotas by pumping too much crude. But Baker said he thinks the ``bad news is behind us'' and that the market is ready to build back its confidence. Prices were mixed among refined products traded on the Merc. The July contrac for wholesale unleaded gasoline lost 0.24 cent to settle at 60.23 cents a gallon after gaining 0.55 cent on Wednesday. Other contract months rose, however. Wholesale home heating oil for July delivery settled 0.27 cent higher at 47.91 cents a gallon after gaining 0.21 cent on Wednesday. In natural gas trading, the August contract closed at $1.528 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.559 on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Revco Sells 10 More Stores, Closes 36
DOC.TEXT: Revco D.S. Inc. on Wednesday announced plans to sell 10 stores in the South and close 36 in that region, primarily in Alabama, in line with its downsizing and restructuring goals. The announcement brings to 487 the number of stores divested. On Jan. 26, Revco announced plans to divest 712 stores in 17 states from its total of 1,853. Revco is operating under provisions of Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, which provides protection from creditors while the business reorganizes. Revco in April announced the sale of 221 stores to Indianapolis-based Reliable Drug Stores. On June 5, 220 stores were sold to Jack Eckerd Corp., based in Clearwater, Fla. Under the plan announced Wednesday, six stores in Alabama, one in Georgia and one in Mississippi would be sold to Big B Inc. of Bessemer, Ala., while two Alabama stores will be sold to Harco Drug Inc. of Northpoint, Ala. Big B also will purchase pharmacy files and inventory of 20 Revco stores in Alabama, and one each in Florida, Georgia and Mississippi. Revco eventually will close those stores. Two Alabama stores not part of the Big B files and inventory purchases are also slated for closing. The company did not say how many jobs would be cut in the closings, but a company spokeswoman said a typical Revco drug store employs 10 to 12 people. The agreements with Big B and Harcor are subject to approval in U.S. Bankruptcy Court at a hearing in Akron slated for July 10.

DOC.HEAD: Highlights of Treaty on German Unification
With AM-Germany-Unification
DOC.TEXT: Here are highlights of the treaty that prepares the economic merger of the two Germanys by July 2.

OVERVIEW _ The two Germanys agree to create a monetary, economic and social union as a first step to unification under the West German Constitution. The international implications of German unification need to be resolved in talks among the four victorious World War II powers _ the Soviet Union, the United States, Great Britain and France.

MONETARY UNION _ On July 2, the West German mark becomes the legal tender in East Germany. The West German Bundesbank, or central bank, will have full control over monetary policy in both countries. The economic union will be based on a free-market economy, including private property, competition and workers' rights.

CONVERSION RATES _ Workers will have their wages converted from East German marks to West German marks at a 1-1 rate. For savings deposits, East Germans 14 and younger will be able to convert up to $1,200 at a 1-1 rate. Those aged 15-59 will be able to convert $2,400 at the 1-1 rate. People 60 and older can covert up $3,600 at the favorable rate. All other savings will be converted at two East German marks for one West mark. East German pensions will be brought to West German levels, raising most of them. Debts will be converted at a 2-1 rate, more favorable to troubled East German companies.

DOC.HEAD: GM Recalls 1.6 Million Camaro, Firebird Cars
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. on Thursday recalled all 1.6 million 1984-90 Chevrolet Camaro and Pontiac Firebird cars because of possible seat belt defects. The company said ultraviolet solar rays could weaken the seat-belt buckles' red-colored release buttons. The latching mechanism then may not hold the seat belt in place, which could make the safety device inoperative. In time, GM said, seat-belt buckle assemblies on all the affected cars will be replaced or repaired. Russell Shew of the Center for Auto Safety in Washington said the larest recall was by GM in December 1971 of 6.7 million cars for engine mount problems. GM said repair priority would be given to Camaros and Firebirds whose buckles fail to latch or to release and to those whose red button is broken. Owners of those cars should contact dealers promptly. Owners who find that their cars' buckles are working properly do not have to contact dealers immediately, but should check the buckles periodically, the company said. Beginning this fall, GM will begin replacing or repairing buckles on cars that did not need immediate attention. Repairs or replacements will be done free of charge.

DOC.HEAD: Protection of Japan's Rice Growers a Special Case, Farm Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: Japan will keep its ban on rice imports, despite signs that some Japanese would welcome them, because the nation's rice farmers need special protection, the agriculture minister said Thursday. ``We have opened the agricultural market, but there is a line beyond which we cannot pass,'' Tomio Yamamoto, minister of agriculture, fisheries and forestry, said in a lecture at the Japan National Press Club. ``Agriculture is the foundation of our nation. ... In other countries, rice doesn't account for over half of all production the way it does here. That is a special circumstance for Japan,'' Yamamoto said. His comments showed the government will continue to resist lifting Japan's virtual ban on rice imports, despite indications of growing public support for liberalizing the rice market. A recent poll showed growing public support for opening the market. A survey of 3,000 people by Japan's largest newspaper, the Yomiuri Shimbun, indicated 71 percent favored easing rice market controls, up from 41 percent in 1988. Only 24 percent wanted to keep the rice market closed, compared with 53 percent in 1988, the survey said. The agriculture ministry buys most of the nation's rice crop at preset prices. It stockpiles or resells the staple at subsidized prices that are several times higher than world market prices. Limited amounts of rice are imported for production of other foods and alcoholic beverages. Former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita, in comments at the press club last week, said he thought Japan ought to consider how to dismantle the food control system that has been in place since World War II, given the apparent shift in public opinion. He praised as courageous a recent shift in position by the Komeito, the second-largest opposition party, which recently endorsed opening Japan's rice market. The United States strongly has urged Tokyo to ease its ban on rice imports during the current Uruguay Round of trade talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which ends in December. Japan has refused, citing a need for self-sufficiency in the country's staple food. ``It is only thanks to the food control system that the Japanese can be confident of always being able to buy rice at a reasonable price. Without it, there could be food panics,'' Yamamoto said. Under pressure to open its markets, Japan has lifted controls on beef and citrus products, as well as on some processed foods. Measured by calories, roughly half the food Japanese eat is imported. As imports have grown, so has concern that serious supply disruptions such as war could leave people hungry. Yamamoto said that even if all its trading partners lift farm tariffs and quotas, making their markets completely free, Japan must continue protecting the small farmers who carry on Japan's ancient craft of rice cultivation. The nation also needs to preserve the rural environment for future generations, he said. ``Our farmers are losing confidence in the future of farming in Japan. This is a terrible thing,'' he said. ``International competition may require that we speed up efforts to improve the competitiveness of our farmers, but it has to be done step by step.'' The struggle to preserve Japan's rice culture also is challenged by declining domestic consumption. In 1978, each Japanese ate an average 180 pounds of rice. In 1988, each consumed only 156 pounds. Consumption fell another 2.2 pounds last year. Unused rice fields can be seen throughout Japan's countryside and only 13 percent of Japan's rice farmers make a full-time living from the crop.

DOC.HEAD: Cocoa Futures Down Sharply
DOC.TEXT: Cocoa futures prices fell sharply Thursday on New York's Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange. On other markets, grains and soybean futures were mixed; livestock and meat prices were mostly lower; precious metals declined slightly; and energy futures were mostly higher. Judith Ganes, an analyst with Merrill Lynch & Co. in New York, said the cocoa sell-off resumed a downward trend in the market. She said a recent rally was a correction of a recent $300 slide. Analysts said a seven-month stockpile of cocoa, rainfall in major cocoa producing areas in Africa and a reduction of political strife in the Ivory Coast, a major cocoa-producing nation, helped push down prices. Celeste Georgakis, an analyst with Cargill Investor Services Inc. in New York, said the market was unsettled by unconfirmed reports of Philip Morris Cos. buying Swiss-based Jacobs Suchard AG, a major purchaser of cocoa. She said it wasn't certain if the sell-off in cocoa futures were influenced by the reports. Cocoa settled $46 to $62 lower with the contract for delivery in July at $1,185 a ton. Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher in subdued trading on the Chicago Board of Trade. Trading in corn futures was thin in reaction to an abrupt collapse in prices late Wednesday. Near-term futures were pressured by weather forecasts, which call for normal temperatures over the next six to 10 days and below normal precipitation. Soybeans futures were slightly higher on the possibility of additional export business due to the continuing port strike in Brazil. Prices were also helped by a lack of farmer selling by South American growers, Karlin said. Wheat prices were boosted by expectations of increased export business and concerns about the quality of the soft red winter wheat crop. The market received some support from concerns that an earthquake in Iran measuring between 7.3 and 7.7 on the Richter scale could disrupt supplies, said Jim Ritterbusch, an analyst with PaineWebber Inc. in Chicago. The market also was nervous over a possible supply squeeze in North Sea Brent oil, while it shruggged off news of a fire at a Siberian oil storage station threateningg 380,000 tons of oil. Precious metals were unchanged to slightly lower on New York's Commodity Exchange. Gold traded in a narrow range, with the market awaiting news that will give it some direction, said Bette Raptopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. in New York. DOC.HEAD: Chicago BOT Wins Approval of Japan-related Options
DOC.TEXT: Federal futures regulators gave the Chicago Board of Trade permission Wednesday to trade options in two futures contracts linked to Japanese stocks and bonds. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission unanimously approved a Board of Trade request to trade options on its Tokyo Stock Price Index (TOPIX) futures contract and on its Long Term Japanese Government Bonds futures contract. An option is the right to buy or sell a specified number of shares, usually 100, in a security or futures contract within a designated time. The TOPIX option contract will give the holder the right to buy or sell one TOPIX futures contract at a specified price by a certain expiration date. Option premiums _ the price an option buyer pays the seller to guarantee the availability of the security over the life of the agreement _ will be quoted in terms of Japanese yen for both the TOPIX and Japanese Government Bond options. The Japanese Government Bond option contract may be exercised on any trading day prior to the contract's expiration. The proposed trading months will correspond with those of the underlying Japanese government bond futures contract, and the last day of trading will be the Friday before the last business day of the month preceding the delivery month of the underlying futures contract.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Sluggish
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against other major currencies Thursday, gaining against the yen but falling against the West German mark in light trading. Gold advanced domestically and overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery rose 20 cents a troy ounce to $350.70. Later, Republic National Bank in New York reported a late bid of $349.90 an ounce, up 30 cents from Wednesday. Dealers said the mark advanced on news that East German lawmakers overwhelmingly had approved a historic economic merger with West Germany, the most difficult step toward unifying the two nations. A vote by the two houses of the West German Parliament was expected by Friday. That parliament also was expected to pass the treaty, which outlines the monetary and economic merger of the Germanys by July 2. In European trading the dollar rose to 1.6795 marks from Wednesday's 1.6785. Later in New York, the dollar closed at 1.6760 marks, down from 1.6783 late Wednesday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.7200, down from $1.7220 late Wednesday. Sterling had been advancing on speculation that Britain would join Europe's exchange rate mechanism this year. The yen also lost ground against the dollar. Analysts said investors were moving funds from the yen to the dollar to take advantage of higher U.S. interest rates, given the relative stability of exchange rates. DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Rises
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended June 11, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,266.6 billion from a revised $3,260.8 billion for the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,060.1 billion from a revised $4,053.1 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $807.6 billion from $808.2 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 3.7 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 1.4 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 2.5 percent to 6.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,267.1 billion, a 3.3 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,060.1 billion, up 0.9 percent, while M1 rose 3.8 percent to an average of $806.2 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $318 million. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $346 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, down from $1.022 billion the previous week. _The Federal Reserve revised its net borrowed reserves average in the two weeks ended June 13 to $269 million, down from a revised figure of $396 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $306.9 billion in the two-week period ended June 13, up from $305.0 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Rose in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last 3 grafs to CORRECT all figures from Bank Rate Monitor to reflect effective annual yield, sted stated yield on the investments.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 512 money market mutual funds rose $1.29 billion in the latest week, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise, to $385.40 billion in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $988.6 million increase in the funds' assets the previous week, according to the Washington-based mutual fund trade group. The funds' assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21, 1990. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 246 general purpose funds rose $567.9 million to $133.85 billion, assets of 105 broker-dealer funds increased $296.3 million to $159.53 billion, and assets of 161 institutional funds rose $425.9 million to $92.02 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.67 percent from 7.65 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.67 percent from 7.68 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, up from 43 days, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.18 percent as of Wednesday from 6.19 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained at 5.04. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.91 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.92 the previous week. Yields were 8.10 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.12 percent; 8.10 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.12 percent; and 8.17 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.18 percent.

DOC.HEAD: NASD Plans its Own Shareholders Rights Rule in Wake of Court Decision
DOC.TEXT: The National Association of Securities Dealers Inc. says it will introduce its own rule to protect corporate stockholders from unequal voting rights if a federal version remains struck down by the courts. Last week a federal appeals court in Washington unanimously held that the Securities and Exchange Commission exceeded its authority in prohibiting publicly traded corporations from weakening the voting power of those who already own stock in the company. The SEC, which oversees the stock and bond markets as well as the exchanges that trade in them, has yet to say if it will appeal the decision by a three-judge panel of the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia. But Joseph Hardiman, president of the NASD, said if the ruling is upheld ``we will propose a look-alike rule.'' The NASD is a Washington-based, self-regulating organization that oversees the so-called over-the-counter stock market. It regulates stocks that are usually not traded on an exchange and provides an automated stock price quotation system to monitor such securities. SEC Rule 19c-4, adopted in July 1988, prohibited publicly traded corporations from weakening the voting power of those who own existing stock by issuing new classes of stock with superior or ``supervoting'' rights. The SEC is not allowed to interfere in how a company runs itself _ a matter left to state jurisdiction. But the rule allowed it to bar an offending company's stock from being listed on the stock exchanges of the NASD quote system _ which the SEC does oversee. Nevertheless, the appeals court agreed with The Business Roundtable, an association of top corporations, that the rule crossed the line into corporate _ rather than exchange _ governance. ``I think we clearly have the authority as a market operator and regulator to adopt those rules for our markets and so does the New York Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange,'' said Hardiman. He insisted that such a rule would not be a ``one share, one vote rule'' because it would not bar companies new to the public market from creating unequal shareholders rights, only preventing them from stripping existing shares of their voting powers.

But he added that if other exchanges don't follow the NASD's lead and permit unequal voting rights, then the plan could be in trouble. ``If the other markets don't go along and if they start to use shareholders voting rights differentials as a competitive tool, then all bets are off,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: East and West German Lawmakers Approve Historic Economic Treaty
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with West German lower house approving economic merger treaty and Polish border resolutions, edits to trim. Also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BON1,3
DOC.TEXT: East and West German lawmakers overwhelmingly approved a treaty to merge their economies Thursday, removing one of the last remaining obstacles to de facto unification. Lawmakers in both countries also passed resolutions declaring that a united Germany would guarantee Poland's western border. The powerful West German Bundestag, the lower house of parliament, late Thursday voted 445-60 with one abstention to pass the economic merger treaty after a sometimes heated debate lasting nearly 15 hours. Final approval of the historic pact outlining the monetary, economic and social unification of the two Germanys was expected Friday, when the West German parliament's upper house, the Bundesrat, takes up the issue. A loud round of applause greeted the announcement of the treaty vote in the Bundestag, which was seen as a major victory for West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who has pushed for rapid unification. Kohl appealed to Bundestag members to pass the treaty, saying he was ``convinced that each one of us will one day be judged by whether he or she faintheartedly backed away or gave full support on this momentous occasion.'' Earlier Thursday, the East German parliament, or Volkskammer, approved the treaty, ending four decades of failed socialism. The treaty, to take effect July 2, basically unifies the two German states. However, details of full political unification, particularly the future military alliance of a united Germany, remain to be worked out by the two Germanys together with the victorious World War II allies _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France. The Bundestag also voted 487-15, with three abstentions, to approve a resolution recognizing the Oder-Neisse rivers as Poland's uncontested western border. The East German parliament earlier in the day passed a similar resolution declaring a united Germany would not seek to reclaim former German territories lost to Poland after World War II. The issue had become one of the most emotional as the two Germanys move rapidly toward unification. Poles had feared a united Germany might try to reclaim the former German lands _ representing about one-third of Poland's present territory. Ultra-conservative West Germans opposed any moves to abandon German claims to the former territories. The two German parliaments met simultaneously in their respective capitals Thursday to take final action on the economic merger treaty. The two governments signed the treaty May 18, but approval by both parliaments was necessary. In East Berlin, as the Volkskammer debated the treaty, about 100 people demonstrated against the measure outside the parliament building. After the 302-82 vote in favor of the treaty was announced, East German lawmakers rose in a standing ovation. There was one abstention. The PDS, the successor party of the old East German Communists, Bundnis 90, which led last fall's revolution, and the Greens opposed the treaty. They said they supported German unity, but not under existing conditions. As debate began in Bonn Thursday morning, Kohl urged lawmakers to pass both the treaty and the Polish border resolution. ``After over 40 years of painful separation, the hopes of the people of Germany for the unity and freedom of all Germans are about to be fulfilled,'' Kohl said. Kohl urged unanimous approval of the economic merger. ``The treaty shows the way to German unity, and whoever doesn't follow this road sign doesn't want unity,'' he said. ``For the people in Germany, this will make unity come true in vital areas of their daily existence,'' he said. ``Whoever rejects the treaty also rejects our compatriots in the German Democratic Republic.'' Under the treaty, the powerful West German mark becomes the currency of both countries on July 2, and East Germany moves from socialism to capitalism. East German wages, salaries and pensions will be converted to West German marks at a 1-1 exchange rate. The exchange rate for savings deposits varies with age, with a maximum of $3,600 at the 1-1 rate for those over 60. West Germany's main opposition party, the left-leaning Social Democrats, criticized the treaty, saying it fails to adequately protect East Germans who face economic hardship in the transition from socialism to a free market. But their chairman, Hans-Jochen Vogel, told the Bundestag a majority would approve the treaty. Failure to do so would be too much of a shock to East German expectations and could lead to ``uncontrollable developments,'' he said. The leftist Greens Party argued against passage, saying the treaty would not bring the two Germanys closer together, but would create newer and deeper forms of division by making East Germany a dependent institution. Some experts predict up to 2 million East Germans could lose their jobs as outmoded government-owned factories and businesses try to compete. More than a third of the enterprises are expected to close and there are fears of social unrest. The economic merger treaty comes after months of work following the collapse late last year of East Germany's Communist government and the opening of the Berlin Wall. East Germany elected a non-Communist government in March. Kohl acknowledge recognition of Poland's current Western border was painful for many Germans. Nonetheless, he said: ``Either we affirm the present boundary, or we lose the chance of German unity.''

DOC.HEAD: Merrill Lynch Agrees to Pay Fine for Alleged Trading Violations
DOC.TEXT: The Chicago Board of Trade said it has accepted a settlement of trading violation charges against Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc. and Merrill Lynch Government Securities Inc. The two investment companies, which are members of the exchange, agreed to pay $30,000 and to ``implement certain corrective measures,'' the Board of Trade said Wednesday. They were accused of failing to ensure compliance by their employees with rules governing the disclosure of trade orders before they are executed. In agreeing to settle, the companies neither admitted nor denied the allegations.

DOC.HEAD: Nissan Buying $22 Million U.S. Supercomputer
DOC.TEXT: Nissan Motor Co. said it has ordered a $22 million supercomputer from Cray Research Inc. of the United States to help design safer, cleaner cars. Japan's No. 2 automaker said the Cray Y-MP8-664, to be installed in August, provides 2.5 times the processing power of the Cray X-MP-432 it will replace. Nissan said it would use the new supercomputer in research on improving vehicle safety, resolving environmental problems and designing more attractive cars. The company said that in April 1986 it became the first Japanese automaker to introduce a Cray supercomputer for vehicle design and development, including analysis of how well cars can withstand a crash. Its second Cray supercomputer, bought in September 1988, has been used in aerospace research as well as vehicle design, it said in a statement. Supercomputers have been a source of trade tension between the United States and Japan. They were one of three key product groups that Japan agreed to open its market to in talks with the United States earlier this year, a move that prompted the Bush administration to remove Japan from its trade ``hit list.''

DOC.HEAD: Cigarette Maker To Change Name, Expand Into Sports, Entertainment Marketing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: K.v.R. in 2nd graf is cq
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette maker Liggett Group Inc. said Thursday it plans to diversify further from its core cigarette business by expanding into sports and entertainment marketing and changing its name. Liggett also announced that K.v.R. Dey Jr. will retire as president and chief executive officer. The company's executive vice president, James Turner, was named to succeed him. Also, Bennett LeBow, Liggett's major stockholder, will succeed William Weksel as chairman of the board, the company said. The chanto stockholder ages are subject pproval at an annual meeting scheduled for July 26. Dey, whose retirement is effective June 30, said the diversification will allow Liggett ``to take advantage of our ability in the work place, to strengthen our assets.'' As part of its strategy of expanding away from its cigarette core, the company will change its name to Brooke Group Ltd. and establish two operating subsidiaries. The cigarette subsidiary will be called Liggett Group Inc., the company said. The other arm, Impel Marketing Inc., will market entertainment and sporting events. Liggett manufactures L&M, Lark, Eve and Chesterfield cigarettes, confectionery products and football trading cards. It had sales of $501 million last year. The crth Carolina and Virginia.
